Where water lingers underground and easily dissolves rocks, hot water may become thick with minerals. As it oozes to the surface to form mud-pots, bubbles of mud burst at ground level with an odd plopping sound. Bathing in cooler mud-pots is thought to be good for the skin.

Fumaroles.
Fumaroles are vents that often occur on the side of volcanoes, emitting thick, often sulfurous gas. While they were once thought to be linked to dormant or dying volcanoes, it is now clear that they may warn of imminent eruptions, as they did at Mount St. Helens in 1980.

Weather and climate.
When a big volcano erupts, the effects on local weather can be dramatic. Dust clouds block sunlight, lightning bolts flash, updrafts set off violent winds, and condensing steam falls as heavy rain. If dust blasts into the stratosphere, it can also affect weather worldwide.

Scarlet skies.
The vivid, atmospheric skies of the English artist JMW Turner (1775-1951) may have been inspired by dust-filled sunsets following the eruption in Tambora, Indonesia, in 1815.

The sunless year. 
Dust thrown up by the eruption in Tambora may have cut down sunlight around the world. In 1816, the northeastern US suffered weather so cold that it was called "the year without a summer".

Dinosaur doom.
Many scientists think that the dinosaurs died out when dust clouds turned the world cold and dark. These could have resulted from a huge eruption or from the impact of a meteorite hitting Earth.

Spreading clouds.
Once dust from volcanic eruptions gets into the stratosphere, high-level winds can quickly blow it far from its source. The dust from the 1982 eruption of El Chichon, Mexico, spread around the world in just three weeks. This satellite picture shows that after Mount Pinatubo, in the Philippines, erupted on June 15,1991, it took just 40 days for dust clouds to form around the globe.

Volcanic oddities.
Volcanic activity often has spectacular results. The combination of immense heat, molten rock, sulfurous fumes, and mineral-rich water can produce a range of amazing landscapes, from salt pillars to fire fountains.

Fire fountains.
The islands of Réunion, in the Indian Ocean near Madagascar, is the world's largest volcano. Its frequent eruptions of runny magma tend to be gentle, but the vents sometimes spout glowing fountains of red-hot lava into the air.

Smoking valley.
In 1912, Mount Katmai, Alaska, erupted, emitting huge quantities of hot ash. Four years later, steam still billowed from cracks in the valley floor, so the area was named the Valley of Ten Thousand Smokes.

Le Puy, France.
The church of Le Puy in France is perched on top of a precipitous rock 60 ft (76 m) high. This rock is a hardened volcanic plug from about two million years ago. The softer ash from the volcanic cone has long since been worn away by the weather.

Karum salt pillars.
Among the strangest of all volcanic features are the Karum salt pillars in Ethiopia. They form from salt washed out of volcanic rocks and into the shallow Assale Lake. The water evaporates in the hot sunshine, leaving the lake amazingly salty. In fact, it is so salty that the surface crystallizes - and pillars of salt can grow 10 ft (3 m) overnight.

Urgüp cones, Turkey.
Ash from an eruption is usually blown or washed gradually away. Occasionally, however, it is cemented into weird shapes. At Urgüp, in central Turkey, ash was blown up into smokers, or tall chimneys, by gas fumes bubbling up within the ash. They slowly hardened into bizarrely-shaped pillars, which were later dug out for houses.

Landscape facts.
The Great Geyser in Iceland has to be stimulated into action with soap powder !
Enormous colonies of clams, or "Clam Acres" feed on black smokers under the Pacific.

Volcanoes in space.
Volcanoes have played a major part in shaping the surfaces of all the rocky planets and moons in our solar system. Our moon, for example, is covered with giant "seas", known as maria. These are believed to be basaltic lava flows on a scale that dwarfs anything found on Earth.

Volcanic inferno.
Io, one Jupiter's moons, is perhaps the most volcanically active body in the solar system. Stretched and pulled so much by the power of Jupiter's gravity, Io's interior rages like an inferno, generating almost 20 times as much internal heat as the Earth. When the Voyager space probe passed Jupiter, it identified eight active volcanoes spewing plumes of gas and dust up to 185 miles (300 km) high and 750 miles (1,200 km) wide.

Olympus Mons.
Mars's Olympus Mons is the biggest volcano in the solar system, at 15 miles (25 km) high and 375 miles (600 km) across. It is probably a hot-spot volcano. And, since Mars has no moving plates, the hot spot keeps pumping up magma in the same place, building up the volcano's cone.

Venus's volcanoes.
Radar maps of Venus made by space probes show that the planet has both ancient and active volcanoes, including a possible shield volcano 310 miles (500 km) across and 2.5 miles (4 km) high. The dense atmosphere that makes Venus hard to see may be mainly made up volcanic gases.

Unearthly volcanoes.
Volcanoes on other planets, and their moons, do not necessarily erupt the same materials as Earth's volcanoes. The colors of Io's volcanoes suggest the magma sulfur and sulfur compounds. The planet Uranus may have volcanoes that spew liquid methane instead of lava.

Volcanic products.
Igneous rocks.
Most of the Earth's crust is made of igneous rocks, which are formed volcanically as molten magma solidifies. There are two other main types of rock : sedimentary and metamorphic. All three types are linked by a continuous recycling of material called the rock cycle.

Igneous rocks. 
As soon as magma rises out of the mantle, crystals appear in the melt. The more it cools, the more crystals form until eventually it turns into hard, crystalline, igneous rock.

Metamorphic rocks.
Metamorphic rock is rock that has been transformed into a new state after being crushed by the forces that move tectonic plates or seared by the intense heat of magma. Made of very fine crystals, metamorphic rock is extremely tough.

Sedimentary rocks.
As thin layers of debris settle on the sea bed, they become compacted and cemented over millions of years into sedimentary rocks. Some, such as limestone, are made from plant or animal remains, or from chemicals settling out of water.  Most, however, are "clastic", made from bits of rock worn away by the weather.

Rock facts.
An old mountain range is made of roughly equal parts of all three rock types.
A young mountain range is mostly igneous or metamorphic rock.
Sedimentary rock often forms the bulk of coastal rocks.

Extrusive igneous rocks.
Some igneous rock is called volcanic rock because it forms from lava spewed out by a volcano. It is also called extrusive igneous rock - in contrast to intrusive igneous rock, which forms from lava ; tuff is made from volcanic ash, and pumice is hardened lava froth. In the diagram below, note how crystals form in rock.

How crystals form in rhyolite.
Molten lava may initially be too hot for crystals to form, and runs like fluid over the landscape until the lava supply runs out, or until it begins to cool and slow down.
As the lava flow slows, the surface layers begin to cool down. Small crystals of minerals with high melting points, such as feldspar, begin to grow inside the melt.
Deeper in the mix, where it takes longer to cool, feldspar crystals grow much bigger. As the lava cools, minerals such as mica crystallize into a different shape.
Eventually, as the lava cools still further, quartz begins to crystallize, but not in clusters like mica and feldspar. Instead, it fills in the gaps, binding the rock together.

Igneous rock facts.
80 percent of all volcanic rocks are basalt, and most oar fine-grained.
Sticky dacite magmas (65 percent silica) tend to form lava domes, like Mount St. Helens.

Basalt columns.
The hexagonal columns of Fingal's Cave in Scotland were formed by " flood basalts", which can spill from fissures in the crust to form plateaus hundreds of feet deep.

Rhyolite.
Pinkish rhyolite forms from the thick and sticky, highly acidic, silica-rich (73 percent) magma found in subduction zones. It piles up thickly around the vent after an explosive eruption.

Andesite.
Similar in mineral content to basalt, but a bit richer in silica (55 percent), andesite can form from block lava flows. These resemble Hawaiian aas (see p.42), but are thicker and slower-moving.

Basalt. 
Runny magma low in silica (50 percent) cools into dark-colored basalt rock. The thin layers of such magma, found along mid-ocean ridges, cool quickly, forming rock with fine crystals.

Intrusive igneous rocks.
Rocks formed from magma that hardens before reaching the surface are called intrusive igneous rocks. Hypabyssal intrusions, like dikes and sills (see p.60-61), are small and form close to the surface ; so they cool quite quickly to form medium-grained rocks. Plutonic intrusions like batholiths are much larger. They cool slowly deep underground to form rocks with big, coarse crystal grains.

Igneous outcrops.
Granite forms entirely underground ; yet it is often seen on the surface because it is tough rock that takes a long time to erode. Granite outcrops are often exposed when softer rock around them is eroded by weather and running water.

Crystal size in rock.
The quicker lava cools, the finer-grained the resulting rock is. Intrusive igneous rocks are almost always coarser than those that cool on the surface. Plutonic rock is the coarser of all.

Granite.
The commonest plutonic rock, granite occurs in big domes where tectonic plates crunch together to form mountains. This light-colored rock forms from acidic, silica-rich rhyolitic magma.

Diorite.
The coarse-grained, plutonic equivalent of andesite is diorite. It is formed when contact with other rocks adds impurities to the granitic magma, often in minor intrusions such as dikes.

Gabbro.
After granite, gabbro is the most common plutonic rock, which is the plutonic equivalent of basaltic rock, and forms in igneous intrusions called lopoliths (see p.61).

Xenoliths.
When magma solidifies to make new igneous rock, it often traps fragments of old foreign rock called xenoliths. These may be partly changed, or metamorphosed, by heat and pressure.

Factbox.
The grains in hypabyssal rocks measure 0.2-0.4 in (1-5 mm).
The grains in plutonic rocks measure 0.4 in (5 mm) or more.

Metamorphic rocks.
The immense heat and pressure created by earthquakes and volcanic activity can dramatically change rock shapes. Baked by magma or squeezed by tectonic activity, this transformation to metamorphic rock can take place on local or regional scale.

Marble David.
Marble, a beautiful rock, is a form of metamorphosed limestone. The most famous type, Carrara marble, is found in Italy, where Michelangelo (1475-1564) used it to sculpt his statue of David.

Contact metamorphism.
When rocks are altered by direct contact with hot magma - such as an igneous intrusion - the change is known as contact metamorphism.

Regional metamorphism.
Rocks can be altered as they are crushed and baked under mountain ranges thrown up by colliding tectonic plates. Intense pressure can give rocks a "foliated", or layered texture, and crystals reform in a banded pattern known as schistosity. Rocks at the heart of the activity undergo high-grade metamorphism - the most intense folding. Those further away experience low-grade change.

Metamorphic facts.
Quartz and kaolinite meld into pyrophyllite above 572°F (300°C).
Over 752°F (400°C) pyrophillite turns to andalusite or cyanite.

Slate.
Slate is a dark, gray, flaky rock, formed by low-grade regional metamorphism of mudstone and shale. Extensive pressure compacts clay and quartz minerals into smooth, flat layers.

Schist.
If medium-grade regional metamorphism acts on shale or mudstone, foliated metamorphic rock forms. Minerals recrystallize into chlorite, biotite and garnet.

Gneiss.
When mudstone, slate, or schists are subjected to high-grade regional metamorphism, a mottled rock called gneiss forms. Within this rock, bands of dark minerals alternate with lighter bands of quartz and feldspar.

Marble.
Marble is usually formed as a result of contact or regional metamorphism of limestone. Heat and pressure transform the calcite in the limestone into sugary marble.

Hot-water minerals.
Chemicals-rich water circulates underground in hydrothermal systems. Washed through cracks to cooler places, chemicals such as sulfur and copper solidify over thousands of years - forming valuable mineral deposits.

Acid attack.
Because the extreme heat vaporizes many substances, liquids and gases from volcanoes are rich in chemicals. Gas masks are needed when researching eruptions that include sulfur dioxide. Some crater lakes, like Kawah Idjen in Java, (right) are full of acid.

Sulfurous fumes.
Sulfur is one of the most common substance in hot volcanic liquids and fumes. Steam bubbling through a fumarole has the unmistakable bad-egg smell of hydrogen sulfide ; and spiky sulfur crystals form around the mouth of the vent.

Minerals from the deep.
Black smokers gave the first clue to the riches of hydrothermal deposits, covering the sea bed on either side of mid-ocean ridges with valuable compounds of sulfur, including the ores of copper, zinc, and iron.

Sulfur facts.
Sulfur is added to rubber to make it tougher - a process called vulcanization.
Sulfur and other gases are still belching from Kawah Idjen, 40 years after its last eruption.

Sulfur crystals.
As volcanic vapors cool, the sulfur they hold slowly precipitates and forms crystals. Under the right conditions, large yellow crystals grow - like those mined for centuries in Sicily.

Making gems.
Crystals form as hot magma cools. Minerals with high melting points crystallize first, changing the melt's chemical mix. As the lest of the melt crystallizes, rocks called pegmatites form; which may contain rare gems.

Amethyst.
Quartz is a common constituent of igneous rocks. In pegmatites, however, it often forms gems like rose quartz, citrine quartz, and, less commonly, purple amethyst.

Agate bubble.
Some of the best crystals are formed in geodes, or magma bubbles. Hot water, enriched by minerals from the magma, trickles through the rock and fills the geodes. As the geodes crystallize, they form gems, such as agate.

Crystal facts.
As spodumene crystal 50 ft (15 m) long was found in the Black hills of South Dakota.
A beryl crystal 33 ft (10 m) long turned up in the Bumpus Quarry near Bethel, Maine.

Massive quartz.
Tiger's eye.
Massive quartz is composed of very small grains of fibers. Sometimes, flecks of foreign mineral may replace the original mineral within the crystal. In stripy tiger's eye, tiny quartz crystals replace asbestos fibers.

Chrysoprase.
When quartz cools in a cavity, it can form solid masses of the fine-grained gem quartz chalcedony ; the most valuable type is chrysoprase, which is bright green.

Jasper.
Another type of chalcedony is jasper, which often forms in the bubbles of cools lavas. Traces of iron oxide turn it red, and actinolite or chlorite turn it green.

Gems from the deep.
Many valuable gems are formed from the crystallization of magma. Many, like ruby, sapphire, spinel, olivine, pyrope garnet, and zircon, have high melting points and simple chemical compositions. Diamond, made of pure carbon, is the simplest and hardest of all.

Diamond.
Diamond is the hardest naturally occuring mineral. Found in the rare igneous rocks kimberlite and lamproite, diamonds are often over three billion years older than the kimberlites that brings them to the surface.

Emerald.
The finest emeralds, a type of beryl, come from the Muzo and Chivor mines in Colombia. They form from mineral-rich brine trapped in cavities in limestone distorted by the movement of tectonic plates.

Eclogite.
As the basalt of a subducted ocean crust is pushed into the earth's interior, heat and pressure transform it into the rock eclogite. The carbon that forms into diamond probably came from sediments dragged down along with the ocean crust.

Sapphire.
Sapphire is one of many hard gems that crystallize at high temperatures deep in the Earth's interior. Sapphire is the blue gem form of the mineral corundum - tinted by iron and titanium. The deep cornflower-blue sapphires from Kashmir are the most valued.

Diamond facts.
The word diamond comes from the Greek word adamas, meaning unconquerable.
The largest diamond ever unearthed was the "Cullinan", from South Africa. Found in 1905, it weighed 3,106 carats - over 22 oz (620 g).

Ruby.
Another form of corundum, rubies sometimes form from magma deep in the Earth. However, the most famous rubies - the fabulous gems from the Mogok area Myanmar - were formed when minerals containing aluminum recrystallized under extreme heat and pressure.

Beryl. 
Traces of manganese turn beryl pink (morganite) and red ; iron turns it blue (aquamarine) or yellow (heliodore) ; and chromium or vanadium turns it green (emerald). Beryl usually crystallizes at fairly low temperatures in granitic pegmatites but may also form when rocks are metamorphosed.

Earthquakes.
When the Earth quakes.
Every day some part of the world is shaken by an earthquake. Some are barely strong enough to rock a cradle, while others are so violent they can destroy cities. Most occur in earthquake zones, which coincide with the cracks between tectonic plates. They are triggered by the immense forces generated as plates grind together.

How an earthquake is generated.
When one plate drags past another, the rock on either side of the crack bends and stretches. Eventually, it snaps. This sudden rupture sends shock waves, or seismic waves, shuddering through the ground at 20 times the speed of sound. The shock waves radiate outward from the hypocenter, gradually diminishing in intensity. They travel so fast, there is little warning of the impending quake.

Earthquake facts.
The major San Andreas fault lies along 600 miles (965 km) of California's coast.
The 1906 Los Angeles earthquake killed 3,000 people and left a further 250,000 homeless.

Shock sequence.
In most quakes, a few minor tremors (foreshocks) are followed by an intense burst, then a second series of minor tremors (aftershocks) over the next hour or so. The main shock may last just a few minutes, but a violent quake is enough to bring down tall buildings.

Big thumper.
By tracing earthquake vibrations, seismologists learn about the rocks underground. A vibroseis truck thumps the ground, creating artificial shock waves. Seismographs then pick up a wave pattern that reveals rock structures.

Earthquake damage.
Many of the world's major cities, including Los Angeles, Mexico City, and Tokyo, are located in major earthquake zones. The people that live in these places learn to cope with minor tremors. If a large earthquake were to strike a major city, it could cause widespread destruction and death.

Shaky ground.
The extent of damage an earthquake causes depends on its strength, the distance of a city from the epicenter, and the type of ground on which the city is built. Loose sediments can magnify a quake ; in the 1995 earthquake in Kobe, Japan, buildings built on landfill sustained the worst damage.

Earthquake facts.
The longest recorded earthquake, in Alaska on March 27, 1964, lasted just 4 minutes.
During the 1989 San Francisco quake, a vast crack 2,150 ft (650 m) long opened up in the Santa Cruz mountains.
Cities well outside earthquake zones are occasionally hit by minor tremors.

Earthquake waves.
Earthquakes generate two kinds of shock wave : body waves and surface waves. Body waves travel underground at great speed, often passing around the world. Slower surface waves move along the ground from the epicenter. They can cause far more damage.
Time lag.
A seismograph shows the arrival pattern of an earthquake's body waves. P (primary) waves arrive first, followed by slower S (secondary) waves. The time lag between the two, in this case 17 seconds, indicates how far away the hypocenter is. The measurement on the Richter scale (see pp. 94-95) is the P wave of maximum amplitude.
Quake facts.
While quakes are rare in eastern states, they affect much larger areas when they occur. The Earth's crust in the east is much less broken up so shock waves are not interrupted.
All around the world.
P waves can travel around the world in just over an hour, registering on seismographs far from the quake. Comparing readouts from two or three stations can pinpoint the quake's location. The way waves are refracted, or bent, as they pass through the Earth reveals much about its inferior.
Body waves.
P waves.
Traveling at 3 miles (5 km) per second, P waves (compressional waves) alternately squeeze and stretch the rock.
S waves.
At a slightly slower 2 miles (3 km) per second, S waves (shear waves) move the ground in a ripple up and down or side to side.
Surface waves.
Love waves.
Love, or Q waves, shake the ground from side to side in a jerky movement that can devastate high-rise buildings.
Rayleigh waves.
Rayleigh, or R waves, shake the surface up and down, often creating a visible rolling and billowing of the ground.

Earthquake measurement.
The richter scale uses seismograph readings to assess a quake's magnitude, while the Modified Mercalli scale records the quake's destructive effects. Both scales are being superceded by Moment-magnitude, which combines Richter readings with observations of rock movements.
Mercalli scale.
On a scale of I to XII, the Mercalli scale, devised by Giuseppe Mercalli (1850-1914), shows a quake's intensity in a fixed place by observing its effects. Since a quake weakens away from its epicenter, so the Mercalli rating varies according to where it is assessed.
I Movement detected by instruments.
II Felt by people resting.
III Hanging lights sway.
IV Plates and windows rattle, parked cars rock.
V Buildings tremble, liquids spill ; vibrations felt by most people.
VI Movement felt by all, pictures fall off walls, window glass shatters.
VII Bricks and tiles fall, chimneys crack, difficult to stand.
VIII Hard to steer a car, tree branches snap, chimneys fall.
IX General panic, ground cracks, mud oozes from ground.
X pipes burst, rivers flood, most buildings collapse.
XI Bridges collapse, train lines buckle, landslides occur.
XII Near total destruction, rivers change course, waves ripple ground.
Richter scale.
Devised in the 1930s by Charles Richter (1900-1985), the Richter scale measures the magnitude of a quake, or the total energy it releases on a scale o 1-10.
Magnitude vs. Intensity?
Though precise, the Richter scale does not necessarily indicate how damaging an earthquake is. Each step in the scale indicates a ten-fold increase in magnitude. However, while a Richter 7 quake may be 100 times a 6, it does not shake your house 100 times harder. It simply  lasts longer and spreads its energy wider.
Earthquake facts.
The global network of seismographs records 10 to 20 quakes a year that measure over 7 on the Richter scale.

Measuring vibrations.
The size of an earthquake can be measured by an instrument called a seismometer. The seismograph is the part of a seismometer that records earthquake vibrations, producing a seismogram, or written trace of the vibrations. This device is derived from the seismoscope, invented over 1,700 years earlier by Chinese scholar Zhang Heng.
The first seismoscope.
The bronze urn seismoscope designed by Zhang Heng (AD 78-139) was the first to detect minor tremors. When the ground shook, he pendulum stayed steady but caused a ball in one of the dragons' mouths near the top of the urn to fall.
Seismograph.
In a basic seismograph, the hanging weight stays still as the rest of the device shakes. A pen attached to the weight traces the shakes on paper. Today, the shakes are recorded electronically.
Recording earthquakes.
In Europe, earthquake recording began in the 18th century. This seismograph, made by Italian vulcanologist Luigi Palmieri (1807-96), produced a ticker tape recording of the intensity of earthquake.
Ocean bottom seismometers.
Every tremor felt around the world is recorded by a linked network of synchronized seismometers. The shock waves from any quake can be traced around the globe and the focus can be pinpointed - so the earthquake can be rated on the Richter scale. Now waterproof ocean bottom seismometers can record vibrations on the ocean floor.

Tsunamis.
When the sea bed is shaken by an earthquake or volcano, vibrations set off waves that roll along as fast as a jet plane - 435 mph (700 km/h). In deep water, tsunamis are hard to detect; but in shallow coastal waters, they rear up in giant, destructive waves.

Wave risk.
Tsunamis can travel over vast expanses of ocean. In 1960, an earthquake in Chile caused a tsunami that devastated the Japanese coast 24 hours later.
Just before a tsunami, sea level falls.
Tsunami engulfs land for up to five minutes.
Tsunamis can change the shape of the coastline.

Tsunami train.
Tsunamis generally occur in trains of 12 or more, from five minutes to an hour apart. They can engulf lowland coasts for up to five minutes.
Swift and devastating, tsunamis can sweep away entire villages before sucking debris - and even the land itself - back out to sea.

A tsunami's life begins deep beneath the ocean with an earthquake, which creates a sudden shift in the ocean bed. Water rushes into the gulf, then rebounds in giant rolling surges that ripple along the ocean floor.
Wave begins. Plates shift. Surges of water ripple outward.
Boat does not move as wave passes beneath.
In deep water, these fast-moving rolls are almost invisible on the surface, barely rocking a boat as they pass underneath it.

Water rears up. 
In shallower water, huge waves about 100 ft (30m) high appear. As the first wave arrives, the beach water is sucked away before the wave hits.

Tsunami facts.
The highest recorded tsunami, 278 ft (84m) hit Japan in 1971.
In 1883, a tsunami set off by Krakatoa swept a ship 1.5 miles (2.6 km) inland.

Mudslides and Avalanches.
Both earthquakes and volcanoes can trigger mudslides and avalanches. Though they often prove minor, they sometimes drop tons of rock, mud, or snow onto villages and towns - a peril even more deadly than the original eruption or quake itself.

Killer mud.
Volcanoes create mudflows called "lahars" when fragments of rock and ash mix with water, resulting in a slurry that can surge down steep valleys at speeds of 19-25 mph (30-40 km/h).

Water unleashed.
An earthquake's shock waves may cause high dams to crack and burst and rivers to change course. The ensuing floods cause damage and often death.

Disaster facts.
On Mount Usu, Japan, mudflows are redirected by check dams and conduits.
A quake in 1970 in the Andes set off a rock-and-ice avalanche killing 18,000 people.

Types of snow avalanche.
Slab avalanche.
Earthquakes in snowy mountain regions often set off slab avalanches. A slab of unstable layers of ice and snow - which have built up during alternate freezes and thaws - crashes down, breaking up as it falls.

Airborne powder avalanche.
Heavy snowfalls often drop dry, loose snow, which slides along the ground and comes to rest. If disturbed by a quake, it can turn into an airborne-powder avalanche.

Wet-snow avalanche.
In spring, wet-snow avalanches are a hazard. Snow becomes saturated with water and moves slowly downhill. Even a minor eruption of a snow-capped volcano may set off a snowslide.

Powder avalanche.
When fresh snow falls, it may slide downhill as it builds up. But an earthquake can trigger a powder avalanche - which bowls down the slope - compressing air in front of it and creating a destructive shock wave.

Reference Section.
Vulcanologists at work.
Vulcanologists study volcanoes to determine when they will erupt. With volcanoes that show persistent eruption patterns, the best way to forecast eruptions is to study past behavior. However, the most dangerous of explosive volcanoes are also the most erratic - and they need constant monitoring.

Hat and glove.
When scientists need to examine a volcano at close range, a hard hat, asbestos gloves, and a heat-proof suit are essential.

Metal-coated protective suit reflects heat but inhibits movement.

Looking for clues.
A crucial sign of an imminent eruption seems to be a buildup of magma beneath the volcano. Tell-tale signs of this include increases in ground temperature, rising levels of carbon dioxide in boreholes, and changes in gravity or variations in magnetic or electrical fields.

Hot rod. 
Occasionally, vulcanologists need to take samples of red-hot lava directly from a lava flow. This is a dangerous task, but a metal rod helps. From as safe a place as possible, the vulcanologist dips the pronged end of the rod into the lava flow and twists it. The prongs hook a blob of lava out of the stream.
Twisted prongs trap lava.

Watching for swelling.
Vulcanologists use hand surveying instruments like mining transit tools to make maps. They also use them to watch for any changes in the volcano's slope, such as swelling caused by the builup of magma. These may not always be accurate enough.

The quest for accuracy.
Tiltmeters use lasers to show variations in fluid level that may reveal slight changes in volcanic slopes. Space satellites, however, make the task safer and more accurate. Many stations use the Global Positioning System (GPS) to detect slight lateral movements. Other satellites use radar interferometry, where light measures tiny distances, to make maps of dangerous volcanoes.


Timeline of discovery.
The threat of volcanoes and earthquakes to cities around the world has encouraged individuals to observe and study them from the earliest times. Their discoveries are the base of our knowledge today. 
Aristotle (384-322 BC).
The Greek philosopher Artistotle, whose ideas dominated European thought for 2,000 years, was one of the first people to study earthquakes scientifically. He believed they were caused when air trapped in deep underground pockets escaped to the surface.
Zhang Heng AD 78-139.
A Chinese imperial historian and astronomer born in Nanyang, Zhang Heng made the first seismoscope to record earthquakes. He also realized - long before his Western counterparts - that moonlight comes from the sun, and lunar eclipses occur when the Earth's shadow falls on the moon.
Avicenna (980-1037).
Born near Bokhara, Turkey, Avicenna was a renowned physician to Persian sultans, known for his prodigious learning. Among his 200 or so books on scientific topics was Liber de Mineralibus, his ideas on earthquakes and geology, which dominated thinking in the field for 500 years.
Athenasius Kircher (1602-1680).
The German Jesuit Kircher, famous throughout Europe for his translations of Egyptian hieroglyphs, was among the great 17th-century scientists and writers. His book Mundus Subterraneous (The Subterranean World) showed how Earth's fiery core feeds volcanoes and heats thermal springs.
Benoît de Mailler (1656-1738).
A French diplomat and traveler, de Mailler wrote a book on earth's history called Telliamed (his name spelled backward). He was one of the first to realize our planet's advanced age. Two hundred years before anyone else, he argued Earth was over two billion years old. However, he also believed volcanoes were pockets of animal oil and fats that had become trapped in sedimentary rock and caught on fire.
Jean-Etienne Guettard (1715-1766).
A natural scientist, Guettard insisted on drawing conclusions from direct observation only and made many field trips to identify rocks. He created the first geological map of France and astounded French scientists by proving that there were once active volcanoes in the Massive Central, in France.
Nicholas Desmaret (1725-1615).
A quiet bureaucrat whose hobby was geology, Desmaret studied volcanic rocks in the French Auvergne. While Guettard and other geologists believed basalts were sedimentary rock, Desmared showed they were once lava flows that, upon cooling, formed the region's hexagonal columns.
James Hutton (1726-1797).
Scottish geologist James Hutton is considered the founder of modern geology. In his day, people believed Earth was just a few thousand years old. Hutton showed that it was much older and that the landscape was shaped gradually over millions of years. He was also the first person to realize that intrusive igneous rocks like granite were once molten rock that had emerged from deep inside the Earth.
Abraham Werner (1750-1817).
German geologist Werner was one of the "superstars" of 18th-century-geology, and people would listen to his lectures spellbound. He believed, however, that volcanoes were underground veins of coal that had caught fire and burned the way to the surface - and were insignificant geographically. Students of his - Jean d'Aubuisson, Leopold von Buch, and Alexander von Humbolt - later realized that he was wrong.

James Hall (1761-1832).
Hall, a fellow Scotsman and friend of Hutton, studied volcanoes in Italy. Many 18th-century geologists that the presence of crystal in igneous rocks proved that they had never been molten. Hall rested rocks in a hot iron foundry and showed that molten basalt forms crystals if cooled slowly.
Alexander von Humboldt (1769-1859).
One of the great scientific explorers of the 19th century, German-born Baron Humboldt went on epic South American expeditions to collect data. From studying American volcanoes, he realized that they coincided with geological faults. He also found that many rocks are igneous. 
George Scrope (1801-1875).
An English gentleman and member of Parliament, Scrope developed a passionate interest in vulcanology after visiting the Italian volcanies Stromboli and Etna. In 1825, he published Considerations on Volcanoes, in which he originated the idea that explosive eruptions were driven by expansion of gases within the magma. He later realized that the most important of these gases was water vapor.
Luigi Palmieri (1807-1896).
While observing the eruption of Italy's Mount Vesuvius in 1855, Italian scientist Luigi Palmieri realized that an instrument capable of detecting very faint tremors in the ground might help predict both earthquakes and volcanic eruptions. To detect these tremors, he invented the first true seismograph in 1855. Later, in 1872, he became a national hero when he stayed at his observatory throughout an eruption of Vesuvius.
Robert Mallet (1810-1881).
An Irish civil engineer, Mallet became interested in earthquakes and volcanoes after studying an eruption of Vesuvius in 1857. To work out how fast shock waves travel, Mallet made a map of earthquakes. It showed, for the first time, that they occur in particular zones.
Giuseppe Mercalli (1850-1914).
An Italian professor of natural sciences, Mercalli was a pioneer in seismology. His detailed observations of tremors in Italy's major earthquake districts advanced the science. In 1897, Mercalli produced his scale of earthquake intensity, which he modified several times.
John Milne (1850-1913).
Milne, a British mining engineer and professor of Geology and Mining at Tokyo University, focused his interest in quakes on seismographs and the earthquake-proofing of buildings. A sensitive seismograph he built was the first to record very distant earthquakes.
Frank Alvord Perret (1857-1940).
American vulcanologist Perret pioneered the forecasting of eruptions. Working on Vesuvius in 1906, he predicted an eruption based on a buzzing sound - the harmonic vibration of the magma mass. Using microphones to pick up vibrations, he also studied Mount Pelée, Martinique.
Thomas Hagger Junior (1871- 1953).
A firm believer in on-the-spot volcano study, this American vulcanologist set up in 1912 the first permanent volcano-observation post, on the island of Hawaii. Since then, the Hawaiian Volcano Observatory has made Kilauea the most thoroughly studied and understood volcano in the world. This observatory that Jagger founded also pioneered the use of bombing to divert lava flows.
Alfred Wegener (1880-1930).
German meteorologist Wegener seriously proposed the continental-drift theory, which holds that all the continents were once joined in one "supercontinent" - Pangea. Despite evidence matching rock strata on adjacent coasts of widely separated continents, his ideas were ridiculed.
Alfred Lacroix (1863-1948).
Lacroix arrived in Martinique on June 23, 1902, right after the eruption of Mount Pelée. He published a report on the volcano nine months later. A celebrated vulcanology text, it describes the nuée ardente, or glowing cloud, that was so deadly to the citizens of St. Pierre.
Charles Richter (1900- 1985).
Working in California during the 1930s, Richter, a seismologist, found a way to compare the size of local quakes. By measuring on a seismograph each earthquake's peaks and the distance of their focus, he devised the Richter scale. This complete scale for quake magnitude is still standard today.
Kiyoo Wadati (1902-1996).
In 1927, Japanese seismologist Wadati showed that many earthquakes start in subduction zones deep in the Earth's crust - at least 185 miles (300 km) down. When American Hugo Benioff (1899-1968) found that these zones lie near ocean trenches, they were named Benioff-Wadati zones.
Haroun Tazieff (1914-1998).
Tazieff, who was born in Poland and worked in France, was a superstar of 20th-century vulcanology. Having investigated many of the world's most famous volcanoes, he was appointed in 1984 the first French Secretary of State for the Prevention of Natural and Technological disasters. His stance at that time on evacuation in advance of potential eruptions was considered controversial.

Volcanic Records.
Some features of volcanic activity, like cone-shaped peaks, crater lakes, and recent lava flows are unmistakable. More subtly, however, every inch of the earth's surface has been affected at some time by volcanic activity, even if its signs have been eroded by the passage of billions of years.
About 130-80 million years ago, in the age of dinosaurs, huge flows of basalt lava - called flood basalts -oozed from the floors of the Pacific and Indian Oceans.
Some 60-65 million years ago, basalt gushed onto the surface in a near-continuous flow to form India's Deccan plateau. 
17 million years ago, huge molten-basalt flows from a hot spot created the Columbia plateau in Oregon and Washington.
Two million years ago, one of the world's biggest eruptions hit Yellowstone, Wyoming. Enough magma poured on to the surface to build a half-dozen Mount Fujiyamas.
In 1645 BC, the Greek island of Thera erupted, burying the Minoan city Akroteri. This may have started the Atlantis myth.
In AD 79, Vesuvius erupted, burying the ancient town of Pompeii.
In 186 Lake Taupo, in New Zealand, was created in a vast eruption.
In 300, an eruption in El Salvador left a caldera  - now Lake Ilopango. Survivors may have founded the Mayan civilization.
In 1669, Sicily's Mount Etna, Europe's largest volcano, erupted, burying Catania in lava.
In 1783, Laki mountain, Iceland, poured out lava and gases. These gases killed crops, and a fifth of Icelan's people starved.
In 1815, Tambora, in Indonesia, erupted and sent dust clouds round the world - dimming the sun.
In 1902, the town of St Pierre, on Martinique, was ruined by burning dust-clouds from Mount Pelée.
In 1963, the volcanic island of Surtsey appeared on Iceland's coast.
In 1980, Washington's Mount St Helens erupted, flattening forests.
In 1986, gases from Lake Nyos, Cameroon, killed thousands but left houses and gardens intact.
The 1991 eruption of Mount Pinatubo, Philippines, was the biggest this century.
In 1996, Grimsvotn, Iceland, erupted under the Vatnajökull glacier.
In 1997, the southern part of Montserrat and its capital were devastated.

Ash comparisons.
The amount of ash a volcano emits can indicate the size of the eruption. This diagram compares emissions of six major eruptions, in cubic miles.

Volcanic peaks.
Many high peaks are volcanic. In the Andes, there are more than ten volcanoes over 23,000 ft (7,000m). Below is a comparison of some volcanic peaks with Everest, the world's tallest mountain.
Mount Everest, at 29,028 ft (8,848m), towers over the biggest volcanoes.
Mauna Kea. Measured from the sea bed, Hawaii's Mauna Kea is taller than Mt Everest by 1,355 m (4,446 ft).

Earthquake records.
Earthquakes are brief, lasting no more than a few minutes. Yet they can cause huge casualties - far greater than those resulting from volcanic eruptions. Moreover, quakes can devastate vast areas. But, unlike volcanoes; they leave no dramatic relics - so earthquakes records are scanty.

Myths and Superstitions.
The awesome powers of volcanoes and earthquakes has long been interpreted by humans as evidence of the work of deities and mythical beings. Many cultures that have experienced quakes or volcanic eruptions have developed myths and superstitions to account for the forces that can spew liquid fire or rip apart the earth's surface. 
Voltaire.
In his book Candide, the French writer Voltaire (1694-1778) wrote about the terrible Lisbon quake of 1755. The destruction shocked Europe, but Voltaire poked fun at religious figures, hinting that God was punishing the city for its immorality. He also mocked Lisbon residents, who blamed foreigners for the disaster.
Hephaistos.
According to Greek myth, volcanoes on the island of Lemnos were caused by Hephaistos, god of fire and metalwork, who set up his forge underground.
Neptune Knocks.
Earthquakes are not uncommon in Greece, and the waters of the Aegean are often upset by tsunamis. The ancient Greeks believed that these were caused by the god of the sea Poseidon (known by the Romans as Neptune), banging angrily on the seafloor with his trident.
Hot-headed goddess.
Pele, the goddess of volcanoes, still inspires fear of the island of Hawaii. This fire-haired goddess is said to make the volcanoes erupt. When she is angry, she stamps the ground, creating earthquakes, before emerging from below riding a wave of lava, screaming curses, and hurling hot rocks.
Hollow earth.
The Earth's interior has fascinated people for centuries. Only a bit more than a century ago, the French author Jules Verne (1818-1905) wrote his Journey to the Center of the Earth. French thinker Benoît de Mailler (1656-1738) asserted that burning animal oils trapped in hollows inside the Earth caused volcanoes.
Shaky frog.
Many cultures have believed that the world was carried on the back of a giant. Ancient Hindu myth places it on the back of eight giant elephants. For Mongolians it was a frog, which shook the ground when it stumbled.
