30 March 1993 p.33

Not quite all the way to hell.

Television

Nigel Hawkes


Horizon, BBC2 

In the global ozone balance, how much hath God wrought, and how much mankind? Nobody but the occasional eccentric now denies that the production of chlorine chemicals for use in refrigerators and insulators has had a serious effect on the levels of ozone in the stratosphere. But is this manmade effect significant when compared with the spectactular pyrotechnics of volcanoes? 

Last night's Horizon set out to find the answer with the aid of an eight-legged robot called Dante, designed in Pittsburg to be lowered down the crater of Mount Erebus, a volcano in Antarctica that lies within the area encompassed by the ozone hole. Dante was designed in a bit of a rush to descend into the inferno of Erebus, the Greek for hell. Originally, by a fine literary conceit, all too rare among scientific projects, Dante was designed to be controlled by a second robot on the surface called Virgil, but appears to have been heaved over the edge by several strong men. 

The inside of volcanic craters is no place for the nervous. A previous expedition to Erebus in 1978 ended in near disaster when a vulcanologist lowered down on a rope was bombarded with red hot lumps of lava and was quickly hauled up again. Since then, nobody has risked a second try. Yet only observations at the very lava's edge, down where the magma boils and bubbles, can really tell us what the gases are that emerge from volcanoes into the atmosphere. Hence the robot Dante, built with money from the United States' space agency Nasa, which hopes that experience inside volcanoes may one day come in useful on Mars. 

The mission was of more than academic interest. Cancers of the skin such as malignant melanoma and squamous cell carcinoma are rising alarmingly, especially in Australia and New Zealand, two countries populated by white-skinned settlers from greyer climes. So far, all of this increase can be attributed to the taste for sunbathing, and none to increased levels of ultraviolet radiation caused by ozone depletion. The ozone hole is too recent to have contributed anything much. But future prospects are alarming, unless ozone-depleting chemicals are quickly brought under control. 

After setting the scene so admirably, it has to be said that Horizon was let down by technology. Barely 20 feet into the crater, Dante developed a kink in its umbilical cord and stopped sending useful information back. Hauled out almost as ignominiously as its live predecessor, the robot left all the interesting questions unanswered. 

The film prompted a few reflections. For years, environmentalists have been arguing that the production of hundreds of new chemicals every year is a form of Russian roulette, with the global environment as the potential victim. So far, though, the earth has mostly had the last laugh, turning out to have a multitude of ways of rendering harmless almost everything the chemical industry can throw at it. The chlorine chemicals, superficially the most benign of products, barely capable of hurting a fly, have proved the major exception. 

The lesson, I suppose, is the familiar one about the price of security being eternal vigilance. While the biosphere is tougher than some have feared, like all systems it has its unexpected weaknesses. As Dante proved, an organism representing the finest in robot technology can be found out by a kink in its umbilical. Not by great things but by small will the earth perish.

30 December 1992 p.4

Volcano tests a robot bound for Mars

By Nigel Hawkes, Science Editor



PERCHED on the edge of a volcano 800 miles from the South Pole, an eight-legged robot is being made ready for a journey into the underworld. 

Within the next few days, the Pounds 1.3 million robot, called Dante, will clamber into the crater of Mount Erebus, a 12,447ft mountain on Ross Island in Antarctica. Braving temperatures of 1,100 Fahrenheit, it will collect the first samples of gases direct from a volcano's vents and send live television pictures to the Goddard space flight centre run by Nasa in Greenbelt, Maryland. 

Yesterday, the 12-man expedition had established camp near the edge of the crater and was readying Dante for the descent, which could begin today. As well as learning more about conditions inside the crater, the project is a test run for robots that will one day explore Mars. 

David Lavery, manager of Nasa's telerobotics programme, said: ``The Erebus project lets us test a rover in the most Mars-like place on Earth while giving us the payoff of using it to obtain unique scientific information.'' 

Dante, named after the author of the Divina Commedia which describes a trip to hell, has been built in a rush so that an attempt can be made on Erebus before the Antarctic summer ends. The robot stands more than 8ft tall and has been designed and built at Carnegie-Mellon University in Pittsburgh. 

A dozen electric motors operate its spider-like legs and give it a maximum speed of around 6ft a minute. Information and pictures will be sent through an umbilical cord to the crater rim, and then by satellite to Goddard. 

Erebus was chosen because it is one of only three volcanoes in the world with a permanent lava lake inside its crater. Dante will be lowered 850ft to the edge of the lake and will take temperature readings, measure gas compositions and retrieve gas samples from volcanic vents. The gases, lava and flying rocks hurled from the depths make the crater far too dangerous for human exploration. 

While in the crater, Dante will have to navigate cliffs, overhangs, soft ash beds and other difficult terrain. Its designer, Dr William Whittaker of Carnegie Mellon, said: ``It's as bad as it gets.'' 

A gas chromatograph carried by Dante will be used to sample gases as they emerge from volcanic vents, known as fumaroles. The composition of these gases should provide information about the source of the magma supplying the volcano. 

Vulcanologists suspect that they will contain a high proportion of carbon dioxide, a theory it is impossible to test from a safe position on the crater's rim. Dante should also gather samples of a powdery material that surrounds the fumaroles. This is thought to contain gold, copper and zinc which have condensed from the hot gases. 

Conditions will be tough even for a robot, with superheated steam and clouds of acid. The idea, says Nasa, is to test technology in an extremely harsh environment.

05 December 1995,p.12

Rumbles raise fear of Fuji eruption / Overseas news 

Mount Fuji, Japan

From Peregrine Hodson in Tokyo



MOUNT FUJI, one of the most evocative symbols of Japan, may be building towards a big volcanic eruption, scientists say. 

A research institute in Tsukuba, northeast of Tokyo, noticed preliminary signs on October 1, when a seismometer registered an earthquake measuring 2.0 on the Richter scale, ten miles undergound, just north of Mount Fuji. 

The seismometer showed the oscillations of a low-frequency earthquake about once or twice a second which is a sign of subterranean magma flows. According to seismologists, the Tokai region near Mount Fuji could be shaken by an earthquake at any time. If so, it could trigger a volcanic eruption. 

Japan is formed by the intersection of four tectonic plates, which cause the country's frequent earthquake and volcanic activity. Despite its symmetrical appearance, the sacred mountain is a composite of three separate volcanoes, and achieved its conical shape comparatively recently. 

Some historians believe that the carefully raked mounds of sand in Zen gardens commemorate the formation of Mount Fuji, which happened in recorded history. The volcano has erupted every 300 or 400 years.

Luxury, despite the volcano / Features 

Property

Mary Wilson



MONTSERRAT has been in the news a lot recently because of its volcano which was threatening to erupt at any time. 

This, however, has not perturbed the Isles Bay Plantation company, which is building large Caribbean-style houses on the northern side of the island, 3.5 miles from Chance's Peak, the volcano that began rumbling in August. Isles Bay has sold 10 houses and hopes to build another 12. The one-storey villas have verandas, sun decks and 40ft swimming pools. Prices range from about Pounds 300,000 to Pounds 550,000. The island is mountainous with lush vegetation, low humidity and an average temperature of 80F all year.

26 September 1995, p.1

Volcano emergency alert / Home news 

Mount Ruapehu, New Zealand

Michael Munro



BOULDERS, mud, ash and poisonous gases are hurled thousands of feet in the air as an eruption of Mount Ruapehu in New Zealand's North Island gained in intensity yesterday. 

The effects were being experienced over a wide area with airports having to close in Napier and Gisborne, 90 miles to the east, and ash falling on high voltage lines causing power surges as far away as Wellington, 150 miles to the south. 

The families of some army staff at the Waiouru military camp, southeast of the 9,000ft mountain, were evacuated yesterday and a hotel at a popular tourist resort was forced to shut its doors. 

A high-altitude section of the Auckland-Wellington ``Desert Road'' was closed after ash and toxic fumes made driving hazardous. In Ohakune, a service town for Mount Ruapehu's ski fields, there were reports of a run on essential supplies as residents prepared for possible disruption to transport services. On Sunday scientists had predicted that a large explosion, eclipsing the 1945 eruption that created a lava dome on the summit and ash falls in Wellington, was imminent. 

The mountain erupted throughout yesterday and emergency services remained on 24-hour alert. It then fell quiet although there were signs that activity might resume today.

11 September 1995, p.16

Past blast / Features 

Science Briefing; Mind and Matter

Nigel Hawkes



THE greatest destruction of species the Earth has ever witnessed seems almost certain to have been caused by a huge volcanic eruption. The loss of species 250 million years ago, at the boundary of the Permian and Triassic periods, was the most dramatic event the Earth has witnessed since life emerged. As many as 90 per cent of marine species and 70 per cent of terrestrial vertebrates died out. 

A volcano has long been the favoured culprit for the Permian-Triassic extinction, but new evidence on the precise timing of the event makes it virtually certain. 

Paul Renne of the Berkeley Geochronology Centre in California and colleagues report in Science that they have used argon dating on rocks from southern China to date the boundary to 249.98 million years ago, give or take 200,000 years. This was within a few hundred thousand years of the best dates for a huge outpouring of lava from volcanoes in what is now Siberia. 

In the course of about one million years, the eruption threw out between two and three million cubic kilometres of lava. The result would have been abrupt global cooling caused by sulphates hurled into the atmosphere. The ice caps expanded, the sea levels dropped, and species after species succumbed. The Earth may even have rocked on its axis, causing further climatic disruption. 

Cause and effect cannot be proved in this case, but the very close coincidence in time between the two events makes it seem highly likely.

Tom Rhodes in Plymouth, Montserrat



THE eerie silence under the volcano was punctured only by the sound of tramping boots through ash-covered undergrowth as Royal Marines and scientists climbed the steep incline leading to Chances Peak yesterday.

The precarious and muddy climb through dense shrubbery, trumpet trees and dasheen jungle rhubarb led past a ravine, snaking up to the smoking vents above, before Lloyd Lynch, a Trinidadian expert in seismic equipment, stopped by a solar panel. Mr Lynch jumped up and down, his handset squealing in protest. ``That should put the fear of God into them down there,'' he said. ``If it starts to wail like a police siren, then we are out of here. But by then you should start to see something.'' 

The thick clouds started to lift and a swirl of smoke could be seen spewing from the fissure above Gages Upper Soufriere. The handset began to whine. 

On the hillside, Captain Paul Mansell and Sergeant Kevin Foster, a member of the Marines' elite Mountain and Arctic Warfare Cadre, were struggling in the mist to find the point where they would knock fixtures into the soft rock and secure the mirrors. 

John Shepherd, the British vulcanologist from Lancaster University who had already erected his electronic distance measuring device on a rocky plateau, waited nervously more than half a mile down the hillside. The team of Marines remained invisible and, without sighting them, it would be difficult to operate his box of tricks. 

The instrument, which bounces a laser beam off the small reflectors, can gauge any recent bulges in the volcano's walls and perhaps determine how serious the rumblings will become for a colony that already has been forced to evacuate more than half its 10,000 population from the surrounding southern region.

27 August 1995, p.1/14

Golf-playing islanders defy volcano threat / Overseas news 

Montserrat

Tony Allen-Mills, Plymouth, Montserrat



BEHIND her the volcano belched malevolently, smothering the hillsides with a brooding grey cloud. Above her head, a clattering Royal Navy helicopter thundered down the valley on a monitoring mission. Over her shoulder, the sea heaved with the early swell of a fast-approaching storm. 

None of it troubled Beverly Harris. Come hell or high water on the Caribbean island of Montserrat and official forecasts indicated both she was going to take a golf lesson. 

After a draining week of mass evacuations, volatile weather and the constant threat of a volcanic eruption, Harris was desperate for relief from the uncertainty and frustration that yesterday was gripping the world's unluckiest island. 

``If only the damned thing would blow, everyone could get on with their lives,'' said Harris, as she wielded a nine iron. It was a sentiment that echoed across the island yesterday as Chance's Peak in the Soufriere Hills continued to threaten its first big eruption in 20,000 years. 

When the steady advance of the seismic rumblings that have been troubling Montserrat for most of the summer reached crisis point with the evacuation of the capital, Plymouth, last Wednesday, an enterprising shop owner responded with a volcano T-shirt: ``Now she puffs, but will she blow? Trust the Lord and pray it's no''. 

After three days of appalling dislocation, however, many in Montserrat were trusting in the Lord and praying it would be yes if only to end the agony of not knowing when they might return to their homes. 

``Okay, when a hurricane hits, like Hugo did here in 1989, you shelter for 24 hours, it passes by, you spend a year cleaning up and it's over,'' said Father Larry Finnegan, priest at St Martin's church. ``But with this volcano, you get moved out of your home, nothing happens, you go back to your home, you get moved out again.'' 

For Reuben Meade, the island's chief minister, and Captain Paul Mansell, commanding the 70 Royal Marines stationed on Montserrat, the mounting frustration threatens to become even more of a dilemma than the physical challenge of rehousing half the island's 10,000 population. 

Mansell, whose men are running the local power station and manning the roadblocks that encircle Plymouth, praised residents for their co-operation so far. ``But frustration will build,'' he said. ``We can't give them precise information because we are not making decisions based on fact. The scientists just can't tell us when any volcano will explode.'' 

The crisis has already seen off an American medical school and Plymouth has become a ghost town, with businesses such as Peewee's Liquor World and the Double Happiness restaurant forced to close their doors indefinitely. 

Inevitably, most of those who fled Montserrat last week were the more prosperous, whose scramble for airline seats left a sour taste among locals. ``Everyone on my church board has left,'' said Ed Gough, a former American long-distance lorry driver, who works for a local evangelical church. ``Frankly, I'm a little disappointed that those who have been blessed with comparative comfort should forget their sense of responsibility to the island.'' 

At least some on the island are fighting valiantly to lead normal lives, however. Orville Clarke, the Montserrat golf club professional, intends to stay open he regards the occasional shower of volcanic ash as good for his greens.

FROM their early warning station in the foothills of Chances Peak, a handful of Royal Marines gazed skyward in trepidation as the shrouded crater 3,000ft above continued to spew smoke.

A diesel generator manned by the Navy and Marines at Plymouth has kept electric power at a maximum, not for the general population of 10,000 but to maintain the delicate monitoring equipment near the edge of Chances Peak and to pick up minute details of any earth tremors. 

Predictions of a major eruption over the weekend ranged from more than 80 per cent to less than 50 per cent. For many, the latest natural disaster represents a further stage in a curse that has plagued the pear-shaped island since it was first settled by Christopher Columbus in 1493. For followers of popular culture, it also left uninhabitable George Martin's famous studios which had brought the likes of the Rolling Stones, Sting and Elton John to these Caribbean shores. Tom Dawkins, an expatriate of seven years standing, said the soft-spoken people of Montserrat would not tolerate living under the volcano for long: ``People here are very good at dealing with the aftermath. But they hate the waiting.''

25 August 1995, p.12

Half of Montserrat evacuated as volcanic explosion grows more likely / Home news 

Nigel Hawkes, Science Editor



SCIENTISTS monitoring the Chances Peak volcano on the island of Montserrat said yesterday that an explosive eruption was becoming increasingly likely. 

Hundreds of people have already left their homes on the Caribbean island and fled to safer areas in the north or neighbouring Antigua. Yesterday Britain sent another 40 Royal Marines to Montserrat to assist the 30 already there with public order. HMS Southampton, a Royal Navy guided missile destroyer, is on standby off the coast, and the ship's doctor, Rory Rickard, has set up a shore-based field hospital. 

Residents have been streaming out of the capital, Plymouth, and into tent cities after authorities evacuated the southern half of the island, which lies in the shadow of Chances Peak. 

The scientists, sampling gases from the volcano, say that the flow has been interrupted, increasing the chances of a big explosion. The volcano has been spewing gas and ash for the past month and is being monitored by experts from the US Geological Survey, the Caribbean Seismic Research Centre in Trinidad, and the French Volcano Observatory in Guadeloupe. It has been quiescent for more than a century, so that predicting the nature of the eruption is difficult. The scientists had been confident that they could give 24 to 36 hours' notice of an eruption, but the slowdown of gas flow in the past few days has disconcerted them. The volcano lies only four miles from Plymouth, which is now a city of empty streets and shuttered windows. 

Yesterday the scientists pointed out that they could no longer be certain of providing even a six-hour warning. ``On the advice of the scientists, we have evacuated quite a large part of the island, roughly half the island, roughly two-thirds of the population,'' Governor Frank Savage said. 

The volcano has a horseshoe-shaped crater about 500ft deep, open on one side and containing a lava dome that rises almost to the rim. The experts have been watching the dome for signs of expansion, which would indicate that the volcano is about to blow. 

An explosion similar to the one that blew apart Mount St Helens in Washington State in 1980 is possible. Volcanoes that erupt infrequently do so in a less predictable way than the regular performers such as the volcanoes of Hawaii. The Hawaiian rocks are permeable when molten, allowing gases to escape and the lava to flow in a predictable way. Where gases become trapped, as at Mount Pinatubo in the Philippines in 1991, and perhaps now in Montserrat, a more violent result is likely. 

Huge volumes of gas and ash can be released and flow downhill at high speeds, killing anybody in their path. Even more destructive are the pyroclastic flows that are sometimes produced by such explosions. Particles of rock and magma are swept along at speeds of several hundred miles per hour in a mass of hot gas. 

It was an eruption of this type that destroyed the city of St Pierre in Martinique in 1902, when Mount Pelee erupted. Almost all the city's 30,000 inhabitants perished. In geological times, even larger explosions have occurred in the region. 

In the case of Chances Peak, the scientists say there is a 70 to 80 per cent chance of a major eruption, and the plan is to evacuate all the island's 10,000 residents when it is judged imminent. So far, they have been ordered only to move out of the southern and eastern sections of the island to the area north of the Belham Valley, four miles from Plymouth.

Royal Marines keep watch on restive volcano / Overseas news

David Adams in Plymouth, Montserrat

Several thousand residents from the eastern side of the island have been evacuated after a vent appeared in the side of the volcano, spouting sulphurous gas and ash. But after almost four weeks of earthquakes and a spiral of volcanic clouds over Chances Peak, he worries that they may be losing confidence.

As a near full moon rose over Montserrat, casting an eerie light over the crater of Chances Peak, which at 3,000 feet dominates Plymouth on its lower slopes, Royal Marines Captain Paul Mansell ordered his men up the volcano to establish an observation post. ``In case the volcano blows, we are here to assist the scientists and local authorities in any way we can,'' he said. The Marines arrived with highly sensitive thermal imaging equipment. 

The scientists believe the volcanic activity is due to tectonic plate movement miles below the surface, pushing magma upwards and forcing water out, creating clouds of steam mixed with sulphurous gases. ``Materials from the North American plate are being forced beneath the smaller Caribbean plate,'' said Dr William Ambeh, a research seismologist leading the team of about ten scientists on the island. They hope that the thermal imaging equipment will help them to detect any heat build-up which could indicate an imminent eruption. 

The people of Montserrat, who have in the past complained of being a forgotten colony, are heartened by the British response. ``It's times like these when I'm glad we're not independent,'' said Midge Kocen, a volunteer manning a public hotline at Plymouth's emergency operations centre.

14 August 1995, p.12

The woman who looks into Hell's mouth / Features 

Mind and Matter

Hugh Aldersey-Williams



Hugh Aldersey-Williams on a scientist who travels the world seeking out the secrets of volcanoes 

Should British tourists interrupt their holidays on the Caribbean island of Montserrat because the 3000ft volcano, Chances Peak, has been spewing ash and sulphurous gases? Last week scientists were predicting a huge eruption, and advising people to leave, now they are not so sure. Every year about 50 volcanoes round the world will erupt. Dr Hazel Rymer of the Open University's Department of Earth Sciences, keeps a close watch on about a dozen volcanoes in five countries Nicaragua, Mexico, Iceland, Costa Rica and Italy. 

Some of these sites, such as Masaya, near Managua in Nicaragua, and Popocatepetl, near Mexico City, threaten large populations. All of them vary greatly both in how often and how violently they might erupt. Askja in Iceland, for example, last erupted in 1961. But its most violent event was in 1875, when a massive explosion formed a huge lake, five kilometres across and one kilometre deep. 

Broadly speaking there are three types of volcano, explains Dr Rymer. There are those where the Earth's plates are moving apart from each other. These tend to be cracks in the ground, rather than the familiar conical mountains, through which ``fire fountains'' spurt. The second type is formed where two of the Earth's plates crash into one another. These are larger, usually conical volcanoes, with very rugged sides because they erupt explosively. Thirdly, there are the volcanoes which appear in the middle of a plate, from a hot spot deep inside the Earth's mantle that bubbles up and burns through the plate. 

There are 40 volcano observatories around the world, where scientists are monitoring geophysical activity as it happens rather than just studying rock samples that tell you about past events. Dr Rymer, 34, holds a Royal Society research fellowship which funds her fieldwork. 

There are many ways of monitoring volcanic activity ranging from the measurement of ground deformation, seismic vibration, thermal imaging, analysis of gases seeping up through the soil of a volcano, to satellite-based radar. Dr Rymer prefers to detect and measure the tiny changes in gravity at ground level which can indicate dramatic changes in mass and density of material underground. 

Poas, in Costa Rica, is a volcano that she has been monitoring for more than ten years. At its summit lay a hellish lake of warm, concentrated sulphuric acid which suddenly evaporated in the late 1980s a clear sign that something was afoot. Her measurements then produced the first unambiguous prediction of an eruption by the microgravity technique. 

Each survey takes her anything between one day and a week, so that she does not have to leave her husband, a mechanical engineer, and two little boys Ben and Sam, for too long. ``I did take Ben up Mount Etna in a Land Rover when he was only six weeks,'' she says. The microgravity technique was developed originally for the oil industry in order to detect underground salt domes that might indicate the presence of oil. ``The instruments are over-designed for that job. You can in fact detect far smaller changes,'' explains Dr Rymer. It is possible to track geophysical events, such as the rise of magma pressure with a ``feeder pipe'' of rock, several kilometres inside a volcano, providing a good indication of the working of a volcano's plumbing system. ``You would expect a volcano to inflate before an eruption, but we have found cases where a change of gravity is the only indication of a coming eruption,'' says Dr Rymer in support of the gravity measurement techniques. 

In practice, the range of tools is what counts. ``The more techniques you have, the more you can refine your models,'' says Dr Rymer. For example, one would normally expect a simple correlation between gravity and elevation: the gravitational pull falls as you move further from the centre of the Earth. But the pre-eruption swelling of a volcano the upward deformation or inflation measured by one type of instrument is often accompanied not by a fall but an increase in gravity as measured by Dr Rymer's microgravity devices. This is because dense magma has flowed into the volcano's core. In other volcanoes, it is not magma but the build-up of gas pressure, and a decrease in density, that presages an eruption. 

On Mount Etna microgravity measurements show that networks of fissures within the volcano can remain open between eruptions. The result is that pressure does not necessarily build up when magma flows in, so staving off eruption. Microgravity monitoring was the only practical way to discover this because the magma fills the fissures without producing significant deformation or seismic activity. 

``There is less worry now about prediction,'' says Dr Rymer. ``Volcanologists know. Pinatubo (in the Philippines) was predicted and thousands of lives were saved.'' She believes the fact that there was a US Air Force base in the vicinity of Mount Pinatubo was instrumental in ensuring that locals were evacuated. By contrast, a relatively minor eruption in Colombia in 1985 resulted in the loss of 22,000 lives. 

Dr Rymer herself was seriously burnt on a trip to Costa Rica in 1986. ``I was in a region of rainforest where boiling mudpools bubble at the base of the volcanoes,'' she recalls. ``I just happened to step on to an area covered with leaves which looked just like rainforest floor. My leg slipped through into the boiling mud.'' She suffered first-degree burns and she had to spend a week in hospital. 

But it did not put her off her work. In particular she loves the spectacular lava flows. ``You can get really close to lava, because it flows past in its own channel. It looks like a steaming red river with black patches where the rock is beginning to cool. Some lava flows are thicker than others, and move really slowly, like caterpillar tracks. But the most incredible thing is the sound it makes like lots of tin cans being kicked around. The last thing you would expect.''

26 June 1995 p.15

Early warning / Features 

Science Briefing; Mind And Matter

Nigel Hawkes



The Alban Hills near Frascati, a few miles south-east of Rome, are showing signs of life. Dormant for 20,000 years, the volcanoes in the area are steadily pushing up the ground ``like a sponge-cake'' says the Italian National Institute of Geophysics. 

The area has risen by 18 ins this century, but two thirds of this has occurred in the past 15 years. Though declaring there is no immediate danger of an eruption, the institute is watching closely, for the area is large and densely-populated. 

Satellites can now be used to study these tiny movements. In Nature, three French space scientists have reported observations of Mount Etna using the ERS-1 satellite, over a period between May 1992 and October 1993 when the volcano was erupting. 

They used radar images, combining them by using the technique of interferometry, to measure the amount by which Etna had subsided. They found that the volcano was collapsing like a souffle, at a rate corresponding to a volume change of 34 million cubic metres per month. This was greater than the actual production of lava, which was 19 million cubic metres a month. 

The beauty of the system, according to Dr Didier Massonnet, of the National Centre of Space Studies in Toulouse, and his colleagues, is that the radar signals penetrate even lush vegetation, allowing active volcanoes in tropical areas to be studied. By watching the volcanoes swell, they hope to give advance warnings.

04 June 1995, p.5/4

Fire & Water / Features 

Stromboli; Travel

Anthony Sattin



ANTHONY SATTIN feels the burn on the sulphurous slopes of Stromboli, while FRASER HARRISON whets his appetite for whale counting off the Isle of Mull. 

The best views of Stromboli were the first ones, from the neighbouring island of Panarea. Only from a distance did I see the volcano in all its threatening majesty, rising triangularly from the Tyrrhenian sea, chutes of volcanic dust creating a narrow shoreline, above it a towering apex blown apart with magnificent force. At the end of the day, the alchemy of slanting sun and accumulated heat produced a shimmering haze that made the island appear less defined, a shadow of itself, a ghostly apparition more appropriate, I thought, for a place of such legend. 

In 1948 Roberto Rossellini, the Italian film director, wrote: ``Very probably, you do not know the Lipari islands,'' and he was right. ``One of them, the Stromboli, is continually active. At the foot of the volcano, in a bay, springs up the little village. A few white houses, cracked by the earthquake. The inhabitants make a living out of fishing and the little they can pluck from the barren land.'' Rossellini explained elsewhere in his letter to Ingrid Bergman that he wanted her and the islanders to appear in a neo-realistic movie. They did, and before long a cocktail was named after the volcano and Stromboli was more famous as a place of illicit passion than for natural eruptions. 

Late in the afternoon, the heat less intense and a hint of a breeze coming off the sea below, a group of people were gathering outside a cafe in Stromboli's main and, by most definitions, only square. They didn't all know each other and I knew none of them, but as they were checking their torches and wrapping their panini, it was obvious that we had all come for the same thing: to climb the volcano. 

I had wanted to climb the 3,038ft to the top of Stromboli without a guide, and I could have done it. Going up is not the problem. It is coming down the dust chute that causes the pain. Alone, I would have had to come down in daylight, which would mean missing the spectacular eruptions after dark, or staying up until morning. Officially it is forbidden to stay overnight: people tend to fall asleep up there and, dreaming of primeval urges, Roman gods at their forges or whatever else takes their fancy, they roll over the rim and into the crater where they are consumed by the burning heart of the volcano, the latest offering in some age-old rite. Enough said, no? 

So there I was, following Nino, the tall Club Alpine Italiano guide, out of the village at the start of a three-and-a-half hour climb, while Prospero, his colleague, brought up the rear to help the stragglers. There were more than 40 of us, the oldest a pensioner, the youngest pre-pubescent, and the numbers, as well as variable levels of fitness, made the going slow. But that allowed me plenty of time to admire the views. 

Stromboli has never done a Vesuvius and wiped out the communities living in its shadow, though a period of serious activity earlier this century persuaded the majority of islanders to pack their bags and head for the United States. Those who stayed found that America Hollywood to be precise came to them after Rossellini got the money and the star to make his film about people whom, he thought, ``live so simply and poorly just because of that knowledge of the vanity of everything we consider civilised and necessary''. Ingrid Bergman and the inhabitants of Stromboli made a potent combination, but in the event, headlines around the world were reserved, not for the movie, but for the love between the star and the director which itself was pretty volcanic. There are love affairs and love affairs. This one was serious. It was also 1949, they were both married. Bergman had a daughter back home in Hollywood and, to add fuel to the fire, she was pregnant again by the time they left. 

Stromboli's inhabitants still fish and farm as they did before the movie, but other things on the island have changed. Now there are bidets, showers and lavatories first imported because Rossellini believed they were mandatory for stars and there are also curious strangers, who come to see the place, the people and the volcano still Europe's most active. ``And the volcano ... the volcano!'' Bergman complained, ``... we slogged for four hours upwards. After I climbed for two hours, I just sat down, gasped and said: `I'm sorry, I can't make it.' But after a rest I did make it, and at the top I could have just lain down and died.'' Until somebody spoils the fun and builds a cable car up the side, the only way of getting on top of Stromboli is by following in Ms Bergman's footsteps, and there were some in the group who would have empathised with the star. 

Stockholm Peter, for example: wheezing and sweating as he peered up at the towering volcano from the Observatory cafe, 45 minutes out of town, he said: ``Just think. We're going all the way up there because of a Swede.'' Spurred on by nationalistic pride, a sense of romance or, like Ingrid Bergman, a sheer adulterous love, Peter's partner picked up her bag and continued slogging her way up the slope. 

By eight o'clock, three quarters of an hour further up, the sun was low, the village shrinking below us, the sea like frosted glass. It was then that the volcano began to growl like a monster out of One Million Years BC, and the talking around me stopped abruptly. 

Two hours later, through the sulphurous darkness, we made out the first of the groups that had got there ahead of us to be sure of a place in one of the shelters piles of volcanic rock that were to be their hotels for the night. A father and his two young sons were sitting in one of them, American students in another, European backpackers in a third. They and many more looked at us with the sharp eye of rivalry, and then ``You're not staying the night? Oh ... well ...'' with disdain. Nino stopped to warn them about past fatalities and came away muttering about the ``Valkyrie brigade''. 

I have never seen anything like the spectacle that greeted me at the top. The volcano acted impeccably, like something out of a geographer's dream, hissing and fizzing, sending up fireworks and, when I least expected it, exploding with a shuddering roar. I understood why Romans believed that Vulcan, Jupiter's son, had his workshop there, why others believed it was the mouth of Hell, and why Jules Verne had his travellers exit this way at the end of their Journey To The Centre Of The Earth. 

The others seemed less engaged, or else completely overawed. Nino and Prospero arranged them in a row along the rim of the summit where they unwrapped their sandwiches, opened their water and, as if this were a tea in the Sahara or a snack back home, they tucked into a late Stromboli supper, gawping at the red-hot lava fires down below. Supper over, they put on warmer clothing and took photographs to prove they had been there. Then conversations turned to hotels, beaches, sex or what ever else was next on the itinerary. 

In his introductory letter to Ingrid Bergman, Rossellini explained that he wanted his heroine to discover ``the value of the eternal truth which rules human lives'' on Stromboli. A less romantic eternal truth that tiredness dulls enthusiasm was being discovered by my fellow climbers and few gave the spectacle a second look as we began our descent. 

But Stromboli isn't some second-rate sideshow. It is a constantly active volcano, and just as we turned our backs it exploded. Deafened, silenced, shaking, we came to a halt as the earth moved around us. Lava and incandescent lapilli shot across the warm night like falling stars, making my heart race, my thoughts, too, and I felt, as Rossellini had wanted his characters to feel, as he and Ingrid Bergman and so many other must have felt an eruption of happiness at being alive in this place. 

Anthony Sattin travelled as a guest of Abercrombie & Kent 

TRAVEL BRIEF 

Getting there: the best approach to Stromboli is to fly to Catania, take the airport bus to Milazzo, then hydrofoil, for which you purchase the tickets (about Pounds 5) locally. Alternatives include flying to Messina and taking a hydrofoil, or getting an overnight ferry from Naples. Carriers offering flights include Alitalia (0171-602 7111) and British Airways (0181-897 4000). Prices from Pounds 327 for midweek travel to Catania. 

Tour operators: Abercrombie & Kent (0171-730 9600) has a week on Stromboli, based on two sharing, from Pounds 681pp in June and July, including transfers and b&b accommodation. Other operators include Citalia (0181-688 9989), Italiatour (0171-371 1114) and Italian Escapades (0181-748 2661). 

Further information: guides authorised by the Club Alpine Italiano make the ascent of Stromboli every day from April to October. For information, tel: 00 39 90-98 62 63. 


06 November 1994 p.5/4

The Indian Ocean / Features 

Island Guide, Week 2; Travel

David Wickers on Seychelles and the Mascarenes and Mark Ottaway

REUNION 

CAN THIS be an Indian Ocean island? With its cloud-wrapped peaks, traffic jams, out-of-town supermarkets and lack of tropical nasties and diseases? Not really. In almost every sense save its geography this is Europe. Welcome to a departement of France, M'sieur, and a totally artificial economy supported by imports and the European taxpayer. 

Waltz through the same passport control as the locals. No need for Brits to fill in forms or audition at immigration. 

All of which might not sound worth going halfway round the world for. But don't let that put you off. If you are a surfer, a mountaineer, or already in the region, Reunion is well worth a visit. 

The island soars to 10,000ft within 13 miles of the ocean, a jagged uneroded landscape the result of relatively recent, indeed in parts continuing, volcanic activity. This is a Hawaiian (as opposed to Strombolian) volcano. Not on a fault line. Not prone to explosive eruption. On average about once a year it starts delivering glowing lava in predictable flows. But once in a geological while, the peaks empty and collapse under the weight of extruded lava to create ``circuses'', almost lost worlds with sheer 3,000ft cliffs all around. Reunion has three, one of which, the Cirque de Mafate, still cannot be reached by road. Here, just 10 miles as the hawk flies from a bustling French provincial capital is a deeply endogamous society, some of whose more elderly members have never left the valley or seen a car. 

Hikers and rock climbers return from a week or more in these mountains with rave reports. There are rainforests, volcanic wastes, dazzling air and 350 micro-climates.

Sun and sequins / Features 

Caribbean Cruising; Travel

Ann Steele

Visiting the world's only ``drive-in'' volcano on St Lucia was an eerie experience. I reached it after a six-hour sea safari around the coast of the island (discovered by Columbus on his fourth voyage in 1502). Tourists can no longer walk freely around the bubbling sulphur springs since a guide slipped in and was badly burnt some years ago. Nearby, local women wash clothes in a hot stream. 

To escape the heat, I cooled off in the rich mineral waters of the Diamond Bath, just outside the town of Soufriere, in one of the most beautiful gardens in the Caribbean. It was built 200 years ago by Napoleon's troops to soothe their weary bodies; today it costs tired tourists $6 (about Pounds 3.50) to bathe there. 

Saint-Pierre was the economic and cultural capital of Martinique until 1902 when it was destroyed by the eruption of Mount Pelee. I'll never forget the twisted molten church bell or the ordinary household items such as a sewing machine and an iron at the Museum of Volcanology. The whole town of 30,000 was killed by molten lava except for one man, a prisoner in an underground cell. He survived terrible burns only to wind up as an exhibit touring the world in Barnum's circus. 


Happy memories linger long in the Caribbean. 

Ann Steele 

Ann Steele was a guest of Cunard Lines (071-491 3930). A two-week Caribbean cruise on the Cunard Countess costs from Pounds 1,395, including return flights, and takes in 11 islands. A one-week cruise (from Pounds 895) includes six or seven islands. Christmas and New Year cruises start from Pounds 1,595.

27 July 1994, p.15

Big bang history / Leading articles 


What better explanation than a great big disaster? 

Catastrophe is suddenly back on the cast-list as an explanation of the past. Reputable scientists now dare suggest that some cosmic collision finished off classical civilisation and brought on the Dark Ages in Europe. 

Those infallible clocks that are buried in rocks and tree-rings record a world disaster around AD 534, followed by a sudden slowing of tree growth in America and Europe lasting for about 15 years. Fallible human chronicles for the same date record that the Sun became dim for years. 

From China to Britain accounts survive of famine, pestilence, wars, crop failures and urban and economic decline. In parts of China the population suddenly decreased by 80 per cent; and in AD 534 the Chinese emperor ordered the half a million inhabitants to evacuate his imperial capital of Loyang for no recorded reason. In Constantinople the plague arrived and started the dwindling that was to reduce the population of the Byzantine imperial capital from 500,000 to 25,000. 

The evidence from both carbon-dating and chronicles points to massive pollution of the atmosphere and a kind of nuclear winter. No other natural disaster on record spread its ripples right round the world in this way. A conventional interpretation of such evidence would be to postulate some vast volcanic eruption, like the one on Thera (Santorini) around 1,500 BC, which has been blamed for everything from the widespread legends of floods to the parting of the Red Sea for the Israelites and the sudden destruction of the Minoan civilisation. But Thera left its unmistakable signature on the ice cores dug from miles down in the Greenland ice-cap, which plot the volcanic history of the planet for the past 9,000 years. These record no volcanic eruption in the 530s. 

Some scientists now advance the theory that the worldwide cataclysm of 534 was caused by the impact of a giant meteor or fragments of a comet, like the pieces of Shoemaker Levy-9 that collided with Jupiter a week ago. Although they have yet to identify a plausible footprint for such an earth-shaking crash, it could be under water or have been mistaken for the crater of a volcano. 

As an explanation for history or geology, catastrophe used to belong to the dark ages of superstition. For the past two centuries evolution has increasingly been seen as a uniform process in which everyday forces have shaped the Earth and the history of its inhabitants. Then it became scientifically respectable to speculate that dinosaurs were extinguished by some cosmic catastrophe. Now it turns out that the Dark Ages for humans may have been caused by some such collision with a comet. Next? 

*
24 July 1994 p.1/22

Scientists link rising temperatures to worldwide loss of human cool / Home news 

Sean Ryan and Lois Rogers



THE heatwaves sweeping much of the northern hemisphere have intensified scientific debate about possible changes in climate and humans' tendency to respond with a startling degree of eccentricity. 

Exceptional summer weather has been reported in the United States, Europe and Asia, and global temperatures around 0.3C higher than the 1950-1980 average are likely to make 1994 one of the world's hottest years on record. 

The heat has been blamed for an international outbreak of irrationality, attributed by doctors to an increase in blood volume that starves brains of their normal levels of oxygen. 

Stefan Effenberg, a German soccer star sent home in disgrace from the World Cup for making obscene gestures at his own supporters, claimed he had been driven to it by the extreme heat in Dallas. In Copenhagen, a conference of semi-professional Santas ended when delegates stripped to their boxer shorts and red woolly caps and dived into the municipal fountains. 

Scientists believe this year's warm weather, in which July temperatures are up to 4C hotter than normal in England, has been accentuated by the disappearance from the stratosphere of millions of tonnes of debris flung there by Mount Pinatubo, a volcano in the Philippines, in 1991. 

Bill McGuire, professor of vulcanology at University College, London, said the eruption had produced a global cooling of 0.4C which appeared to have gone into reverse. ``Over the last two years, Pinatubo may have depressed a tendency towards warming which is now coming through again.'' 

Sir John Houghton, a former director-general of the Met Office and now co-chairman of a group of experts advising the United Nations on climate, said temperatures appeared to be rising faster over land than sea. ``We cannot definitely say we are seeing global warming but this is consistent with it,'' he said.

11 April 1994, p.19

The Eruption Of Vesuvius / Features 

11 April 1906; On This Day



The first recorded eruption of Vesuvius was in 79AD when Pompeii was overwhelmed. Since then, numerous eruptions have occurred, many with disastrous results. The one reported here destroyed the town of Ottajano. 

THE ERUPTION OF VESUVIUS. DISTRESSING SCENES. (FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT.) NAPLES, APRIL 10. 

Last night was a quiet one in Naples. On Sunday night there was a notable diminution in the activity of the volcano, which is now still further decreasing. The intermittent explosions and continuous rumble below are only to be heard at comparatively close quarters; the change of wind carries the dense cloud of ashes out to sea, stretching a thick veil between Naples itself and the coast line of Castellammare and Sorrento; and, what is more important, the slow course of the lava streams is stayed at Torre Annunziata and Torre del Greco, though there was still a discernible movement this morning in the stream which branched off near Torre Annunziata towards Pompeii. Professor Mattucci, who has regained his post of observation, reports a decided amelioration in the symptoms and has expressed his belief that the worst is over. 

Naples has to-day resumed its normal life, though very far from its normal aspect. Though the ashes have ceased for the moment to fall on the town, they lie inches deep in all 

the streets, rising in clouds of fine impalpable dust and thickly coating both houses and wayfarers. It appears a grey city inhabited by grey ghosts, which is at least an improvement upon Saturday and Sunday nights, when the threatening thunder of the volcano, a thick pall of darkness torn by distant flashes of volcanic explosions, and a suffocating atmosphere made it resemble an ante-chamber of hell. The Neapolitans, too, have taken courage again, and the pitiful little processions bearing a holy image or picture, sometimes composed of only a dozen or so of half-distraught peasant women, have now deserted the streets, though even last night they were still to be seen here and there. If the appearance of Naples is still forlorn enough, that of the threatened towns is most wretched. Torre Annunziata seems utterly abandoned save by a few carabinieri and troops, who mount guard in its empty streets. Torre del Greco is in little better ease. Resina and Portici suffered less in the general panic, but were deserted temporarily by a good many of the inhabitants, who are now returning to their homes. Bosco-Trecase is destroyed. The villages on the north-east of VesuviusOttajano, San Giuseppe, and TerzignoI have not yet been able to see, but from all reports their condition is sufficiently deplorable. 

From San Giuseppe is reported the only serious loss of life. The roof of the old church, long known to be unsafe, succumbed, it is supposed, to the added weight of ashes and volcanic debris and fell in, burying in its ruins a great number of women and old people who were gathered in prayer to avert the destruction of their town. According to the last accounts, 37 dead bodies have been extricated, besides a number of injured. A report of a similar disaster at Terzigno is now denied, though that town also has suffered severely from the hail of redhot stones and debris ...

10 February 1994, p.11

Vesuvius threatens a million / Overseas news 

Nigel Hawkes



AN ERUPTION of Vesuvius could engulf a million people within 15 minutes, causing disaster on an unprecedented scale, three scientists have calculated. 

An area four miles in radius around the summit of the volcano would be wiped out at horrifying speed. They call for effective evacuation plans, new roads, and the depopulation of the area to diminish the risks. Better methods of forecasting eruptions are also needed. 

Vesuvius, dormant since 1944, overlooks Naples. In AD 79 the towns of Pompeii and Herculaneum were destroyed by an eruption. 

Writing in Nature, Dr Flavio Dobran of New York University and Italian colleagues used data from past eruptions to create a computer model. Vesuvius has long been silent but no volcano is ever extinct, he contends.

17 January 1994, p.12

Raining cats and Filipinos / Features 

Peter Barnard



If you were wondering what has happened to the weather, look to the Pacific, says Peter Barnard. 

With Chichester gone Venetian and bits sliding off the Isle of Wight, yesterday's weather was a positive relief for most of us: gales, sleet and snow make a change from emptying water out of the ceiling light fittings. 

But even this pick'n'mix of misery has failed to flush out the superstars who dominated the weather charts a mere two years ago, the meteorological Madonnas who toured the globe with arms raised towards the heavens. 

We followed their upward gaze transfixed and saw ... the ozone layer. Or rather, we didn't, for even in the best of times the ozone layer, being made of gas, has proved less than photogenic. 

The Met men, nonetheless, wanted us to know that in places the ozone layer wasn't there at all. We had blown a hole in it with our underarm deodorants and our fancy cars. And then there was global warming, a related disaster, as a result of which the Earth would warm up and it would rain more often. More often? It hardly seems possible. 

Oddly, the doom merchants have been silent through the wettest December since goodness knows when. Even as we welly our way through January, climatologists (halfway decent universities have a couple, self-respecting ones have a whole department) refuse to strut their stuff on the stage of Armageddon. 

The reason is the truth. And the truth of this sloshing winter is that it is all got up by foreigners. Filipinos, if you must. What we are wading through is a meteorological Peking flu. The English weather, per se, is not at fault. 

In June of 1991, Mount Pinatubo in the Philippines erupted, and then some. It was a spectacular human tragedy and as such it was famous for 15 minutes. 

However, 30 months on, Pinatubo has come back to haunt the rest of the world. The result is running into your drains: or even worse, not running into your drains. 

Phil Jones, of the University of East Anglia's climatic research centre, was a lead runner in the global warming stakes, which reached its peak in 1990. The work of Mr Jones and, in particular, Sir Crispin Tickell, formerly our man at the UN, is credited with the greening of Margaret Thatcher. 

Jones and Co are sticking to their guns but ozone depletion and global warming are long-term phenomena, whereas a winter of discontent is but a passing frisson. 

Mr Jones explains: ``There has been a lot of press comment in America asking whatever happened to global warming? But the wet weather here and the excessively dry conditions in parts of California and Australia have nothing to do with that. 

``Pinatubo is the culprit. The dust rises in to the upper atmosphere and the effect is a warming one. And the Earth's radiation balance changes, which, as temperatures start to cool back, leads to extremes of weather. The normal airstream flow around the globe is west-east but in conditions like these you get more of a north-south flow and that obviously influences weather patterns.'' 

Even before the eruption, warming was evident, with 1990 and 1991 being the warmest pair of years ever recorded: compared with the average for the period 1950-79, global temperatures in those years were 0.4 and 0.35 centigrade above average respectively. 

But part of the effect of the eruption at Pinatubo is shown by the statistics for 1992 and 1993, when the average was exceeded by 0.19 and 0.27 centigrade. Now temperatures are cooling again. 

This tends to make for a confusion of signals between volcanic eruptions and global warming, which reinforces the split in scientific circles about the extent of the warming process. Forecasts in the late Eighties had the polar ice caps melting and flowing down the streets of Norwich; subsequent estimates say that for that to happen temperatures would have to rise far higher than even the most alarmist predictions. 

There is even a view, supported by research at Edinburgh University, that global warming could cause ice caps to get thicker rather than thinner, thus reducing sea levels rather than increasing them. 

The reason is that higher temperatures at the poles would increase snowfall and lead to more ice, not less. This theory is attractive to mere mortals because it encourages more complacency, not less. 

For the time being, we can wallow in the twin British satisfactions of bemoaning the weather and blaming foreigners, even if the foreigners in question can hardly help it. Indeed, they may well regard wading through Chichester as an easier option than living under a volcano. 

As for the chances of scorching summer to compensate for present horrors, nobody is willing to put a wet shirt on it. As with politics, a week in meteorology is a long time. June is a light year away. 

There is, however, a small portion of recent history smiling on people who prefer Factor 25 to a mackintosh. Indeed the real message of the Great Wet Out may be good tidings for all but the water boards and those who obsessively hose their plants every time the sun puts in an appearance. 

The present downpour roughly follows the pattern of the mid-1970s and mid-1980s. Those spells were followed by a brief drought in 1975-76 and a much longer one between 1988-92. In fact Mr Jones says that prolonged droughts in Britain tend to outlast prolonged wet spells. Better check the standpipes haven't sunk without trace. 

*
15 June 1995, SP/p.7

The Times Red Cross appeal / Features 

By Ruth Gledhill
Kibumba camp, with 200,000 refugees, squats at the foot of the Nyaragongo volcano, which last erupted in 1987, and which sometimes glows an apocalyptic red in the night, its burning rocks reflecting a hellish halo onto the clouds above, its lava rising at the rate of ten metres a month. 20 October 1994, p.9

5ft worms found on deep-sea volcano / Home news 

Riftia pachyptila

By Nigel Hawkes

GIANT 5ft tubeworms have been found at the bottom of the Pacific around the vents of submarine volcanoes. 

The worms, Riftia pachyptila, were found 8,000ft down in the east Pacific by the submersible Alvin. Although the deep oceans are thought of as inhospitable, three visits to the spot showed that the tubeworms flourish there. 

On the first visit, in April 1991, a subsea volcano had recently erupted and fresh lava could be seen. In March 1992, the area was visited again and, although it showed some signs of life, there were no giant tubeworms. 

When the submersible returned 18 months later, American and French scientists report in Nature, large numbers of the tubeworms were found. This means, they say, that they must have been growing at almost 3ft a year, the fastest growth rate recorded for a marine invertebrate. 

The team, led by Dr Richard Lutz of Rutgers University in New Jersey, says that since the deep-sea volcanoes were discovered in 1977 there has been growing evidence that creatures may grow very rapidly in the nutrient-rich waters created by the volcanic eruptions. 

*

23 July 1994 WE/p.21

`A hard day's work beside my blue lagoon' / Features 

Travel

Richard Morrison



HAWAII: The attentions of a bronzed young maiden help Richard Morrison to forget his sunburn. 

Put aside those images of Honolulu as ``Highrise-on-Surf'', the Miami of the Pacific, swarming with low life and high prices. Yes, Honolulu is as garish as you imagined, and then some. But the Hawaiian archipelago consists of 132 islands, trailing westward across the north Pacific towards Japan. And paradise still prevails in 131 of them. 

The air is sparkling clean, there being no heavy industry within 2,000 miles. The ocean is as warm as a bath and so clear that, when you snorkel, the fish glint beneath your nose like peripatetic Smarties. In the winter months, migrating humpback whales frolic harmlessly just off the beaches, leaping and spouting for the visitors' delight, looking for all the world as if they had been booked by Lew Grade for the season. 

And waves? Well, they don't come any bigger, if big is what you want. The island of Maui boasts the world's greatest surf, and the whole surf culture with its charming, laid-back, dropped-out, tuned-in, turned-on devotees is as big in some resorts here as in Sydney. 

But these hyper-active beaches are easily avoided by those of the more seden tary persuasion. Being something of a small-wave connoisseur myself, I preferred to drift motionless in the palm-fringed, white-sanded blue lagoons. And although these hotel-run lagoons don't have Brooke Shields on hand, they do have deeply-bronzed young men and maidens who set up your sun umbrella, bring you cooling drinks, and offer to massage sunblock into your peeling shoulders. 

Deeply bronzed young maiden: Aloha, sir! May I carry your deckchair? 

Me (embarrassed): Oh, please don't bother, it's not heavy. 

DBYM: No sirree. You're on holiday. You mustn't do anything. 

Me (sweating): No, actually I'm working. (Giggle of non-comprehension from DBYM.) I'm a journalist writing about Hawaii. 

DBYM: Oh my goodness, your back is so red! Here, let me rub sunblock into it. I have gentle fingers. 

Me (sweating more profusely): No, please, I am English. 

DBYM (sweetly): Well then, you just think of England while I do it. 

And so it went on. One has to take the rough with the smooth in this job. 

Perhaps you suspect that I never left my blue lagoon. Untrue. The Hawaiian islands there are eight main ones are so spectacular that you would have to be a particularly obtuse type of vegetable not to explore. The best way is by helicopter, for which you must pay handsomely, perhaps Pounds 80 for an hour's trip. It's worth it. 

On the Big Island trip (Hawaii itself) you go straight over Kilauea, the world's most active volcano. Most of the helicopter pilots tell you that they learnt their flying in 'Nam, and appear not to have lost the taste for danger. They hover a few feet over the volcano craters so that you can savour the heat of the 2,000F molten orange lava. You will never complain about the office air-conditioning again. 

Then they take you down to the coast where that same lava hits the sea, producing huge clouds of steam and then solidifying into the black, lunar landscape that dominates this island. Amazingly, the immaculate Ritz Carlton Hotel at Mauni Lani, on the east coast, has been built on this solidified lava, though you would never think it when you look out of your bedroom window and see the acres of lush, green championship golf course surrounding you. 

The other helicopter trip, on the island of Maui, was equally spectacular. No active volcanos here, but there are plunging valleys and waterfalls. And extraordinary changes of vegetation. Although the leeward coasts get so little rain that you can virtually guarantee 14 baking hours of sun any day of the year, the interiors get more rain than Manchester. Indeed, from the air the rain forests are so dense that the treetops seem like a spectacularly woven Wilton carpet. ``Spielberg filmed Jurassic Park here,'' yelled my helicopter pilot, as we flew up a giant waterfall that seemed to flow from the clouds. 

This balmy climate, allied to the fertile lava-rich soil, is also what gives Hawaii its glorious horticulture. On the island of Lanai I stayed at the Manele Bay Hotel, where the rooms are built, Renaissance-style, round courtyards with sumptuous gardens, and the corridors are stacked with Hawaiian, Chinese and Polynesian art. The same hotel also runs a Lodge up in the hills at Koele: an extraordinary mansion, rather like an eccentric Oxbridge college, with a vast central hall stuffed full of astonishing artefacts. 

Another surprise was Hawaiian cooking. Even in the big hotels, bold local cuisine is operated in parallel with the standard international fare and it is delicious, full of startling new fish and vegetable tastes. But the renaissance in Hawaiian cuisine is just one aspect of the revival of native Hawaiian culture. You don't even have to leave the hotels to realise that. The Ritz Carlton at Kapalua (on Maui) incorporates an ancient burial ground into its grounds; indeed, the sacred place was discovered during excavations for the hotel, and the hotel site was moved elsewhere out of respect for native sensibilities. And on Big Island dozens of ancient fishponds and caves inhabited by the first Hawaiians when they made their intrepid crossings from the Polynesian Islands six centuries ago have been restored. 

Even we heritage-obsessed British can be impressed by the diligence with which Hawaiian history is being preserved. A guided tour can be an illuminating step back into an ancient culture and that history, of course, includes the Hawaiian version of how Captain Cook met his violent end in these islands. To cut a grisly story short, the Hawaiians say he deserved it for behaving like a bloody idiot. 

To this English traveller, however, the Hawaiians were generosity personified. The ``Aloha'' spirit means a lot more than pretty girls garlanding you in airport lounges with a fragrant lei, though I didn't strenuously object to that. The tranquillity of these islands is infectious. I dream of my blue lagoons still, but the sunburn is a bit better now, thanks. 

How to get there 

Richard Morrison was a guest of United Airlines (081-990 9988) and of Elegant Resorts, 24 Nicholas Street, Chester CH1 1ER (0244 325620). 

Price for ten nights: from Pounds 1,995 per person, including an overnight stop at the Ritz Carlton, San Francisco, three nights at the Ritz Carlton, Kapalua (Maui), three nights at the Manele Bay (Lanai) and three nights at the Ritz Carlton, Mauna Lani (Hawaii). Price for seven nights: from Pounds 1,370 per person at the Ritz Carlton Mauna Lani, including a night at the Ritz Carlton, San Francisco. Both prices include return economy class flights with United Airlines, inter-island flights with Aloha Airlines, and all private transfers. 

For further details, contact Elegant Resorts.

03 April 1994, p.8/45

Over the volcanoes / Features 

Hawaii's Big Island; Travel

Jan McGirk


Jan McGirk takes to the summit trails as she treks across Hawaii's Big Island in search of volcanic activity. 

Rich coffee steamed in our breakfast mugs, but we couldn't linger over it. To see the plumes of steam and sulphur hissing up from the lava bed, we had to hit Volcanoes National Park before full sun-up. 

This was, after all, the very reason we had come to the Big Island, the easternmost in Hawaii's chain of eight. We wanted to watch the earth seethe in an active caldera, where the lava is still molten just a foot or two beneath the crust. 

We took a path that was lined with giant tree ferns and petered out on to Steaming Bluff, a raised basin of brittle black stone. Fissures were fringed with delicately plaited, glittering strands of black and grey minerals. Chunks of pumice crunched underfoot and yellow-rimmed potholes at our feet puffed out putrid fumes. My sons pocketed a couple of pieces of loose lava as keepsakes of this eerie place. 

Back at the breakfast table, the landlady, Joan Morse, dished out papaya halves heaped high with pineapple and macadamia nuts. The conversation strayed to Madame Pele, the vengeful fire goddess said to sleep in the Kilauea Caldera. 

We had spied offerings to her, flower leis (garlands) and cigars left on the edge of the crater. A psychiatrist from San Francisco and a doll salesman from Brisbane debated whether the heiau a temple of human sacrifice erected by a Tahitian priest in the 12th century was meant to appease this female spirit. 

The latest lava flow had skirted around the old temple at Wahaula but destroyed the government visitor centre a mere 150yds away. While guidebooks were brandished and Jungian jargon spat out, Mrs Morse rolled her eyes. 

``Every day I get parcels in the post. People know that Pele gets riled easy, but lava makes a nice souvenir. Bad things start to happen as soon as they leave the island, so they send the stuff back. We try to figure out exactly where it came from, but Pele isn't real picky. Just wants it back here.'' 

Sheepishly, the guests eyed one another and each of us guiltily plunked down a lump of cursed lava beside our plates. 

``Without Pele, we wouldn't have much island left,'' Mrs Morse added. ``Best take those rocks along on your next hike and chuck 'em back where they belong.'' 

There are not many spots on Hawaii where lava would be out of place. Two hulking volcanoes, Mauna Loa and Mauna Kea, are over 13,000ft high and dominate the horizon, and rubble from cinder cones lines most roads. Where eruptions are recent, the land is starkly barren, but the rich volcanic soil becomes quickly overgrown. 

Plantations of coffee and macadamia nuts thrive in the highlands, and lush rainforest gardens grow orchids and anthuriums (those fake-looking red flowers with odd phallic stamens). Beach sand comes in startling shades of black or olive green as well as the more prosaic golden grains. Cowboys ride the ranges, while astronomers scan the clearest skies in America. 

The brutal landscape seems to summon heroic feats to match: the Ironman triathlon, a gruelling race which requires a 2.4-mile swim, a 112-mile bicycle ride, plus a 26.2-mile marathon, brings hundreds of athletes here every October. 

Offshore, game fishermen stalk monster marlin while daytrippers scan the water for whales. 

But paradise need not be pre-packaged on the Big Island. Fly over, rent a car and just poke around at your own pace, leaving the condominiums on the Kona coast to the honeymooners. 

There is a network of three dozen b&bs across the Big Island, and prices start at $40 per night. Mrs Morse runs a free reservation service from her own unpretentious establishment, ``My Island'' (0101 808-967 7216), and will even recommend rivals in the town of Volcano if her 100-year-old house is fully booked. For those who prefer more privacy, she also rents out three garden bungalows. 

The high-profile tourism of hula shows, helicopter tours and glass-bottomed boats does exist in Hawaii, but nowhere is more remote from all this than Waipio Valley on the northeastern shore. 

A precipitous path leads down to a perfect black sand beach, cut by a stream, which gives the warm rollers a cool backwash. Waterfalls cascade down a thousand feet from towering cliffs, and wild horses graze in the back black taro fields. Jeeps and mule carts take tourist groups on forays, but most ramblers and campers struggle down on foot. 

The 45-minute hike back up a 25-degree slope left us breathless, and not solely because of the view. We were glad to bed down at the Waipio Wayside Inn (0101 808-775 0275); a comfortable 1930s home with bathrooms stocked with lotions and potions to counteract sunburn and muscle strain. 

We did not leave the Big Island before searching out the last corner of Britain in the former Sandwich Isles. This is an obelisk in Kealakekua Bay, where the explorer, James Cook, returned three days after being received as a living god. Sailing in on a broken ship from an inauspicious direction, he was bludgeoned to death by terrified Hawaiians. 

Thankfully, the welcome is considerably more friendly these days. 

Getting there: There are no direct flights from the UK to Hawaii; most route through Los Angeles. Air New Zealand (081-741 2299) flies four times a week from Gatwick via Los Angeles where you can pick up connecting flights to Honolulu; midweek Apex fares from Pounds 638 return; Continental Airlines (0293-776464) flies from Gatwick to New York, Huston or Denver for a connecting flight to Honolulu the following day, American Airlines (081-572 5555) has daily flights to Los Angeles from Heathrow and daily connecting flights on to Honolulu. United Airlines (081-990 9900) flies daily from Heathrow to Honolulu via Los Angeles or San Francisco. Virgin (0293-747747) flies daily to Honolulu via Los Angeles. Midweek Apex fares start from Pounds 724.
