23 January 1994 p.8/48

Italian Islands / Features 

Ultimate guide; Part 2; Travel

David Wickers



Vulcano for mud baths, Pantelleria for celebs. In this last of a two part guide, David Wickers selects the best Italian islands for you. 

AEOLIAN ISLANDS 


Salina 

A twin-peaked island, with twin ports, the hydrofoils stopping at both on their way to and from Lipari. Salina is the greenest of the Aeolian islands, but neglected because of its more glamorous sisters. I'd recommend a visit rather than a stay, stepping ashore at Rinella and taking the bus up the valley, over the saddle bridging the volcanic mounds, past Salina's soccer pitch, which enjoys the only patch of flat land, and down to the port of Santa Marina di Salina on the opposite coast. 

The ride, past cultivated terraces of Malvasia vines, a sweet but heady wine, through the villages of Leni and Malfa, is delightful, made all the more fun by impromptu stops by the driver to pick up deliveries, walk the elderly to their front door, tickle children etc. If you want to stay, choose the 15-room Le Ariana (010 39 90-980 9075), an old patrician villa overlooking Rinella. 


Stromboli 

A living volcano, among the world's most active. At 10-minute intervals, a salvo of sparks and steam is propelled from the crater and molten lava flows down into the sea. It has to perform, otherwise it would explode. For obvious reasons, the main village is on the opposite side of the action. It is a fairly dishevelled community with mainly rooms to rent Stromboli attracts a lot of Swiss, Austrians and Germans in boots and backpacks, who come both to hike and enjoy the island's big black beach. 

To see the volcano at its best or worst you need either to climb to the crater, a five-hour tough roundhaul for which a guide is essential (two tourists fell off last year), or take a boat excursion to the raw side of the island (the price includes dinner at a second hamlet, Ginostra, just outside the line of fire). Both trips are more spectacular at night, which means an overnight stay, most agreeable at La Sciara (010 39 90-986004), which has a superb pool, gardens and some 60 rooms stuffed with family heirlooms and artworks. 

Vulcano 

Whereas Stromboli looks the part, with its perfect cone, clear smoke signals, fireworks and rumbles, Vulcano offers a more intimate contact with the dark forces. It is a most peculiar place, reeking of rotten eggs, steaming with vapours, bubbling with hot springs, streaked by weird colours and famous for its al fresco mud baths, where people sit up to their necks in slime, smear their faces like ghosts and then huddle like gnomes over steam vents in the rocks. Vulcano is also easier to climb around an hour to the summit. 

Apart from the feeling of landing on a geological time bomb, quietly simmering away waiting for the next big bang, Vulcano's general atmosphere is very exotic, almost Caribbean in a sultry sort of way. Most people come on day trips, swelling the 550 inhabitants to 16,000 in August, but it is worth a night or two at either of two hotels, the four-star Sables Noirs (010 39 90-985 2014) or more modest, lively Conti (010 39 90-985 2012), both on Potente Bay's attractive and sheltered black sand beach. The rest of the island, beyond the volcano's bulk, is fairly conventional and well forested, although everything man-made tends to the unsightly. 

Alicudi 

An island that looks just what it is, the summit of a volcano, straight up, flat top, and straight down again on the other side. A few houses cling to the gradients by their nails, others form a more concentrated community beside the small grey pebble beach where the fishermen park their boats. And that's about it. Divers get excited, but I can't think of anyone else who would, and there are much more attractive islands to lose yourself on. 



PANTELLERIA 

Pantelleria 

Italy's most westerly outpost, an unusual, moody, interesting island, is clearly on the map. Since Armani bought one of the distinctive domed-roofed, Arabian-style dammusi houses and Michelle Pfeiffer came to holiday, Pantelleria is fast becoming voguish. It is an island not of our time, very different from all others, with pleasures that are almost purely scenic. The beaches are few, dark and rocky, its main town a monster, bombed to rubble by the Americans and rebuilt without a care, and the tourist development, concentrated in the northeast corner, is painful on the eyes. 

From the air, Pantelleria looks like a gigantic green brain, the terraced hills parcelled by dark lava walls into hundreds of small plots of low-slung vines for Moscato wine and rambling capers. The style of cultivation, including curious structures like gun emplacements built to protect single orange trees, as well as the unique rural architecture and several place names, was established by the Arabs. Pantelleria's volcanic origins have put a stamp of pleasures everywhere: natural saunas in mountain caves, paths along the ridge of the vast caldera, views of Africa just 43 miles away from the pine-covered summit of Monte Grande, numerous birds on and around a crater lake called the Mirror of Venus, and there is bathing in Roman hot springs. Go on a round-the-island boat ride and the skipper will even cook octopus in a patch of boiling sea. 


USTICA 

A remote volcanic pimple, some 40 miles north of Sicily, with no siblings. All the way out in the hydrofoil you ask yourself, can it be worth the ride? The answer is a tub-thumping yes. Ustica comes right at the top of my class of 27 islands. 

Ustica's fretted coast doesn't have beaches, but does have everything else: scenery, cultivated and wild, clear water, grottoes (one Blue, one Green, one Golden, one Secret...) and a pretty town, part waterfront, part hilltop, centred on a piazza adorned with leafy trees and scores of beautifully painted murals. The carabinieri even allowed a seascape of seagulls and sailboats on the front of the nick. 

On top of all its tangible qualities, the islanders so obviously care about their island. Ustica's transformation from a penal colony, most recently for Fascist dissidents, to a place of gentle, sensitive tourism, has lots to do with Ercole Gargano, who grafted the spectacularly sited Grotta Azzurra (010 39 91-844 9048 or 9567), with its terraced gardens and splendid pool, on to a wall of rock, as well as defining the pattern of development, or non-development, for the rest of the island. The hotel is now owned by a Palermo consortium which is still finding its feet, but with its newly refurbished rooms it has potentially one of the best hotels in Italy. 

There is a wide choice of alternative accommodation, from simple country houses for rent to the Club Villaggio Punta Spalmatore (010 39 91-844 9388), a friendly, low-rise giant full of fun and the sporting life, though not for everyone. 

Ustica is unique in its commitment to conservation of both land and sea. The marine reserve, which forms a ring around the coast, in some places zoned to prohibit even swimming, was the first in Italy (there are now 22, but Ustica's is still way ahead). There are guided snorkelling trips, glass-hulled-boat rides, an underwater archeological trail, with ancient anchors and amphorae in situ, and an aquarium. As one reservist told me: ``There's no point in saving the whale unless we save everything else in its food chain.'' 

Getting there: by hydrofoil from Palermo. 

David Wickers travelled to the Italian islands as a guest of Abercrombie & Kent.

1996
Hotter-than-ever world adds to fear of climate change
Nick Nuttall, Environment Correspondent
Warning on greenhouse effect THE Earth last year was at its hottest since records began. Scientists at the Meteorological Office's Hadley Centre for Climate Prediction and Research said yesterday that, on average, the world's temperature is 1C higher than in 1860, when measurements were first properly recorded.
The United Nations team of climate scientists charged with advising governments about the myth or reality of global warming recently concluded that the world is in the grip of a greenhouse effect that is at least partly attributable to mankind's carbon emissions.
They said: "The balance of evidence suggests a discernible human influence on global climate through emissions of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases."
The official figures for 1995 confirm their fears that, by 2050, the world could be 2C hotter unless urgent action is taken. While this may not appear a huge increase, a permanent shift in global temperatures of this magnitude could have devastating effects on agriculture, wildlife and water supplies.
Dr Phil Jones of the University of East Anglia's Climate Research Unit in Norwich, which has helped the Meteorological Office to compile the figures, said yesterday: "The way to understand it is by comparison with last year's temperature in Britain. It was 10.5C or one degree above the average. A lot of people thought it was very hot last year. What might they think if years became two degrees higher, which is a lot warmer?"
Scientists still cannot say for certain how the world's climate will behave. The missing links are the levels of rainfall likely over different continents, and whether the Gulf Stream, which warms Britain, might shift south, causing cooling rather than heating.
Some research indicates that amounts of rainfall in northern latitudes will remain the same but will fall in sudden downpours, triggering landslips, contaminating rivers with run-off from the land and making it harder for water companies to collect enough to meet supplies.
The new figures show that, on average, surface temperature last year was 0.4C above the 1961-1990 average, which is the 30-year yardstick against which measurements are made. Previously, 1990 had been recorded as the warmest year, with temperatures climbing to an average 0.36C above the 30-year level.
Some parts of the world were, as predicted by computer climate models, significantly hotter than the average in 1995. In parts of Siberia, where scientists have been chronicling changes in plant life and a northward shift in the tree line consistent with global warming, temperatures were 3C higher than normal.
Ocean surface temperatures near the Azores were 1C above normal.
The gradual warming of the Earth's surface was slowed down by the eruption of Mount Pinatubo in the Philippines in June 1991. The volcano pumped thousands of tons of dust into the atmosphere, creating a veil that filtered the Sun's rays. Researchers say the dust effect has now disappeared and warming has recommenced.
Dr Jones said: "1995 was the warmest year yet and we would expect gradually to get more and more of these. They will go on. It's all down to burning fossil fuels and the release of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere from power stations. To slow it down, we have really got to do something and that is where the political side of things comes in."
While Britain and Germany are pushing hard for cuts in emissions beyond 2000, scientists are concerned that America, the most important country in climate negotiations, is being overwhelmed by lobbying from industry and big business.
Researchers investigating the likely effect of climatic change on the frequency of food poisoning have found evidence suggesting that the food industry, and not the housewife, is to blame for the rising number of cases.
A team at the University of East Anglia compared the number of cases of food poisoning in England and Wales with the average monthly temperatures and found the crucial factor was the temperature of the previous month, and not the month in which the food was consumed, suggesting the food was contaminated on the farm or in the food processing industry rather than in the home.

The New Greek Island

The Santorini region has since become a popular resort, because the volcano is inactive and there is the chance to peer into the defunct craters.
THE NEW GREEK ISLAND
(From our Athens correspondent)
A new island began to rise above the level of the sea in the Bay of Thera (Santorin) on the 4th inst, and in five days it attained the height of from 130ft to 150ft, with a length of upwards of 350ft and a breadth of 100ft. It continues to increase, and consists of a rusty black metallic larva, very heavy, and resembling half-melted scoria that has boiled up from a furnace.
The present eruption commenced on January 31. A noise like volleys of artillery was heard, but without any earthquake. On the following day flames issued from the sea, in a part of the bay called Bulkanos, where the water is always discoloured and impregnated with sulphur from abundant springs at the bottom. The flames rose at intervals to the height of 15ft, and were seen at times to issue from the southwestern part of Nea Kaimene. That island was soon rent by a deep fissure and the southern part sank considerably. On February 4 the eruptions became more violent. Gas forced itself up from the depths with terrific noise, resembling the bursting of a steam boiler; flames arose at intervals, and white smoke formed an immense column, crowned with a curled capital of dark heavy clouds. The new island was visible next morning, increasing sensibly to the eye as it rose out of the sea at no great distance.

1996
Volcano dates biblical history
Steve Connor, Science Correspondent
TWO CAMBRIDGE professors have come up with scientific data that they claim pinpoints the exact time when Joseph, the Old Testament figure renowned for his coat of many colours and for predicting a seven-year famine in Egypt, was alive. If they are right, many key episodes in biblical history, including the exodus of Jews to the Promised Land, can be dated precisely for the first time.
The key to their theory is the volcanic eruption of the Greek island of Santorini, in 1628BC. Colin Humphreys, professor of materials science, and Robert White, professor of geophysics, claim that the explosion which ejected enough rubble and dust into the sky to fill the Channel tunnel more than 4,000 times led to an unprecedented seven-year famine around the Nile's fertile region.
The volcano threw up to 192m tons of sulphur over an area extending from present-day Turkey to the Nile. This fell as acid rain. With climate cooling caused by atmospheric dust, this would have caused crops to fail for several years, Humphreys said.
This was the famine that the Israelite Joseph forecast when he interpreted a pharaoh's dream, foretelling seven years of plenty followed by seven years of famine.
Until now biblical scholars believed that Joseph could have lived at any time between 1900BC and 1350BC, a span of more than 500 years, which has led to doubts over other biblical dates. If it can be proved that he lived in the 17th century BC, that suggests the pharaoh reigning at the time was Khyan, the greatest of the six pharaohs of the Hyksos dynasty, the scientists said.
Because Khyan took Joseph's advice and stored grain during the good years, he became very powerful, said Humphreys. "It fits in with Khyan being so famous. He had a huge influence that extended from Crete to Baghdad."
More significantly, having established Joseph's dates, all other subsequent biblical events can be slotted into place. In particular, the exodus of Moses from Egypt to the Promised land can be pinpointed as 1280BC, the same year that Rameses the Great was building the temple of Abu Simbel.
A similar controversy exists over the chronology of key events in Egyptian history. Leading Egyptologists have greeted the Cambridge findings with caution. Professor Kenneth Kitchen, of Liverpool University, said other attempts to link Egyptian dates with biblical events were also beginning to provide some interesting coincidental dates, "but it's not absolutely guaranteed. We don't know enough to endorse it fully or to fault it, but it's an interesting possibility".
Other specialists, such as David Rohl, author of the bestselling book A Test of Time, dismissed the Cambridge work.
"They are on to a loser," he said. "It just doesn't fit with recent finds in Egypt. It is science versus archeology and a big schism is developing between the two over dates."

*
1996
Rough Diamonds
Robert Elms
It is wild, empty, unpredictable and awesome but, says ROBERT ELMS, it is the power of its natural world that is Iceland's jewel.
At first you just see grey. A lank sky sodden with cloud, lashed by rain swirling over a soil that is not soil at all but ash, spiteful shards of volcanic afterbirth forming an unstable, crunchy mat beneath your feet, a dusty near-black blanket that is whipped up by the swirl to add to the gloomy air of enveloping monotone. This feels like the end of the world. But then, as you grow accustomed to the light and the wind and the rain, you begin to see shades emerging; a vague, hazy, mossy green wrapped around clumps of ash that have solidified into something like rock. A glimmer of blinding white in the far, far distance, a glacial gleam piercing the sky. Then, causing a joy far in excess of its size, a tiny sprig of wild flowers purple and brilliant, proof of life. And then you see the steam, a fierce jet of vaporised water pouring not from the sky but the ground, a startling, shocking eruption from the very belly of this strange earth. This is not the end of the world but the beginning.
The Reykjanes peninsula on the southwest corner of Iceland is one of the most inhospitable and dramatically bleak parts of this island at the limit of the habitable world. It is also where you first land. Keflavik airport is on the coast of this scarred, volcanic wasteland, and visitors are siphoned hurriedly onto coaches and rushed off to Reykjavik and the many more voluptuous natural wonders that lie ahead. But this dark and foreboding area, with its sporadic outbursts of primeval power and tenuous, often touching signs of life, is among the most moving and magnetic. The most potent images Iceland provides are of nature born anew, and nowhere is that more tangible than here in this great grey place. You must return.
First, though, you have to get to know the charming and wayward little capital. With 100, 000 or so souls, almost half the population of this eerily empty land, Reykjavik is a peculiar combination of the rustic and the sophisticated. Everywhere neat boxy houses with brightly coloured corrugated iron roofs give the city the squat, haphazard appearance of an unfinished frontier town. Yet it's blessed with a couple of good hotels, a few excellent restaurants and bars, and a surprisingly hectic social and cultural life, all of which make Reykjavik a fine place to base yourself. The hardiest travellers forsake its softened pleasures for the tough stuff that lies out there in the wilderness. You see them, solitary figures on long lonely roads, riding bicycles burdened with their worldly goods or walking, cowering under the weight of erupting rucksacks. The locals shake their heads and drive past in their huge-wheeled four-wheel drives. Unless you're a fanatic, base yourself in the capital and plan your forays from there.
Every region of this island, ejected into the Atlantic from the unstable chasm between two continents, has wonders to make a geography teacher weep. The southeast has natural spas and lakes, woods and the largest glacier hovering behind it. The northwest, intensely rugged, indented by filigree fjords and small isolated communities, possesses a tugging, verdant beauty unknown elsewhere. The northeast boasts the volcanic drama of lake Myvatn, right over the mid-Atlantic ridge, with surreal landscapes and vivid mineral hues. There's also Akureyri, a relatively sunny, pleasant town of 15,000 people, which makes it the second largest metropolis on the island and the only real alternative base. Finally, there's the daunting, impenetrable subarctic desert of the interior. Roadless, endless, uninhabited and uninhabitable, a true heart of darkness that draws mountaineers and madmen. For most, though, the southwest is sufficient. There's enough here, in the lap of the Icelandic culture, its spiritual epicentre, to call you back time and again. The story goes that it was to stop unwanted visitors coming here in the first place that the original Viking settlers called this relatively green island Iceland, while truly icy Greenland was so named as a false lure. Today they just make everything extraordinarily expensive. As a result, most tourists opt to explore in guided groups, being bused from geyser to waterfall, lake to glacier. If you can break the bank, though, and hire a car for at least a couple of days, you get a chance to wander at your own pace, stop to marvel at the extra-ordinary solitude, to revel in the occasional, almost overpowering sense that you might just be the first person to have trodden here in many northern summers. Driving is feasible because the road network in the southwest is decent and because Reykjavik is so small that you can be out there communing with nature at its most effusive within 20 minutes of downing a £6 beer in a designer bar. Those who really wish to go off the beaten track have to take precautions because, although Iceland may not be especially icy, it is extremely volatile. Weather can change suddenly, terrain turn from the dramatic to the dangerous, and help, in a land with only two people per square mile, is often very distant. But then the stuff within safe and easy reach is so spectacular that you don't need to take risks. Just take any road out of Reykjavik.
Within a day trip's circumference of the capital there's an area known cornily as the golden circle. This is an array of natural wonders, something of a geological freak show, but it's a show that has to be seen. And as you move from one famous phenomenon to the next you start to feel an almost elemental sense of this unique land and the equally singular souls who inhabit it. Nowhere is that relationship between man and nature more graphically entwined than in the blood- and saga-soaked valley of Thingvellir.
This lush amphitheatre, a gorge divided by a tumbling, serpentine river, bounded by Iceland's largest lake, snow-peaked volcanoes and a vast natural granite wall, is one of the most conventionally beautiful spots in the country, but its scenic serenity is deceptive. Ever since the first settlers banded together in the 10th century, this place, its name meaning "parliament plains", has been the arena for settling disputes. At best this was a rudimentary form of democracy that attracted wise men from all over the island. But when the Norse gods were frowning, so blood boiled and flowed like the violent geothermal waters that spurt nearby. Nowhere is the Viking past and its haunting poetry as vivid as at Thingvellir. The single Icelandic standard blowing in the inevitable wind, planted there with independence in 1944, brings that history up to date. This is a mighty place.
As you travel from it towards the geyser that has given all such fountains their name, you begin to realise just how forceful the few Icelanders are. Anywhere there's a swathe of land stable and fertile enough to support some sheep and a small, hardy horse, you will see a solitary farmhouse. Anywhere there's a couple of farmhouses, the simple spire of a little Lutheran church will pierce the unbroken skyline. Life out here, even with the four-wheel drives and the relative affluence of modern times, is tough, silent and stern. The traveller can expect few luxuries en route. Where anything like a village exists, it is likely to be spare, almost spartan. This is not a land of cosy hotels and roadside inns. Stop at the famed spa at Laugarvatn, where scalding steam fringes a freezing lake, and the facilities consist of an old wooden hut. Despite this and the usual driving rain, Icelanders come regularly to shed their clothes and immerse themselves in these dread extremes. This is not Provence.
But when the enveloping blanket of cloud lifts and the sun shines, things start to look very different. Suddenly the horizon extends to an almost supernatural degree, and vast vistas reveal themselves, always with a looming volcano or two hovering on the pale horizon. The absolute lack of pollution gives both the air and the light now pouring through it a sharpness, a biting clarity that is startling. The colours of summer mauve-green mossy grasses, pink, blue, purple and yellow wild flowers, endless blue skies and an orange ball sun leap out at you. Nature seems almost benign, but then you haven't seen what it can do yet.
The Great Geyser, Iceland's most famous geological phenomenon with its 600ft spume, is not the old faithful it once was. But in the rich red and ochre-stained lava fields all around it, the very floor you walk along bubbles and boils with a frantic, fetid energy that seems almost diabolical. A smaller but more reliable geyser gives forth every few minutes, erupting 80ft from a swelling pool that expands and explodes in front of your eyes. The whole place is moving, both literally and emotionally, disquieting, humbling and uplifting like, perhaps, being present at birth.
The road to and from the geyser, one of the few that reaches for any distance into the interior, has just six miles still to go. It peters out as a Tarmac path in a nondescript car park with a simple hut that gives you no
END indication of the powerhouse round the bend. You hear it before you see it, an unfathomable roar that seems to emanate from the air itself. Then you spot a high watery mist, which, in this capricious country, could be a geyser or a steam vent. It isn't; it's a waterfall. You also feel it before you see it, a fine soaking spray carried on the wind and a rumble beneath your feet, like some kind of quake. As you finally reach the awesome end, you see the gully that carries the torrent, then your eyes know what every other sense has already anticipated: Gullfoss, the Golden Falls. The river Hvita, leaping and diving more than 100ft, twisting as it drops into a ravine more than a mile wide. The greatest falls in our continent just feet away, and if you're lucky you may just be the only soul present.
Gullfoss is a glorious thing, untainted and raw, worth many drenching, deafening minutes in its presence but, before you head back for the thankfully sophisticated pleasures of the city, there's one more wonder to gaze upon. If the northern deities have smiled upon you, the sun will still be out and the view still clear. For if it is, due north you will see the source of this immense power. Nestling between jagged peaks of black rock sits Langjokull, a prehistoric monster, the alter ego of the dragon, breathing ice over its bleak domain. This great glacier, shimmering, tempting like a siren, does, indeed, call some to take of its bitter terrain. For most of us, though, a view of this terrifying, beautiful thing is enough.
Those who wish to experience a glacier usually head onto the Snaefellsnes peninsula, visible from Reykjavik, where the much smaller Snaefellsjokull, Arne Saknussemm's entry point in Journey to the Centre of the Earth, offers a relatively easy introduction to the frozen world. Perhaps, though, the time has come to witness another kind of wonder at work. Iceland is essentially one big volcano, but off its southwestern coast sits an archipelago of 13 small islands... well, now there's 13; a few years back there were 12.
The Westman Islands are among the newest places on earth and the most geologically active. Surtsey, the lucky 13th, emerged from the sea over a couple of dramatically documented years in 1963. The largest and only permanently inhabited island, Heimaey, had to be rapidly de-inhabited in 1973, when it erupted with murderous force. You can fly the 15
minutes to Heimaey, or take a boat from the coast of that grey peninsula where your journey began. However you get there, it's extraordinary.
When Heimaey exploded suddenly one winter's night, its people fought a heroic battle against the flying fire and the lava flow that threatened to swamp their land. A 500ft wall of molten earth crept towards their town and their precious harbour, and for three months they struggled to survive. They did; just. When you land on their island, you can see the scars, the crushed and half-buried houses, the completely reshaped harbour wall. You can climb Edfel, the 800ft conical hill that now hides one third of their old town. A few yards up, the loose ash starts to get warm to the touch, to smoke and to scorch. You can feel it literally baking within, revealing a thrilling fraction of the power these people took on and tamed. For now. The sense that it could all happen again is almost spooky.
The boat journey back, swarming with seals and sea birds, is also eerie and ethereal and, what's more, it returns you near to that promontory you promised to revisit. All along this coast there are sheer cliffs, surreal rock formations and wonderful black sand beaches battered by the Atlantic waves and giving off an intense air of gothic drama. (The finest of them, at Vik, was recently voted in the top 10 beaches of the world.) But it's inland that the true fascination lies.
Lake Kleifarvatn sits in a huge bowl between sprawling hills of volcanic ash, almost completely barren, near-black and brutally empty in all directions. It's no surprise that this is reputed to be the home of an aquatic monster, a cousin of Nessie, and when you're standing by its lonely shores feeling small and vulnerable, its existence seems much more likely. It's rare to see a human here, even though there's plenty of trout to fish for. You can, though, see those telltale plumes of steam that eventually lead you to Krisuvik.
In this near desert of dark shades, Krisuvik is a hotbed of remarkable colours and occurrences. This is where steam shoots from the ground, where the ground itself seems to be alive, where the process of creation is so real it burns you, showers you, fills your nostrils with its pungent, sulphurous odours. This is the largest steam vent in the world, an entire field of brewing muds in bright, unnameable colours, like some huge chemistry experiment allowed to run wild. Here, close to the airfield that will take you back to your ancient home, you really can witness the world being born.
Robert Elms travelled to Iceland as a guest of Time Off and the Hotel Borg

1996
The collector's collector
Isabel Carlisle
Sometimes, although rarely and unpredictably, an exhibition achieves a dynamism of its own that makes it not just good but great. That this mysterious chemistry should be present in the British Museum's current exhibition on Sir William Hamilton is surprising but palpably true.
I could analyse at length the factors that have brought this about: the infectious enthusiasm of the curators; their appetite for detective work; the high quality of the loans; the lack of inhibitions in mixing ideas with exhibits, science with art; the character of Sir William himself; and an installation that evokes the late 18th century in an entirely unpompous way, are all contributing factors. Much better just to go and experience for yourself this beguiling and stimulating gem of a show.
Sir William Hamilton took up the post of British envoy at the court of the Bourbon King Ferdinand IV of Naples in 1764 without any great ambitions for a diplomatic career. Lacking fortune or title, he concentrated instead on establishing a reputation for himself as a man of "virtu" through collecting art and antiquities, publishing his collections, entertaining the many Grand Tourists and artists passing through Naples and minutely recording the activities of Vesuvius for the Royal Society.
Vesuvius was more active in the second half of the 18th century than at any time since antiquity or afterwards and Sir William was near by for the three violent eruptions of 1767, 1779 and 1794. The evocative scenes that he commissioned from local artists convey the drama of the pall of smoke by day and the glowing orange of the night sky.
Despite the volcano, there can hardly have been a more pleasant place to live: the Bay of Naples was still one of the most beautiful places in Europe. A panoramic view by Giovanni Battista Lusieri, 2.7 metres long and painted from the balcony of Hamilton's Palazzo Sessa, shows it in all its limpid seductiveness, and in such detail that you can pick out Hamilton's seaside retreat, the Villa Emma, on the far side of the bay.
This was also when the first major finds were being brought up from the excavations of Pompeii and Herculaneum. Sir William promptly started his first collection of antiquities. In selling these to the British Museum in 1772 he revolutionised the character of that institution until then a repository of the natural sciences and put it on the path to becoming a showcase for art and antiquities.
The recovery of Hamilton's scattered collections of Greek painted vases, gold jewellery, cameos, gemstones, Old Master and contemporary paintings, bronzes and sculpture is one of the triumphs of the show. The magnificent, colossal head of Hercules, chipped out of the lava at the foot of Vesuvius, is too good to go back into the museum's stores. So is the reconstructed 5 th-century BC Greek tomb from Trebbia, with a bronze cheese-grater among the grave goods and small vases hanging on the back wall. Famously unrecoverable is the part of Sir William's second vase collection, which went down in HMS Colossus in a storm off the Isles of Scilly.
To be remembered as a victim of this disaster and the long-suffering cuckold of the menage a trois with Nelson and his wife, Emma, has been Hamilton's fate until today.
Emma was effectively dumped on Hamilton by his nephew Charles Greville, whose mistress she had been. In tackling the delicate task of establishing a role for her in Neapolitan society, Hamilton had the idea that Emma should pose as classical statues she had already posed for Romney in London. Her metamorphosis from one character into another, with three cashmere shawls for props, became one of the tourist sights of Naples. Among the drawings and paintings of her, including those by Romney and Reynolds, the most enchanting is by Elisabeth Vigee-Le Brun, who sketched her upturned face onto one of the doors at the Villa Emma with a stick of charcoal taken from the fire.
To resurrect Sir William as a benefactor to the nation, a connoisseur and man of taste who aimed to raise standards of design and art in Britain is one of the aims of this exhibition. Most successfully of all, it evokes the enormous excitement of living at the end of the 18th century, when so many branches of knowledge were at their very beginnings and the arts were enthusiastically embracing the discoveries of classical Greece and Rome.
Vases and Volcanoes: Sir William Hamilton and his collection, sponsored by Pirelli, is at the British Museum until July 14.

1 July 1997
Fears grow on island after huge eruption
Tom Rhodes in Plymouth, Montserrat
THE biggest volcanic eruption in Montserrat's memory engulfed the tiny island in clouds of ash last night as the British Government promised further aid to relieve the colony from disaster.
Like a giant mushrooming sponge, plumes of white and brown ash from Chances Peak volcano turned the sky black seconds before the residue started to rain down on the north of the island.
Baroness Symons of Vernham Dean, the Foreign Office Minister who toured the Caribbean island for the second time in two weeks yesterday, had just finished her last engagement when the first puffs became visible. She had promised more money for emergency housing and transport, £1.5 million for roads and further funds for a hospital and fuel.
Her message had been that Britain was committed to rebuilding the infrastructure after an eruption last week that claimed the lives of at least 23 people and left the southern two thirds of the island uninhabitable.
"Our absolute priority is the welfare of the people on the island," she said. "I am here today to show that the British Government is committed to Montserrat."
By the time she started for the helicopter that would take her to Barbados the volcano had erupted again.
Carol Osborne, sister-in-law of Bertrand Osborne, the Chief Minister, said as she gazed into the sky: "It's the biggest eruption we have ever had."
Scientists last night predicted further eruptions. The area hit by the most recent waves of lava has been fully evacuated and no human victims were expected. But the renewed activity can only cause further anxiety for the 6,000 islanders who remain and is certain to provoke an exodus which could make the island unsustainable.
The casualties last week, the first since the volcano became active again two years ago, have left a deep impression on the population. Inside the unsafe zone before last night's explosion, Clifford Farrell, a fireman, gazed at the spewing vents of the Soufriere Hills less than a mile away. "That's nothing to what she can do," he said. "If she really blows then we're all dead. It would take less than a minute for the pyroclastic flow to reach this point."
Plymouth, the once thriving capital, is coated in ash so thick that driving through its empty streets is like braving a Saharan sandstorm. Face masks are required to avoid lung damage from inhalation. The noxious smell of sulfur is as pervasive as the sense that this land will not be farmed again for generations. Only the animals remain. Dogs, cats, goats and cows scurry through the ghost town in search of scant food.

2 July 1997
Irritable volcano turns an island paradise into hell
Tom Rhodes
Tom Rhodes pays a flying visit to Montserrat, where 23 people died last week amid fears of another Krakatoa.
GEORGE MORRIS, a civilian pilot from Barbados, manoeuvred his Squirrel helicopter around the crater of Montserrat's angry volcano. Below us bubbling vents spurted plumes of dense ash above the British colony, threatening to disable the small machine in a single puff.
This once beautiful Caribbean resort was an awesome spectacle. The villages of Trant's, Harris and Streatham, where as many as 23 islanders had died last week, were completely covered in a light brown carpet of lava and ash. Houses had been gutted by fire. Whole valleys and forests had vanished under thick volcanic mud, the flow stopping 15 yards short of the single-strip runway at Blackburne Airport.
Plymouth, the once proud capital with its brick-red British telephone box and cannon pointing seaward, is barely recognisable. At least five buildings had burnt after a big eruption the previous evening and most Montserratians are convinced the town will never again be habitable.
As the T-shirts that have become de rigueur among islanders put it: "Now she puffs but will she blow? Trust the Lord and pray it's No."
Volcano-watching is the national pastime. There is scant employment and schools have closed to accommodate evacu ees from the south of the island. Along the roads, in the shelters and even at the home of Frank Savage, the inscrutable British Governor, people gaze for hours at a beast none can control. All are tuned to the local radio station which broadcasts hourly updates from the Montserrat Volcano Observatory interspersed with prayer readings and reggae.
Yesterday William Aspinall, British chief scientist at the observatory, was again predicting significant eruptions from Chances Peak.
But vulcanology remains an inexact science and its practitioners are loath to offer any long-term prognosis. While they consistently rebuff the fears of more imaginative islanders that Montserrat could become the next Krakatoa, none is prepared to say with any certainty that it will not.
"There is no blueprint," said Mr Aspinall. "It all depends on what the volcano decides to do. The risk at this time is that overspills could be greater than before but we do not expect the north of the island to be affected." In the past, West Indies volcanoes have tended to explode forcefully for as little as two months.
The experience of the Soufriere Hills in Montserrat has been very different. Since it awoke from centuries of almost undisturbed slumber two years ago, the activity of this volcano has increased by the day.
The fortitude and deep religious commitment of Montserratians is well documented: they have paid a heavy price for living in paradise. First sighted by Christopher Columbus in 1493 and colonised by Irish Catholics 140 years later, the island has endured more than its fair share of tempest and flood. First the cotton industry was ruined, then tourism was crippled.
Hurricane Hugo in 1989 destroyed much of the island and affected 98 per cent of the housing stock, but the people stayed. Since the volcano opened its vents, however, thousands have deserted and, without swift intervention from the British Government and local authorities, it is all but inevitable that another mass exodus will take place.
The crew of HMS Liverpool , the West Indies guardship, was yesterday building additional emergency shelters for those without homes, but the task is unlikely to satisfy many who have lived in makeshift shelters for two years. Nervous breakdowns are increasing, as are reported cases of asthma and respiratory diseases from the ubiquitous ash.
Teenage pregnancies are increasing, too, as young shelter girls turn to prostitution. Father Larry Finnegan, the island's Roman Catholic priest, said family discipline was harder to maintain but he is sure Montserrat will survive. "There is no magic wand for the volcano but we pray that she will go back to sleep."

2 August 1997
Volcano stays on the boil
David Adams in Miami
A MONTH after a volcano erupted on the Caribbean island of Montserrat, killing at least ten people, more explosions of super-heated rock and gas have showered the British dependency with ash.
The latest blasts were not as strong as last month's and the authorities said there was no immediate threat of another major eruption. Many of the island's 11,000 residents have left the 39 sq mile island, while many others are living in refugee shelters.
British officials monitoring the Soufriere Hills volcano said a new dome of rock was steadily forming and added that it was impossible to predict when it might blow again. Britain is considering evacuating the 5,000 or so people remaining on the island. About 1,300 have already gone to Britain.

2 September 1997
Foulkes pledges start of new era for Montserrat
Tom Rhodes
Tom Rhodes reports on the attempt to mend fences among the Caribbean islanders living in the shadow of a volcano
GEORGE FOULKES, the International Development Minister, accepting government mistakes over its handling of Montserrat, yesterday pledged unequivocal commitment for a new start in the tiny British colony.
In a clear effort at fence-mending during his two-day visit to Montserrat, Mr Foulkes, whose predictions of a cataclysmic eruption by the island's active volcano sparked panic evacuations last month, said that Whitehall and the local government had entered a new era of co-operation."Now it is a new start and we are looking to the future and making an unequivocal commitment to both the people and the island of Montserrat."
Mr Foulkes said that he was looking at immediate needs such as housing, roads, upgrading the hospital and creating employment for the 5,000 islanders who have remained on Montserrat since the Soufriere Hills volcano erupted two years ago for the first time in four centuries.
During his first hours on the island, however, the minister gave no hint of whether further funds might be made available to the beleaguered British outpost in the Caribbean. "We want to ensure the viability of the safe area in the north so that the people of Montserrat can have real choices, given the constraints," he said. "Because the villain of the island is the volcano, and I think we should never forget that."
Mr Foulkes visited the emergency centre, then flew around the fuming volcano crater and made a deliberate visit to the emergency jetty in Little Bay, begun under the former Government and completed after Tony Blair came to power in May.
HMS Liverpool , the West Indies guardship, provided a suitably symbolic backdrop before departing yesterday evening for Puerto Rico, its white ensign flying at half-mast in honour of Diana, Princess of Wales.
In the afternoon, Mr Foulkes, accompanied by Frank Savage, the British Governor, toured various shelters and other areas of Montserrat. He was expected to make a joint statement of intent with David Brandt, the Chief Minister, today.
Over lunch he was presented with plans for a new capital at Little Bay and Carr's Bay, a project designed by Landbase International, a company based in London. The scheme - including plans for businesses, hotels, a hospital and a Test-standard cricket ground - requires an underwriting guarantee by Whitehall.
Mr Brandt, who has been critical of Mr Foulkes in the weeks since the minister's volcano remarks caused widespread panic, yesterday said that he welcomed the new signs of co-operation by London. "We do not want to fight with the British Government, we want to work as partners giving each other mutual respect," he said.
Mr Foulkes's predictions of a terrible eruption, necessitating a complete evacuation, were disputed by scientists last month. The minister's aides said yesterday that he had read from a draft report stating that a "cataclysmic eruption" could not be ruled out. They attempted to blame civil servants for the gaffe.
Islanders are still smarting from subsequent comments made by Clare Short, the International Development Secretary, in which she said that local authorities were demanding too much money and would next be calling for "golden elephants".
So far, £30 million in government aid has been spent in Montserrat with another £11 million promised. Mr Foulkes rejected claims that the Government had been withholding the additional funds.

2 October 1997
Attack of the killer cliches
Geoff Brown
NEW MOVIES: Geoff Brown sees a rumoured $100 million go up in flames as LA gets toasted in Volcano
The forces of nature are not treating us kindly. Out in the Pacific, in the real world, El Nino is warming the ocean and turning the world's weather topsy-turvy, stimulating droughts or unleashing torrential rain. Over in Hollywood, Volcano has erupted, spewing fireballs, ash clouds, molten lava and dramatic cliches all over the city. Inside or outside the cinema, there is no escape.
In the old days, it was exciting to contemplate screen devastation. Twenty years ago, when the disaster movie last had its boom, you could enjoy watching fading Hollywood stars getting charred round the edges or burnt to a crisp in The Towering Inferno . You could relish the hokum of an Earthquake , an Airport or a Poseidon Adventure secure in the knowledge that the film-maker, usually Irwin Allen, knew what he was up to: peddling trash.
Volcano is a different matter. The film cost a great deal of money, some say about $100 million, and it was made by people who take their cliches seriously. Fun is drained from the game as a result. It should be bracing watching Tommy Lee Jones wade across chaos, manly and brave. Our muscles should tighten as people scream "Oh, my God!" and the lava envelops buildings, subway tunnels, cars, loved ones and dogs. Or at least we should enjoy a good laugh. But the sheer efficiency and impact of the special effects, as well as the intricate detail of the sets, stop us in our tracks. The effects appear realistic, but everything else is so phoney. How can we remain interested in such threadbare characters, such an absurd and ponderous plot?
True to the genre, the characters come with little personal dramas attached: failed relationships, broken marriages, a problematical 13-year-old daughter (useful for placing in the lava's path). But even Jones's considerable charisma, or the brisk fire of Anne Heche in her mainstream cinema debut, cannot make much headway against the weight of stereotypes.
Jones's character is Mike Roark of LA's Office of Emergency Management, a man never without protective headgear or an ear fused to his mobile phone. Heche is Dr Amy Barnes, a feisty seismologist, the voice of science and moral rectitude. "The city is finally paying for its arrogance," she says, contemplating the hubris involved in building an underground transit system above a centre of seismic activity.
Comments like that bring hints of the real Los Angeles, with its new Metro system, into the film's fantasy. And there are suggestions at times that the director, British expatriate Mick Jackson, intends a satire of contemporary lifestyles, just as he did six years ago in his Steve Martin vehicle, LA Story . He has fun, for instance, at the expense of TV reporters babbling at the disaster's edges.
But it is hard to stay impish when a film lumbers as much as this one, and every curlicue in the script needs to be trimmed to make way for the lava chugging down the streets.
Since volcanoes appear to be in this year - do not forget Dante's Peak , in which an eruption ruined the Pacific Northwest - who knows what Hollywood will think of next. A volcano erupting over a hi-jacked airliner? Impossible, you say. But no more unlikely, surely, than the spectacle of Hollywood remaking a Norwegian black comedy. I will repeat that last phrase. A Norwegian black comedy.
Four years ago Nils Gaup, best known for his Lapland drama Pathfinder , made a little movie called Hodet over vannet , in which a former lover's corpse wreaked havoc on a couple's vacation off the Norwegian coast. Somehow news of Gaup's grim jest reached across the Atlantic. So we now have Head Above Water , featuring Harvey Keitel summering off Maine with the newly ubiquitous Cameron Diaz as his young wife.
Novel origins aside, there is not much here to relish. Black comedy is a tricky art, which the director Jim Wilson has yet to acquire. Over-acting is the norm. Dialogue is punched to the skies. The music strives to be loud and comical, always annoying when nothing comical is happening.

3 September 1997
Short seeks to heal rift with volcano island
Tom Rhodes in Montserrat and Philip Webster, Political Editor
CLARE SHORT, the International Development Secretary, made a tacit apology to Montserrat yesterday, agreeing to visit the volcano-ravaged colony within two months to oversee a new long-term plan for the island's development.
The announcement of the visit by George Foulkes, her deputy who ended his own tour of Montserrat yesterday, came after Ms Short's refusal of an invitation by the island's Government and comments in which she accused local leaders of deliberately misrepresenting British offers of help.
Mr Foulkes, who also announced a five-year "sustainable development plan" for Montserrat to be funded by Britain and the European Union, has failed during his trip to apologise publicly for his department's apparent mishandling of policy.
Last month Mr Foulkes, reading from the wrong report by the Montserrat Volcano Observatory, had predicted a "cataclysmic eruption", sparking evacuation panic among islanders. His comments were compounded by Ms Short, who said she was exasperated by the Montserrat Government's "silly political games" and "hysterical scaremongering" in its demands for an improved financial package to help the 5,000 residents who have remained since the Soufriere Hills volcano started to erupt two years ago.
She said the local authorities would next be demanding "golden elephants" from London and, despite an almost empty diary, cited future trips to Bangladesh, Hong Kong and Africa as reasons why she could not undertake a visit to the Caribbean.
Ms Short was then removed from oversight of the Montserrat affair and replaced by a taskforce headed by Robin Cook, the Foreign Secretary. It came as part of government efforts to mend fences with the colony and to salvage the Prime Minister's "caring" foreign policy.
Bernie Grant, MP for Tottenham, who has just returned from Montserrat, saw Ms Short yesterday and voiced his delight at her decision to go to the island. "We all know Clare, we all love Clare. We know she is well-intentioned," he said. He added that he had explained to the islanders that she was a "good person" and had their interests at heart.
However some of Ms Short's ministerial colleagues are still angry about her attack on Whitehall officials and parts of the Foreign Office for criticism of her handling of the affair. In an interview she criticised "vile and dishonest" spin doctors and suggested that there was an attempt to destroy her department.
Fellow ministers have accused her of self-indulgence and naivety for going public with her complaints. Tony Blair might have come under pressure to dismiss her were it not for the death of Diana, Princess of Wales.
In Montserrat, Mr Foulkes and David Brandt, the island's Chief Minister, signed a joint declaration that would ensure healthcare, education, utilities as well as internal and external communications for all who wished to remain in the island.
For those on Montserrat who want to leave, the British Government will provide an initial right of unrestricted entry to the United Kingdom for two years. It will allow the islanders access to income support, housing benefit, schooling and healthcare. Transport costs to Britain will be included.
A separate financial package will be made available to those who prefer to stay. Work on a remaining batch of 200 homes to be built will continue. Mr Foulkes declined to be specific about costs, but said the scheme would amount to much more than the £41 million spent or put aside for Montserrat.

4 February 1997
Fall in love with the heart of Java
Rebecca Mobray
Rebecca Mobray experiences the timeless culture and natural splendours on magical Yogyakarta.
IF YOUR vacation plans afford you only one destination in Java, it should be Yogyakarta, a one-step cultural infusion that can be sampled in a three-day drive-by, or savoured in a month-long meditation.
Yogya, as it is abbreviated, is a national treasure, the heart of Java, common cultural property in a land of diversity. "Ah, Yogya...," Indonesians respond upon hearing this mystical word.
Not surprisingly, it is also Java's number one tourist destination. But leave behind images of London prices for a peasant's meal or shops full of tourist schlock cheapening Indonesia's national heritage. Yogya's popularity is well deserved: people come to pay homage to the sultan's kingdom, and the kingdom handles the attention gracefully.
Visitors can absorb its cultural offerings on foot or by becak , the traditional tricycle taxi, and also use the city as a base for half-day excursions to Mount Merapi, one of the most active volcanoes in the world, or wander the cool highlands of the Dieng Plateau.
Yogya's designation as the heart of Java also stems from its location in the middle section of the island, in the shadow of Merapi's destructive force to the north, and the Indian Ocean to the south.
At the heart of this centre lies the keraton , or the sultan's palace. Yogya is the only functioning sultanate in Indonesia, and Sultan Hamengkubuwono's home is a 240-year-old city within a city, where 25,000 people reside. The sense of the timelessness of Javanese culture is overwhelming. The palace guards and tour guides wear traditional Yogya pattern sarongs, blue surjan high-collar jackets and blangkes (wrapped hats). Visitors can listen to gamelan concerts and watch the palace's dancers perform classical Yogya dances with graceful precision.
Extending north from the keraton is a two-mile promenade, now Jalan Malioboro, home of Yogya's favourite sport: bargaining. Locally made batik, silver, leather goods, ceramics, wooden sculptures and shadow puppets are all found on Malioboro, where the bargaining starts at a price sometimes two-thirds higher than what you should pay. The tenor of Malioboro is exhausting, but I found the price volleys with street vendors a satisfying interaction that gave me some nice souvenirs.
If you prefer to learn about Indonesian handicrafts by making them yourself, Yogya provides courses for just about any art form. You can also watch silver artisans in Kota Gede, tour the batik factories or design your own handbag with a leather craftsman.
But the most remarkable memories of a Yogya visit will come from the breathtaking Buddhist and Hindu sites outside the city, all of which are best appreciated at sunrise.
Less than an hour's drive from Yogya, is Borobudur, the world's largest Buddhist monument. A seven-level pyramid ringed by Buddhas peering out from shelters resembling giant bells, the entire ensemble is meant to be a prayer wheel. This striking piece of masonry was built by hand between 778 and 850, and was only enjoyed for six years before Hindus overthrew the Buddhist Saliendra princes. One thousand years of volcanic eruptions later, surveyors working under Britain's Lieutenant-Governor, Thomas Stamford Raffles, rediscovered it in 1814.
Only when walking up and up and up the steps of Borobudur does one get a sense of its sheer size. It is eerie climbing this ancient hill of Buddhas, some of which have been decapitated by volcanic rages, or perhaps by warring Javanese tribes. From the uppermost level, I watched the rising sun and marvelled at the gardens below, the volcanoes all around, and simmering Merapi towering over them all.
On the other side of Yogya is Prambanan, the 8th and 10th century Hindu wonder. In contrast to Borobudur's horizontal weight, the lines of Prambanan's three main temples are vertical and light. The network originally included another 244 temples, but all were abandoned in the 13th century when the political power moved to East Java, and were subsequently destroyed by earthquakes. From the fenced-off piles of rubble on the temple site, it is clear that restoration still has a long way to go.
I rented a bicycle and pedalled the ten miles to Prambanan so that I could stop at some of the remaining little temples. Meandering through the rice paddies on the outskirts of Yogya replaced the intensity of Malioboro with a serene peace rarely found in the tourist honeypots. Outside the main temple complex are gardens with benches shaded by trees, making for a pleasant outdoor excursion.
Visitors who come around the time of full moon are treated to special performances of the Ramayana Ballet in the park's outdoor theatre. The dancing is gymnastic, and the costumes vivid against a backdrop of the moon rising over the main temples.
FROM YOGYA, Merapi can be seen sporadically beckoning in the distance. Nocturnal adventurers may want to treat themselves to the lava tour, where you sit on a hill at night and watch red-hot molten rock spill down the side of the mountain. Or you can travel to the safer side of the volcano, hire a guide from the village below, and make the steep, rocky trek by moonlight.
Staring down into a frothing cauldron of lava and seeing the first streaks of day give way to distant volcanic peaks tearing through the morning mist was the most amazing moment I experienced in Java.
Those looking for a more mellow conclusion to their Yogya stay may want to continue on from Borobudur to the Dieng Plateau, where the air is cool and the pace of life practically stationary. You can stroll around the coloured lakes, visit any of the tiny temples scattered across the plain or just drive around and take in the artful terracing of the highlands.
In the opposite direction lies Parangtritis, a dramatic black sand beach with churning surf and barren cliffs - another great spot in which to reflect on the wonders of Java.
READING
FOR anyone visiting Indonesia, the following books are worth reading:
Indonesia Handbook by Joshua Eliot, published by Footprint Handbooks.
Indonesia: From Sabang to Merauke by John Keay, published by Boxtree Ltd.
Lord Jim and Victory by Joseph Conrad published by Penguin.
Island of Indonesia by Violet Clifton, published by Oxford University Press.

*
4 July 1997
Lava louts

Frightening scenes viewed from a sufficient distance inspire a terrible delight, as Edmund Burke observed. While few may choose to wander the flanks of a volcano while it is erupting, seen from afar the spectacle has an undeniable grandeur. It seems to mock man's pretensions and make clear that nature's power is of an altogether different order. Such sights, to Burke, summed up the sublime, though his critics took much pleasure in seeking a precise measure to distinguish sublimity from sheer terror. How far away did one have to be, they inquired, before the quaking legs gave way to aesthetic euphoria?
Had he known, he might have answered that it depended greatly on the type of volcano. Those in Hawaii are as good-tempered as volcanoes know how to be, the steady flow of lava down the mountainside posing few risks and plenty of harmless excitement. Strombolian volcanoes, which hurl out rocks of a consistent size and at a consistent speed, are also relatively benign, though they can sometimes change their tempo and catch out the unwary. The truly dangerous eruptions, such as those in the past week in Montserrat, are composed of a hot cloud of dust and gas which sweeps down the mountain so fast that escape is impossible. In such pyroclastic flows the element of fear far outweighs any possible pleasure, and the damage done to life and property is enormous.
Such destructive eruptions are relatively rare events in relation to human lifespan, far too infrequent to determine settlement patterns. Around the world many great cities lie almost in the shadow of volcanoes that have been dormant so long that their danger is discounted. Often, the fertile soil produced by the volcano actually attracts people to live around it, while expanding populations ensure that the numbers theoretically at risk are higher now than they have ever been in human history. The eruption of Vesuvius in AD79 claimed about 2,000 victims; if it happened again today without warning, it would probably kill 200,000. The island of Java, where a high proportion of the 175,000 deaths that have been caused by volcanic eruptions in the past 200 years have occurred, is four times as densely populated today as it was in 1955.
Many efforts have been made to improve volcano prediction, with some success, but it remains an inexact science. Even when successful predictions are made, as at Mount St Helens in 1980, it is difficult to persuade everybody to believe them and leave the area. Even more is this true of the developing world, where mobility is lower and the credibility of government agencies less. In the past few decades we have been lucky, with only one eruption, at Nevado del Ruiz in Colombia, claiming lives on a massive scale. But it would be unwise to assume that this state of affairs can continue indefinitely. The risks are much greater than is generally acknowledged.

4 September 1997
Out from under the volcano
Peter Stothard
THE INSULA OF THE MENANDER AT POMPEII Volume 1 The Structures. By Roger Ling, The Clarendon Press, £85 - ISBN 0 19 813409 6.
Peter Stothard on Pompeii's race against time, tourists and tunnellers.
In the years after Pompeii was buried under the ash of Vesuvius it was not altogether forgotten. Modern tourists who battle their way through dirt and heat to see the town today might be comforted to know that their predecessors were enduring similar discomfort almost from the August day in AD 79 when the town left the map of southern Italy and began its journey into the imagination of the world.
Some of the first people to hack their way through the streets and houses may have themselves been survivors of the eruption or relatives of the dead returning to salvage their lost legacies. Some of the skeletons and human plaster casts, described today as victims caught by the volcano's sudden blast, may have been treasure hunters of late antiquity who underestimated the danger of tunnelling through a slag-heap of pumice. When guides today point out the holes in the walls made by desperate escapers it is always worth wondering whether the route from room to room might have been more appropriate for some gold-getting mediaeval intruder.
In the 16th century came the aqueduct builders; in the 18th, the serious looters for the royal collections of Europe. By the end of the 19th century the scholars were more or less in charge. But the popular appeal of this "time capsule" from the ancient world has produced its own surge of destructive visitors. As Roger Ling describes in his introduction, the great houses of Pompeii are deteriorating even under a regime of the most concentrated and obsessive scholarship. In the single small and much-recorded area (known as insula X) to which he has devoted himself for this book, recent losses have included the ironwork of three houses, a landscape painting, room decorations and a phal lic relief which was last photographed in 1977.
The central building in Ling's study is the Casa del Menandro, the home of a wealthy landowner and wine-maker whose possessions included a striking honey-yellow portrait of the 4th century Athenian playwright, Menander, semi-naked from the waist upwards and reading a book. As well as this picture, which gives the house its modern name, and various others on the eerily appropriate theme of the destruction of Troy, the owners had a fine collection of 118 silver dishes, cups and mirrors which were found earlier this century on a ledge close to the kitchens.
These may have been brought together to be ready for a great escape, possibly by the six adults and three children whose bones were found in a corridor near by. One can almost imagine the mistress's inventory as the departure time drew near: two goblets with doomed gladiator decoration, one bowl showing grief of Ariadne, one jug with head of negro slave, one large cooking plate with animals fleeing the hunt, one cup with oarsman in a tiny boat screaming to the skies.
Thoughts of Pompeii stimulate even the most jaded imaginations. Perhaps the dead were merely the unlucky or the foolish who failed to run when the first egg-sized stones began to hail from the sky. Perhaps the master of the house was caught at the circus games which Bulwer Lytton made the climax of his Victorian best-seller The Last Days of Pompeii . Despite the efforts of Ling and his many fellow scholars, it is unlikely that we will ever know the answers to such conjecture. Nor, however, in an age of mass tourism and many followers of Lytton in both literature and film, are the questions ever likely to stop.
Ling's aim is to submit the Casa del Menandro and its surrounding area to the minutest study and to clarify at least some of the provable truth about one typical part of the town. This is the first of three volumes and covers probably the least seductive part of the enterprise. It is stronger on lime, loam and lava bricks than on paintings, mosaics or silverware. Until the subsequent books appear, those curious about the art of the Casa will have to find copies of Amedeo Maiuri's works, in particular his 1933 monograph, La Casa del Menandro e il suo tesoro di argenteria .
What Ling shows in awesome detail is how the houses were built, how they fitted in with their neighbours, how a big house might spread to take over its block and the impact of subsequent tunnelling of every time and type. Ling likes to spar a little with Maiuri, whose directorship of the excavations lasted from 1924 to 1961 and who made himself the 20th-century emperor of his domain. More scholastic jousting can be expected in the volumes to come.
The modern history of Pompeii has been mostly a story of archaeological progress - from the efforts of the 18th-century Swiss hero, Karl Weber, whose scholarship curbed some of the worst excesses of the Bourbon treasure-hunters, through the domination of the 19th century Italian, Giuseppe Fiorelli, who mapped the area for the first time and invented the technique of making plaster casts from the shapes left by bodies in the ash, to Maiuri himself.
Each generation has aimed to be more precise and scientific than the last. But Ling's generation recognises better than all its predecessors how desperate is the battle against people, time and decay. This book is the beginning of a magnificent publishing project. Without levels of protection and restriction so far unimagined at Pompeii, future scholars may come to value it even more than should we.

5 August 1997
London starts talks on volcano island's future
By Michael Binyon, Diplomatic Editor, and David Adams in Miami
BERTRAND OSBORNE, the Chief Minister of the stricken island of Montserrat, yesterday began talks in London on whether the tiny Caribbean island is still viable after two years of devastating volcanic eruptions.
The talks started after eruptions early yesterday morning and on Sunday night sent an avalanche of hot gas, rock and ash pouring down the slopes of the Soufriere Hills volcano into the streets of Plymouth, the abandoned capital.
Mr Osborne, leading a delegation of six ministers and prominent businessmen, will hold talks at the Foreign Office and the Department for International Development as well as the Red Cross, emergency relief officials and some of the hundreds of islanders who have fled to Britain. Tomorrow, the delegation will be received at Buckingham Palace by the Queen.
Britain, which has announced emergency aid and relief amounting to £41 mil lion, yesterday reaffirmed its commitment to Montserrat. "There is no doubt that we are determined that the island - provided it remains viable - should have an economic future," a Foreign Office spokesman said. "The question is how we can help, and what more should be done."
However, after two years of intense volcanic activity, any hope of reoccupying Plymouth is quickly fading. Yesterday plumes of smoke and flame could be seen rising from the town from miles away.
Pebble-sized volcanic debris fell on roofs of some homes in Salem, a central town five miles north of Plymouth, but no damage was reported.
Officials say it was expected that Plymouth would be lost after a large eruption on June 25, which killed at least ten people.
The town had been protected from ash and rock flows by a shallow ravine separating it from the main volcanic activity. But the latest eruption appears to have filled that in, leaving the town exposed. When intermittent eruptions began two years ago, much of Plymouth's infrastructure, including its docks, schools, government buildings and the Governor's residence had to be abandoned. All important public services have since been moved to the north end of the island. The small airport has also been closed, leaving Montserrat accessible only by ferry from nearby Antigua.
Nearly half of the island's 11,000 residents have already fled. Of those who remain, about 1,200 have been forced to seek refuge in overcrowded government shelters.
At the London talks, various options are to be considered, including the permanent relocation of the island's main infrastructure to Salem.
Britain is considering holding a referendum among the remaining inhabitants to find out how many people want to continue living there.

6 August 1997
Cook pledges aid to volcano island
Glen Owen and David Adams
Montserrat, where Irish labourers dwelt alongside black slaves and shamrock symbols abound, still looks to Britain, write Glen Owen and David Adams
ROBIN COOK, the Foreign Secretary, promised yesterday to secure the future of Montserrat in the West Indies, which is threatened by increasingly violent volcanic eruptions, as a delegation from the island lobbied the Government for help.
Bertrand Osborne, Chief Minister of Montserrat, took part in the talks as hundreds more islanders fled the previously safe centre of the island when new eruptions rained ash and rocks on them.
Before dawn yesterday the Soufriere Hills volcano erupted again, causing hundreds to flee from nearby villages while the island's abandoned capital continued to burn. The colony's Government had ordered hundreds more people to be evacuated from villages in the west-centre of the island, including the sole remaining hotel, just hours before yesterday's eruption, which continued into the afternoon.
Mr Cook said he had discussed options for Montserrat's future with the delegation of six ministers and businessmen. "The Government will continue to place the highest priority on sustaining and improving the economic and social structure of Montserrat," he said, adding that Britain's intention was to secure a viable future for the island.
Clare Short, the International Development Secretary, who has allocated £41 million in emergency aid for the island, said that, although residents were likely to be given the chance to leave, a full evacuation was unlikely. Some islanders have alleged that there was a "hidden agenda" to abandon the colony. The new efforts will focus on housing schemes in a 15-square-mile zone in the north to relieve pressure on makeshift arrangements.
Montserrat is one of Britain's six remaining Caribbean dependencies. But despite the long association, the island's main cultural identity has more to do with a blend of Irish and African origins. It was first visited by Columbus in 1493 and was colonised by Britain as a sanctuary for victims of religious persecution. In 1632 Irish indentured labourers, whose Catholicism was rejected in the American colonies, were introduced. Soon afterwards the first African slaves were introduced. By the late 1700s they outnumbered whites ten to one.
The shamrock still adorns everything from passports to bars and brochures refer to "the other emerald isle". A popular folk dance, the "heel and toe," is attributed to Irish custom, and the national dish, "goatwater", is said to be traditional Irish stew.
From 1871 to 1956 Montserrat was linked with the neighbouring Leeward Islands. But in 1960 a new Constitution gave the island a partially elected government. Occasional talks have been held since the early 1980s to find ways of giving the 11,000 residents their independence.
The island has had its share of disasters. In 1965 a Pan Am jet rashed into the side of the volcano, killing 34 passengers, and in 1989 Hurricane Hugo ripped homes apart.
Even after two years of volcanic eruptions, most islanders say they want to stay on and remain profoundly loyal to the Crown.
James Reynolds, a local tailor, who returned to his native isle after a 16-year military career spent largely in Scotland, echoes the widespread gratitude on the island for Britain's help. "As far as I'm concerned, without Britain we would be in a terrible state," he said.

8 March 1997
Popping about old Pompeii
Peter Brown
My Italian barber's face erupted into a smile as wide as a comb. "Pompeii?" he said. "Then you must go to Ischia. It is an island with a volcano in the Bay of Naples. It is a paradise."
The next ten minutes were laced with tales of Lachryma Christi (wine), limoncello (liqueur), grapes, peaches, stewed rabbit, sulphur and thermal baths. Suddenly our family holiday, planned as a supplement to the Cambridge Latin Course, Part 1, seemed more enticing. We were headed towards a region still throbbing with volcanic pleasures.
The bus to Vesuvius leaves from Ercolano station and hairpins up the mountain, past prickly pears and vineyards. From the crater rim the view is astonishing. To the right, the sprawl of Naples. In front, the bay, curving left along the hilly Amalfi peninsula, with Capri at its tip, and on the other side Ischia, lost in the mist.
Below, to the left, Pompeii is just a distant blur in the urban network. How could Vesuvius have spat as far as that? With little difficulty - in 1631, its ashes fell on Istanbul.
Revision note: on August 24, AD 79 a mushroom cloud burst from Vesuvius at noon and the sky went dark for days. Pompeii and Herculanaeum, its little neighbour, were obliterated. The Italians are still digging them out.
We started with Herculanaeum, which the children enjoyed, cavorting around the gardens and squirting fountain water. The town was flooded by mud, so the villas and bathhouses still have upper storeys and seem real. You can amble round Herculanaeum in half an hour.
Pompeii, buried under ash and pumice stone, is a vast, roofless maze. Bringing it to life requires an effort, on an August scorcher with your ragazzi begging for ice-cream. Look, look, imagine: the streets, the villas, Beware of the Dog mosaics, cartwheel ruts, casts of the dead, theatres, forums, the temple to Vespasian (sainted emperor who introduced the public lavatory), the big willies (sorry, good luck symbols). On which subject, outside a Roman brothel, I heard a guide putting a group of nuns in the picture: yes ladies, these girls were the price of a glass of wine. The nuns just nodded. Like us, they were trying hard inwardly to digest.
A surprise, on the edge of Pompeii, is the Villa of the Mysteries, where the rich wall-paintings seem like a lost link to the Italian renaissance. We villa-hopped some more, until we felt sufficiently like dead Romans. Then we took the jetfoil to Ischia.
Green and fruitful, Ischia was once the culmination of the Grand Tour. It is bigger than Capri and less glamorous - no Gracie Fields, just Ibsen, William Walton and Alan Clark (it's his favourite foreign place). There are pretty wine-growing villages, and little towns with beaches where men fashion wicker lobster pots and women bellow at sandy children from second-floor windows. No opera could wish for a better set, or chorus.
Dominating the island is Mount Epomeo, dormant but still hissing. Its fumaroles fuelled the Roman showers which you can still use, and on some beaches (look for Marina dei Moronti), you can cook potatoes and eggs in the sand, or scorch your toes in the water.
Epomeo erupted about a century after Pompeii, destroying all life on the island. Then, a century ago, it rose again and killed 3,000, in 15 seconds. Now droves of arthritic Germans throng the thermal hotels, but Ischia absorbs them all, with space to spare.
We stayed in Il Monastero, a hotel converted from a ruined monastery, perched high on a rocky outcrop. Above the hotel stands the ruined Castello Aragonese, at which Nelson took some pot shots. Below, in the crypt, are ranks of stone seats where the corpses of nuns - Poor Clares - were left upright to ruminate upon their maker.
On the hotel's terrace overlooking the bay, we followed their example each evening, inspired by ice-cold limoncello. Ischia proves that Italians can shake off eruptions when they want to; and after a course of Pompeii it makes a perfect summer pudding.
* Il Monastero: 0039 81 992 435 .
