November 26, 1999, p.A20 
Vulcanologist was pioneer in the use of Landsat satellite images: Created new technology 
Peter Francis, who has died of a heart attack aged 54, was among the foremost vulcanologists of his time. His fascination with volcanoes began during an expedition to the Andes from Imperial College, in London, in 1970. On his return, he started a series of geochemical studies of Andean volcanic rocks to shed light on the physical processes by which volcanic deposits are generated. Struck by the vastness of the geologically unmapped Andes, he went on to lead the field in the use of images recorded by Landsat satellites. He was the first to recognize that the mountain group of Cerro Galan, in northwest Argentina, is of volcanic origin. He realized that the group was a "resurgent caldera" overlying a site once occupied by a 20-mile wide chamber of molten rock within the crust. To prove this, he led an Anglo-Argentinian expedition to Cerro Galan early in 1981. This received military support and was the last joint operation between Britain and Argentina before the Falklands War. The year before, Mount St. Helens in Washington had surprised experts by erupting with a sideways blast. Satellite images of other volcanoes enabled Mr. Francis to show that many had suffered similar collapses. He applied similar reasoning to spacecraft images to help to unravel the types of volcanic processes that had occurred on the planet Mars. He once spent three nights in a Peruvian jail after photographing some Mars-like sand dunes a little too close to a military base. As the 1980s wore on, a new generation of Landsat satellites came into service, showing finer detail and registering the short wavelength infra-red part of the spectrum. This enabled Mr. Francis to make the discovery in 1985 of an infra-red glow within the summit crater of the Lascar volcano in northern Chile. Until then, this volcano had not been recognized as active, but a series of eruptions soon ensued. Thus was born the modern era of eruption detection and early warning from satellites. Its development owed much to Mr. Francis. Peter William Francis was born on Dec. 28, 1944, in Mufulira, Northern Rhodesia (now Zambia), where he spent his early years. The family returned to England and Peter studied geology at Imperial College. He was awarded a doctorate in 1969. In later years, realizing that gases emitted from volcanoes carry vital information about what is going on inside, Mr. Francis concentrated on ways to measure the composition of these gases. He secured funds to develop a new kind of instrument called a Fourier Transform Infra-red Spectrometer, and led a European project on volcanic gases. Mr. Francis was the driving force behind the gas monitoring performed in Montserrat during the recent volcanic eruptions on the island. He had three tours of duty there as senior scientific advisor. He formed several fruitful collaborations with scientists in America and became deeply involved in the planning for NASA's Earth Observing System satellites. During the 1990s he successfully argued the case for a new Open University course in which the geological evolution of the Earth is taught in conjunction with the history of the atmosphere and biosphere. Mr. Francis became director of teaching for the Open University's Earth Sciences department in 1996, and in 1997 was awarded the title of professor of vulcanology. In America, he was a senior visiting scientist at the Lunar and Planetary Institute at Houston, Texas, from 1981 to 1989, and later a visiting professor in the Planetary Geosciences Division of the University of Hawaii. Peter Francis became known to a whole generation of geology and volcano enthusiasts through the publication of his Penguin book Volcanoes (1976). Away from his work he was an accomplished sailor, and collected antiquarian volcanic books and prints. In 1991, Peter Francis married Mary Brown (nee George), whom he had met a year earlier in Washington where she was working at the British Embassy.

'I thought we were all going to be cooked'. Volcano displaces 500,000. Quebecer joins Congolese in racing against the lava.
Finbarr O'Reilly 
A resident walks amid the wreckage of corrugated tin houses inundated by a lava flow in the Congolese city of Goma. Tens of thousands of displaced people returned to Goma yesterday, three days after an eruption of Mt. Nyiragongo destroyed nearly half the city.; See related story "Early return creates new crisis in goma" by Matthew Green on page A12.
KINSHASA - Trapped between the advancing flow of lava and thousands of desperate refugees as she fled Africa's most violent volcanic eruption in 25 years, Karine Morency of Trois- Rivieres, Que., was afraid she might not escape. ''I thought we were all going to be cooked,'' said Ms. Morency, 30. She works for the United Nations in the town of Goma in the eastern reaches of the Democratic Republic of Congo, formerly Zaire. This weekend the sky was glowing red over Goma, reflecting the fires sparked by tongues of molten lava that flowed through the town and poured into Lake Kivu, turning its fringes to coils of steam. ''Everyone was terrified for their lives -- people were jumping on our car and pulling off the mirrors and antennas,'' she said last night. ''I think at that point they were more dangerous than the volcano. There were soldiers with guns who could have just taken our car. Safely back with friends in the Congolese capital, Kinshasa, en route home to Canada, last night she danced to Abba, cheered ''I survived the volcano!'' and recounted her escape. More than half of Congo, including Goma, is controlled by rebel factions backed by either Rwanda or Uganda. ''Working in a place like Congo, you expect some heavy things to happen from time to time," Ms. Morency said. "But at least with a drunken soldier you can negotiate. You can't negotiate with an exploding volcano.'' Ms. Morency, who expects to be home in Trois-Rivieres tomorrow, lost most of her belongings -- souvenirs from other missions, photographs, CDs and much of her wardrobe -- and had time to grab only one change of clothes and a stick of deodorant. ''I can't really be too upset about losing my things because I can buy new stuff in Canada this week," she said. "The people there have lost everything.'' A 1977 eruption of Mt. Nyiragongo killed 2,000 people, but the death toll this week stood at about 40.

January 19, 2002, p.A16
Controversy erupts over France's fake volcano: 'The giscardoscope'
Hugh Schofield 

A watery sun breaks over the empty mountainside of the Auvergne, a crow caws, mist rises in wisps from the frost-laden earth -- and the sudden sound of a pile-driver interrupts the pastoral reverie. The finishing touches are being put on a project which next month becomes France's latest tourist extravaganza -- an attraction to rival EuroDisney. The name is Vulcania, and the theme: volcanoes. Ten years in the making, the park is the inspiration of Valery Giscard D'Estaing, the 75 year-old former French president who is also president of the Auvergne regional council. For him -- and for probably most inhabitants of this part of central France -- the project is a chance to promote the local economy, and to generate international interest in the Auvergne's principal attraction, its spectacular chain of extinct volcanoes. But others are less kind. They say it is a white elephant meant only to flatter the vanity of a man famous for his self-esteem. They say it has cost too much and will attract the wrong type of tourist. They have called it the Giscardoscope. The 60 hectare site, which opens on Feb. 21, is still strictly off-limits to visitors or journalists, but its promoters say it will be an "educational and recreational journey into volcanoes and the sciences of the Earth." Crowned by a 28-metre cone, two-thirds of Vulcania is actually underground, and visitors will descend a massive crater before enjoying a variety of simulations and visual presentations. There is a volcanic garden and a vibrating cinema with one of the world's biggest projectors. Mr. Giscard D'Estaing has made it clear he wants the site to become a world centre for vulcanologists, and extensive areas are also set aside for research. Situated among the volcanic peaks on a former military base 16 kilometres outside the city of Clermont-Ferrand, the project has been welcomed by local business interests, who are eager to arrest the region's gradual decline as a tourist destination. "Vulcania has given us a real boost," said Jean-Pierre Bara, mayor of the nearby town of Royat. "Of course we are delighted that it's opening." But despite the hype, there are serious questions about the project's cost, its purpose and its impact. The Green party has been doggedly opposed to Vulcania, arguing that it is perverse to construct a theme park on the subject of volcanoes in the centre of a natural park that actually contains them. "Auvergne's greatest asset is 'green' tourism," said Green party euro-deputy Danielle Auroi. "Our image is the purety of the volcanoes. Volvic mineral water and all that. So what's the point of building fake volcanoes in the middle of real ones?" Environmentalists question whether a remote and poorly connected area like the Auvergne can attract the half-a-million visitors Vulcania is banking on every year, and they fear there will be growing pressure to put up roads, hotels and restaurants to draw them in. There is also the cost. Originally budgeted at US$50-million, Vulcania has ended up at more than US$142-million -- most of it borne by the local tax-payer. What opponents enjoy most, though, is accusing Mr. Giscard D'Estaing of "folie de grandeur." "In France everyone down to the village mayor wants to leave his mark, and this is Giscard's," said Marcel Breugnot of the Movement to Save the Auvergne Volcanoes.

January 19, 2002, National Edition, p.A14
Molten rock covers town in Congo: Fast-flowing magma swallows the town of Goma, killing dozens and sparking a mass evacuation: Lava flows continue
Matthew Green
A Goma resident walks on hardened lava spewed by the 3,470-metre-tall Nyriagongo, one of the most active volcanoes in Africa. Red Cross staff said the neighbouring town of Gisenyi is also at risk. 
GOMA, DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF CONGO - Hundreds of thousands of panicked people fled the town of Goma yesterday after molten rock poured from the Nyiragongo volcano, killing dozens of villagers and engulfing everything in its way. Thousands more were thought to be marooned on a hill outside the town on the borders of the DRC and Rwanda, cut off by two flows of lava. United Nations officials warned that the Rwandan town of Gisenyi, where many had taken refuge, was also threatened by the volcano, which was continuing to erupt, albeit at a slower rate. The 3,470-metre-tall Nyiragongo suddenly erupted into life on Thursday, sending streams of molten lava down its steep slopes and through villages. The lava moved so fast many of the inhabitants did not have time to escape and were buried under the fiery onrush. It quickly rolled into Goma, home to about 300,000 people, and now covers large parts of the town. Yesterday, the United Nations said the eruption was continuing and could also threaten Gisenyi, which is only about 10 km from the volcano. There could also be underwater explosions and pollution if the magma, the lava flows, reach Lake Kivu. One eruption had opened up a one-km-long crack in the side of the volcano and three major lava flows were running through Goma and nearby villages. One was also heading for Gisenyi. Two staffers from the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) who managed a swift visit to Goma reported no reduction in the lava flow and seismic activity. "We can estimate that in the next few hours there will be maybe half-a-million people on the roads. It's a very likely, plausible estimate," said Juan Martinez, an ICRC spokesman. Mr. Martinez said many people had already fled toward Ruhengeri further to the east and Bukavu in the south, following directions given by local radio. "The problem we have now is that, given the uncertainty of the situation, we cannot bring people to Gisenyi if the town has to be evacuated tomorrow," Mr. Martinez said. The United Nations was now suggesting people head for the greater safety of Ruhengeri. Trudging through a fire-scarred landscape draped in smoke and mist, refugees clutching bedding, live chickens and water cans formed a tide of human misery. Some were travelling eastward into Rwanda, while others fled in boats to Bukavu on the lake's southern tip. "Fire is burning everything," said Lieutenant-Colonel Alain Pereira, a Senegalese officer with a UN observer force in Goma as part of efforts to end a civil war. "We were in the car park, then suddenly we felt our car rocking as if it was in the sea," he said, describing one of the tremors that rocked Goma yesterday morning. Nyiragongo, part of a chain of eight volcanoes lying along the borders of Uganda, Rwanda and the DRC, is one of Africa's most active and most deadly. Formed on a fault line connected to the African Rift Valley, it has erupted every decade in recent history. Because Nyiragongo's lava lake is high and the slopes of the volcano are steep, escaping lava flows at remarkable speeds. Legends in the area speak of an angry spirit trapped in the volcano and venting its wrath in eastern Congo. In Goma yesterday, only the wealthy district of Himbi appeared to have been spared. More hilly than the rest of the town, its slopes served as a barrier to a lava flow at least two km wide. As night fell yesterday, flames lit up the evening sky and fresh tremors shook the nearby hills and the lakeside port, now virtually reduced to a ghost town. Streams of lava two metres high continued to pour through the streets. Gaping holes wrought by intense heat opened in the ground and molten rock reduced roads and buildings to fiery ash. "The smell of sulphur is everywhere, there are tremors every 10 minutes," Desire Bukasa, a UN radio controller, said. "There are fissures opening up in the town which billow smoke. People are scared." In the DRC capital of Kinshasa, the Health Ministry asked the international community for immediate assistance, including shelters, blankets, drinking water and sanitation facilities. "This is going to be a human catastrophe," said an official of the UN contingent in Goma. "We have to find them shelter, put them up in camps. There's no electricity, no running water." Florian Westphal, a spokesman in Nairobi for the ICRC, quoted colleagues in Goma as saying access was a big obstacle in relief efforts. "Our warehouse and workshop garages with seven trucks have been destroyed. The airport is unuseable and the port in Goma has been destroyed by an explosion," he said. "The water company is no longer operational, two out of three pumping stations are out of order."

Early return creates new crisis in Goma: Agencies scramble to deliver aid as residents leave camps and flood into city devastated by volcano: Tremors continue Matthew Green National-Post National Post, January 21, 2002, National Edition, p.A12 Goma; Democratic-Republic-Of-Congo News; Restricted World Reuters 20020121 Short GOMA, DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF CONGO - Aid plans for up to half a million Congolese left homeless and hungry by a volcanic eruption were in disarray yesterday as most refugees returned to their ruined city to try to salvage homes amid the rubble. GOMA, DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF CONGO - Aid plans for up to half a million Congolese left homeless and hungry by a volcanic eruption were in disarray yesterday as most refugees returned to their ruined city to try to salvage homes amid the rubble. Ignoring the risk of further eruptions, tens of thousands streamed back into Goma yesterday, picking their way across swaths of still steaming lava to see what remained of their houses since a cascade of molten rock swept through the town on Thursday. Aid agencies said the unexpected mass return to the lakeside port of Goma had turned plans for food and water distribution on their head. "It seems that nearly all the displaced people have returned to Goma," Alison Preston of the World Vision agency said. "That has produced a whole new crisis, because we have half a million people returning to only a fraction of what Goma used to be. There is massive overcrowding, the streets were just thick with people." Two lava flows from 3,469-metre Mt. Nyiragongo and a third flow from a recently formed volcanic crater have destroyed about 40% of the city of 500,000 people. Relief workers had hoped to assemble most of the refugees in designated camps across the Rwandan border, where they said aid distribution would be easier and safer. But Goma's residents, braving violent earth tremors and carrying everything from babies to bicycles, made their way back over streets flooded with crusted lava, saying they would rather be weak and hungry at home than in Rwanda. "We didn't feel welcome in Rwanda. We spent two days without food, without water, they refused to change our money," said Chabani Shani, 42, one of the lucky ones to return and find his home still standing. The United Nations initially estimated 45 people were killed when Mt. Nyiragongo erupted on Thursday and said it was extremely concerned the volcano could erupt again. A strong earth tremor rattled Goma yesterday, underlining fears among volcanologists that more seismic activity was still possible, while fumes from the lava could pose a health hazard. Families trudging home through the wasteland strewn with blackened trees and twisted roofs were hungry, thirsty and weak and relief workers said water was a pressing concern. Desperately thirsty, many sought relief by drinking from Lake Kivu despite fears that lava pouring down its banks since Thursday may have poisoned its waters. "The big question since so many people are coming back is how are we going to deal with the water situation," said Jean Jacques Simon, a worker for the International Committee of the Red Cross in Goma. Water from the lake was being analyzed to assess the extent of the pollution. Meanwhile, a local aid agency was providing chlorine that would at least prevent cholera, but could have little impact on volcanic pollution. Aid agencies said they were reassessing their whole operations. "The issue now is we have got the food, blankets and water ready to go, but if we begin a distribution [in Goma] it would just be a disaster," Ms. Preston said. "We are putting into place a contingency plan, so we can begin distribution as soon as possible, that will be safe and will get to the right people." She said several hours of rain yesterday evening had further complicated Goma's predicament, turning mounds of dried lava into a grey slurry which emanated steam heavy with sulphur. Many people were still sleeping outdoors. Rubera Manywa, an official of the Rwandan-based rebel group that controls Goma, said it would be better for refugees to stay on the Rwandan side of the border until experts declare the volcano safe, but added they were free to choose. The Congolese government in Kinshasa, at war with the rebels since 1998, said it planned to send a delegation of ministers and aid worth US$1.5-million, in the first government visit to Goma since civil war divided the former Zaire. British and U.S. aid consignments were expected to arrive in the coming days, and Germany, France and former colonial power Belgium all promised money and supplies. But it seemed a modest effort in view of the scale of the emergency. Mt. Nyiragongo, rated one of Africa's most dangerous volcanoes, appeared to have stopped pumping lava yesterday, although fires continued to burn in some parts of the city. But despite the misery awaiting them in their home town, residents seemed determined to stay. Aime Okito, 20, walked for an hour from her waterless home in Goma to a tap by the border, but she was happy to return, despite the devastation. "Life over there is so bad," she said, nodding toward the Rwandan side of the border, before resuming her walk back towards streets filled with lava.

Looters killed in gasoline explosion: Scores die in Goma as lava ignites depot Adrian Blomfield and Tim Butcher
GOMA, Democratic Republic of Congo - Scores of looters were killed in the stricken Congolese town of Goma yesterday when a gasoline station exploded, apparently ignited by smouldering lava. A series of explosions sent fireballs high into the air and caused billows of dense black smoke that could be seen from kilometres away. The looters, some of whom had not eaten for four days after the eruption of Africa's most dangerous volcano, Mt. Nyiragongo, were trying to take the gasoline to sell for food. The station is located near one of the main lava flows, but the lava had cooled enough for people to walk across it. They were using plastic containers to retrieve the fuel and carry it away to be sold. Witnesses said as many as 100 people were inside the depot at the time and were engulfed by the flames. Adolphe Onusemba, President of rebel-held eastern Congo, said attempts to recover the bodies had been hampered by the fire. Periodic explosions sent huge fireballs 10 metres up. The smoke made it impossible to tell the exact loss of life even from close by. The latest disaster came as a series of earthquakes rocked the once-charming lakeside town. Western scientists are baffled by the shocks, which were more numerous and stronger than had been recorded in the region previously. At least one measured five on the Richter scale, sending people running out of homes they had just returned to after fleeing the river of lava that destroyed nearly half of Goma last week. Jacques Durieux, a French volcanologist flown to Goma by the United Nations, paid tribute to local experts who predicted last week's eruption four days before it happened. The monitoring system they used was destroyed in the eruption. "We have no explanation for the shocks and earthquakes although we think they are connected to last week's eruption," he said. "I spent a long time flying over the volcano today and I saw fractures on the lower slopes that were bigger than I have seen in this region." It appears that a series of earthquakes hit the region last week and at least two cracked the earth on the volcano, allowing its lava to flood out. Mr. Durieux could not rule out further and more devastating earthquakes in the region, which lies in the southern part of the Great Rift Valley, one of the Earth's fault lines between tectonic plates.

January 24, 2002, p.A14
Under Nyiragongo: Africa's largest volcanic eruption in 25 years is a reminder Congo is unstable politically, as well as geologically 
Finbarr O'Reilly
GOMA, Democratic Republic of Congo - From the air, the trail of destruction left by a torrent of lava that tore through the city of Goma last week looks like a smouldering black scar against the lush green landscape of eastern Congo. In the lava-clogged streets that were once Goma's downtown core, the overpowering stench of methane seeping from the earth only adds to the idea that, from up close, the flow looks like a river of animal dung. More than four-metres deep in places and up to half-a-kilometre wide, this petrifying river has engulfed houses, businesses, vehicles and perhaps a quarter of the city, much of which is still smouldering after last Thursday's eruption of Mt. Nyiragongo -- Africa's largest eruption in 25 years. Anyone who risks stepping on to the blackened crust is enveloped in painful waves of shimmering heat generated by the glowing magma still visible underfoot. "At least it's a dry heat," jokes one sweating journalist. In some parts, molten lava flows beneath the brittle, razor-sharp surface while frequent tremors cause the ground to shift underfoot. A misstep could cost the unwary a foot or worse, as several people have discovered. Throughout the day, locals in flip-flops pick their way carefully across the lava, which had split the city in two. Bulldozers have opened up a lava road between the previously separated east and west halves of Goma. Many have lost everything they owned, which often wasn't much in this Central African country, rent by a three-year-old civil war that has involved at least six countries. "Before, we were at war and didn't have much, but now we have even less," says Aldolphe Sutani, a 27-year-old taxi driver whose home was incinerated. "I never thought the lava would reach the town, but when it did, it was everyone for themselves. All I have left is the clothes I'm wearing." As with many such disasters, nature is selective, destroying one building and leaving others untouched. Ushu Mehta, an Indian merchant, lost the lava lottery. Her pharmaceutical store, Depot No Problem, was destroyed, along with US$150,000 worth of stock. A shop two doors away stands unscathed. Ms. Mehta approaches a United Nations delegation touring the disaster site and tries in vain to sell them some medical supplies she has stored in the Rwandan capital, Kigali, a two-hour drive away. As she pleads, her lips quiver and tears well up in her eyes, perhaps because she has lost more than most. It's a rare show of emotion among a population that deals with loss stoically. Everywhere, people are picking up the pieces, hauling jerry cans of water and carrying scraps of corrugated iron on their heads to wherever they might build a makeshift shelter to keep the chill of night at bay. When it comes, nighttime offers a Dantesque scene. Haze shrouds everything and glowing pockets of fire or molten lava cast ghostly shadows as people drift through the wreckage. But those whose homes and families escaped the destruction have reason to celebrate. At La Maitraise bar, a bamboo hut with white plastic chairs and tables, colourful beer banners, a banana-leaf roof and dirt floor, Congolese music pumps loudly from distorted speakers and warm beer flows until morning. "If people keep reliving the images of disaster in their heads it could cause all kinds of psychological trauma," says Commandant Celestine Kwitonda, a soldier in the Rwandan-backed rebel army that controls much of eastern Congo, including Goma. "When a town is destroyed like this, people need to amuse themselves to create a distraction. It's pure escapism, but it works." Leaving the bar, the commandant agrees to take a journalist along for a midnight cruise. Day and night, the soldiers with rubber boots and AK-47s patrol the streets for looters who pry open metal bars on store windows in an attempt to steal whatever they can. The military shot several people in incidents immediately after the eruption, a reminder the area is as unstable politically as it is geologically. Analysts fear the natural disaster may be used as an excuse to derail the peace process aimed at ending the civil war between Rwandan- and Ugandan-backed rebels and the central government, which is supported by Zimbabwe and Angola. But the soldiers have more pressing concerns and stop to relieve themselves. Their urine vapourizes with a hiss as it strikes hot lava. Throughout the night, the ground heaves and buildings sway in the frequent aftershocks. Lying in bed, it is hard to enjoy a comfortable night's sleep for fear of what could still happen. People feel powerless to escape the humbling force of nature should it choose to unleash another wave of destruction. Irrational fears are made rational by recent events and there is no real comfort in the words of volcanologists who say the worst is probably over, at least for now. The international community is doing what it can to deliver emergency aid to Goma and the Nkamira refugee camp 30 kilometres inside Rwanda, where hundreds of thousands fled after lava spewed from fissures in Mt. Nyiragongo's slopes. Many have since returned to their homes in search of food and water, which was lacking across the border. Businesses that weren't buried under tonnes of lava are doing great trade. In the comfortable little hotels that offer scenic views of the Virunga chain of volcanoes, armies of humanitarian workers chatter on cellphones and are busy "organizing." But many UN workers seem more interested in holding meetings and organizing massive meals for themselves than in actually getting anything done. In a city where thousands of people have not had proper food or water for days, one senior World Health Organization official complained to the waiter that his steak was overdone, even though he had been told "it's a bit difficult for us to work a la carte. The vegetables left with the lava." Some aid is trickling through, but help is coming too slowly for frustrated residents who occasionally take their anger out on journalists. One photographer was stoned, others have been shouted at. But many locals smile warmly at foreigners as they show them around what is left of their city. There is the risk of additional eruptions, cholera and other outbreaks of disease, but a constant refrain among the inhabitants is that they would rather die on their own scorched soil than in the enemy territory of Rwanda. "We'd rather suffer at home than here," says Eric Mwakilongo, a 30-year-old refugee at the Nkamira camp. "This is not our place." Despite the dramatic aftermath and the lives it has ruined, the disaster isn't nearly as bad as first feared. Only 25% of the town has been destroyed, rather than 85%, although much of the commercial district is gone. The number of damaged homes is likely to be closer to 100,000, rather than 250,000, and 15 of the 20 clinics run by non-governmental organizations survived the eruption. Electricity and water are running sporadically in most neighbourhoods. "We will rebuild the town and tourism will slowly come back," says one hotel owner who watched lava flow between his home and his business, leaving both untouched. "The climate here is cool and people will come back again to see the volcano, Lake Kivu and the mountain gorillas. Look what the international community has done for Kabul and for Sarajevo. With a minimum of will, we could get things done here, too." A 1977 eruption of Mt. Nyiragongo killed 2,000 people, but the estimated death toll this week stood at 40. Witnesses said another 80 people were killed in a fuel dump explosion on Monday, but the figure was difficult to confirm. A week after the eruption, the story is drifting from the headlines and journalists are leaving the residents of Goma to the quiet tasks of their difficult lives, made even more difficult by a seismic twist of fate. As they go about rebuilding, they remain ever mindful of the restless giant looming above town. It may be another 25 years or more before the next major eruption. Or it may not.

March 26, 2001, p.A3
War of words erupts over tragedy. Galeras volcano disaster. Two authors dispute blame for expedition that left nine dead ; Row erupts over volcano tragedy. Author attacks scientist who led Galeras expedition. Two upcoming books dispute blame for volcanic experiment that left nine dead
Michael Higgins
Author Victoria Bruce  claims Stanley Williams a volcanologist, failed to take safety precautions during the 1993 Galeras expedition. Bruce and Williams give different accounts of the tragedy in two books. 
At 1.43 p.m. on Jan. 14, 1993, the Galeras volcano in southern Colombia erupted killing six scientists and three local hikers. At 1.43 p.m. on Jan. 14, 1993, the Galeras volcano in southern Colombia erupted killing six scientists and three local hikers. The scientists were part of a team led by renowned volcanologist Professor Stanley Williams and were conducting experiments when they were blown apart by the powerful blast. The three hikers, a father, his son and his son's friend, had gone up the volcano to see the scientists work. Next month, a new book launches a scathing attack on Mr. Williams and claims the tragedy could have been avoided. Author Victoria Bruce, a 34-year-old former science writer for NASA with a master's degree in geology, alleges Mr. Williams should have cancelled the expedition and also failed to enforce safety precautions that could have saved lives. But in his defence, Mr. Williams, an Arizona State University professor who also has a book about the tragedy coming out next month, says the allegations are nothing more than Monday-morning quarterbacking. Both authors received advances in the half-million dollar range; Ms. Bruce for the HarperCollins book No Apparent Danger and Mr. Williams for Surviving Galeras (Houghton Mifflin). Mr. Williams's team had arrived the morning of Jan. 14 and had descended into Galeras's crater. That afternoon, the volcano erupted sending black ash two miles up into the air. The publicity for Ms. Bruce's book claims it would show "how clashing cultures and scientific arrogance resulted in tragic and unnecessary loss of life." Ms. Bruce says on the Web site promoting her book: "At the time Williams led the expedition into the volcano, Galeras was showing signs of activity that appeared as long screw shaped signals on the monitoring equipment. (The Colombians call these "tornillos.") Similar signals had preceded an eruption of Galeras six months before. So there was data warning against the trip. And the night before the expedition, Colombian scientists voiced their concern about this data to Williams. But he didn't share this information with any of the scientists who he led into the crater the next day. "At the very least, it was Williams's responsibility to let the others know that there were dangerous signs. He didn't do that." Ms. Bruce is also scathing of the safety precautions. "Williams failed to take even the most basic safety precautions. As the leader of the trip, Williams was responsible for coming up with a safety plan in the event of emergency. He didn't do that. He also didn't instruct any of the group to bring safety gear on the expedition, and most of them went into the volcano without hard hats or adequate gas masks. They just hiked into an active volcano wearing Gore-Tex and synthetic fleece-garments that melted instantly when the victims were hit with super hot rocks from the eruption, causing third degree burns on most of the survivors. Also, several of the injuries and fatalities-including the skull fracture that Williams received-were caused by blows to the head that could possibly have been prevented by wearing helmets. One scientist said that the expedition was run like a 'Sunday walk in the park.' " Mr. Williams answers many of the criticisms on the Houghton Mifflin Web site advertising his book. "There is general agreement among geologists that we couldn't have known Galeras would blow when it did," Mr. Williams says. "In the days and hours before the eruption, Galeras showed none of the classic signs that a volcano is poised to blow. Galeras erupted four more times in 1993 before scientists eventually discovered that its blasts are preceded by small numbers of tornillos -- weak, long-lasting earth tremors that etch a screw-shaped pattern on a seismograph (tornillo is Spanish for screw). To our knowledge, Galeras is the only volcano in the world whose eruptions are preceded by so few tornillos." As for safety equipment Mr. Williams says: "Many of my colleagues that day had at least as much experience on active volcanoes as I did, so I trusted them to use their own judgment. Of the sixteen scientists on Galeras, only two chose to wear protective gear. This might seem surprising in retrospect, but keep in mind a couple of facts. At that time it simply wasn't standard practice for volcanologists to use lots of safety gear, except for gas masks, which many of us brought with us that day. "Given the massive trauma the dead scientists sustained at Galeras, I'm sure that hardhats and fire-retardant suits would not have saved a single life." Pulitzer Prize-nominated journalist Fen Montaigne, who co-wrote the book with Mr. Williams, claims: "There are people in volcanology who do not like Stanley Williams. Clearly, word got around that he got a whopping advance for this book. I think ... from the beginning [Bruce] was trying to prove that Stan was a bad scientist, that Stan recklessly led people to their deaths. ... She marshalled her facts in a prosecutorial war against Stan. But she doesn't make her case." Ms. Bruce's agent, Peter McGuigan, claims the accusation of finger-pointing is unwarranted. "The book is not about, 'Let's get Stan Williams,' " he says.

May 5, 2001, Toronto Edition, p.G4
Former death zone a hot draw for tourists: Mount Pinatubo
Jim Gomez
THE PHILIPPINES - Nearly 10 years after Mount Pinatubo erupted in one of the past century's most violent volcanic events, tourists are trickling back to marvel at the devastation that killed hundreds and wiped out the Philippines' main rice-producing region. "This isn't really for the faint-hearted," says Mike Benneth of Dreamtreks, a small tour agency in Angeles City, near Pinatubo. "We cater to people with a taste for adventure." Dreamtreks and a few small travel firms started escorting the three-hour climb up the 1,445-metre volcano in 1997 on the least treacherous of five routes. Dreamtreks' Web site includes photos of tourists trekking the volcano's slope and dipping into the crater's turquoise-blue waters. An overnight tour costs US$70 per person, including food, bottled water, tents, sleeping bags, guides and transportation. From the starting point in the village of Santa Juliana, visitors take a bumpy ride in 4x4 jeeps across the dusty expanse of Crow Valley to a campsite, where the hike begins. As the country's tourism industry recovers, the Philippines are now seeing up to 1,000 visitors a month, especially during the hot months from March to May. "This place has a big potential but it hasn't been exposed much," says Danny Cerdena, a travel agency owner who includes the volcano among his company's destinations. Pinatubo, about 90 kilometres north of Manila, exploded in June, 1991, after a 500-year slumber. It dumped billions of tonnes of volcanic debris on three provinces, erasing entire farm communities and altering the world's climate. Pinatubo's eruptions were so massive that its top was blown away, reducing its height by 300 metres, forming a crater lake. During the rainy season, roughly from June to October, climbing is forbidden as the volcanic debris on its slopes fall down in deadly avalanches. Since Pinatubo is classed as one of the country's 22 active volcanoes, Mr. Benneth checks with the Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology before every climb. Guy Hilbero, a tourism officer, was the first to climb Pinatubo, two years after the eruption. He led a few friends and outsiders on treks to the crater and this out-of-this-world place sculpted by fire, water and wind. He and others are hoping to have Pinatubo declared an ancestral domain of Aeta natives. That would protect it from land speculators who have arrived with the tourists. There also are incidents of opportunistic villagers preying on outsiders. In Santa Juliana, a sign outside a visitors' registry centre reads: "Please beware of fake gold bars! There is no such thing." The trail up the volcano from Santa Juliana rises so gently most of the way that the only indications of ascent are gushing brooks; some hot enough to boil eggs. On a recent climb, Hilbero and his entourage broke into yells when they first glimpsed the sky-blue crater lake behind the rim. When the euphoria subsided, some swam in the lake. Others dozed off their exhaustion during the two-hour stay in the crater. IF YOU GO: When to go The climbing seasons are January to May, shortly before the rainy season starts and October to December. What to wear Light, casual clothes are recommended for the trek due to hot, humid weather around Pinatubo. What to bring A wide-brimmed hat and sun-block lotion are musts. On the Web Dreamtreks is at http://www.dream treks.com. The Philippine Institute of Volcanology is at http://www.phivolcs.dost. gov.ph.

May 10, 2001, p.A17
Bulge in Oregon may be volcanic: Four years' growth 
PORTLAND, Ore. - A large bulge in the Earth's crust has developed during the last four years near volcanoes in central Oregon but it is not clear whether it could mean a volcanic eruption any time soon, geologists said this week. The bulge -- 15 to 20 kilometres across and about 10 centimetres high -- was detected by satellite radar, said Willie Scott, a scientist at the United States Geological Survey's volcano lab in Vancouver, Wash. "Because it's a volcanic area and there's been a long history of volcanic activity in that part of the Cascades, it's possible it might be magma, or molten rock, moving deep underground," Scott said. The bulge is located near the Three Sisters, a trio of volcanoes at the centre of the Cascade Range in Oregon. The last big eruption in the Pacific Northwest occurred in May, 1980, when Mount St. Helens blasted off about 400 metres of its top. The uplift in Central Oregon is too broad and low to be noticed from the ground. The USGS scientists discovered the bulge through use of a relatively new technique called satellite radar interferometry, which uses satellite data to create images of the Earth's surface. Images taken at different times can be used to detect changes of even a few centimetres in the elevation of the ground. Scientists have looked across the West for signs of bulges but this is the first prominent change on record using this technique. "There's nothing as striking as this one," Scott said. "This is quite a prominent uplift. "But there's nothing right now that makes us think there's an imminent danger" of an eruption, he added. In addition to accelerating uplift, other indicators of an eruption would include earthquakes -- typically swarms of small quakes generated by rock fracturing as magma moves upward -- and large emissions of volcanic gases, such as carbon dioxide. The Cascades, which run from the California border into British Columbia, contain a number of volcanic peaks. Mount Hood, Oregon's highest mountain, is believed to have erupted just before the Lewis and Clark expedition reached the mouth of the Columbia River in 1805. About 7,000 years ago, Mount Mazama exploded south of Bend in an enormous explosion that left behind a caldera that now holds Crater Lake.

July 23, 2001, p.A10
Lava edges closer to Sicilian village. Residents near Mount Etna 'praying to God'.
NICOLOSI, Sicily - Residents of this Sicilian village perched on the slopes of Mount Etna came to church yesterday to pray for help as tongues of molten lava edged ever closer toward them. The seething magma from the mountain, Europe's highest and most active volcano, is within four kilometres of the first houses of the community of about 5,000. The lava has moved around two kilometres in the past four days, but has slowed in the last 48 hours and is heading for a shallow basin above Nicolosi, which may pool and slow its flow. Five fissures have opened up in the mountain and are spitting out lava. Security forces used earth movers to make mud and dirt barricades to divert the flow and were ready to evacuate Nicolosi if necessary. A state of emergency was declared on Thursday, which allows the civil protection agency to call on the army for help if needed. The lava flow, 400 metres across at its widest, has damaged several chairlifts dotted over the volcano, which is also a popular ski resort. Tourism representatives have said the magma is so hot it is unlikely any snow will settle this winter. The mountain, which has been active for centuries, rumbled into life again in mid-June and has been gushing smoke and ash for more than a week. On Wednesday, a new fissure cracked open at a height of 2,100 metres, sending fresh lava creeping down the volcano's southern slope. Hundreds of people have headed to Etna to watch the eruption, but officials have urged them to stay away. The last time Etna posed a threat was in 1992 when lava streams headed toward Zafferana, a town of 7,000 crouched on the mountain's lower slopes. The Italian military had to use controlled explosions to divert the flow.

July 25, 2001, p.A10
Lava flow on Mount Etna 'shows signs of fatigue'. Village in volcano's path prays for safety.
NICOLOSI, Sicily - A village on Mount Etna that feared being engulfed in a river of lava had its prayers answered yesterday as the magma flow slowed. But civil protection officials said the situation on the mountain, which has been spewing lava for a week, could change quickly and the respite could be short-lived. "The situation is more positive and encouraging compared to yesterday," Franco Barberi, national head of the civil protection department, told a news conference. He said two fissures at high altitudes had closed and there was reduced activity on the southeast slopes of Etna, Europe's largest and most active volcano. During the night, a snaking river of lava remained steady at an altitude of about 1,065 metres. "The lava shows signs of fatigue. It is broadening out and becoming more dense," said Calogero Murgia, a civil protection official. The lava flow approaching the village of Nicolosi slowed as it pooled in a shallow basin about four kilometres above, seemingly in answer to prayers of the villagers, who had asked God to stop or divert the lava during a Sunday procession. Legend has it that in 1886 the village was spared from a threatening lava flow after the local archbishop brandished a statue of St. Anthony before it. A new fissure opened Monday on the eastern side of the volcano, acting as a natural safety valve that weakened the main lava flow downhill threatening Nicolosi.

September 6, 2001, p.A1
Mount Pinatubo's crater to be drained: Engineers hope canal will avert natural disaster 
Jason Gutierrez 
ON PINATUBO VOLCANO, Philippines - Thick fog wrapped the crater of this infamous Philippine volcano yesterday as tribesmen completed excavation work on an engineering project aimed at preventing a natural disaster. Ninety Aeta tribesmen hurriedly erected sandbags on one end of a 70-metre canal as the temperature dropped and grey fog descended on the work site in late afternoon, reducing visibility to a few metres. Volcanologists plan to breach the crater wall and bleed 24 million cubic metres of water at 7 a.m. this morning, or about 11% of the volume that has accumulated in the past decade. They hope to reduce the possibility of the swollen crater lake bursting its walls and burying up to 44,000 people in watery volcanic debris in the town of Botolan to the west. "We are all excited that it will go well, but anxious that it won't go as planned," government volcanologist Mariton Bornas said as two rubber boats ferried the workers across the 2.5-kilometre- wide lake back to their base camp to the northeast. "We have no assurance that the entire crater wall will not collapse," added crew chief Nelson Pangilinan, an Aeta chieftain. Excavation work was completed by 90 tribesmen working around the clock in rotating eight-hour shifts from Aug. 26. Some members of the crew had been at the site for three weeks for preparatory work. They used only picks, shovels and wheelbarrows because there are no roads to the project site, situated 860 metres above sea level. Their base camp can only be approached on foot, after a three-hour hike across a moon-like grey wasteland of caked volcanic debris called Crow Valley. The five-metre wide canal spills into the Bucao-Maraunot river toward the South China Sea about 50 kilometres to the north-west, on the west coast of the island of Luzon. About 40,000 residents of Botolan began leaving the area yesterday to avoid a possible mud avalanche should the canal operation go awry. The crater lake started to fill soon after a huge eruption in 1991 and now holds about 210 million cubic metres of water. Foreign volcanologists have long warned of a potential catastrophe after an eruption because of the trapped water that was gradually eroding the crater wall. But it was only last month, as the water level rose close to the rim during the rainy season, that the government decided to act. Workers are paid the equivalent of $7.60 a day, good money for the Aetas. "We are confident that the Lord Mallari will safeguard us," Mr. Pangilinan said, referring to the Aetas' supreme deity.

February 29, 2000, p.A14
Storm traps volcano gawkers
Jon Svanur Johannsson
REYKJAVIK, Iceland - Seven people reported missing after a volcano eruption, including four who helped rescue people stranded in their cars en route to see the spectacle, were found yesterday. Thousands of Reykjavik residents set off on Sunday to drive 120 kilometres east to witness the eruption of Mount Hekla, the country's most active volcano. Civil emergency services warned drivers not to go too near the volcano as it spewed lava from a seven-kilometre-long fissure into a deserted plain and emitted a column of ash up to six kilometres high. However, many curious onlookers ignored the advice and weather turned wintery. Up to 2,000 people were trapped in their cars by snow storms and had to wait up to 16 hours for rescue teams. Overnight, trucks helped ferry those trapped in their cars to the nearby town of Thorlakhofm or back to Reykjavik. Icelandic media said it was the most extensive rescue operation in the country since 5,000 people on the remote Vestmannaeyjar islands off the south coast had to abandon their homes in a volcanic eruption in January, 1973. Ragnar Stefansson, a geophysicist from the Icelandic Meteorological Office, said most people probably spent the night on the road in vain as the poor weather made it almost impossible to see the volcano. "On Sunday, the wind changed and started blowing to the east, directing the ash toward Europe. However, we have not received any news of the ash hitting Europe as by the time the wind changed, the power of the eruption had decreased considerably," the meteorologist added. "The force is at most no more than one-tenth of what it was in the beginning." Even though the eruption at Hekla, one of Europe's highest volcanoes at 1,491 metres, had calmed considerably yesterday, geologists said the activity could continue for about a month. That was the case when Hekla last erupted in 1991. There were major eruptions in 1510, 1693, 1766, 1845 and 1947. In the Middle Ages, the volcano was known as the "Gateway to Hell," and its rumblings were believed to be the screams of the tormented.

February 25, 2000, p.A14
30,000 flee volcano's deadly rivers of fire. Philippines' Mayon erupts. Burning rocks and ash darken sky over central province.
Enrique de Castro 
LEGAZPI, Philippines - One of the Philippines' deadliest volcanoes erupted yesterday, sending rivers of fire surging down its slopes, darkening towns with ash falls and forcing about 30,000 people to flee, officials said. The Mayon volcano in the central Philippines, which has been steadily building in activity since it reawakened last summer, unleashed 14 separate eruptions throughout the day. No casualties had yet been reported. The volcano, 330 kilometres southeast of Manila, hurled burning rocks and ash 10 kilometres into the sky. Some of the volcanic material fell back on to the mountain's slopes to gather in superheated torrents as hot as 900 C that roared downhill at about 80 km/h, volcanologists said. Joseph Estrada, the president, was to have flown to affected areas but cancelled the trip after the airport in the provincial capital of Legazpi was forced to close due to the airborne rocks and ash. The fiercest of the eruptions, occurring at mid-morning, threw up a mushroom cloud of ash that blotted out the sun, casting foothill towns into darkness, relief officials said. "I was cooking when the sky suddenly turned dark," said Luz Perela, who fled her home in Mayon's foothills after the fireworks began. "I could not see my surroundings. I just abandoned my cooking and ran outside with my children. It was so scary ... that's why we are here," Ms. Perela said while waiting for a government truck to take her to a refugee centre 10 kilometres from Mayon. As evening fell, rains began pelting the volcano and volcanologists warned of possible mudflows down Mayon's flanks if the rains intensified. "We have raised the alert to the maximum level of five, meaning a hazardous eruption is in progress," said Raymundo Punongbayan, chief of the Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology. Waves of tremors shook Mayon as it began erupting early yesterday, unleashing rumbling sounds heard by residents as far away as Legazpi, 11 kilometres from the crater. "It's like a stampede of horses," a Legazpi resident said of the noises. Others compared the sounds to the booming of cannon. Relief agencies said a patient at a local hospital may have died of a heart attack amid the volcano's thunderous rumblings. Relief officials used military vehicles and dump trucks to ferry people from their villages to evacuation centres. Provincial officers said about 5,000 people living on Mayon's slopes had been evacuated before the eruption but by nightfall yesterday, refugee centres had swelled with more than 29,000 evacuees. Mayon has a history of violent eruptions, the worst occurring in 1814 when flaming ash killed some 1,200 people. It killed 77 villagers in its last major eruption in 1993. Located in rice-and coconut-growing Albay province, the 2,460-metre Mayon is one of 22 active volcanoes in the Philippines. While farmers hauled away their meagre possessions, tourists clicked cameras at the spectacular display. Ed de Leon, director of the Philippine Information Agency, said hotels in Legazpi had reported a 50% increase in room occupancy as tourists poured in to witness Mayon's awesome fury. On Wednesday night, spectators armed with cameras and video recorders gaped as glowing boulders rolled down the peak, breaking into small luminous pieces as they snaked down a deep gully on the volcano's southeastern slope. Like a gigantic cauldron, the crater glowed in a sea of darkness. "It was spectacular," Mr. de Leon said.

February 29, 2000, p.A14
Evacuees scurry from Mayon's ire
Mynardo Macaraig 
LEGASPI, Philippines - The Mayon volcano roared with its strongest eruptions yesterday as hungry villagers swamped evacuation camps for free meals offered to tens of thousands of others genuinely displaced by the disaster. A plume of volcanic ash shot seven kilometres into the air as smouldering boulders flew skyward and lava gushed from the glowing crater in Albay province, 217 kilometres southeast of Manila, the capital. "This is stronger than Feb. 24," said volcanologist Ted Sandoval, referring to the volcano's initial blast last week. Other scientists warned a bigger blast could be on the way. "This is not yet the big one," said Ernesto Corpuz, chief of the eruption prediction division of the Philippine Institute of Vulcanology & Seismology. By Saturday night, nearly 48,000 people had taken shelter in schools, tents and other government buildings around the cone-shaped mountain, even though only 32,000 had been asked to move because of threats of lava flows, rocks and poisonous gases. Thousands of people, many wearing hoods and dust masks because of the sulphur-smelling yellow volcanic ash, fled their homes in villages outside the declared danger zone on foot and by trucks. Authorities said the number of evacuees could swell to 60,000 and overwhelm meagre food supplies. Experts appealed on radio for people not to flee because of ash falls, saying these could reach them in evacuation centres anyway. But mingling with genuine refugees from the eruptions are thousands seeking temporary relief from massive poverty, officials said. "We have received reports that some are just flocking to the evacuation centres to receive some relief goods," Alberto Romualdez, the health secretary, told radio station DZRH in Manila. "That is OK with us because these people are needy." Jose Salceda, a congressman who represents Albay in the House of Representatives, said the eruption has highlighted massive poverty in the area, which he blamed on a "systemic neglect" by the government. The Bicol region, which includes Albay, has the Philippines' highest unemployment rate, 45.1%, compared with a national average of 22.1%. It is also the second-poorest region, with 50.1% of residents living below the poverty threshold. Among the economic evacuees was a group of villagers from Busay, outside the danger zone, who crammed into a refrigerated van used to transport frozen chicken. "It's just too scary," said vendor Madel Lucila, 33, as she fled. Florentina Arenda, 52, a housewife and mother of three who fled Padang, also outside the declared danger zone, said mudflows threatened her home. "We are not going to risk our lives there," she said. The mountain, a top tourist draw in the region, started erupting on Thursday after months of increased volcanic tremors. There were no casualties in the volcano's 47th eruption since the 17th century. It was the first since 1993 when it killed 78 people who were tending farms on its lower slopes.

March 22, 2000, p.A14
MANILA - Overweight police in the northern Philippines have been ordered to climb Mount Pinatubo volcano once a month as part of a physical fitness campaign. Roberto Calinisan, a police chief in Central Luzon, said yesterday the rotund officers will make the climb on April 4 and once a month thereafter until June, when the rainy season begins. He said more than 100 officers from Pampanga province, north of Manila, will join the exercise. Many Philippine police are overweight, prompting national Police Chief Panfilo Lacson to launch a physical fitness campaign in early March. He said those whose waists exceed 34 inches will be required to jog or do push-ups for six months, and could face dismissal if they don't slim down. The 2 1/2-hour trek to Pinatubo's summit, the location of a scenic lake, has become a popular activity for foreign and local tourists. Chief Calinisan said he would lead the men who have to make the trek. "This is not going to be a picnic," he said. "We will bring food but not sumptuous meals, because it will just defeat the purpose." Pinatubo, 88 kilometres north of Manila, exploded in June, 1991, in one of the 20th century's most violent volcanic eruptions. This dumped billions of tons of volcanic debris on three provinces, erasing entire communities from the map and destroying many farms. The eruptions were so massive that they blew off the top of the volcano, reducing its height by 300 metres to 1,450 metres. During the rainy season, the volcanic debris on its slopes and in river channels become deadly avalanches.

Officials said Abuta's roads were covered in 20 centimetres of ash by Saturday. But Mount Usu has shown little sign of developing into the most feared scenario -- the volcano blowing its top and spraying lava, hot gas and stones into the towns below. Fujio Watanabe, 76, speaking by telephone, praised the authorities' efficiency since he moved into a shelter on Wednesday with his 66-year-old wife Chiyoko. "Abuta town has given us a mask and a package of daily necessity goods such as a bottle of water, clothes, towels and soap. I am very impressed by the government's swift work," said Mr. Watanabe.

April 28, 2000, p.E13
Driving Kilauea's lava highway. Crater Rim Drive gives motorists a circle tour of the birthplace of the Big Island of Hawaii. Hawaiian hot spot.
Ted Davis
It's a safe bet that none of us will ever drive on any surface other than that of planet Earth, but a very good extraterrestrial substitute can be had by traversing by road the eerie landscape of one of the world's most continuously active volcanoes. The Crater Rim Drive and Chain of Craters Road wind their way through a sea of jagged black lava that has been deposited by the Kilauea Volcano in the shadow of towering Mauna Loa, on the Big Island of Hawaii. The relative geothermal silence at the actual cone of Kilauea has allowed the construction of a visitors centre that is well stocked with maps of hiking trails in the area, as well as the roads themselves. But the steaming, sulphurous vents of the Kilauea caldera and spectacular ongoing eruptions of the lava through rifts at the water's edge leave no doubt that Kilauea is very much alive, and is still in the midst of forming the island. The Big Island is officially named Hawaii, but this simple, English language moniker is used to avoid confusion with the title of the state, which actually comprises six main islands. And it is indeed big, easily dwarfing the other five, with a land mass more than twice the size of Kauai, Maui, Lanai, Molokai and the popular Oahu combined. The southern-most island in the Hawaiian chain, the Big Island is also the most youthful, in geological terms. While the other islands are known for their lush vegetation and white sand beaches, the Big Island is distinguished by black lava beaches and vast ranch lands in its northeastern reaches, as well as more typical South Pacific flora. Two snow-capped volcanoes -- Mauna Loa and Mauna Kea -- formed the island, and dominate the view from most points. They rise to more than 3,960 metres, while Kilauea reaches about 1,220 metres. But for a ringside seat to volcanic action, Kilauea is the place to be. From the town of Hilo, on the Big Island's northeastern coast, Kilauea is about 48 kilometres southwest in a gradual climb on Route 11 to the gateway of Volcanoes National Park. After paying a fee of $5 (US) per car, you enter the park and make a quick right turn on to Crater Rim Drive, which takes you to the visitors centre. Check out the volcano displays and watch the short film on eruptions before setting out to circle the Kilauea Caldera on the 12-kilometre Crater Rim Drive loop road. Observation areas provide an opportunity to watch the steaming craters within the caldera, and short hikes have been organized to the lava fields. After making the loop, a right turn starts the 32-kilometre Chain of Craters Road toward the sea, and en route passes through the moon-like lava fields caused by volcanic rifts dating from 1969 to 1974. The jagged black fields stretch to the horizon in all directions. Hikers are advised to prepare for "a long, hot hike over uneven terrain." When the road reaches the Pacific coast, it bends left and runs parallel to the water's edge near some spectacular headlands, until reaching an abrupt end where more recent lava flow engulfed the pavement. Here, lines of cars crowd both sides of the road leading back from the dead end, and people walk up a small lava rock rise to get a glimpse of the most active and photographed rift, located about three kilometres away. A telescope is the best way to see the fire show at this distance, and most people time their arrival for the early evening, when the colourful explosions are best seen. For a better view, hiking shoes, long pants and water will be necessary, as the walk through the lava shield and back is about a four-hour trek. Bring a long lens for your camera, and heed the park warnings that "frequent explosions" near the rift "can rip open the ground and throw rocks in all directions." The much older Mauna Loa and Mauna Kea volcanoes that form-ed the Big Island aren't very accessible by vehicle, although there is an east-west saddle road that straddles the highlands between the two mountains. If your rental car or SUV is approved for the job, then drive on the saddle road to see both mountains up close. Mauna Kea has nine astronomical observatories at its summit, owing to the extremely clear, calm weather up there. Intrepid vacationers can drive to the information station at the Onizuka Center for International Astronomy after calling 808-961-2180 to check for any weather restrictions. The town of Hilo is the most convenient centre from which to explore the northeast side of the island, and has a lot of local history to fill a day. It thrived as a whaling port in the 1800s, and was battered by tsunami waves in 1946 and 1960. The park on Hilo's waterfront is the site of commercial buildings and homes destroyed by the waves.

December 21, 2000, National Edition, p.A15
Popo lets off some steam: Many volcanoes aren't too predictable. 'They're like people,' says one scientist. 'They'll have a fit of temper and you don't really expect it.' But Popocatepetl is different.
Patchen Barss 
On Monday, the second highest mountain in Mexico cut way back on its smoking. Popocatepetl, an active volcano about 60 kilometres east of Mexico City, cut down from about 200 giant puffs of steam and ash per day to just 10. This was not a good sign. "Volcanoes aren't too predictable," said Mark Stasiuk, a volcanologist at the Canadian Geologic Survey. "They're like people: They'll have a fit of anger and you don't really expect it." Popocatepetl's outbursts, though, are easier to predict than many volcanoes', as geologists have been monitoring its behaviour for decades. They know that, as with many people, the reduction in smoking meant an explosion was imminent. To understand why Popocatepetl on Tuesday started hurling 1.5-metre chunks of molten rock half a kilometre in the air and red hot cinders two km high, it's informative to examine why the mountain started smoking in the first place. The volcano's smoking problem (really a steaming problem) has deep origins, starting about 50 km below the surface, where the suboceanic Cocos Plate is sliding under the North American continental plate, a process known as subduction. As the Cocos Plate subducts, it takes a bit of the Pacific Ocean with it. "As it goes down, it releases that water to the rock above it," said Stasiuk. "Water has a strong tendency to reduce the melting temperature of rock." This molten rock, or magma, is less dense than the surrounding material, so it becomes buoyant and tends to rise through fissures in the crust. It works its way up to a depth of 10 or 15 km, where its density matches that of the surrounding solid rock. When it has found equilibrium, the magma starts to cool. "Once the stuff gets into a magma chamber it solidifies slowly," said Stasiuk. "While solidifying, certain crystals form dense crystals that allow the remaining material to get lighter and more buoyant. The early crystals tend to be devoid of any water. As they form, they concentrate water in the remaining molten rock. The water starts to form steam bubbles that make a bit of a froth. If the pressure gets high enough, it causes cracks in the magma chamber." Depending on the weaknesses in the rock, magma can shoot in any direction. If it goes sideways, it can cause minor earthquakes. If it moves upwards, though, it sets off eruption warning signals. "These things don't start instantaneously. The stuff has to crack the rocks, then make its way up that crack -- we're talking 10 km and it doesn't ooze very quickly," said Stasiuk. "In the weeks or months beforehand, you get lots of warnings. When a rock cracks you get little earthquakes. And because there's stuff pushing its way up, the ground tends to swell. You can monitor these things and see the stuff is getting closer to the surface." As the magma gets closer to the surface, it heats the rainwater that saturates the top few metres of the crust, causing the plumes of steam and ash that foretell an eruption. Many volcanoes have individualized patterns for how they react to such pressure. Popocatepetl initially finds release by puffing away, but eventually starts to hold everything in. Then, thousand-degree lava bursts through the surface, creating spectacular images for well-prepared observers. But, impressive though such an eruption is, Popocatepetl's current violence is small potatoes, geologically speaking. On the Volcanic Explosivity Index, a rough system akin to the Richter Scale used for measuring earthquake intensity, the eruption rates a 2 (explosive) on a scale from 0 (non-explosive) to 8 (mega-colossal). "Popo has had some quite large eruptions but they're few and far between," said Stasiuk. That's because Popocatepetl is one mountain that usually knows how to let off steam before the pressure gets too great.

February 10, 1999, p.A17
Sounding out a volcanic disaster. The collapse of volcanic islands off the west coast of Africa will inevitably cause giant tidal waves, one of which could threaten Florida thousands of years in the future -- or much sooner.
Aisling Irwin
The night the Atlantic island of Fogo erupted, its flank split open as though cut by a knife. Fire roared from a line of fissures as lava bombs the size of small buses were catapulted 455 metres away. By morning a cloud of ash stretched five kilometres into the sky. Nearly four years later, just a gentle wisp of smoke rises from the vent and villagers have returned to live in the crater. But Fogo -- one of the Cape Verde islands, 800 kilometres west of the African country of Senegal -- still fascinates British geologists. They believe that monumental changes are going on deep inside the island that may help them to understand an impending catastrophe at another volcano -- La Palma, in the Canary Islands, 992 kilometres to the northeast. If they are right, they are the first to witness, and understand, a unique moment in the evolution of a volcano. Fogo appeared a few hundred thousand years ago when it erupted from the ocean floor. Today, it reaches a daunting 2,700 metres and is growing ever bigger and steeper. Its eastern flank has collapsed once already, thundering cataclysmically into the ocean 40,000 years ago and leaving a giant landslide scar of a perfection that delights a volcanologist: It is 8-10 kilometres across, and at least 1.5-3 kilometres deep. Fogo's future is inevitable: It will become so unstable that the eastern flank will collapse again in a drama with global consequences. But how this will happen has not, until now, been understood. If it collapses quickly, its impact on the ocean will cause a tsunami, or large destructive wave, that could travel several thousand kilometres, hitting the Canaries and devastating the coasts of Portugal, Spain, and north and west Africa. There is little need to worry, however, say Simon Day and Bill McGuire of the Benfield Greig Hazard Research Centre at University College, London. The disaster will not occur for many thousands of years. But the same cannot be said of La Palma, which is further along in the same process and, like Fogo, is one of the steepest volcanic islands in the world. La Palma may take thousands of years to hit the sea -- but there is a small chance it may go very soon. Because it faces west, the resulting tsunami could lash Florida with waves tens of metres high. ``These are the two volcanoes we are most worried about,'' says Prof. McGuire. ``It's not that La Palma is going to collapse sometime -- it has already started.'' The latest stage of the collapse began during an eruption in 1949, when a vast chunk of land on the western side began to slide toward the ocean. For some reason the rock shuddered to a halt after a trip of only four metres. There it waits today, ready for another trigger. It is vital to understand the geology behind such collapses, and scientists have been gathering evidence of past devastation in the Canaries in order to do so. They believe that an oceanic volcano is cyclical, crumbling into the sea every hundred thousand years or so. Doug Masson, a marine geologist at Britain's Southampton Oceanography Centre, visited the islands with Tony Watts, a professor at Oxford University, in a ship equipped with a multibeam echosounder, a device that projects 80 sound waves in a fan shape towards the ocean floor. On La Palma's western side, the reflections disclosed an ancient landslide that stretched for 80 kilometres and had ruffled the ocean floor as far as 590 kilometres away. Supporting the story of an ancient collapse, Dr. Day and some Spanish colleagues have discovered tsunami deposits in the Canaries that are the unmistakable detritus of waves that once surged 100 metres up the islands' flanks. On La Palma, the geologists are monitoring minute changes in the shape of the volcano, which they hope will reveal the imperceptible swelling before an eruption that could trigger the collapse. Measurements taken since 1994 show that the western part of the island may still be sliding slowly seawards at around eight millimetres a year. On both Fogo and La Palma, Dr. Day is doing research of a more fundamental nature. He is trying to understand how the instability occurs in the first place, by studying Fogo's collapse scar and tentative 1970s evidence of a sub-sea avalanche stretching up to 3,600 metres from the island. Virtually all volcanic oceanic islands have the same structure: a central magma chamber from which three rift zones emanate. It is a stable set-up, as the zones are held in place by the pressure exerted by the magma in each swarm of vertical fractures, or dykes. Above the dykes lie tell-tale eruptive fissures; it is these that Dr. Day has been mapping on Fogo. He has noticed something odd: Over time, their orientation seems to have changed. Dr. Day believes that he is close to showing that the reorientation was the first episode of Fogo's preparation for its ancient collapse. The strange drama unfolded as follows: Something made the volcano a little unstable, which forced the magma to start flooding into a new north-south set of fractures parallel to the coast. Eventually, it abandoned the earlier rift zones to form a realigned one. Quickly, a positive feedback built up as the magma, now exerting its pressure in a single direction because of the rift-zone realignment, caused the ground to the east to become unstable. Collapse became inevitable. The same process is going to happen again, believes Dr. Day. He is studying the newer fractures on Fogo and thinks that the same pattern of reorientation is beginning again. Over the past few centuries, the magma has abandoned the two rift zones that stretch from the centre to the southwest and to the northwest. A new rift zone has developed, parallel to the coastline and through the zone of the ancient collapse. Every new eruption in this rift zone -- there are several each century -- is forcing the eastern flank of the volcano a little closer to the sea. Over on La Palma, there is evidence of a similar pattern of rift-zone reorganization -- but it is 6,000 years ahead. No one knows what triggers these changes, but the most likely candidate is a change in the sea level. Collapses tend to occur during, or soon after, periods of rapid sea-level rise, especially at the end of glaciations. The rise, coupled with the switch to a more humid climate, causes the water table to ascend within a volcano. Perhaps the water pressure increases, forcing the rocks apart and weakening the volcano's structure. The scientists are itching to do more work on Fogo to glean more knowledge of this moment in a volcano's evolution. They want to take advantage of an innovation in the Global Positioning System to monitor tiny movements on the island at a tenth of the usual cost. Dr. Day and others are putting together a proposal to sail around the Cape Verde Islands to make an acoustic map of the ocean floor. They want to update the 1970s seismic survey, to see just how powerful that old landslide was. The sea floor there is unusually rugged. If they can discover the extent to which the landslide surged up the submarine mountains, they will be able to estimate the landslide's speed, from which they will be able to calculate the size of the resulting tsunami and predict how large the next one will be.
