March 13, 1999, p.23
Extreme Hiking: For the adventurous (with thick leather shoes): A stroll on an active volcano
Michael H. Sedge
Travelling throughout the night, I arrived in Catania, on the east coast of Sicily, two hours before sunrise. It had been an unplanned, spur-of-the-moment trip, triggered by the sudden eruption of Mount Etna the previous day. Now, in the distance, I could see a glowing red, snake-like trail running down the 3,352-metre mountain slope. In a matter of hours I would stand along the edge of that river of lava, feeling the heat rise from the molten rock, and the steam seeping up from beneath my feet. Since the beginning of human existence, humans have been intrigued by the fire-belching geological phenomena known as volcanoes. They are spectacular displays of the Earth's energy and temperament. It has only been during the past century, however, that our knowledge of volcanoes has grown to a point where adventurers feel comfortable enough to explore the flaming slopes of such monsters as Mount Etna. Because of the excitement and obvious danger involved, volcano exploring has become a favoured pastime among thrill-seeking athletes and adventurers. Inasmuch as volcanoes have always inspired awe and wonder, they are one of nature's simpler phenomena. The Earth's centre is nothing more than a molten hotbed, and from this core, magma flows directly to the Earth's surface through channels, such as those making up the volcanoes of Hawaii, which are constantly active. In other cases, magma is stored in chambers that expand below the Earth's surface like balloons, and eventually erupt. The latter was the case of Mount St. Helens, which erupted on May 18, 1980, in a wooded area of Washington state, creating a rapid and sudden flowing of rock and other materials known as a ``debris avalanche.'' Italy's Mount Vesuvius, which erupted in AD 79, covering the ancient cities of Pompeii and Herculanium, is another example of a sudden volcanic eruption. In this case, however, a turbulent mixture of gas and rock fragments was violently ejected from the crater, creating a high-temperature ash flow that rapidly moved down the slopes, devouring everything in its path. Volcanoes, for the most part, are found along the tensional cracks of the Earth's surface -- the ocean ridges and their continental links. The plate that forms the Pacific Rim is the reason for the so-called ``Ring of Fire.'' In fact, there are more than 10,000 volcanoes in the Pacific alone that extend 1,000 metres or more. Most of these, however, are located below the surface of the ocean. The reason for this multitude of submerged volcanoes is that the ocean floor is thin, making it easier for the underlying magma to pierce. Most European volcanoes are the ``vent'' type, with the expanding gases forming the surrounding earth into a cone shape as they are forced outward. With these ones it's common to see smoke but no magma, since the molten lava cools prior to reaching the surface. Belching white-hot lava as it hissed and bellowed, it was obvious that nothing had cooled below the surface of Etna. From the village of Nicolosi, we'd driven to the Sapienza Refuge, on the mountain's southern slopes. A cable car ran up Etna until 1985; that year, lava flow destroyed part of the cableway, making it inoperative. Today, most adventurers begin their ascent from here, either by foot, which takes a few hours, or by four-wheel-drive vehicles for a 45-minute uphill ride. Guides also gather here to accompany visitors to the summit craters, which are often flowing with hot magma while. From the opposite side of the mountain, lava is spewed skyward with lion-like roars. There have been more than 160 recorded eruptions from Mount Etna, resulting in a volcanic mountain with a base circumference of 201 kilometres. The mountain today is constantly bubbling in one or more of its many craters; it is as close to a vision of hell as any mortal is likely to get. Because of this, Etna is rated highly on adventurers' lists, although it commands respect: It can be threatening, and even dangerous under certain conditions. Despite the ever-present 704C lava flows, Etna, like most of the world's volcanoes, is a seasonal adventure. Most explorers make the trip between May and October, when the all-terrain tour vehicles operate; during the rest of the year, the summit is often buried in snow. Since the slopes of most volcanoes are not patrolled, safety, conditioning, and proper gear are essential in volcano exploring. Even at the height of summer, the higher levels of most volcanoes can be very cold. Etna, for example, often has winds of up to 185 kilometres an hour and more that add to the chill factor. In other months, temperatures can be extremely bitter. The higher altitudes, more often than not, are shrouded in clouds, and visibility can be poor. Volcano exploring is really no more dangerous than mountain climbing, but when the ground thunders beneath your feet and a lump of hot rock shoots a half-kilometre into the sky, you'll feel a thrill -- if you want to call it that -- which no other adventure can provide. GEARING UP FOR VOLCANIC ADVENTURES Like any sport, volcano exploring requires some special gear. Boots are number one on the list. There are a number of good brands, but the key factor is to have thick leather soles. Many people have made the mistake of using boots with rubber or plastic soles on the slopes of Etna. This frequently results in hot feet and, in some cases, melted soles. Heavy socks, long pants, long underwear, coat, hat, gloves, and sunglasses should be seriously considered, particularly for excursions up European volcanoes. Weather at the mountain base is sunny and mild, but once you get into higher altitudes you will be glad to have the extra clothing. A walking stick is useful when it comes to stepping along hazardous areas. A light aluminum stick is best. A full canteen of water is another must, even for short excursions. You will not find any water holes on volcanoes. Because of the natural beauty that volcanic environments provide, a camera is often a good idea. Some of the most dramatic images ever captured on film have come from sudden lava bursts. Though you may never need to use it, a first aid kit should be taken for all outings. Most of these items will easily fit into a backpack. If you decide to camp on a volcano -- which is frequently done, though sites must be selected with great care -- you will also want to include the usual camping equipment. One very important thing is a medical mask, which can be purchased inexpensively at medical supply stores. These come in handy if you are exploring an active volcano that has sulfur fumes seeping from its crevasses.

GLOBE TROTTER New Zealand Volcano a magnet

March 7 2001 
Title: Red flames in a velvet sky: on the Italian island of Stromboli, an evening climb leads to a stunning view of Europe's only continuously erupting volcano. 
Author: Heather Hill 
The sun is not yet up when the overnight ferry from Naples bears in on the island of Stromboli. In the dark-blue velvet of the Mediterranean night, you can stand on the side of the ship and watch the scattering of lights from the town slowly approach. The outline of the towering volcano for which Stromboli is renowned is barely visible, but its cone, more than 900 metres above the town, is smoldering like the tip of a giant cigar. Suddenly, the decks of the Luna Rossa are filled with gasps and cries of amazement: the volcano has just exploded, expelling violent red flames skyward with a fury that has to be seen to be believed. "Incredibile!" confirms one of the Italian passengers. The cone soon disappears from view as the ferry angles toward the pier, but the excitement lingers. Stromboli has more than lived up to its reputation. As Europe's only continuously active volcano and one of only five such in the world, it has performed right on cue. Stromboli is probably the best known of Italy's seven Aeolian Islands, which are the highest points of a submerged chain of volcanic mountains. Not just for the volcano but for the stream of authentic celebrities alighting to sample the black-sand beaches and ink-blue sea, the unparalleled views, the unique architecture of the bone-white houses and the narrow, flower-filled streets of the town. From Aristotle Onassis and the king of Belgium in the island's early years of tourism to Umberto Eco, Isabella Rossellini and fashion kings Dolce and Gabbana today, Stromboli's guest list certifies its cachet in an era of mass tourism. Exclusive or prohibitively expensive the island is not, however. Aboard the Luna Rossa are hard-core backpackers who will head for low-priced pensione, or simply camp out on the beach, dining on pizza ($3.50 a slice). Even those with the means to stay in one of the three-star hotels find the accommodation relatively spartan. Everything -- from drinking water to vegetables and furniture -- has to be brought to Stromboli by boat. Even the restaurant seafood is imported, despite a sea teeming with fish. That's because the only industry here is tourism. This chapter in the island's intermittent occupation (dating back 3,000 years ago) began when Ingrid Bergman and Roberto Rossellini (Isabella's parents) landed on Stromboli in 1949 to make a movie of the same name. Their very public and adulterous affair (conducted in a small red house on Via Vittorio Emmanuelle III, identifiable by a bronze plaque commemorating the event) triggered worldwide headlines. With the advent of tourism, the native-born farmers, fishermen and traders (who caught rainwater on the roofs of their houses to survive) gradually gave way to hotel employees, shop owners and vendors, many from Sicily, the Italian province to which the islands belong. "Giro?" inquire bored, macho young men sprawling at small umbrella-shaded tables from where they sell boat tours around the island. The giro is a must. In the course of 2-1/2 hours, I saw Ginostra, a hardscrabble cliff-top hamlet (pop. 20) that boasts the world's smallest harbour (big enough for exactly one boat). With a donkey as the sole mode of transportation, Ginostra is a haven for those seeking utter tranquillity. Next, I saw a colossal black slide of hardened lava called "La Sciara del Fuoco -- literally, the "ski run of fire." This is the route that the magma takes as it tumbles down the west side of the mountain to the sea. La Sciara is overwhelmingly cinematic, seemingly created for the opening scene of a James Bond movie. At the base of La Sciara are waters that are a scuba divers' paradise, with dramatic rock formations and abundant marine life. But even at three metres, where we were allowed off the boat for a swim, it is heaven. The sea, gently heated by the black rock, is of a colour the Italians call blu assoluta. By a trick of light, however, the water around Strombolicchio, our next stop, is a stunningly pure azure. "Little Stromboli" (pop. 0), a 60-metre-high outcropping of solidified lava about two kilometres off the east coast, is home only to a lighthouse, but it is a magnet for divers, snorkellers, cabin cruisers and tour boats like ours. The boat returned us to the town of Stromboli (pop. 400) just in time for lunch. Italy is legendary for its indulgent beach culture, and Stromboli is one of the purest expressions of the form. Many of the people on the beach are nude or semi-nude and their chief pursuit is a tan. But the island, whose name derives from the ancient Greek word meaning "round," is a true wilderness paradise, a joy to explore on foot, by bicycle, in a kayak, or a boat. (There are no cars here, just scooters and a few golf cart-style commercial vehicles.) And, of course, there is the volcano, which I, like countless others, had come determined to climb. So it was that on a Friday evening at 5 p.m. I joined about 50 trekkers in Piazza San Vincenzo, the main square and departure point for the official tours. (Many people climb on their own, unwilling to pay the $40 fee and to move at a pace set by the guide.) I was issued with a white hard hat and gauze mouth protector and assigned to group number one. Several moments later, to my surprise, I heard someone asking Signora Eel to identify herself. Unthinkingly, I owned up to my name, and was told to join the second group. I had an immediate intimation of trouble even though the guide, a genial man named Mario, assured me his group, "the blue helmets," would be leaving just five minutes after the first. But Mario was slow right from the start. He was chatty, too, halting frequently to regale us with local lore. We stopped to rest, to have a snack, to receive instructions on the next leg of the journey. I looked up the mountain in dismay. Group number one was out of sight. "Andiamo!" I begged Mario. "Avanti!" He just shook his head, amused by the straniera's impatience. Hadn't he been doing this for 25 years? When we were just below the summit, a tantalizing 20 minutes away, Mario reined us in yet again. We had to sit down and wait, he announced. The clouds were wrong, he explained. The weather was not good. Conditions were not right. By now it was dark and cold and I had had enough. I was trapped in a Seinfeld episode, playing Elaine. I argued furiously with Mario in my fractured Italian. Why were we huddled down in steerage when everyone else was on the top deck enjoying the view? The one eruption we had seen so far was so fantastic that it was senseless to sit here in the dirt while the party was in full swing up above. Mario went off to the Italians in the group and complained to them about me, but the mutiny was starting to spread. He conferred softly on a two-way radio with fellow guide Antonio. The eagle must have landed, somewhere, because suddenly Mario had us on our feet, putting on the hard hats, getting out the gauze masks, priming our flashlights. We were up and climbing. The pizzo is a slender ridge about 100 metres above the cone from where you have an excellent view of the volcanic activity. The eruptions come every 10 to 20 minutes, so spectators usually stay up top for an hour to make the journey worthwhile. The blue helmets managed to see one more explosion from the volcano before dense clouds rolled in, bringing an overpowering stink of sulphur. Coughing broke out up and down the ridge. The masks were useless. The cone was invisible. We didn't need Mario to tell us the show was over. One more minute up there would have been unbearable. As we trudged back down in silent exhaustion, over hectares of loose sand that found a permanent home in my shoes, and then through endless stands of wild bamboo, I calculated: seven hours with Mario, two bursts from the volcano. No wonder women are so mad at men. However, what we did see was magnificent. Shooting cinders, moving walls of fire. They brought to life the classical myth of the god Vulcan, a lame but divine smith who works at his forge in the depths of the volcano, hammering out weapons for the god of war. The islands were also believed to be the home of the god of the winds, Aeolus, who refused to give Odysseus the favourable breeze to take him back to Ithaca, a decision that gave the wily Trojan warrior the longest Mediterranean cruise in history. Traces of this ancient world are housed in a splendid archeological museum on the Aeolian island of Lipari. A 90-minute ferry ride away, through pale purple lava islets, Lipari is everything Stromboli is not: urban, developed, heavily touristed. But the museum is a marvellous portal to the prehistoric past. One archeological excavation yielded salt and pepper shakers, teapots and colanders, all made of stone -- prototypes, you might say, of modern-day Italian design. The Aeolian Islands were declared a World Heritage Site by UNESCO in December and will now be protected from the worst depredations of developers. Up to now, on Stromboli, development has been checked by the unpredictability of the volcano, whose cataclysmic eruption in 1930 killed six people and drove away nearly all of the island's 8,000 residents. The steep slope and the constant lava flow have made it impossible to build a road all the way around the island. Indeed, Stromboli, the most remote of the Aeolian Islands, is so basic that public electricity did not arrive until 1976. Vito Russo, proprietor of La Sirinetta, Stromboli's first hotel, says the community has applied its own breaks, giving almost full compliance to a ban on new building. Buyers can build on or renovate existing residential properties only. Unusual for Italy, where illegal building proliferates, only three houses have been built in defiance of the regulations. When Dolce and Gabbana decided to buy a home on Stromboli (Giorgio Armani already being installed on another volcanic island called Pantelleria), they spent a small fortune remodelling two adjacent houses. "The people here want to protect the island," explains Russo. "They have no problem with not being able to build. They see the value in the nature. Yes, we are isolated, but that isolation is what has saved us.

April 28 1997, p C1. 
Title: Television: trip to `live' volcano makes for hot documentary. 
Author: John Haslett Cuff
THE very telegenic and well-informed host of Journeys With Lauren Millar (Discovery, tonight at 9 p.m.) described the plight of her documentary film crew during filming of tonight's episode, Volcano, this way: "Just a few days before, an American geologist painted a doomsday scenario for us: 'If that mountain really blows, we're only about four kilometres away. We wouldn't have a prayer. First we would burn from the inside out because the air would be like a charcoal fire. Then we'd be consumed by hot, black ash.' Little did we know this ash fall was just a taste of what would come." The volcano in question is located in the West Indies amidst Montserrat's Soufriere Hills, and in August of 1995 it blew for the first time in 300 years. Hurling ash and smoke more than a mile into the sky, the volcano deluged the island's capital and forced more than 3,000 people to flee. There were subsequent eruptions and earth tremors, and all evidence pointed to a potential disaster on the scale of Mount St. Helen's in 1980 in which 57 people perished. The documentary begins as the "lava dome" of the volcano is building dramatically, suggesting two possible outcomes. In the best case, the dome would eventually settle and seal the volcano, preventing any further eruptions in the immediate, foreseeable future. Or it could just as easily blow up and create further havoc in the entire region of the West Indian islands. Millar, who produces (with partner Craig Moffit), writes, directs and hosts the series, went with her crew to Montserrat to hang out with the geologists and volcanologists who were monitoring and studying the "live" volcano which seemed so ready to explode and rain devastation on the small, idyllic island. Disaster is the best possible subject for television and can quickly raise an informative documentary into the realm of the exceptional. Millar and the Journeys team stayed close to the volcano specialists, following them around for days. In the process of filming, they shared in some of the risk and all of the excitement of discovery as the volcanologists "read" the entrails of the explosive mountain. Scaling the mountain on foot, hanging around close enough to risk being buried in boiling lava, drowned in ashes or crushed by rocks, the filmmakers tried gamely to convey a sense of the "adventure" of science, which is the whole point of the series. The cameras capture some impressive eruptions of smoke and ash, and Millar flies in a helicopter with the team of scientists as they touch down on an ash-covered beach which reaches temperatures of 400 C when the lava scorches the verdant landscape and literally evaporates the waves as they wash in to shore. This may seem like pretty tame stuff compared to the million-dollar special effects of such Hollywood disaster films as Dante's Inferno, but the danger is very real. Throughout, Millar remains pristine in her white tank tops and extremely calm and collected as she interviews the scientists who explain the portents of "pyroclastic flow," ultraviolet light and sulphur dioxide emissions with just enough controlled enthusiasm to impart a sense of drama and danger (after all, this is prime-time TV). Next week the show explores the plight of porpoises, and future shows will look into forensic science, emergency medicine and sharks. Journeys With Lauren Millar was originally produced by TVO and is now in its fourth season, but this is its first run as an independent production of Millar and Moffit's Indigo Moon Pictures Inc. While we're on the subject, disasters and professional risk-takers seem to be something of a theme for the Discovery Channel as it begins another new season. On Wednesday (at 10 p.m.), a new series called (what else?) Disasters has its debut. The first show is called Riders of the Storm and it explores the phenomena associated with tornadoes and lightning. And tomorrow night (also at 10), The Professionals profiles people who take considerable risks to earn a day's wages. Fine Tuning Talk shows Studio 2. Sports panel will discuss Cito Gaston; NHL playoffs (TVO at 8 p.m.) Face Off and Pamela Wallin have been pre-empted for election-call specials. (\f6 Newsworld at 8:30 and 9 p.m.) rDavid Letterman. Kurt Russell, Sinbad, Paula Cole. (CBS at 11:35 p.m.) Jay Leno. Norm MacDonald, Deborah Farentino. (NBC at 11:35 p.m.)\f6 rBill Maher. Rebecca De Mornay, Wayne Dwyer, Emme, Joe Montegna. (BBS, ABC at 12:05 a.m.) Dates and times may vary across the country. Please check local listings.

May 31 2000, p 1. 
Title: Volcano draws thousands of visitors yearly. 
Author: Ken Becker 
"For many people, the 1980 eruption is a historic event," says Peter Frenzen, staff scientist at Mount St. Helens National Volcanic Monument in southern Washington state, which attracts more than one million visitors a year. "But many of the people who come here now weren't even born then. To them, you might as well be talking about Abe Lincoln." At 8:32 a.m. PDT on Sunday, May 18, 1980, awakened by a powerful earthquake, Mount St. Helens erupted, propelling an avalanche of ice and boulders more than 20 kilometres. Moments later, a second blast uncorked whirlwinds of debris that downed some 400 square kilometres of old-growth forest and sent a mushroom cloud of ash nearly 25 kilometres into the sky. It blocked out the sun, caught a northeast wind, and rained inky ash throughout the northwestern United States. Red-hot lava flows poured from the crater. By the time it stopped, the mountainside was transformed into a moonscape. Fifty-seven people -- and uncounted animals and plants -- were killed. Over the years, survivors returned and began rebuilding. Plants poked through the blackened crust. Mammals such as elk, black bears and mountain goats found a new, or old, home. Now, perhaps attracted by the notoriety of the catastrophe, visitors from across North America and around the world travel to the 18,000-hectare U.S. national monument, about a two-hour drive north of Portland, Ore. Many gravitate to the Johnston Ridge Visitor Center, opened in 1997 and named for a geologist killed in the blast, for a view of the crater and the volcano's lava dome. "But the best way to see the crater is to hike up to the rim," says Frenzen. "It's a long slog but a very rewarding one." The monument issues a maximum of 100 permits a day to hikers heading for the rim. About 12,000 go each year. For those who can't make it to the mountain, the mountain comes to them -- on the Internet, at: www.fs.fed.us./gpnf/mshnvm/volcanocam.

July 31 2001 
Title: Mount Etna casts shadow over tourism: volcano's latest eruptions cause flow of visitors to dwindle, businesses to suffer. Author: Ljubomir Milasin 
Darkening the sky over Europe's most active volcano, Mount Etna's latest eruptions are also casting a pall over the region's thriving tourist industry at the peak of the summer season. For the third time, a rain of black volcanic ash closed the airport nearest to Mount Etna yesterday, but the lava flow appeared to be slowing. In the two weeks it has been acting up, the mountain has been full of surprises. The rivers of lava slow one day, only to speed up the next, fed by new fissures in the mountainside. Though they have yet to threaten any residents or towns, the molten streams swallowed a ski lift last week. Yesterday, red-hot lava was licking the edges of a tourist base, Rifugio Sapienza, at an altitude of nearly 2,000 metres, about halfway down the mountain slopes. Italian troops have used bulldozers to break up the asphalt in the parking lot in an attempt to create a channel that would redirect the lava away from populated areas. In the village of Nicolosi, at the mountain base, the mood is grim. The town normally thrives on tourists eager to visit the volcano, both from the rest of Italy and from overseas. Now, however, the volcanic action seems too risky for the comfort of many visitors, who normally arrive hoping to see the volcano in action. "Normally during this season we have three to 4,000 tourists a day taking the cable car up the mountain," Nicolosi Mayor Salvatore Moschetto said. "The worst thing is that we don't know when we will be able to get back to normal." The scene from the mayor's office window, featuring a lone pine tree in a dust-covered landscape, explains why. It is not just the threat posed by the eruptions and the streams of lava, but also the ashes that rain down on Nicolosi and the region downwind of the volcano that make life uncomfortable. Etna's last major eruption was in 1992. The volcano, which towers 3,310 metres above Sicily, comes to life every few months. Nicolosi, a town of 6,000 at an altitude of 700 metres, prides itself as being the gateway to Etna. There have been 300 family businesses affected by the latest eruptions which started on July 12. Structural damage to cable-car installations and the area's main road, which was cut off by lava flows, is also severe. Mr. Moschetto fears that the winter season, which attracts skiers, could also be threatened because repairs will not be carried out in time. Salvatore Mazzaglia, the head of the company that manages the sporting facilities on the volcano, said it will be two years before skiers will be able to use the site again. The government in Rome has pledged more than nine million euros ($12-million) in immediate financial assistance for villagers and business owners. It has also promised tax breaks to help the region get through the crisis. While the eruptions are trouble for the tourism industry, scientists are eager to study the mountain's actions. Paola Vanolli, a geologist with the National Institute of Geophysics and Vulcanology, said yesterday that teams are analyzing the lava and gases the mountain has been spitting out. "The emissions are being studied to understand how the volcano will behave in the future."

February 20 1999 
Title: Going with the flow on an Indonesian volcano trek. 
Author: Christopher Torchia 
The guide's "Sorry, Sir" every time I tripped over a rock was just as annoying. Still, scaling the 3,726-metre Gunung Rinjani, or Rinjani Mountain, was a curious mix of hardship and pampering. With two guides and two porters lugging tents, food and bags, the biggest weight my companion and I bore was the guilt of carting nothing but a plastic water bottle. Peering from an airplane window on a clear day, it's easy to spot the corrugated slopes of volcanoes that dot the Indonesian archipelago. The cones remain shrouded in lore, symbolism and sacredness for many who live in their shadow. Indonesia has 130 active volcanoes, the most of any country in the world. With a smoke-spewing inner cone, hot springs and a crescent-shaped crater lake, Rinjani is among the grandest. It is the second-highest peak in Indonesia outside the remote, mountainous province of Irian Jaya. For travellers grown restless with a diet of beaches and sunbathing, it offers a strenuous escape from the tourist hustle of nearby Bali. Rinjani is active, last erupting in 1994 and peppering ash over much of Lombok, the tropical island it towers over. Indonesia is prone to seismic upheavals because of its location on the Pacific "Ring of Fire," a series of volcanoes and fault lines from the Americas through Japan and Southeast Asia to the South Pacific. But rain, not lava or sulphurous gases, is the real threat on Rinjani. Narrow trails turn slippery during the wet season between October and April, and hikers have lost their footing on the rocky volcano walls and perished. "How is your life today?" our chirpy guide, Rusman, chimed enthusiastically at 7 a.m. after a shivering night on the pine-studded crater rim. It takes a day to get up there, marching across waist-high savannah before the slopes surge upward into forest paths laced with tree roots. Here, the layers of mist and silence are heavy. Down in the belly of the crater, travellers bathe in scalding hot springs reputed to heal skin diseases and other ailments. Fishermen tether live catches to stakes in the lake, like pets on a leash. Many Hindu Balinese and Muslim Sasaks, who are the dominant ethnic group on Lombok, treat Rinjani as a holy place and trek there to fling rice, jewellery and other tributes into the lake. A full moon is a popular time for pilgrims. Indonesian volcanoes draw farmers because their soil is fertile and good for crops. Their terrible power inspires fear, too. In 1883, an eruption at Krakatau volcano killed more than 36,000 people. For hikers, three days and two nights of camping on Rinjani is ideal. You need an extra day to stagger up the wind-swept summit. But the path out of the crater basin is perilous enough. The usually attentive guides were absent when we crossed one stretch of fallen boulders and loose gravel. A chasm beckoned below. "I went ahead to pass water. Perhaps you are enraged?" a rueful Rusman said later. The mountaintop isolation can be fleeting. On our second day, descending into a rain forest, we pitched tents on raised wooden platforms at a campsite. Monkeys swaying in the trees were our only company. Within hours, half a dozen other climbing parties had turned the spot into a hikers' slum: campfire smoke enveloped tents, cutlery clanged on cooking pots, plates heaped with rice and chicken traded hands. At nightfall, laughter and gossip in Indonesian and a string of European tongues gave way to the grunts and snores of fitful sleepers. On the last day, driving past palm trees to a beachside hotel, we watched in alarm as a carsick Rusman leaned out the window and retched in the road. "It is because I am sad to say goodbye to you," he told us. It was an inspired bid for a bigger tip.

November 10 1999 
Title: Airlines pay close attention to volcano warnings. Author: Ken Becker 
But Canadian and all other airlines pay close attention to such warnings. That's because some volcanic eruptions invade the rarefied altitudes where the big jets fly, posing a serious threat to aviation. Over the past two decades, more than 80 commercial airliners have been damaged in flight by volcanic ash. The most dramatic incident occurred 10 years ago when a KLM Boeing 747 lost all four engines while descending for refuelling in Anchorage, Alaska. It was the day after the Redoubt volcano, near Anchorage, began erupting on Dec. 14, 1989. The jumbo jet was approaching 7,600 metres when it was engulfed in an impenetrable mass of inky ash. The cockpit and cabin filled with a sulphurous odour. The pilot tried to rise from the darkness. A moment later, all four engines quit. The huge plane glided in space, gradually going down. An emergency was declared as the pilot attempted -- unsuccessfully -- seven or eight times to restart the engines. Finally, two of them kicked in at about 5,200 metres. The other two also restarted before the 747 landed safely at Anchorage. It cost about $80-million (U.S.) to repair the ash-clogged engines, other gummed-up systems and exterior damage -- the ash had sandblasted the aircraft. Three years later, another Alaska volcano, Mount Spurr, sent a giant ash cloud into the upper atmosphere. It jetted across Canada and the northern United States for three days, causing air-traffic chaos. Such incidents prompted the International Civil Aviation Organization to establish nine Volcanic Ash Advisory centres -- at Montreal; Anchorage; Washington; Buenos Aires; Darwin, Australia; Wellington, New Zealand; Tokyo; London; and Toulouse, France. Each is responsible for a geographic area. Montreal covers all of Canada, the North Atlantic west of Iceland, and the north polar region. Analyzing information they receive from satellites, volcano observatories and weather agencies, the centres forecast movements of ash clouds and pass alerts to airlines and air-traffic control centres.

Globe and Mail, May 26 2001 
Title: Science: under (and inside) the volcano: (No apparent danger: the true story of volcanic disaster at Galeras and Nevado Del Ruiz; Surviving Galeras). 
Author: John Wilson
No Apparent Danger: The True Story of Volcanic Disaster at Galeras and Nevado Del Ruiz By Victoria Bruce HarperCollins, 240 pages, $39.50 Surviving Galeras By Stanley Williams and Fen Montaigne Houghton Mifflin, 270 pages, $36.95 At around 1:40 p.m. on Jan. 14, 1993, Galeras, an obscure volcano in the Central Cordillera of Colombia, erupted. It was a minor event, leaving no trace in the geological record and even going unnoticed by many people in the city at the foot of the mountain. In fact, few non-vulcanologists would ever have heard of Galeras had Stanley Williams not been leading a field trip to its summit that afternoon. The field trip turned the eruption into a disaster. In a matter of seconds, six scientists and three locals, who had hiked up to see what was going on, were dead, crushed and burned by superheated rocks thrown out of the volcano's vent. Others were injured, including Williams, who was lucky to survive the horrific damage his body suffered. Stanley Williams and the Galeras eruption are central to both No Apparent Danger and Surviving Galeras. Both books expand the story to encompass other events, but each handles that afternoon, its aftermath and Williams's responsibility very differently. Victoria Bruce is a geologist and former science writer. In No Apparent Danger, she enlarges the Galeras story to include the much larger disaster of another Colombian volcano, Nevado Del Ruiz. In 1985, a minor eruption of Nevado Del Ruiz melted part of the ice caps on the mountain's summit. Huge mud and debris flows raced down the surrounding river valleys, obliterating the town of Armero and 23,000 people. It was the second-largest volcanic disaster of the 20th century, and could easily have been avoided if the people of Armero had been educated in the dangers, if warnings had been heeded and evacuation procedures put in place. However, the disaster did focus international attention on Colombia's volcanoes, and led to the rapid development of vulcanology in that country. The scientists involved in that development are the link in Bruce's book between Nevado Del Ruiz and Galeras. No Apparent Danger is a journalistic book. It paints a broad backdrop of political power struggles, guerrilla terrorism and drug cartels, and relies heavily on quotes to tell the detailed story. This works well as far as it goes, and there is much to be learned here about these two tragedies. However, the real drama in the story is introduced only after we meet Stanley Williams on page 82. Williams is portrayed as a "notorious maverick" who believes sampling volcanic gasses is the way to predict eruptions and who is "very dismissive of seismology." Because he was leader of the ill-fated field trip, Bruce holds him responsible for ignoring seismic indications that Galeras was dangerous, not requiring safety clothes or hard hats, and not having sufficient radio communication with the base. For good measure, Williams is also portrayed as presenting himself as the sole survivor of the disaster and stealing a colleagues' work. Not surprisingly, Williams's own account in Surviving Galeras is different. Helped by Pulitzer finalist Fen Montaigne, Williams recreates, in striking detail, the day that changed his life. He intersperses his narrative with biographies of the characters and tales of famous volcanic eruptions from Vesuvius to Mount St. Helens. Surviving Galeras is a well written and intensely personal tale. It provides the reader with less background information than No Apparent Danger, but makes the main characters come much more vividly alive -- and, hence, makes their deaths more tragic. Was Williams responsible? He says no, claiming that no one could "appreciate the significance" of the seismic record, that it was not his responsibility to impose a dress code which would not have saved lives in any case, and that the party was in continuous radio contact. But there are inconsistencies in Williams's account. Bruce describes a meeting the night before the disaster in which Colombian geologists expressed apprehension about the seismic record and had their concerns dismissed by Williams. Williams makes no mention of this crucial meeting. Undoubtedly, hard hats would not have helped those caught in the throat of the erupting volcano, but Williams himself suffered a severe head injury that would almost certainly have been prevented by a hard hat. Bruce states that, without a relay radio on the rim, it is impossible to communicate directly between the Galeras crater and the seismic observatory in town. Williams placed no such relay person on the rim, yet claims that his one radio was "checking in regularly" with the observatory. Short of cancelling the field trip, which some of Williams's colleagues believe he should have done, it is unlikely that the other precautions would have made much difference. But that does not mean that they should not have been implemented. As Williams states, "One should always prepare for the worst on a volcano." He did not. Williams undoubtedly has a large ego, but that is probably neither unusual nor a handicap in the eccentric world of vulcanology. What I found disturbing was his total lack of guilt and his propensity to blame events on external sources. For him, the main cause of the disaster was a power blackout that necessitated moving the field trip back a day. No Apparent Danger and Surviving Galeras present a fascinating tale of tragedy, leavened with scientific controversy. Falling somewhere between the Stephen Jay Gould/Conway Morris altercation over the Burgess Shale, and the more dramatic debate around responsibility for the Everest tragedy of 1996, they are probably not the last word on this topic. These books obligate readers to take sides, pro- and anti-Williams, but that is part of the fun. Read them both. John Wilson is an ex-geologist whose latest book is a biography, John Franklin: Traveller on Undiscovered Seas .

July 27 2001 
Title: Philippines volcano eruption could last weeks, experts say. 
LEGAZPI, PHILIPPINES -- The eruption of the Mayon volcano, which spewed towering ash columns and rocks "as big as cars" yesterday, could last up to two weeks, experts said. The eruption, which came without warning, forced more than 40,000 villagers to flee their homes in the province of Albay. No casualties were reported, but residents of the capital Legazpi, 20 kilometres from Mayon's crater, rushed out of their homes in panic as ash showers -- known as "black rain" -- fell on the city of 130,000 people, Governor Alfrancis Bichara said. "This could last for one to two weeks," chief government vulcanologist Raymundo Punongbayan said. Located 330 kilometres southeast of Manila, the volcano unleashed a series of eruptions on June 24 but subsided 10 days later. Yesterday, it blasted out ash columns reaching heights of 10 to 12 kilometres "and rocks as big as cars, if not bigger," vulcanologist Ed Laguerta said. More than 40,000 people, riding in military trucks, state-commandeered buses, pedicabs and motorcycles fled to schools serving as temporary evacuation centres around Legazpi, officials said. Flaming rocks and gases with temperatures of about 900 degrees -- hot enough to raze everything in their path -- tumbled down the slopes of the volcano at speeds of 100 kilometres an hour, scientists said. Mayon, one of the Philippines' 22 active volcanoes, has a history of 47 violent eruptions. Its deadliest blast occurred in 1814, when it buried a town under mud and rocks and killed 1,200 people.

January 19 2002 
Title: Thousands flee from volcano in Congo: desperate families try to salvage what they can as lava streams from mountain. Author: Allison Lawlor 
A river of red-hot lava streamed through the eastern Congolese city of Goma yesterday, destroying everything in its path, killing dozens and forcing up to 500,000 people to flee for their lives. Shrouded in smoke and mist, men, women and children hauled rolled up mattresses, cooking pots and live chickens as they frantically tried to save what they could from the devastation caused by Central Africa's most destructive volcanic eruption in 25 years. "We're suffocating in this town, the smoke is killing us," said a 25-year-old man named Stephen, as he helped load furniture into the back of a van parked not far from the burning lava. A 50-metre-wide river of lava, in places two metres thick, cut through abandoned Goma. The port city, on the north end of Lake Kivu, is 10 kilometres from the 3,469-metre Nyiragongo volcano, which began to erupt Thursday. United Nations officials estimated 45 people had died in the 24 hours since the eruption. Rescuers found corpses where lava engulfed houses. "Fire is burning everything," said Lieutenant-Colonel Alain Pereira, a Senagalese officer with a United Nations observer force. As night fell, the sky glowed scarlet from the volcano's fires, and tremors shook buildings. Gaping holes opened up in the ground and molten rock reduced roads and buildings to fiery ash "The smell of sulphur is everywhere, there are tremors every 10 minutes," Desire Bukasa, a UN radio controller, said. "There are fissures opening up in the town which billow smoke." Aid agencies are scrambling to help the thousands of displaced people. A UN official said hundreds of thousands of people had fled across the country's borders. As fresh plumes of smoke poured from the top of the volcano, residents said the Rwandan town of Gisenyi across the border was also under threat, with magma less than three kilometres away. About 50,000 people from there were moving to the city of Ruhengeri further east. The Congolese Health Ministry asked for immediate help from the international community, including shelter and sanitation facilities, water and blankets. "This is going to be a human catastrophe," said an official of a contingent of UN observers deployed to Goma as part of efforts to end a civil war. "We have to find them shelter, put them up in camps. There's no electricity, no running water." But with the Goma airport unusable because of lava on the runway and many roads cut off, getting aid into the area will be difficult. "People haven't had any food for more than a day now," James Mathenge of the World Vision aid group said. The need for clean water is a major concern. Two of the three water purification plants in the city, which had a population of 500,000, are no longer operational, said regional spokesman with the International Committee of the Red Cross. A UN disaster-assessment team, including volcano experts, was on its way to the area yesterday. Britain pledged $4.6-million to help the disaster victims, while Belgium promised $1.7-million in emergency aid. Florian Westphal, a spokesman in Nairobi for the International Committee of the Red Cross, quoted colleagues in Goma as saying access was a big obstacle in relief efforts. "Our warehouse and workshop garages with seven trucks have been destroyed. The airport is unusable and the port in Goma has been destroyed by an explosion," he said. UN workers were in Goma and other towns in the area as part of efforts to end the three-year-old war in which Rwanda and Uganda support rebels trying to topple the Kinshasa government, which in turn is backed by Angola, Zimbabwe and Namibia.

Title: Goma residents regroup in wake of volcano's fury. 
Author: Murray Campbell 
The ruins of the Virunga hospital, caught up in the flow of lava that swept through the eastern Congolese town of Goma last week, are testimony that disaster can visit more than once. The hospital was home to two clinics set up by the aid agency Christian Blind Mission International in the wake of the humanitarian crisis that overwhelmed Goma when a million people fled the genocide in neighbouring Rwanda in 1994. The clinics, which gave eye exams and did orthopedic and cataract surgeries, disappeared overnight. "There are some walls standing but nothing else survives the lava flow," said Annette Schouten-Woudstra, a CBM worker from Edmonton who witnessed the destruction. "All that you see on and around the lava is metal sheeting and the odd burnt tree trunk." But Goma, in the Democratic Republic of Congo and the centre of one humanitarian disaster after another for years, is once again picking itself up. When they are not tending burn victims, staff members of the CBM clinics are looking for temporary headquarters. Schools, churches and community centres are housing the homeless while volunteers are trying to chip roads out of the black volcanic mounds that clog the town's main streets. "They're being extremely resourceful and entrepreneurial in the midst of this huge catastrophe," said Ellen Kupp, a worker for World Vision in Goma. "I think of how long after Sept. 11 we in North America were in shock and these guys just seem to get going again." The flow of molten rock that erupted from nearby Mount Nyiragongo on Jan. 17 ran down Goma's main street and cut the town in two. The United Nations says about 35 per cent of the town was affected, displacing 70,000 people and leaving about 400,000 in need of food aid. Goma's residents initially fled to Sake, about 25 kilometres away and across the border from the Rwandan town of Gisenyi. They began returning on the weekend, even before the lava had completely cooled. Experts say the flow from Nyiragongo has stopped but sporadic small earthquakes continue to send shudders through buildings spared from the lava. A declaration on Monday that Nyiragongo's fury was spent helped convince aid agencies that it was time to start work in Goma in earnest. World Vision began distributing food and blankets to 20,000 displaced people in Sake on Tuesday. Other agencies began handing out bags of corn yesterday at points around the town centre, where a shoulder-high morass of volcanic rock blankets entire neighbourhoods. "We have no sugar, no rice, no salt, no cooking oil," said Francoise Senga, a 32-year-old mother of four waiting at a stadium for food aid.

Costa Rica 

Ring of fire 

First there were storm chasers, but now tourists are looking for a more explosive thrill - volcanoes that belch smoke and spew rivers of molten lava. Matthew Brace reports from fuming Arenal in Costa Rica 

Saturday February 12, 2000
 
There's something about volcanoes that brings out the child in otherwise mature travellers. It is impossible not to be thrilled when standing at the foot of a cone spitting flaming boulders and belching plumes of ash, especially at night when you can see the magma's fiery red colours. 
The heart beats fast as the ground shudders before an eruption. One belch from a smoker is never enough. Even with ultra-sensitive, multimillion-pound seismic equipment, there is still enough element of chance about volcanoes to make being in their presence exhilarating. Lately, people have been getting addicted and have begun organising their travels around hot-spots where the earth's crust is fluid and prone to violence. 
The world has about 500 active volcanoes. More than half are in the Pacific Ocean, in what is known as the Ring of Fire - Indonesia has about 70, Central America roughly 60 and Japan around 45. A search on the internet will bring up a healthy-looking list of tours and accommodation from Hawaii to Indonesia and Iceland to Costa Rica. 
The Costa Ricans are deeply proud of their most famous volcano, Arenal, a shapely cinder cone that rises into the clouds from t he rainforest around its base. Climbing it is forbidden and only the truly foolhardy would try. My guide spared no detail when telling me about four German tourists who ventured up a few years ago and were killed instantly when they were struck by a still-burning giant boulder blown from deep within the crater. Visitors can, however, get quite close in relative safety by taking a trail from the Tabacon Resort near the pretty town of La Fortuna. 
The trek would not look out of place in an Indiana Jones film: the opening shot would be the security sign - beyond here your travel insurance runs out. The path leads through a cutting in a snake-infested forest. Miniature motorways of leaf-cutter ants cross the path and howler monkeys whoop it up in the trees on either side. Towering over everything is Arenal. 
The trail leads to a clearing and a small beach of fine grey rock and sand - crushed particles from an old lava flow. A rock thrown in the air thuds on the sand and echoes underground. This is the roof of a giant subterranean complex of caverns leading to the central magma chamber bubbling at ferocious temperatures and, on occasion, pumping its bile up the volcano's oesophagus. 
Beyond this lies an almost vertical 60ft wall of loose lava and boulders - this is as far as the last lava flow reached. The wall is climbable with great care but, once on top, walking is near impossible. From here, the eruptions (mainly ash plumes) are clearly visible and accompanied by great booms that shudder through the valley and resound in the pit of the stomach. 
Seconds later, a clatter and rush of rocks down the cone signals the fall of boulders. The rocks leave puffs of smoke as they bounce down the mountain towards you. Their final resting-place is still several thousand yards away but, as these boulders measure up to 50ft across and travel at about 70mph, it seems like spitting distance. 
At night, the view from the hot spring-water pools at the Tabacon Resort is spectacular, but the place does get crowded and you will have to share it with noisy, boozy American tourists bawling every time the mountain spits fire. Just repeat loudly enough that a full eruption would see a river of lava sprint down the valley and vaporise their margaritas in about a minute and a half. That should shut them up. 
True volcano addicts watch in silent awe, then retire to their room at the nearby Tilajari Resort to celebrate with an ice-cold beer and plan which of the planet's smokers to head to next year. 
The practicals
Matthew Brace travelled with Valle Dorado Tours (00 506 228 9932, e-mail: vdorado@sol.racsa.co. cr.)
He stayed at the Grano de Oro (255 3322, granoro@ sol. racsa.co.cr) and San Jose Palacio (220 2034,palacio@sol. racsa.co.cr) in San Jose, and the Tilajari Resort (details from Valle Dorado) near Arenal.
Travel agents offer fares with BA (0345 222111) from £580. Also American Airlines (0345 789789) from £560, and Continental (0800 776464) from £698.

Burnt offerings . . . . volcanoes around the world

Emma Owen

Many of the Caribbean islands (Martinique, St Lucia, St Vincent, ) promote their volcanoes as day-trip destinations. If you want to go independently, contact the relevant tourist boards. The Caribbean Tourism Organisation is on 0171-222 4335. 
In Hawaii, it is possible to fly over Kilauea volcano by helicopter. Hilo Wings, e-mail: info@hilowings.com. 
The Philippines has 37 volcanoes, 18 of them active. Mount Mayon in Legaspi, South Luzon, is one of the more famous ones, along with Mount Pinatubo in central Luzon. Both Blue Horizons Travel and Tours (00 632 893 6071), and Interisland Travel and Tours (00 632 522 1405) organise sightseeing trips. Over here, the Philippine Department of Tourism is on 0171-835 1100. 
Japan has more than its fair share of volcanoes, with a major eruption every 20 years or so. Mount Fuji is an obvious and busy destination, but a hike through the Kirishima National Park allows you to stroll through 15km of lunar landscape, volcanic lakes, hot springs and waterfalls. Maps for the various walks can be collected at the tourist offices in Ebino-kogen and Takachihogawara, or contact the main tourist information office in Tokyo on 00 813 34 31 13 51. Here, the Japan National Tourist Organisation is on 0171-734 9638. 
In Indonesia , the mountains' eruptions are seen as a sign of anger from the gods. Gunung Bromo, on Java, has an annual festival when offerings are thrown into the crater in an attempt to pacify the gods. Organised tours can be arranged from the main tourist centres in Bali and Java. The Indonesian Tourist Office is on 0900 1600180. 
Mount Etna, in Italy, is Europe's largest active volcano. Tourist visits to the craters are restricted - when it blew in 1983, it took the tourist centre with it. Vesuvius is potentially the most dangerous, as the surrounding area is densely populated - emergency plans recommend the evacuation of 600,000 people in the event of rumblings. The tourist centre at Linguaglossa (for Etna) is on 00 39 095 64 30 94 and at Pompeii (for Vesuvius) on 00 39 081 850 72 55. The Italian tourist office in Britain is on 0900 1600280. 
Iceland sits precariously on top of the mid-Atlantic rift, and some 11% of the country is made up of lava fields. Active volcanoes include Eldfell on the Isle of Heimaey, Surtsey, Grimsvötn and Krafla. The tourist office in the UK is on 0171-590 1100.

Under the volcano 

An eruption once nearly wiped out the human race. Bill McGuire reports 

Thursday February 3, 2000
 
Volcanoes are unique among natural hazards in that they can kill, maim, and destroy in a remarkably diverse number of unpleasant ways. Although for most people volcanoes mean one thing only - flows of molten lava - these are actually the least dangerous of all volcanic phenomena and are formed during the quietest volcanic events known as effusive eruptions. 
Lavas are highly effective in bulldozing buildings and roads and inundating agricultural land but rarely kill. Most move so slowly that one can simply walk away from them. The really nasty volcanic hazards are generated during much more violent explosive blasts that are sometimes energetic enough to shatter a volcano entirely, sending gigantic plumes of gas and debris into the stratosphere. 
The reason some volcanoes explode with such violence is that the molten magma that feeds them is particularly rich in gas - mainly steam, but also containing carbon dioxide and sulphur gases. While the magma remains beneath the surface, this gas remains dissolved in the liquid magma, rather like the carbon dioxide in a bottle of soda before the cap is broken. In the same way that bubbles pop into existence and froth upwards when the bottle cap is removed, so the gas contained in a body of magma forms bubbles that explode outwards and upwards when the seal on a simmering volcano is broken. 
The amount of energy involved is trillions of times greater, and within fractions of a second the bubbles rip the magma to shreds and blast it tens of kilometres into the atmosphere faster than a Concorde. The magma fragments may pour down the flanks of the volcano as hurricane-force blasts of superheated gas and semi-molten ash known as pyroclastic flows or be carried far and wide to rain down as ash hundreds or even thousands of kilometres away. Shock waves from the blast may flatten everything within thousands of square kilometres while rains triggered by the eruption turn the ash into destructive torrents of mud. 
Around 50 volcanoes explode every year, but their impact is normally confined to the vicinity of the blast. About every hundred years on average - a volcano explodes with enough violence to hurl its sulphur gases into the stratosphere where they slowly spread out across the planet, cutting out some of the sun's radiation and lowering surface temperatures. In this way the 1991 eruption of Pinatubo in the Philippines cooled the Earth by about half a degree Celsius, while the 1815 blast of the Indonesian volcano, Tambora, led to the bitterly cold "Year without a summer" in North America and Europe. Volcanologists have known for some time that even the Tambora catastrophe pales into insignificance beside the greatest volcanic explosions. 
Fortunately only a couple of these super-eruptions occur every hundred millennia. Somewhat worryingly, however, the last great blast was over 70,000 years ago when a super-volcano blew its top at Toba in Sumatra. The gases contained in the magma beneath this part of Indonesia were under such incredible pressures that in perhaps less than a day they blasted out enough debris to bury greater London - from Slough in the west to Romford in the east - to a depth four times the height of Canary Wharf. 
Along with the gigantic volumes of ash, sulphur gases were blasted more than 50 kilometres into the stratosphere, where they mixed with atmospheric water to form up to five billion tonnes of sulphuric acid. 
As the sun struggled to penetrate a global veil of dust and acid, temperatures plummeted by perhaps five degrees Celsius and the planet was plunged for years into deepest volcanic winter. Recent biological evidence paints a terrifying picture of how our ancestors fared. 
Examination of mitochondrial DNA from human cells shows that it varies much less than expected across the peoples of the Earth. In other words all humans, whatever their race or colour, are - genetically speaking - very similar, much more so than they should be given the length of time they have lived on the planet. 
The horrifying explanation for this is that around the time of the great Toba blast, human beings were almost wiped out. Only a few thousand survived from which all six billion souls on planet Earth are descended. Whether or not the appalling legacy of Toba was responsible for taking our race to the brink of extinction remains to be confirmed, but this apocalyptic blast is the best candidate we have. 
With the next super-eruption technically overdue, perhaps the government should be looking not to the stars but beneath our feet for the source of the next global catastrophe. 
Supervolcanoes is broadcast as part of the BBC2 Horizon series at 9.30pm tonight 
 Bill McGuire is the Benfield Greig professor of geohazards and director of the Benfield Greig Hazard Research Centre at University College London. His new book Apocalypse: A Natural History Of Global Disasters is published in paperback by Cassell at £14.
*
Why the cracks in the volcano's slopes warn of total devastation explosion 
Volcanic activity reports 

James Meek, Science correspondent 
Thursday April 6, 2000
 
The plume of ash roiling into the air out of Mount Usu looks awesome enough. But it is all the more fearful when you realise that Usu is a mere junior branch of a much larger volcano, Toya, on whose rim it lies. 
Fortunately, there now seems little chance of a repeat of the gigantic eruption which ripped open the earth's crust where Toya lies, leaving a lake. 
But Toya's power lives on in the regular eruptions of smaller volcanoes like Usu. What Japanese scientists, admired as some of the world's most experienced volcano-watchers, now fear is a fresh explosion leading to the devastating phenomenon known as "pyroclastic flow." 
The danger signs are the cracks appearing on the slopes of the volcano below where the most recent explosions have taken place. 
This suggests that the molten rock just beneath the surface - called magma when it is inside the volcano, lava when it it outside - is forming a lava dome, a cap of hardening rock plugging the efforts of the magma to burst out. 
It is this build-up of pressure, combined with rock falling off the steepening sides of the lava dome, which could be violently released by a new explosion and a pyroclastic flow. 
This is an avalanche of hot gas, rock and ash which races from the flanks of the volcano down neighbouring river valleys at speeds of up to 90mph, laying waste to any people, animals or vegetation unfortunate enough to be in its path. 
Moving above and with the avalanche is an "ash cloud surge", a cloud of superheated ash which can spread destruction far beyond the main flow. 
The devastation is sudden and unpredictable, if localised, hence the need for evacuation. 
Between 1995 and 1997, the growth and collapse of lava domes and the subsequent explosions and pyroclastic flows from the Soufriere Hills volcano devastated entire communities and the airport on the island of Montserrat. 
Residents, who were ordered to retreat in successive evacuations, were stunned - the volcano had not erupted in 400 years. 
Mount Usu's rumblings come as less of a surprise - the volcano last erupted 22 years ago.

Impatience tempts volcano refugees into danger 

Japanese evade roadblocks to tend crops and recover valuables 

Jonathan Watts
Saturday April 8, 2000
 
Refugees from the Mount Usu volcano are slipping into the police-guarded exclusion zone as they begin to doubt expert forecasts of a devastating new eruption. 
A week after the relatively minor release of gas and ash last week, the town of Date, three miles from the volcano, resembles a scene from a Godzilla film: television helicopters constantly buzz overhead, military vehicles line the side streets, and thousands of refugees huddle in evacuation centres.
But the new peak that vulcanologists say will soon rise out of the ground in a devastating explosion of molten rock and superheated gas has still to appear, and it is increasingly disputed whether it ever will.
Refugees who fled in terror a week ago are starting to sneak past the police blockades into the danger zone to check their houses, feed their pets and tend their crops.
"It's easy to understand why they return," said Takamachi Kimura, one of the 500 people bedding down in the giant hall of Date's culture centre. "We're fed up with waiting. Nobody knows if this situation will last a month, half a year, or for ever."
Yesterday the volcano was quiet, puffing just the occasional milky white cloud into the otherwise clear blue sky. Approaching its most distant slopes, the only signs of activity were the pungent smell of sulphur dioxide and a layer of brown-grey ash on nearby trees and fields.
It is a far cry from last week, when violent earthquakes rattled homes twice an hour in a terrifying prelude to the eruption on Friday, which sent a plume of gas and ash almost two miles into the air.
But even that failed to impress many refugees, who remember the last eruption in 1978, when Mt Usu belched smoke six miles into the sky and three people were killed.
Residents of Date, Abuta and Sobetsu, the towns that ring the mountain, are arguably more used to such disasters than anyone in Japan, a country with 86 active volcanoes.
The earth in this part of the world is rarely still. Mt Usu blows its top every few decades, throwing up new peaks, such as the 400-metre (1,300ft) Showa Shinzen, which suddenly became a neighbour of Date city in 1942 and 1943.
Rather than inspiring terror, the frequency of volcanic activity seems to have bred familiarity and, in some cases, complacency. Even in Japan, where land is at a premium, there is amazement that the Koya hot spring resort in Abuta was built on an area overlapping Mt Usu's northern slopes.
But the resort owes its existence to a huge eruption in 1910, which opened a channel to a source of hot underground water for the onsen (spas) which attract hundreds of thousands of tourists each year.
What the volcano created it is now taking away. Craters have appeared on the edge of the town and cracks up to 30ft wide have swallowed houses.
Although the tremors have more or less stopped, measurements taken by satellite indicate that the expansion and contraction of the earth is accelerating.
According to Mitsuhiro Nakagawa, a professor at Hokkaido University, these are signs that an underground lava dome will push its way to the surface within the next two weeks.
He said there was a strong danger that such an eruption would produce pyroclastic flows of molten rock, which travel at speeds of more than 60mph, incinerating every thing in their paths. "It is very similar to what happened during the eruption of 1910," he said. "You have to know your history."
Residents are more concerned about economics. Far mers are frustrated at being away from their fields in their most important season. According to one agricultural cooperative, 30%of the crops in the exclusion zone are already ruined and this will rise to 70% by next week. Farmers and fishermen have petitioned the authorities to lift the entry ban.
With the mountain now apparently docile, refugees say they are tempted to return home to pick up valuables - nobody is insured against volcano damage - and bedding to make life more comfortable in the evacuation centres.
"I just want me and the kids to be able to sleep on a proper futon," said Hiroko Ishi, a mother of three, who only had time to grab nappies for her baby when she was evacuated. The family now occupy the space of a few blankets on the hard floor of a gymnasium.
"I'm exhausted, especially mentally. Not knowing how long this will last is extremely stressful."
For the moment, most still accept the validity of the official warnings, not least because they remember the last eruption, when lava stones the size of pingpong balls rained down on Date.
But as the boredom and tension of waiting increase, the most common prayer is for Mt Usu to make up its mind.
"I just wish the volcano would get on with it: either destroy my house or let me go back," said Ken Homata, who works in a hot-spring hotel. "The volcano created our business, but now it just seems to be playing with our existence."
