Under the volcano 

The British government's inadequate response to the crisis in Montserrat is criticised in a new report 

Polly Pattullo 
Friday May 5, 2000
 
The 5,000 or so remaining residents of Montserrat, afflicted since July 1995 by the eruption of the Soufriere Hills volcano, are now settling down to the demanding task of rebuilding a society in the safe northern corner of their tiny eastern Caribbean island. Yet two-thirds of the island remains out of bounds, still threatened by the volcano: abandoned communities have become ash-ridden ghost-towns or, worse still, have been buried under the millions of tonnes of volcanic rubble. The capital, Plymouth, has been virtually destroyed. 
While the trauma of seeing homes and businesses devastated has begun to ease, the lessons learned from this unprecedented natural disaster in one of Britain's last remaining colonies are only just beginning to be articulated. What is clear is that unfinished colonial business returns to haunt. 
During the crisis, perceptions in Montserrat took on a colonial model of mistrust. At the worst moments, many Montserratians believed that the UK was deliberately seeking to "depopulate" the island, either completely or sufficiently enough to reduce HMG's financial burden. As a Montserratian journalist said: "We felt that one day we would wake up and a British ship would come and take us off." The British always denied this (a fact supported by the official records), maintaining that given its priority to protect lives it had to make contingency plans for a worst-case scenario - off-island evacuation. That this was interpreted negatively by Montserratians reflects the complexities of the emergency and the inadequacy of some of Britain's responses. 
The first inquiry into the volcano crisis was by the House of Commons select committee for international development in late 1997, in the wake of escalat ing hardship on the island. That June, 19 people had been killed by the volcano; in August came the comments from Clare Short, minister for international development, that the islanders would be wanting "golden elephants next". The despair increased as the danger from the volcano forced further evacuations. 
The select committee report, trenchant in its criticism of both the British government and the government of Montserrat, recommended that the Department for International Development (DFID) commission a "frank and impartial" report - to assess what had happened and what lessons could be learned. Undertaken by a team from the Overseas Development Institute, a detailed two-volume report, An Evaluation of HMG's Response to the Montserrat Volcanic Emergency, has just been published. 
It describes its main findings thus: "An achievement for Montserratians and a qualified success for HMG". Accolades go to the Montserratians for having coped with the "continuing volcanic menace that was wholly outside their experience". There is less enthusiasm for the British government's role, although it describes the disaster response as "a success in comparison with many other recent natural disasters elsewhere in the developing world". 
O ne exceptional quality of the problems facing Montserrat was uncertainty. What would the volcano do next? An effect of such uncertainty, as this even-handed evaluation points out, "allowed different strategies to be promoted by key stakeholders", with a feeling on the Montserratian side that DFID was "acting ungenerously" by looking at cheaper solutions to address immediate needs rather than taking a longer-term perspective. Earlier, both "sides" had adopted a "wait and see" policy: Montserrat because it was desperate not to see the island slide into virtual economic close -down, Britain because it could thereby limit its financial commitments. The denial - from both perspectives - ill-served the people of Montserrat. 
One of the most important points to emerge from this evaluation is that while overseas territories like Montserrat retain a "first call" on DFID's development programme, there is neither a budgetary ceiling nor agreed standards for the provision of housing, education and so on. In Montserrat, this led to considerable friction between the two governments. The island authorities, for example, criticised the housing relief as "socially, culturally and structurally unacceptable", particularly in relation to the public shelters with primitive sanitary conditions, overcrowding and little privacy. While Montserrat is not the "first world", it had enjoyed a good lifestyle remote from the poorest of the poor (the group targeted by DFID for priority aid). 
And then there are the institutional weaknesses of colonial structures. In a bizarre tripartite arrangement, neither the governor (the Foreign Office), DFID nor the government of Montserrat had "clear authority for many of the decisions which had to be taken". The effect was "delays, omissions and shortcomings", especially in the early days. What was re quired was not a reactive, learn-as-you-go approach but a more ambitious task force strategy, says the evaluation. 
And so planning for the future remains largely unresolved: how to plan the quantity and quality of housing, health care, education for an unknown size of population? How to reduce dependency when the economy has collapsed? What could stimulate investment? And always, there remain the uncertainties of the still-active volcano, which continues to cast its shadow over the lives of Montserratians, both on the island and in the diaspora. 
And, indeed, over Whitehall - forced through disaster to examine its responsibilities to a colony in crisis. 
Polly Pattullo is the author of Fire from the Mountain: the Tragedy of Montserrat (Constable, £9.99) comment@guardian.co.uk 

*
Dominica 

The day the earth boiled 

Chasing volcanoes is a risky business as some tourists discovered at Mount Etna last week. But the thrill of watching the earth move is a powerful draw. Polly Pattullo goes to the edge of the Boiling Lake 

Saturday June 17, 2000

 When Henry Nicholls, a British-born doctor and agriculturalist, claimed to have "discovered" Dominica's Boiling Lake in 1875, he recounted his exploits in the Illustrated London News as if he had just returned from a major imperial expedition to the head of the Nile. The local newspaper made fun of him - for while he was the first person to write an account of his adventure, hunters and map-makers had, of course, long known about this boiling volcanic cauldron in the heart of Dominica's stupendous rainforest wilderness. 
Even so, those who these days make the trek to the Boiling Lake might sympathise just a jot with the old colonial's vanity. For to go there -and return - is to feel excitement and a hint of anxiety (before), exhaustion and amazement (during) and exhilaration and more exhaustion (after). So what is it that makes it the stuff of legends (with its own "I survived" site on the internet)? 
The world's second largest boiling lake (New Zealand has the largest), its surface churnings hint at an unstable, shuddering earth below. For Dominica, along with many of its eastern Caribbean neighbours, is volcanic. Such a geology gives the island rippling mountain ranges, deep fertile valleys dense with a dazzling greenness, and water galore - streaming from rivers that plunge down waterfalls or ripple contentedly like a Scottish trout stream. 
You can know the island backwards but never know it all. The green-blanketed interior invokes an African heartland rather than an island a good deal smaller than the Isle of Wight. Hidden within these forests are sulphur springs, patches of boiling mud, fumeroles, multi-coloured streams, crater lakes, underwater hot springs and, of course, the Boiling Lake itself, deep inside the Morne Trois Pitons National Park, now a Unesco world heritage site. 
There are ambitious plans for a great long-distance hiking trail - a tropical challenge to, say, the Pennine Way. But for now, the Boiling Lake is the island's ultimate trial of strength. The one route to the Lake starts from the ridge-top village of Laudat, embalmed in sweet cooling breezes. Leave behind until your return the hot and cold delights of Titou Gorge, a sort of base camp, with its own residents, the eccentric Dr Fix-It and Sulphur, the hiking cat. And set out into the rainforest glades that are the glory of Dominica - tree ferns glittering in sun or rain, the straight-as-an-arrow trunks of the gommier, and chataigners with giant buttresses. Through the green are glimpses of the gaudy yellow-red bracts of the heliconia plant. And yet this is only "secondary" forest - a mere 20 years old, born after Hurricane David blasted its way through the island in 1979 turning green to brown hours. 
But Dominica replenishes itself fast, back to a familiar tangled, green warm-wet blanket. As Hagan Dorivea, our conscientious guide, explained, the fertility of the soil, the rain, the heat means that Dominica is a place where "one stop and you grow". So no stopping for the first hour or so until a drink from the waters of the Breakfast River. And then toiling up and up again on to the narrow ridge of Morne Nicholls. Here, the forest gives way to tough, wind-battered vegetation where the cloud cover sweeps down without warning, obliterating a view that stretches back to Laudat and down to the sea and the little coastal capital, Roseau. Then the clouds dissolved and way in front of us, but beyond one more ridge or perhaps even two, was a glimpse not of the lake itself but of steam bursting from within its green-encircled crater. 
But before you reach the Lake, you must cross the macabre Valley of Desolation. After a punishingly-steep descent, we reached a flat, bleak basin, stripped of vegetation except for mosses and ferns and surrounded by brown scree. Yet the valley seemed alive: with a whooshing sound from clouds of sulphur that rise from fumeroles; streams come and go, rocks are the colour of stained-glass windows, bubbling waters emerge inky-black or dribble milk, or flow primrose-yellow from sulphur, or orange from iron. 
By then, there was a sense of urgency to push on to the Lake itself. Another hour perhaps and then, in a final burst of energy, we reached the cliffs that edge the crater and peered through the sulphurous steam that swirls off its surface. That day, sitting above the steaming crater, I could see that its muddy, milk-white waters were calm at the edges and boiling turbulently at its centre. "Seething like a huge cauldron, so utterly unlike anything I had ever seen in nature," wrote a British visitor in 1900. 
Indeed, that is how it has seemed to me the three times that I have made it to the Lake. But not always: it can be pale-green and glassy; or grey and stormy, and despite its "boiling" reputation (people have been seriously burned by its waters and two at least killed by poisonous fumes), a friend of mine, amazingly, once swam in it - on a day when the water had been tepid, almost cold. 
But there there was little time for contemplation at the Lake before starting out on the return hike. This included an idyllic rest-stop, a bathe in a tiny, milky, wayside pool with its own warm waterfall. Then the ascents and descents, but by then the narrow green ridges were filled with afternoon sunlight and the peaks on either side rose up like a child's spiky drawing. And eventually (six to seven hours is an average time for the trek), we were back at Titou Gorge, greeted by teenagers having fun jumping into the calm waters of its mouth. Sulphur the cat was still waiting for company or food and there was the self-styled Dr Fix-It tending his vegetable garden. A local farmer locked in some impenetrable battle over land ownership, he is a man of many moods - sometimes angry, sometimes placid. Not unlike the Boiling Lake itself. 
Other volcanic hot spots in the eastern Caribbean 
This "necklace" of islands lies at the point of convergence of two tectonic plates. There are at least 17 live volcanoes - of which 10 are on Dominica - stretching from Saba, in the north, to Kick 'Em Jenny, the submerged volcano near Grenada, in the south. The first recorded volcanic event in the Caribbean occurred in St Kitts in 1692. 
Some of the most intriguing volcanoes in the eastern Caribbean include: 
Martinique: The worst catastrophe in the Caribbean's volcano history was in May 1902, when Mont Pelée erupted and some 40,000 people were killed in the coastal town of St Pierre, known as the Paris of the Antilles. The town has been rebuilt, although the ruins of the theatre remain. Visit the fascinating museum about the volcano, and hike to the summit of the now tranquil Pelée itself. Information on Martinique from the French Tourist Office (0906 8244123). 
Montserrat: Since July 1995, the Soufriere Hills volcano has been active for the first time in recorded history. Roughly two-thirds of the island remains in the "exclusion zone", although day-time visits can sometimes be made to the abandoned outskirts of the capital, Plymouth, for an awesome view (when the clouds lift) of the volcano dome and the route of the pyroclastic flows that poured into Plymouth in 1997. 
On the other side of the island, from a viewing point at Jack Boy Hill, look down to the abandoned airport where flows reached the southern edge of the runway. From there, you can also see the route down Mosquito Ghaut, where the lava killed 19 people in June 1997 after burying several communities. Visitors are welcome at the Montserrat Volcano Observatory (telephone in advance). Montserrat Tourist Board: 020-7242 3131. 
St Lucia: The famous Pitons, twin volcanic peaks, south of the village of Soufriere (named after the French word for sulphur) are the most dramatic examples of St Lucia's volcanic past. Nearby is a somewhat over-rated "drive-in volcano", where visitors admire steaming sulphur springs. St Lucia Tourist Board: 020-7431 3675. 
St Vincent: The Soufriere volcano erupted twice in the 20th century - in 1902 when 1,500 people were killed and in 1979. Start the hike from the north-east corner of the island, at the Rabacca Dry River. It's about a two-hour hike to the 700ft deep crater, one mile across. The last part involves crunching over the bare upper slopes of rock and ash. Take a guide. No nearby accommodation - the nearest is in the capital, Kingstown. St Vincent and the Grenadines Tourist Board: 020-7937 6570. 
Guadeloupe: In 1976, an increase in activity at the La Soufriere volcano on Basse Terre prompted a temporary evacuation of 70,000 people. Photographs and information about that mini-crisis can be seen at Maison du Volcan, on the flanks of the volcano. Then take the trail for a two-hour there-and-back hike to the summit. Best to go on a clear day. Scientific monitoring continues. Contact the French Tourist Office (0906 8244123). 

*
The defiance of science 

Last night's TV: Gareth McLean 

Tuesday October 24, 2000
 
Volcanoes, like dinosaurs, exert a primal fascination over humanity. While the memories of ancient cave-dwelling ancestors perhaps still hide embedded in our neural pathways ("Tree, good. Fire, bad", that kind of thing) and keep us genetically in awe of volcanoes, that wouldn't explain our enchantment with dinosaurs. Most likely, our obsession is due to the awesome, slightly fantastical nature of both dinosaurs and volcanoes, their actual existence an affront to our fanatical ordering and taming of the world. They appeal to a deep-rooted, subliminal masochism, a desire for disorder and mayhem: the defiance of science. 
Hence these days, humanity's fascination with giant lizards and flaming mountains mainly manifests itself in small boys of a certain age, who enjoy the notion of chaos. Such boys - I am speaking from experience here - draw tableau upon tableau of dinosaurs and volcanoes whenever the opportunity of being alone with a set of Berol felt tip pens arises. (Crayola crayons, I have always been convinced, are for girls, since the colours have names just like lipsticks.) In these drawings, the dinosaurs are sometimes fighting on the slopes of volcanoes. Sometimes they are running from the flowing lava and the falling ash and very occasionally - perhaps after too much orange juice - the dinosaurs are eating the volcanoes whole. (They were big dinosaurs and orange juice contained excessive tartrazine in those days.) 
In a strange parallel universe then, I might have turned out like John Seach, a volcanologist who braves noxious clouds of gas, showers of volcanic rocks and smothering rivers of ash to study his chosen subject up close. Volcano (Channel 4) followed John and his colleagues up the slopes of active volcanoes ("If the volcano blew now, John and Geoff [the cameraman] would be incinerated"), down the deserted streets of a town in the shadow of a brewing, spewing volcano ("We need to get out of here now"), to acid lakes ("More corrosive than battery acid") and underwater to examine lava flows ("Blub, blub, ooh, hot"). 
Volcano didn't cover any ground that a hundred previous documentaries on the subject haven't, but such is the allure of volcanoes themselves, that hardly mattered. It is for the spectacle as well as the science that we watch programmes about super-natural phenomena. John and his ilk may seem like graduates from the Homer Simpson School of Doing Sensible Activities, but their bravery/stupidity is something we all envy slightly. Were it not for the likelihood of a horrible burning death, who wouldn't want to adventure like a volcanologist, if only to see lava up close. (I have always thought lava looks edible. If they ever invent raspberry treacle, it will look like lava.) 
Ruby (BBC1) was up close and personal with Roseanne in the first of a 12-part series of conversations over drinks and dinner. (This is a great and underused format which would be really good if, each week, Ruby - or whoever - had a different telly chef make her and her guests a meal before they sat down to a jolly discussion. Parkinson meets Ready Steady Cook, if you will.) An encounter between Ruby and Roseanne could so easily have descended into a competition - of the who-can-strip-paint-with-their-voice-quicker variety - but both women were surprisingly restrained, with the result that a revealing, funny and tender chat developed. Thanks to sparky chemistry, Ruby turned out to be an invigorating watch and could be accorded the highest compliment for a chat show. At 40 minutes, it seemed too short. 
Only one thing niggled and that was the identity and purpose of the mysterious couple who were sitting at the other table in Ruby's restaurant? Friends? Lovers? Business partners? Researchers put there to fill an empty space? Whatever, if they thought they were having an illicit meeting, boy are they mistaken. 
The Teapot Incident (when Handy Andy and the lovely but shrieky Linda Barker managed to destroy a participant's prized collection of - admittedly hideous - teapots by putting them on shoddy shelves which promptly collapsed) marked an all-time low in designer-participant relations on Changing Rooms (BBC1). Amazingly, members of the public are still letting them into their homes. That isn't the biggest shock however. It would seem Carol Smillie isn't pregnant.

Popo exhales behind a smokescreen 

Locals scorn warning of Mexican mega eruption 

Jo Tuckman in Santiago Xalitzintla
Tuesday November 21, 2000
 
Billowing plumes of sulphur dioxide, water vapour and ash have been shooting miles up into the sky from Popocatepetl's crater for weeks. But Antonio Analco has nothing but disdain for the official alert. 
"I know nothing is going to happen," he says. 
Don Antonio is a shaman and rainmaker and the Mexican volcano's "spirit" comes to him in dreams, personified as an old man called Don Gregorio - Don Goyo for short. 
"If Don Goyo warns me, then I'll warn everybody else. These scientists and their instruments are a big con trick." 
Don Antonio's village, Santiago Xalitzintla, nestles about seven miles from the crater on the volcano's north-eastern flank. It would almost certainly be wiped out by the avalanche of sludge and acidic gases surging down the canyons at more than 60mph which is likely to accompany a major eruption, even before the lava reached it. 
Geologists believe that this last happened 1,200 years ago, and none of the experts are predicting a repeat. They think Popo's huffing and puffing may intensify to the point of producing incandescent material, but they do not expect the sacred mountain of the Aztecs to blow. 
But they could be wrong. The prediction that Pinatubo volcano in the Philippines would erupt in 1991 is the only significant example of accurate scientific forecasting. 
"At Popo they just don't know what's going to happen, and it is not for want of trying; but it's the same problem we face with any volcano," says Jim Luhr a volcanologist from the Smithsonian Institution in Washington DC. 
"What we get up to is barely a science." 
So why bother trying? asks Don Rufino, standing in front of the 5,465-metre (17,930ft) symmetrical cone."If the volcano decides it's time, we won't have time to do anything about it." 
He is more worried about soldiers enforcing the ban on going within six miles of the crater, which prevents villagers reaching their fields to harvest their maize. 
The National Disaster Prevention Centre says that about 30,000 people living in the nearest villages are at serious risk from a major eruption. There are about 300,000 people in the second-tier danger zone, and 800,000 in the entire risk area, while the tens of millions in Mexico City to the north-west and Puebla to the east could be affected by ash clouds. 
This is why Popocatepetl is the most closely monitored of Mexico's 14 active volcanoes, with a special unit in the capital to keep a 24-hour watch on it. 
Instruments on the mountain relay the seismic activity caused by smoke exhalations and deep molten-rock movements, tiny increases in volume which could indicate the build-up of pressure, and changes in the the gases emitted. 
"We are pretty certain to see a big one coming hours to days before it actually happens," says Enrique Guevara, the unit's coordinator, pointing to the automatic alarm systems which would give the signal to evacuate the area. 
But people on the volcano are often reluctant to abandon their houses and animals. 
"They can keep their shelters and their second-hand clothes. I'm not going," says Dona Ines. 
She has bad memories of the last and only evacuation in December 1994, when the volcano awoke after being dormant for almost 70 years. 
"The volcano is only breathing. It has always smoked," she says. 
Popocatepetl smoked for the Aztecs, in whose mythology it was a torch-bearing warrior mourning his dead love - a nearby volcano called Iztaccihuatl, which resembles a reclining woman. 
It smoked when the Spanish conquistador Hernan Cortes passed by on his way to the Aztec capital, and it went through several heavy puffing bouts in subsequent centuries, with the last one in 1921. 
The 1994 reawakening, the scientists say, was triggered by a new injection of molten rock into the magma chamber, and the current intensification of activity is due to the formation of a lava dome inside the crater which is obstructing the regular release of energy. 
But although Popocatepetl even means "smoking mountain" in the indigenous Nahuatl language, its main sacred function is its relationship to water, and it particular the pre-Colombian rain god Tlaloc. 
"The conquest suppressed the large-scale rituals but the small community rites to bring rain or keep away bad weather continue until today," says Julio Glokner, an anthropologist, who has been traipsing up and down the volcano after Don Antonio and other shamans since 1989. 
Every community on Popocatepetl has its traditions and every rainmaker his or her own style. 
In Don Antonio's dreams Don Goyo asks for specific offerings that are carried up to mountain shrines. In recent years these have included a business suit, an accordion and a warrior costume. 
Don Antonio says he would be willing to talk to the scientists in Mexico City, but "only if they are willing to listen to what I have to say too". 
But it is not just the experts who are loathe to rely on the shaman's confidence that the volcano would not erupt without telling him first. 
"I've been a sceptic ever since I was a little boy. I used to throw things at their rituals," says Raul Sanchez, whose family has lived for decades in Amecameca on the side of the volcano. 
He has worked out his own system for understanding the clouds around the summit, and has collected ash samples to investigate the probability of a major eruption. 
He believes that Popocatepetl may erupt, but not on his side of the mountain. 
"I do this to see whether we really have to start running or not, and the truth is we don't." 

*
Villages deserted as Popo spits red 

Jo Tuckman in Cholula
Thursday December 21, 2000
 
With red hot rocks spewing from the crater of Mexico's Popocatepetl volcano for the second night running, and no end in sight to the mountain's most dramatic eruptive phase in more than 500 years, tens of thousands of people face a prolonged exile from villages dotted around the danger zone. 
"When the volcano started spitting fire we realised we couldn't wait any longer and had to leave," explained Adolfo Flores, 16, from the safe distance of a school-turned-shelter in the colonial town of Cholula, famed for its stunning views of Popocatepetl. 
Like many from the poor villages at the volcano's feet which are most at risk if the eruptions prompt a major lava flow or avalanche of acidic sludge, Adolfo's family had ignored evacuation calls over the weekend. 
"When there were just the white and grey plumes coming out of the crater we thought we didn't need to worry," he said, displaying generations of collective memory in which periodic phases of intensified exhalations were dismissed as unthreatening heavy breathing. "But then the volcano showed that this was something different this time, something serious." 
Popo, as the mountain is commonly known, had been pouring out water vapour and ash for days, but a dome of lava inside the crater had blocked the release of the energy, triggering the first eruptive episode on Monday night. 
The evacuees in the Cholula shelter described how the waves of incandescence spraying across the night sky just a few miles away sent them scurrying for the evacuation buses which had been on standby since Friday. 
"We have nothing with us. Documents, a few clothes, but that's all," said Irma Sanchez, waiting in a lunch queue with her standard-issue plate and mug. "When you have to make a choice between your material possessions and protecting your life, you don't have to think very hard." 
This shelter holds about 700 of the approximately 35,000 people evacuated, mostly on Monday night or during the second eruptive episode, before dawn on Tuesday. While the majority went willingly, some refused to abandon all their possessions, although most of those who remained were persuaded to go when Popo erupted for several hours during Tuesday night. 
"I can't go. Who will feed my piglets?" Juana de la Cruz, 71, said as she trudged through the village of Santiago Xalitzintla. She believed that the volcano would never harm those who lived by its side, but promised to bail out if it started spitting red again, as it did three hours later. 
During the relative daytime calm on Tuesday, a twisted mass of vapour and ash stretched for miles into a bright blue sky, providing a dramatic backdrop to the now ghostlike villages below. 
With shutters down, the only signs of life were provided by the odd evacuee picking up essentials or feeding animals, dogs roaming in packs, and troops on standby to evacuate even the most reticent if a major eruption were forecast. 
The alert has captured Mexico's imagination, with millions glued to the live transmissions of eruptions on television. It has also provided President Vicente Fox with his first test of disaster-management in a country that, as well as being home to 14 active volcanoes, is plagued by floods, hurricanes and earthquakes. 
On a tour of the danger area, Mr Fox called for caution but promised everything was under control because "the volcanologists have all the information about what is going on in the intestines, the stomach, and the mind of the volcano. We just have to be prepared to react to what it tells us." No injuries have yet been reported. 
But if the correct prediction of the first eruption has forced locals to rethink their view of the experts as scaremongers playing with expensive useless toys, many still believe there is much more to the eruption than pressure build-ups. 
"Me and my mates have been talking, and although we aren't sure why he [the volcano] is acting this way, we think it might be that he's angry that we're cutting down the trees on his side," explained Adolfo, who recalls seeing the personification of the volcano, an old man called Don Goyo, in a forest on the mountain's flank six years ago. 
In an updated version of the traditional offerings taken to Popo's mystical shrines, Adolfo and his friends plan to rent a sound system and hold a dance to honour and placate Don Goyo as soon as it is safe to go home. 

*
'It was dangerous. That was the point' 

In 1993, volcanologist Stanley Williams led 16 people up a Colombian volcano. It erupted and nine of them died. Having survived with terrible injuries, Williams presented himself to the world as a plucky hero, but now he is being blamed for the tragedy. He tells James Meek why it was not his fault 

Monday June 4, 2001

Stanley Williams likes the taste of guinea pig. In the city of Pasto in south-western Colombia, where the dish is common, they grill a few of the animals on a single skewer and serve them sizzling hot, roughly chopped into several pieces. It's not the kind of fare you'd get at a restaurant in Williams' native Arizona. In America, in western Europe, guinea pigs are pets. Eating pets is wrong, right? Eating pets is weird. 
Even before the volcano Galeras, near Pasto, erupted while he was on it, smashing Williams' skull and vapourising some of his friends, the volcanologist was coming to the conclusion that it was his country, rather than the rest of the world, which was weird. Local scientists can't afford the equipment and training they need to monitor it as volcanoes in Europe, the US or Japan are monitored. 
On January 14 1993, Williams, professor of geology at Arizona state university, led a party of 16 people - 13 scientists and engineers, including himself, and three tourists - to the crater at the summit of the 9,000ft volcano. It was the highlight of a UN-sponsored conference in Pasto. Although they knew Galeras was the most active volcano in Colombia, and had erupted almost 30 times in 500 years, most recently in July 1992, they believed from the seismological and gas emission evidence they had that it was quiet. 
At about 1.40pm, just after Williams had asked the group to begin wrapping up for departure, rocks began to tumble off the wall of the crater, first singly, then in a cascade. Williams shouted: "Hurry up! Get out!" It was too late. The volcano shook, there was a sound like thunder, and the earth opened up. Gas pressure which had been building up for months was released and tons of rocks and ash poured into the air. Stones, some of them white hot and some the size of television sets, bombed down. 
Carlos Trujillo, a local engineer, died in a blast of intense heat which left nothing but a blackened, lacerated head and torso. A scientist from another part of Colombia, Nestor Garcia, together with the distinguished Russian volcanologist, Igor Menyailov, who were actually in the crater at the time of the eruption, were instantly turned to gas; no trace of them was ever found. Nor did anything remain of Geoff Brown, an expert in volcanoes from the Open University, or Fernando Cuenca, who had been close to Trujillo on the lip of the crater. Jose Arlez, another Pasto scientist, and the three tourists were burned and bombed to death by rocks flying with the velocity of bullets. 
Williams and three others, who were standing close to Arlez, were lucky not to bring the number of deaths from nine to 13. Williams came closest to sharing the fate of Arlez and the tourists: a rock the size of an orange smashed into his head, sending skull fragments deep into his brain. Another bombardment broke both his legs; his left leg had one bone sticking out of his trousers, his right foot remained attached only by tendons and strips of flesh. He was saved in a rescue led by two brave women colleagues, Marta Calvache and Patty Mothes, and by a young Colombian neurosurgeon who removed a piece of his brain the size of a peach stone. 
In the years since the eruption, Williams has become a celebrity. He has also acquired enemies. The bitterness about his personality, and about what happened on Galeras, has now broken out of the small circle of volcanology with the publication of two book versions of the events of 1993. One, Surviving Galeras, is Williams' own, written with Fen Montaigne; the other, No Apparent Danger, is written by a geology graduate and science writer, Victoria Bruce. 
Bruce's book accuses Williams of recklessly leading a party to the summit of Galeras, without safety helmets, protective suits or an emergency escape plan, in the face of evidence that the volcano was about to blow. They are harsh allegations, which Williams denies. He disputes the notion that a few screw-shaped blips on local seismographs represented warning enough that trouble was imminent. What he doesn't dispute is that active volcanoes are dangerous places - but he maintains that everyone in the group was well aware of that. The title of Bruce's book, he argues, doesn't make much sense. 
"Everybody who went there knew they were going to a dangerous volcano. That was the whole point," he says. 
"I was very careful to include some of the world's experts in volcanic earthquakes. In meetings we had we talked to each other, we had looked at the records, and in the days before the fatal eruption several different people had talked about the activity of Galeras to Colombian scientists who'd lived there for 25 years. Even if we'd been crazy and refused to listen to their warnings, would they have allowed their close friends to go into a ridiculously dangerous place on that day?" 
Hard hats could have saved lives and his head, Williams admits. He wears one on volcanoes now. But it is hard to see how an emergency plan would have helped. And Williams was in the company of two of the world's most eminent experts on volcanoes; Brown and Menyailov, who first went up a volcano in Kamchatka before he was even born, in the womb of his volcanologist mother. They are dead now, and cannot bear witness, but it is hard to take seriously Bruce's suggestion that these tough, experienced scientists were intimidated by Williams into going up Galeras. 
Williams sees the criticism of his actions, in part, as an attempt to project the fantasy values of America onto the real world, the world of actual hazard, the world where people eat guinea pigs instead of hamburgers and grow coca for cocaine instead of corn. America glorifies those who take risks in the abstract, and sues over risks in the particular. 
"People are obsessed with their liability," he says. "When I was 13 I lived in a part of the suburbs where they were building new houses and I worked as a helper. The builders liked me so they let me do more and more tasks, they let me take scraps of wood to build a fort, they let me drive their steamroller. None of that would be allowed now because they'd be terrified of legal liability. It's not an option for my son, Nicholas, who's 13 now. People are afraid. They think they learn about dangers but they don't learn quite enough to be realistic. 
"When I discovered volcanology was what I wanted to do I never even considered the danger. I was enthralled by watching with my own eyes the process of rocks being formed, watching nature do its thing. When prospective students approach me, curious about volcanoes, I never let them go anywhere near one until we've discussed the dangers. But I have to remind people that climbing a volcano is much less dangerous than driving in Colombia, whether you have an accident or you're held up at gunpoint." 
Williams accepts no guilt for the nine dead on Galeras. He does accept responsibility for his behaviour after the eruption, when for years he presented himself in the media - or, as he puts it, allowed the media to present him - as the sole survivor of the disaster. At least three others - Mike Conway, Andrew McFarlane and Luis Lamarie - were close to him when the crater blew, and were injured as they fled. He finds it hard to explain why he did that. Enough colleagues have gone public with their complaints about him - including allegations that he filched research, which he denies - to suggest that he was aggressive and abrasive in his dealings with fellow-scientists. In a mea culpa in the book, he admits his fame "fed my not inconsiderable ego." 
He played up the lone survivor image, he thinks, because the experience on the volcano that day changed him. The original Stanley Williams - a sharp scientist, not the best, but pretty good, and anxious to help secure the safety of the 500m people who live in danger range of volcanoes - didn't come back from Galeras. "I'm different," he says. "That guy died. I have to accept that." The post-eruption Williams is partially deaf, walks with some difficulty on extensively reconstructed legs, suffers from depression and unreasonable anger, mixes up words and is no longer up to scratch in the kind of higher abstract thinking scientists need. The first impression you have when you meet him is of anxiety and unease. 
"My guess is I'm still wrapped up in myself, because I'm still working on my health," says Williams. "Last week I went to see three different physicians. I take 20 pills a day. I think about myself too much." 
He has returned to Galeras since 1993, although only after another eruption aborted one planned trip. 
"In 1995, Galeras finally let me back inside its crater. I was in and out in two hours. I came down with pneumonia. Basically it was my not being strong enough to handle that effort. I shouldn't have done it. It wasn't an unbelievable, facing God kind of thing. I'm just not that sensitive, I guess. I wanted to go back there, I wanted to go back and stand on that spot, and think about Igor smiling, Geoff waving at me, me just explaining to the tourists what was going on. And a minute later everyone died. I don't have any sense of guilt for the deaths, but I miss them. It's a very sad thing."
