On Sunday morning, an earthquake measuring 6.1 sent rocks and mud tumbling, cracked roads and burst a water main. Later in the day, a typhoon that had killed more than 80 people in the Philippines raced up Japan's eastern coast, lashing Miyake-jima with strong winds and heavy rains. Five people were killed on the Japanese mainland.
And there is no end in sight just yet. Yesterday the meteorological agency warned the earthquakes indicate that the volcano will continue to erupt.

*
Wave of destruction 

Bill McGuire looks at the horrifying wall of water that could sweep away a coastal city and cause the greatest natural catastrophe in human history 

Thursday October 12, 2000


Tsunamis are silent, stalking horrors that often appear without warning and with no apparent cause to devastate a coastline thousands of kilometres from their source. 
Compared with earthquakes and volcanic eruptions, images of tsunamis are rare. Anyone close enough to photograph them is usually rewarded with a watery grave alongside the fragmented remains of the camera. 
Most result from large submarine earthquakes that give the sea floor and the water above such a jolt that waves shoot outwards in all directions. In the last century alone, earthquakes around the Pacific rim produced over 400 tsunamis in this way resulting in the loss of over 50,000 lives. 
Volcanoes can also produce devastating tsunamis, with the cataclysmic 1883 eruption of Krakatoa (Indonesia) churning up the sea sufficiently to produce lethal waves that killed 36,000 people. 
Submarine landslides are also particularly effective: a gigantic collapse off the coast of Norway around 7,000 years ago resulted in north-eastern Scotland being inundated by huge waves. 
Even scarier are the mega-tsunamis formed by gigantic landslides at ocean island volcanoes. Before the last Ice Age a chunk of rock ten times the size of the Isle of Wight fell off the flank of the Mauna Loa volcano on the Big Island of Hawaii, forming tsunamis that raged 320m up the sides of neighbouring islands and even pounded the coastline of New South Wales 7,000km away. 
Scarier still, when a 1km asteroid plunged into the southeast Pacific just over two million years ago it sent a 70m wave of destruction hurtling across the entire Pacific. 
They are very different from the normal, wind-driven waves that break millions of times a day on our shores. One of their strangest properties is the Jekyll and Hyde transformation as they approach the shore. In deep water a tsunami is to all intents and purposes invisible; a wave less than a metre high that is lost among the troughs and peaks of a turbulent sea. 
Only when the tsunami enters shallow water does it start to build in height as the front of the wave slows and is caught by more water from behind. In a matter of minutes a half-metre swell can become a wall of water 20m or more high. And if the waves are focused into estuaries and bays, this height can increase even further. This behaviour sheds light on the derivation of the term "tsunami", which in the original Japanese means 'harbour wave'. 
The building of a tsunami as it approaches a coastline also results in another of its weird properties. As the wave increases in size it sucks in water that causes the sea to retreat from the shore, sometimes as far as the horizon or beyond - collecting it all together for the big push. 
Unless the local population has been educated in the mysteries of the tsunami, this can be lethal as thousands rush curiously on to the exposed sea-bed only to be battered by the sudden appearance of the tsunami itself. And can they move? In deep water, tsunamis can move at speeds in excess of 800km an hour - as fast as a jet aircraft - and even when the wave slows as it enters the shallows there is no possibility of outrunning it. 
Another difference between tsunamis and wind-driven storm waves is that the entire column of water from the sea surface to the sea floor, perhaps several kilometres high, is involved in the wave motion. 
So, for example, the entire volume of the ocean is involved in the transmission of a tsunami from one side of the Pacific to the other. Trying to cram all this movement into progressively shallowing waters is part of the reason for the terrifying height increase as a tsunami approaches a coastline. The water simply has nowhere else to go but up. 
But it is not only the spectacular height and power of tsunamis that makes them so destructive. When they hit the coast they just keep coming - perhaps for 20 to 30 minutes - before taking the same time to drain back into the ocean. This is because a tsunami wavelength is typically hundreds of kilometres long rather than the few tens of metres characteristic of storm waves. 
Such long waves reflect the scale of the phenomena that generate tsunamis. If a submarine quake thrusts upwards an area of sea floor the size of England by a metre or two then you can be sure that the ripples formed will be of a comparably spectacular scale. 
The destructive power of a tsunami is truly awesome. Ships and coastal installations are smashed to matchwood in seconds and solid metal structures such as parking metres are combed flat. A three-storey building would be lucky to survive an impact from a 10m wave, while a 20m wave would leave a five storey office block much the worse for wear. 
A fragile human caught in the open has almost no chance of survival and severe battering by debris results in few bodies being recovered intact. Many, in fact, are carried far out into the ocean never to be seen again. 
Things have been relatively quiet on the tsunami front since 1998 when an offshore earthquake and accompanying submarine landslide generated a series of waves that flattened villages and took 3,000 lives on the north coast of New Guinea . Sadly, further big earthquakes are sure to repeat this scenario time and time again in coming years. 
Waiting in the wings, however, is the terrifying prospect of the coming Atlantic mega-tsunami. The western flank of the Cumbre Vieja volcano on the Canary Island of La Palma remains unstable and poised to slide into the sea. Recent modelling has shown that when this happens the initial wave will be 600m high. Eight hours later, as the wall of water bears down on the east coast of the United States and the Caribbean Islands, the human race will face the greatest natural catastrophe in its history. You have been warned! 
 Bill McGuire is the Benfield Greig professor of geohazards and director of the Benfield Greig Hazard research centre at University College London. The coming Atlantic Mega-tsunami is the focus of tonight's Horizon programme on BBC2 at 9.30pm

*
Rage of the gods 

For centuries, humankind has gazed in awe at the world's volcanoes. Even today, vulcanologists are unable to predict their fiery tantrums. But for Melanie McGrath, a self-confessed volcano junkie, the power of nature's devastating time-bombs is as life-enhancing as is their will to destroy 

Saturday October 12, 2002


A year ago this summer I travelled to Sicily to watch Mount Etna erupt. I did this on a whim. Police had cordoned off the roads leading to the summit, so we drove as close as we could, up to a tree-lined parking bay a few kilometres from Sapienza, where lava from the eruption had already incinerated the ski-lift and a tourist lodge, and was rolling down to meet the road above us. It was the middle of the day and the sun was obscured by cloud, the sky a dark yellow-grey and stinking. A few spectators had gathered at the cordon. A few more stayed in their cars, all the better to make a quick getaway, if it became necessary. At one end of the bay an enterprising trader had set up a stall selling coffee, panini and the little almond biscuits typical of the region. The rumble of stomachs was lost in the louder geologic grumbling, and no one had much of an appetite. Someone joked that if fate brought the lava stream our way, there might at least be time to order a decent double espresso and leave this world on a high. There was all the usual anxious camaraderie and morbid humour you get on such occasions. 
Several hundred metres above us, two vast Plinian eruption columns spewed ash over Sicily. The smoke rolled like waves and there was a slight shaking of the ground. It felt as though the world was on the move. Ash came down as black rain, making a sound like the hissing of breakwater through the pines and junipers. From time to time an unnaturally hot wind gusted down, as though fleeing the summit to safety. Ash collected on my lungs and a small pile of grit settled in my stomach. It was one of those rare moments when the internal organs lose their mystery and make themselves known, just as the volcano itself was. We were suddenly intensely aware of our mortality and of the murky fragility of human offal. 
At the end of the parking bay, furthest from the coffee stall, a handful of amateur vulcanologists stood on the wrong side of the police cordon, taking notes. Beside these men, in the gathering dust, lay various Heath Robinson-style gadgets - lovingly crafted, no doubt, in potting sheds as far apart as Cardiff and Sofia, from bits of old ham radio and the like. They spoke rarely, in English, in a dozen different accents, flexing the technical jargon of their hobby. Words such as pyroclastic, Strombolian, phreatic, maar and magma drifted up to meet the eggy air. They wore insouciant expressions, as if to emphasise that the boiling tumult above them was all in a day's work for men such as they, and from time to time paid grave attention to waterproof notepads and twiddled instrument dials to prove the point. 
For thousands of years Etna has imbued everything around it with a sense of doom that would seem melodramatic were it not for the very real threat posed by the volcano's regular eruptions. The little villages poised on its foothills are dependent on the rich soils for the success of their grape, apricot and almond crops, but subject also to swamping and demolition. In 1971, an eruption destroyed the observatory built to give warnings of the event. In 1992, the town of Zafferana Etnea was part buried. In 2001, it was Sapienza's turn. 
Catania is the nearest major city to Etna. A construction of volcanic tuff and basalt, it is dominated both physically and economically by the volcano. Once a great port, the huddled and depressing city streets have fallen prey to the enervating parasitism of the mafia; its citizens now depend for a living on the tourism that Etna brings. Every so often, as if offering a lesson in hubris, Etna reminds the city who is boss. In 1669, the place was completely destroyed, its castle surrounded by a moat of molten rock. It seems appropriate that the mafia hold out here. It is a place for dark business done by violent means. 
A brawny Frenchman emerged from the haze above us, sooty-faced and sweating from the heat. He'd been to see the lava flow where it crossed the road about 2km beyond the cordon and reported that a better view was to be had from the other side of the volcano. We drove around the foothills towards the town of Adrano on the western slopes, and from there took a semi-paved side road uphill. A few kilometres from Sapienza, we again came up against a police cordon, but a better tended one. Here, many people were gathered to watch the sun come down behind the plumes of ash, staining them a downy red-brown: from where we were standing, they looked like the great iron columns of a king-sized Victorian railway station rusting in the black rain. 
The eruption was, as the Frenchman had promised, more dramatic from this vantage. As the sun retreated, the ashy plumes dissolved into darkness, leaving bright patches here and there as the flow of lava cracked, exposing its flaming interior. We clambered in the dark across tuff, silent or speaking in low whispers. Ash ticked against the rock, and every so often a low, loud growling issued from the lower crater, followed by a boom as magma burst into the air in a Roman candle and began to creep down the mountainside, shuddering the ground on either side. As the lava roiled, I thought I could smell the pine and juniper trees it was burning up on its lightless procession towards Catania and the sea. The contradictory nature of the scene struck me very forcefully. This was something both of the earth and otherworldly. We had entered geologic time. 
I can tell you when I climbed my first volcano. It was about 15 years ago, and the cone in question was Volcan Agua in Guatemala. I climbed it for the view, but, as so often with volcanoes, a band of cloud ringed the summit and obscured everything more than a metre or two away. My companion and I got lost; darkness fell before we could find our way back down, and I became rather tearful at the prospect of a night on the shale. All the same, something must have woken in me as I napped on the slopes that night, because I've been clambering up volcanoes ever since. Ordinary mountains bore me, but there's something at the top of a volcano beyond the abstract notion of a summit. There's a crater. (OK, it's not always at the top.) Volcano fans such as myself will go any distance just to be able to gaze down into that ultimate depth. Jules Verne set his Journey To The Centre Of The Earth at the volcanic glacier of Snaefell in Iceland. The villain's den in You Only Live Twice is a hole in a volcano. Hell is to be found there. I've been, so I know. 
The euphemistically named Yucca Mountain, near Las Vegas, Nevada, is actually an extinct volcano, in which the US is currently planning to store its high-grade nuclear waste. I visited it to report for this newspaper. A mile inside its bowels there is a Bond-like scene - caves and tunnels filled with scientists and other madmen tweaking Geiger counters, checking the viability of waste plutonium pellets and, in one way or another, planning world domination. 
Aside from the crater, the appeal for me is the peculiarly archaic nature of the cone. It's impossible to imagine dinosaurs without envisioning a backdrop of volcanoes behind. There is something transcendent and sublime about them - also, as a consequence, something slightly florid, even camp. The 19th-century American landscape painter, Frederic Church, instinctively knew this when he painted Cotopaxi, Ecuador, in mid-eruption. I saw the painting in a recent exhibition at Tate Britain. Church first visited Cotopaxi in 1861 and painted it in repose; a year later, he was asked to repaint the thing erupting, apparently as a symbol of the American civil war. 
In western culture, volcanoes are generally associated with Boys' Own values, dangerous adventure and furious passions. It was the Roman god Vulcan, after all, who forged Apollo's bronze arrows and Hercules' armour, and was himself possessed of a grand temper. There's a certain undeniable sexual symbolism, which no doubt titillates the lads at some, perhaps unconscious, level. I don't want to press this, but I ask you to note that most volcanoes are breast-shaped and, when erupting, more or less ejaculate. That pretty much covers all bases. 
Vulcanologists, both amateur and professional, come equipped with a reputation for obsession and spoddishness that makes mere volcano enthusiasts, such as myself, rather wary of them. As a consequence of this prejudice, I have avoided their company over the years, happy to watch from the sidelines as they plunge across antique lava flows, messing with their instruments and peering bug-eyed into quaking fissures. There are around 700 professional vulcanologists operating around the world today. Out of a sense of fairness, I rang a few and asked them what it was that drove them to devote a life to cones. 
Grant Heiken, former president of the International Association of Vulcanology, was 12 when he came across a book about the emergence and eruption in 1943 of Volcan Paricutín in a cornfield in Mexico. "I digested it from cover to cover," he says. "I just had to understand what happened, the mechanics of the thing." 
For Magns Tumi Gudmundsson, a vulcanologist based in Reykjavik, "It was the eruption of [the Icelandic volcano] Hekla when I was nine years old that stays fixed in my memory," he says. "I remember the fine ash falling - it was almost invisible, but you could feel it on your skin. Most of my work has to do with eruptions under ice. We are dealing with the forces of fire, ice and water. The fieldwork involves working in a landscape that is so raw, intense and changeable that you feel privileged just to be there." 
It was this same dynamism that attracted Steve Sparks, now a professor at Bristol University. "Volcanoes are unusual in geology in that eruptions happen fast," he says, "and you can directly observe the processes. And, yes, it does have a kind of glamour." Needless to say, cone-love is a dangerous kind of romance. In the past 30 years, 23 professional vulcanologists have lost their lives while working near or on volcanoes. 
The mannish impulse to master nature is, in the case of the volcano, a very good and necessary thing. Millions of people live in the shadow of cones, most of them poor farmers, dependent on the rich volcanic soils. The development of predictive technologies such as ultrasound, as well as detailed computer simulations for lava flows - and, most recently, the use of satellites to monitor ground distortions - all make eruptions easier to predict. Using satellite technology, scientists at the California Institute of Technology very recently detected volcanic activity in four Andean volcanoes (Uturuncu in Bolivia, Cerro Blanco, on the southern rim of the Robledo caldera in Argentina, Hualca Hualca in Peru - all of which had been thought extinct - and the previously unknown but now named Lazufre on the border between Chile and Argentina). Even so, the science of volcanic eruptions is still not fully understood, and there is much work to be done - research that is made more complex by the fact that every volcano is unique. But science itself cannot guarantee safety, particularly since so many volcanoes are in areas with few economic resources. 
There are no records as to how many people are buried under Etna, but it must be a great many: the volcano has come alive every few years since written records began. Pindar wrote the first recorded description of an eruption in 475BC ("From the mountain pure springs of unapproachable fire are vomited from the inmost depths"). Virgil witnessed another, and said it was the burning breath of the Titan Enceladus as he struggled to free himself from the underground prison to which Zeus had condemned him. A hundred years or so before, the Greek philosopher Empedocles lived in an observatory high up the slopes of Etna and eventually, convinced by his own intellectual investment in hot air that the escaping gases would support his weight, threw himself into the crater. That's philosophy for you. 
Things have moved on somewhat since then, though it is only recently, since the early 1990s, that vulcanologists have concentrated their efforts on minimising the hazards presented by the cones. Before that, research tended to focus on the whys and wherefores of eruptions, rather than their effect on proximal human populations. Since 1995, an international group of city planners, medics, vulcanologists, politicians and aid agencies has been meeting biannually, under the rubric of Cities On Volcanoes, to plan for possible disasters. It will take much longer, of course, to shift the cultural rubble. 
For me, standing watching Etna, the scene was much the same as it had been for Pindar, Virgil and their suicidal friend: freighted with age-old personifications and imbued with the crude symbolism of the eruption as a manifestation of anger, violence, instability, the primitive, the id. Its moral symbolism was fresh in my mind, too: the idea of a refurbishment, of resurrection, a turning inside-out, of the emergence of something elemental and virtuous - a "truth", of some kind. 
This past summer, exactly a year after my trip to Etna, I found myself standing on another volcano on the other side of the world. Mombacho on the shores of Lake Nicaragua has long been dormant. In its old glory days, it calved islands in the lake where palm trees and cottonwoods now grow. The lower slopes of the volcano have for hundreds of years provided a living for coffee growers. Beyond the plantation terraces, at the higher elevations, the cloud forest stretches to the sky, dank, still and archaic. Ferns, bromeliads, lianas and orchids spring from the branches of trees; 119 species of bird live among their leaves, and pumas and ocelots are said to prowl about at Mombacho's summit. Remnants of the Jurassic scurry about in the form of iguanas and salamanders, part concealed in the ever present mist. Mombacho has a deeply undisturbed air; the forest is primary, ancient and uncut. In spite of the presence of the plantations, there were no coffee stalls here, no police cordons or amateur vulcanologists. Mombacho's offerings are less obviously dramatic than Etna's, but together they add up to something profound. 
Scientists now know that the earth's atmosphere was formed from the ancient eruptions of cones long since extinct. We breathe the breath of volcanoes, purified and augmented by forests such as the one on Mombacho. And that brings me to the wonderful paradox of volcanoes and the real source of their fascination for me. Living volcanoes have so often brought death to everything around them that it is easy to forget this one fact: it was dead volcanoes that first breathed us into life

Science update 

Tim Radford 
Thursday December 16, 1999

Mudshed and bloodshed 
It isn't always the eruption that kills, the University at Buffalo vulcanologist Michael Sheridan told the American Geophysical Union on Tuesday. Dormant volcanoes - in the north-west, in Mexico and other places - are also a threat. Collapsing soft spots on the mountainside could be enough to trigger devastating mudflows which can flow for up to 80 miles. "This is the frightening part about it. These volcanoes don't have to erupt. They just sit there and a part of it comes roaring off," he said. "We have to pay more attention to these older volcanoes that have been sitting around for a while, stewing in their own juices." It created problems for development near Seattle and Tacoma, below Mt Rainier in Washington state, where there is a history of mudflows. "People are not willing to accept the concept that this is a really dangerous area."

Thousands flee Congo eruption 

Fires rage as mile-wide river of lava engulfs village 

Helen Vesperini in Goma
Friday January 18, 2002


A volcano with a deadly past erupted yesterday in Congo, forcing thousands of residents to flee as fires started by the lava spread to the eastern border town of Goma, witnesses said. 
People clutching possessions, from sewing machines to ducks, abandoned villages in the path of the molten rock, some leaving relatives behind. 
"I left my father and my grandmother," said one refugee, Boniface, 20. "My grandmother refused to move and my father refused to leave his mother. I think they're going to die soon,". 
Buildings and trees caught fire and crashed to the ground as winds fanned flames sparked by the lava from the 3,469-metre (11,380ft) Nyiragongo volcano, creating a spectacular orange glow in a starless sky. 
"I've never seen so much fire in my life. I look up at the volcano and all I see is burning trees and fire," said Karine Morency, a worker at the United Nations base in the Goma area. "It's hard to imagine that nobody has been killed in the villages near the mountain. Everything smells like burning." 
Trucks, buses and cars crammed the streets of Goma, a major crossing point into Rwanda, as residents sought to escape. The ash and molten rock swept to within half a mile of the UN base and Goma's airport. 
By late afternoon, aid workers said lava flows had advanced about five-and-a-half miles. The volcano erupted at 9.30am. Ms Morency said at least one village appeared to have been destroyed as had a road north to the town of Rutshuru. The lava flow was more than a mile wide, she said. 
A UN spokesman in the Con golese capital, Kinshasa, said the agency had moved more than 400 staff to Goma and was ready to retreat into neighbouring Rwanda if the situation worsened. 
In 1977, scores died when a lake of lava burst through fissures in Nyiragongo at 40mph, which experts said was the fastest lava flow on record. 
The volcano is one of eight on the borders of Rwanda, the Democratic Republic of Congo and Uganda. The tropical rain forests in the region are home to rare mountain gorillas. A World Wildlife Fund official in Nairobi said the gorillas were unlikely to face any immediate threat. 
Only two of the volcanos are active - Nyamuragira, which erupted early last year, causing no casualties, and Nyiragongo. Nyiragongo was last active in 1994 when a lava lake in its crater reappeared, casting an orange light on to clouds at night. 

*
Moon's hard heart just a fallacy 

Matthew Genge on the soft, warm centre of Earth's closest neighbour 

Thursday April 18, 2002


Despite the fact that lovers are supposedly driven to romantic excess by its light, the moon is a harsh and lifeless place. Even geologically, the moon is considered to have cooled long ago and be entirely dead. New research, however, presented at the Lunar and Planetary Science Conference in Houston, suggests that the moon's endless affair with the Earth betrays its deep-down warm nature. 
Our satellite has been thought completely dead because it is too small to retain heat. However, shortly after its formation, from the hot debris of a giant impact with the Earth, the moon was mostly molten. It was during this stage that the lunar highlands, which make up the pale mountainous regions of the moon, formed. 
These consist of rocks made from the low density mineral feldspar and are thought to have formed as the scum floating on top of a giant magma ocean. In only 90m years, a short amount of time compared with the 4.5bn year history of the moon, the magma ocean is thought to have crystallised. 
Later in the history of our satellite, magma was generated by the remelting of rocks within the interior of the moon by huge impacts. These magmas erupted at the surface to fill in the giant craters and form the dark, smooth plains of the lunar Maria that make up the pattern of the man in the moon. The ages of lava returned by the Apollo missions suggest that these basalts ceased to erupt by 3.2bn years ago. The last of the lunar volcanoes are thought to have become extinct more than 2.5bn years ago. 
The moon has, therefore, been thought geologically dead for at least the last 2.5bn years, in marked contrast to our planet, whose surface is covered with thousands of active volcanoes. The Earth has a molten metal outer core and a partially molten zone below the crust where melting occurs due to the churning of its interior, which brings up hot rocks from depth. In the moon there is no convection and it is thought to be completely solid from its surface to its core. 
However, Dr James Williams, a scientist at Nasa's Jet Propulsion Laboratory in California, thinks differently. Williams and colleagues have been studying the shape of the moon, which has now been determined more accurately by using lasers. The measurements were made by bouncing lasers off mirrors placed on the moon by the Apollo astronauts. 
The time the light takes to make the trip to the moon and back allows the Earth-to-moon distance to be identified to within two cm and the moon's shape to be determined. The measurements indicate that the moon is not always the same shape but bulges in and out by as much as 10cm as it orbits the Earth. It is this flabby wobble that Williams has used to determine the moon's deepest secrets. 
Our satellite, it seems, is not the perfect sphere it appears to be, but is stretched out by the pull of the Earth. The near-side of the moon is closer to the Earth and is pulled more by our planet's gravity than the far-side. It is this difference in force that stretches our satellite. The changes in the moon's shape occur because its orbit around the Earth is an ellipse. Sometimes the moon is closer to the Earth and the moon is stretched more than when it is further away. This bulging of the moon due to differences in the Earth's gravitational pull is similar to the bulge in the Earth's oceans that produces the tides. 
Just how much the moon's shape changes is given by its Love numbers, which describe how much the moon's 3D shape differs from a sphere. The latest measurements made by Williams of the moon's Love numbers are much higher than would be expected for a completely solid moon, even though they are lower than those of our own partially molten planet. Nevertheless, the moon, it seems, bulges too much to be a solid ball of cold rock. 
Computer models conducted by Williams suggest that a zone of partially molten mantle at below 1,000 km depth would most readily explain the high values of the moon's Love numbers. This hot, partially molten interior makes the moon deform more easily and thus explains its bulging. The existence of magma at depth in the moon, Williams argues, is not precluded by cooling since, like the Earth, the moon's interior is heated by the decay of radioactive elements and we are uncertain of exactly how many of these the moon contains. 
The absence of young volcanoes on the moon is because its interior is not churned by convection and the hot rocks at depth are no longer brought close enough to the surface. 
The presence of partially molten rock deep inside the moon is just a leftover from its hot past. It does mean, however, that romantic moments in the moonlight need not be spoilt by the reality of its cold, armadillo-like surface. After all, even the moon is hot and squishy inside. 

*
Goma faces horror of more lava flows 

James Astill in Goma
Sunday January 20, 2002 

The volcano that has devastated the town of Goma in the Democratic Republic of Congo and made up to half a million people homeless erupted again yesterday, threatening what relief agencies warned would be 'an unimaginable humanitarian catastrophe'. 
Vulcanologists who flew over Mount Nyiragongo saw through its sulphurous haze a new crater, seven miles below the main volcano. The cone is two metres high and was spewing lava six metres into the air. The lava was streaming down towards the town's airport, which has massive reserves of jet fuel. 
Goma faced renewed misery after a night and day in which a mass migration was followed by fear and disorder. Early yesterday, as a night sky lit neon-orange by the burning lava turned into a hazy dawn, many crossed back into Congo from nearby Rwanda, where they had sought refuge, to inspect their homes. Others came to loot. 
The United Nations says that the death toll is so far 45, but it will rise as the scale of destruction becomes apparent. At least 15 looters are reported shot by police. 
Up to half a million were seriously at risk of malnutrition and disease, stranded without food, drinking water or shelter along the shores of Lake Kivu. Aid agencies were struggling to bring in emergency relief. 
A river of lava half a mile wide had bulldozed through the town centre, oozing into sidestreets and pouring into the lake on the far side. A fug of hot air and sulphurous steam hung over the burning ruins. Creaking and groaning, the lava slowed and cooled into a wall of black rock, three metres deep in places. 
Youths looted abandoned shops and scavenged the remnants of household possessions. 'Goma is finished. There is nothing to do but take what we can,' said Cedric Kabo, as behind him a smartly dressed man pulled a bright, green dress through a smashed shop window. 
Patrick Gabo, one of the few who remained in Goma throughout the eruption, said his parents were too infirm to flee. 'There are a few of us still here, though one woman died from the fumes yesterday,' he said. 'Even if there is another eruption, I will not go. Now I am poor. If I lose my house, I will have nothing.' 
At a hospital run by the Sisters of Charity Order, Dr Achille Mudiandanbu despaired of the crowds traipsing through the wreckage. 'The fumes are very toxic, they can kill you,' he said. 
Though Goma's rebel authorities had no news of the western side of town, cut off by lava, refugees said those trapped there had made it across to the Rwandan side. 
But aid workers said up to 100,000 people could still be stranded between two lava flows, pouring from fissures at the base of the volcano, between Goma and Sake, 20 miles to the west. 
On a beach outside Goma, where the Rwandan shore of Lake Kivu begins, crowds of refugees were gathered, watching a 150ft column of steam rising where the lava entered the lake half a mile away. Women washed and cooked with the toxic waters, despite thousands of dead fish floating on the surface.

Under fire Mexico holds its breath as Popocatepetl erupts 

Jo Tuckman in Mexico City
Wednesday December 20, 2000


A volcano 40 miles outside Mexico City erupted on Monday night, spitting red-hot rocks into the sky and prompting the evacuation of nearly 50,000 people. 
The interior minister, Santiago Creel, said yesterday that the Popocatepetl volcano had calmed down but added that a critical period was now approaching. 
President Vicente Fox, who called for caution and calm in a late-night address to the nation on Monday, was expected to tour the refugee shelters yesterday. 
The overnight eruptions, televised live, lit up the sky with bright red sprays and turned the cone into a twinkling incandescent carpet. 
It was "Popo's" most intense activity since historical records began with the Spanish conquest nearly 500 years ago. Constant monitoring started in 1994 after an eruption ended 70-odd years of slumber. 
No injuries or major damage was reported, although many feared further eruptions could melt a glacier and send an avalanche of acidic sludge towards abandoned villages. The last catastrophic eruption happened 1,200 years ago. 
There were warnings of ash showers in nearby towns. The 18 million people of Mexico City, north-west of the 5,451-metre (17,884-feet) volcano, was not expected to be affected because of southerly winds.

Sicilian emergency as Etna erupts 

Rory Carroll in Rome
Saturday July 21, 2001


Italian army helicopters flew through smoke and ash yesterday to spray water over rivers of lava spilling down the slopes of Mount Etna, Europe's most active volcano. 
An emergency was declared and roads were closed off as the molten rock flowed at 10 cubic metres a second towards the village of Nicolosi, in eastern Sicily. 
Workers built walls of mud and asphalt to divert the lava and assured villagers that their homes would be safe, despite a new fissure cracking open on the southern slope. But a small resort with two restaurants will almost certainly be destroyed, said Enrico Galeani, a civil protection official. 
Several acres of chestnut groves and pine trees were destroyed as the magma, belching steam and ash, slid across Route 92. Fresh eruptions in two craters shook the mountain. 
An aeroplane with water cannon was expected to join the bombardment last night in the hope of cooling and slowing the flow. 
Locals further down the slope were sceptical of assurances that they were not at risk. Salvatore Moschetto, the mayor of Nicolosi, population 5,000, was reported to have asked authorities to use explo sives before the magma, about four miles away, crept closer. 
"The situation is critical. If the lava continues to come out at this speed, it will be on Nicolosi within a week." 
The state of emergency means that army reinforcements and central government funding can be tapped at short notice. 
Ski lifts were shrouded in ash and winter sports were expected to be called off for the one year needed for the lava to cool. 
Etna - at 3,320 metres (10,890ft) high - is the tallest volcano in Europe. The lava has travelled more than 1,000 metres down, but is likely to slow down as the slopes become broader and less steep, said Alfredo Pace, head of Catania's police force. 
A 40-year-old tourist who entered an off-limits area to get a better view broke his back after panicking and tripping over rocks. The spectacle is visible from almost all of eastern Sicily. 
The volcano has spouted lava, ash and smoke intermittently since January last year 
Etna last threatened inhabited areas in 1992 when lava streams headed towards Zafferana, a town of 7,000 people crouched on the lower slopes. Controlled explosions diverted the flow.

Ash rained down on large areas west of the volcano and the authorities closed the airport in Legazpi, the closest city to the volcano. 
The 2,460-metre (8,118ft) mountain has been emitting ash plumes and occasional lava flows for about a week.

Volcano covers Quito in white ash 

Gustavo Oviedo in Quito
Saturday November 27, 1999


Residents in Ecuador's capital Quito woke up yesterday to a covering of white ash after the Guagua Pichincha volcano erupted, shutting schools and the airport in the city of 1.2m. 
Quito residents walked the powdered streets wearing protective face masks after the eruption on Thursday night, which officials from the country's geophysics institute said was of "moderate magnitude". 
A light rain of ash continued to fall yesterday as traffic disturbed the dust to obscure the morning sky. 
Quito's mayor, Roque Sevilla, asked for calm and told residents to use masks to protect their eyes and lungs from abrasive ash. He also asked them to help sweep the streets. 
Mr Sevilla said Quito would remain on yellow alert - meaning the volcano, located 7.5 miles from the city, could erupt again within weeks or months. 
He said ash was likely to continue falling as the volcanic activity continued and winds blew in from Guagua Pichincha, or "baby Pichincha" in the Quechua Indian language. 
The city's airport, situated near the centre of town, was closed while the runway was swept, an airport official said. 
The minister of education, Rosangela Adoum, said classes for the city's 400,000 pupils were suspended until further notice. 
Quito sits in what locals call "volcano alley", a ring of nine active volcanoes that surround the city, which is cradled in a 9,446ft-high (2,880-metre) valley in the Andes mountains. 
Guagua Pichincha has been rumbling since September and has shut the airport half a dozen times since then. 
The volcano, whose crater is 15,724ft (4,794 metres) above sea level, belched out a massive mushroom cloud of steam and smoke in early October. 
Its status has since remained on yellow alert after moving between yellow and orange alert (where an eruption is thought likely in days or weeks) several times since September. It has yet to reach red alert, where an eruption is imminent in hours or minutes. 
Guagua Pichincha last erupted 340 years ago. An eruption now could shower Quito with volcanic ash.

Villagers flee stream of lava from Mount Cameroon

*
Japanese volcano erupts 

The site of the eruption: graphic 

News Unlimited staff and agencies
Friday March 31, 2000 

Japan's snow-capped Mount Usu volcano erupted today, spewing out a huge column of smoke and ash and hurling a flood of volcanic ash and rock toward a small nearby town. 
There were no reports of injuries or damage, and the eruption appeared to be abating - at least temporarily - three hours after it sent a huge column of ash and debris shooting into the sky early in the afternoon. 
Officials warned that the danger was far from over, however. "It is possible that widespread damage could result from this eruption," chief cabinet spokesman Mikio Aoki said from the government's emergency headquarters in Tokyo. Prime minister Keizo Obuchi was also at the headquarters monitoring the situation. 
Roughly 51,000 people live in the coastal city of Date and several smaller towns near Usu, 475 miles north of Tokyo on the island of Hokkaido. Experts had predicted the eruption because of increased seismic activity that began earlier this week, and the evacuation of more than 11,000 people began on Wednesday. 
Almost immediately after the eruption, volcanic ash began to rain down on nearby towns. Residents downwind were soon also enveloped by the pungent, rotten smell of sulphur. The coast guard, military and police mobilised to evacuate the town of Abuta, which lies between the volcano and the sea. It has a population of 13,000, but thousands had already been evacuated and it was not immediately known how many people were still there. 
Seven ships, two helicopters and several dozen trucks were deployed amid concerns at the possibility of landslides or mudslides caused by melting snow. Before the eruption, snow 1ft deep covered much of the 2,416-ft volcano. There had been no rumbling, no explosion and no screams. Mount Usu erupted in the afternoon in near silence, just a blue-grey plume of rock and ash billowing over the crater and down the snowy slopes. 
"I didn't feel anything, I didn't hear anything," said Norimichi Nagao, a resident of nearby Date, which escaped the ash fall. "I didn't know there was an eruption until I saw it on television." With so many residents in the three towns evacuated, the eruption became more of a public spectacle than a threat. People rushed onto the streets and rooftops to take photographs, relaxed and prepared after days of high-level warnings. 
Cars coming in from other areas around the mountain were covered in dust, however, and Abuta and Sobetsu were ghost towns. "Some kids and some parents are a bit jittery, but you couldn't call this a panic," said Daisuke Kadoaki, an official at the Abuta town office. He said nearly all of the residents had left. 
The number of people in evacuation centres is however expected to rise. Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi has warned that evacuees may have to stay put for a while, and said the government would consider building temporary housing. At the centres, where families are marking off private space with blankets and cardboard partitions, officials are concerned about the effects of stress. 
Two people were killed and 200 homes destroyed in mudslides following Usu's last eruptions, which began in 1977 and continued for several months into the following year. Today, the plume rose from the volcano amid generally clear skies. Within two hours, it had risen to a height of 10,560 feet. Mobile phone service was briefly cut off, but was quickly restored. Some domestic flights to Hokkaido were suspended, but international flights were not delayed. 
Most of the ash appeared to be wafting northeast over a nearby lake, and not over the more populous areas. "We are worried that the wind direction will change," said Date mayor Hidekichi Kikuya. "We have been spared so far, but that could change." 
This is the seventh major eruption of Mount Usu in the past 300 years. Fifty people died when the volcano erupted in 1822 in its most lethal eruption. Japan, one of the world's most eruption-prone countries, has not had a fatal eruption since 1991. An eruption of the 4,459-foot Mount Unzen that year sent avalanches of hot rocks sweeping through the outskirts of the town of Shimabara, in southern Japan, killing 43 people and leaving nearly 2,300 homeless. Officials were concerned that Usu would also spew a similar mix of gas and rocks. 

*
Fatal volcano trip row boils over  
 
A science expedition to Colombia which ended in nine deaths has led to a feud over blame - and now 
Hollywood is interested too  
 
Robin McKie 
Sunday March 25, 2001 
  
It was supposed to be a quiet scientific expedition, a study trip designed to find ways to predict volcanic eruptions. But the visit to Galeras ended in disaster when the Colombian volcano exploded and engulfed the researchers - including one of Britain's finest volcano experts - in a rain of glowing rocks, ash and steam. Nine people died. 
The Galeras tragedy was one of the worst scientific calamities of recent years and passions surrounding the 1993 incident have been simmering ever since. Now they have erupted in an extraordinary public outpouring of bitterness that promises not only to ignite old hostilities but transform the story of Galeras into a Hollywood blockbuster. 
On one side, expedition leader Stanley Williams - who received near-fatal injuries on the volcano - has published his dramatic account, Surviving Galeras . At the same time, US science writer Victoria Bruce has produced No Apparent Danger, alleging that Williams was negligent, ignored key seismological data 
and led his party to their doom. 
'He was like a sailing boat captain who, out of ego, takes his boat into a hurricane and causes the deaths of his crew,' she told The Observer last week. 
Bruce savages Williams - a professor of volcanology at Arizona State University - for repeatedly claiming he was the only survivor of the catastrophe. In fact, six others lived through the eruption. 
It has also been alleged that Williams misappropriated scientific data about volcanoes such as Galeras. 
The current issue of Nature includes a series of antagonistic quotes from several US geologists including one, Bernard Chouet of the US Geological Survey, who simply states that Williams 'ripped me off'. 
For his part, Williams - who did not respond to email or telephone inquiries from The Observer last week - simply told the journal: 'Chouet is not correct.' On the other hand, no matter who wins the propaganda battle over the events on Galeras on 16 January, 1993, neither party is likely to become destitute. Both Bruce and Williams were paid more than $500,000 each for the US rights for their wildly differing accounts of that day. Additional foreign publishing fees are likely to make both of them dollar millionaires. 
In addition, versions of the story are now being touted round Hollywood in the hopes one will be filmed as the logical disaster sequel to The Perfect Storm. Williams, although maligned, may yet appear in the guise of Jeff Bridges or Tim Robbins to the cinema-going public. 
The Galeras expedition was the outcome of a scientific conference in the equatorial city of Pasto, which is perched on the volcano's flanks. Williams agreed to organise a geology workshop leading 12 scientists and three tourists into the volcano. 
Galeras had been seismologically quiet for decades until 1988 when it began to blast out bursts of material. By 1993, the volcano consisted of a mile-wide amphitheatre with a newly created, 450-feet-high cone in its centre. The expedition went to the rim of this cone, and then into its inner lip. 
Only two scientists wore hard hats, Williams recalls in his book. At first, the study trip went well. Then, at precisely 1.41pm, the volcano began to shake, Williams recalls in Surviving Galeras , which is to be published in the UK by Little, Brown in June. 'I turned to run down the scree-covered flank. I had made it only a few yards when the air was rent by a sound like a thunderclap or a sonic boom. Immediately afterward I heard a deafening craaaack, the sound of the Earth's crust snapping.' 
Pressure had been building up under Galeras's dome, and had suddenly burst through. White-hot rocks the size of TV sets were blasted into the air and began raining down on the hapless group. Williams was struck by a rock. 'The blow, just above my left ear, caved in my skull, driving several bone fragments into 
my brain,' he states. Williams staggered down the slope, passing the body of one geologist, Jose Zapata. 'His head was bloody, his body contorted. Not far away, the three tourists were splayed across the field of scree. They too were clearly dead.' 
By this time, Williams had severed a foot and his trousers and jacket were on fire. 'I rolled around to extinguish the flames,' he says. In the end, Williams was rescued - thanks mainly to the bravery of two female geologists, Marta Calvache and Patty Mothes, who had been working not far from the volcano. In addition to Zapata and the tourists, five other members of the party had disappeared without trace, including Geoff Brown, a distinguished UK geologist. 
On the other hand, six other members of the group who visited the cone did survive, though this did not stop Williams from going on to claim on several occasions that he had been the only survivor. 'There were 10 people, and I'm the only one that's alive,' he told NBC's Nightly News . 
Later on, Williams claimed that his sole survivor tag had been pinned on him by newspapers against his will. However, he told Nature last week that he had made a mistake. 'I am sorry,' he told the journal. 
Far more damaging to his reputation is the claim by Bruce that Williams should have known that he was leading his group into severe danger. In his book, he claims that the eruption was 'a hiccup' and that Galeras had behaved 'capriciously'. 
But this is rejected flatly by Bruce - a professional writer with a masters degree in geology - who says that tiny seismic signals, called tornillos, had already been used to predict eruptions on Galeras. 'Seismic data indicating dangerous conditions was available prior to leading an expedition into Galeras, and Williams was aware of that data,' she states.

Ms Carr, who runs an orphanage, said: "We had no sleep, the children were so frightened, and the flames seemed to be about two yards from the orphanage." 
A Rwandan official, who asked not to be identified, said: "The sky was totally scarlet, there were terrible earthquakes, and one was so bad that there is a crack in the ceiling of my house." 
The UN peacekeeping mission in Congo, MONUC, reported 350 UN staff members had been evacuated by road and by plane from Goma. 
The UN has sent several thousand military observers and peacekeepers into Congo following a cease-fire in the civil war that broke out in Goma in August 1998. 

*
Wave of disaster warning 

Scientists conjure up possibility of volcano triggering world's worst natural calamity 

Tim Radford, science editor
Wednesday August 29, 2001


An eruption of the Cumbre Vieja volcano in the Canary islands could trigger one of the worst disasters ever recorded, British and US scientists warn today. 
A lump of rock twice the volume of the Isle of Man would slide down the unstable western flank of the mountain at more than 200mph and travel up to 40 miles along the sea floor. This would set off the worst tsunami, or giant wave, ever recorded. 
Destructive waves far higher than those generated by the Lisbon earthquake of 1755 could scour British harbours and estuaries, damage power stations, shut down oil refineries and flood low-lying regions. 
There would also be massive damage in Africa, Spain, Portugal and the Canaries themselves. But waves as high as Nelson's column in London, travelling at colossal speed, would crash on to coasts from Canada to Brazil, sweep up to 10 miles inland in low-lying regions and cause trillions of dollars of destruction. 
Wind-driven waves disturb only the top few metres of an ocean. A tsunami involves the entire column of water from surface to seabed. It generates a wave train which accelerates as the ocean gets deeper. Tsunamis characteristically cross the deep ocean at up to 500mph, slowing but building into massive bodies of water as they reach the shallow coastal slopes. 
"Quite often buildings float away, ripped out of their foundations. Oil tanks and gas tanks float away and spread burning oil around the place," said Simon Day of the Benfield Greig geohazard research centre at University College London. 
He and Steven Ward of the University of California report on the dangers of Cumbre Vieja in the September issue of Geophysical Research Letters. They calculate that the avalanche could, in a few seconds, release the equivalent of all the energy used by the US in six months. The resulting "mega-tsunami" would be far more violent than any in recorded history, with turbulent waves repeatedly pounding the coasts most at risk. 
"This is going to impose very large loads on buildings and literally knock buildings over," Dr Day said. "The first wave is going to come in, maybe take out the first few blocks, take the debris away, flatten the ground. The next wave takes out blocks progressively further inland. Over a large part of the area that is inundated, you will be seeing near-total destruction." 
In the past 100 years, around 50,000 people have been swept away by 400 tsunamis generated by earthquakes on the Pacific rim alone. Volcanic collapse is a relatively rare trigger for tsunami destruction - but geophysicists have now identified 11 cases of massive landslides to the ocean floor in the past 200,000 years, in the Hawaiian islands, Cape Verde and the Canary islands. After an eruption in 1949 an ominous fissure appeared in Cumbre Vieja, first evidence of a huge faultline in the massive basalt rock of the mountain, which could one day turn into another landslide. 
Geologists calculate that future discharges of lava will heat the water trapped in the rock. The mass of the rock would act for a while as the lid on a pressure cooker, preventing the water from flashing into steam. But one day, said Dr Day, in some future eruption, the pressure would become too great. He and Dr Ward used a computer program to model what would happen if 500 cubic kilometres of rock slid at 100 metres a second for a distance of nine miles (15 km). They calculated that within 10 minutes a huge tsunami would spread from the ocean region to the west of the island. 
Although the worst waves would race towards the US coasts, menacing New York and low-lying Florida cities, the computer showed destruction threatening most coasts on the Atlantic. 
After an hour the first waves would hit west Africa, and after three hours waves measuring up to 20 metres from crest to trough would have crashed against the coasts of Spain and Portugal. Within six hours a procession of waves measuring 14 metres in total could be racing up the shallows of Ireland and Cornwall. Nine hours on 50 metre-high waves would be closing in on the Florida coast. 
The scientists believe that vulcanologists could have days or even weeks of warning of the collapse. Warning systems would also track the process of the tsunami across the ocean. 
Cumbre Vieja erupts violently at intervals of 22 to 237 years. The last eruption was in 1971. 
"Anyone planning a holiday to the Canary islands, and the islanders themselves, need not panic," said Dr Day. 
"Cumbre Vieja is not erupting, so the short-term and medium-term risks are negligible."

Magma menace 

Archbishop prays for holy protection at Etna 

Rory Carroll in Rome
Monday July 30, 2001


Sicilians gathered on the slopes of Mount Etna to pray last night as a river of orange-black lava oozed towards the mounds of earth protecting a tourist resort. 
A new fissure in the volcano opened earlier as emergency crews, blackened and sweating, battled to reinforce the mounds and divert lava away from Rifugio Sapienza. Mount Etna is Europe's most active volcano and stands at 10,860ft (3,310m). 
The archbishop of Catania, Luigi Bommarito, held a mass on the slopes to ask for God's protection against an eruption that has wrongfooted vulcanologists and threatened the town of Nicolosi further down the slope. According to folklore, the town was saved in 1886 after the local archbishop held a statue of St Anthony before advancing lava. 
Two main fronts sliding down the mountain appeared to have slowed, but the resort's kiosks were still menaced by magma that has consumed a warehouse, car park and ski-lifts, cut a highway in two and showered ash on to Catania's international airport. 
Authorities closed the airport on Saturday for the second time in two weeks, forcing 190 flights to be cancelled. It reopened yesterday after workers had cleared debris from the runway, but explosive booms and smoke from the crater could yet force it to close for a third time. 
Fields and tourism worth £5.7m have gone up in smoke and vulcanologists say the eruption could last several more weeks. Local guides who were born in the mountain's shadow are sceptical of assurances that Nicolosi, with a population of 6,000, is safe. 
"It is a terrible moment. Even our grandfathers can't even remember it being like this," said Giovanni Serafina as lava bubbled less than three miles from the town's houses, many of which were adorned with statues of the Madonna for protection.

*
Rumbles underfoot - then the explosion 

Special report: natural disasters 

Rory Carroll on Mount Etna
Thursday August 2, 2001


The lava slides close enough to touch and for the first time even Marco the fireman hesitates. Rock underfoot softens and warmth seeps through the thickest boot. Everyone scrambles back. 
Marco blasts a fusillade of water but in less than a second it is vapour hissing from the orange-black mass. "It does more good than you think," he shouts. "Cools it a bit." 
The lava oozes over a mound of earth, the last barrier, and it is as if an oven door has swung open. After five hours on Mount Etna the heat is welcome. They don't warn you that it gets cold halfway up an erupting volcano. 
A molten fountain dances in the dusk of a devastated landscape as convoys of bulldozers and trucks wind up from the valley, heaving boulders and technology in the unequal struggle to protect a tourist resort, Rifugio Sapienza. 
A dozen diggers and earth movers are already pounding away, trying to shore up the barrier which was supposed to redirect the lava flow. 
It seems impressive until Etna explodes. Rumbles deep beneath our feet swell into a series of booms and a column of flame and smoke shoots two miles high. Eyes and nostrils fill with ash. 
"Scassau a muntagna!" yells Marco. You don't need to know Sicilian dialect to realise the mountain has cracked again. 
Two weeks after Europe's tallest volcano erupted scientists yesterday said that the pyrotechnics could go on for weeks or months. Such is the build-up of magma and gases that not even six craters have eased the pressure. Two rivers of lava, at temperatures above 1,050C (1,922F), snake down Etna's southern flanks. 
It is like an early Christmas for the scientists, though they remain baffled by Etna's plumbing. One of the two types of lava has not been seen in 15,000 years. 
Lava has breached two barriers and eaten a car park, a warehouse, ski lifts and hectares of fields. It is threatening to overwhelm the third barrier, a seven-metre (20ft) wall of earth. 
Built 70 years ago, Rifugio Sapienza is an undistinguished collection of souvenir shops and hostels huddled around the departure point for ski lifts. But as it sits on the verge of oblivion it has become a symbol of human impotence. 
"We have tried everything possible. We have worked night and day. But the mountain is stronger," Vanni Calli, an engineer, said. 
Franco Barberi, head of the civil protection agency, said his 70 men could be ordered to evacuate at any moment: "The probability of saving the area is less and less." 
Behind him, black skin flaked from a moving mound. Red gleamed beneath. A glimpse of hell straight from Dante, murmured one fireman, exhausted after a 24-hour shift. He urinated and steam hissed. "Can't do any harm." 
The phenomenon which towers more than 3,310 metres (10,860ft) above eastern Sicily has been mythologised for millennia and took its name from the Greek for 'I burn'. 
It has long been famed as a killer which wiped out cities, but some modern scholars reckon put the combined death toll from its ancient eruptions at only 73, just one more than died on Italian roads last weekend. 
"The mountain is good, it is a friend. It reminds us of the immensity of nature. My family has always loved it," said Antonella Ragusa, 33. That the lava was 10 metres from her restaurant, Terrazza del Etna, soured the relationship, she admitted. "At the moment it is not so good. Only God can stop it." 
Madonnas carved from volcanic rock have been placed in front of some shops and the archbishop of Catania held a mass not far away. 
Further down the valley a separate molten river is less than two miles from the town of Nicolosi. However, vulcanologists agree the town is not in danger. 
That is good enough for most locals, who mock the so-called Pompeii syndrome - the fear of being poked at by future generations of archaeologists. They are proud, not afraid, of Etna. 
But the foreign media demands superstition and terror. Some locals furnish quotes about divine retribution and rumours of 500 body bags, then they watch themselves on satellite television and snigger. 
"Of course we're not afraid," Nino Chisari, 58, said. He reckoned the only danger was being run over by the visiting fleet of Land Rovers. 
Much to the surprise of hoteliers the eruptions are drawing more tourists than they repel, prompting pleas for the authorities to allow closer views. 
By last night more trucks were grinding up to Rifugio Sapienza to reinforce the barrier. They were loaded with the one material which may yet save the resort: old lava. 

*
Thousands flee as river of molten rock engulfs villages in Congo 

James Astill in Goma and Owen Bowcott
Saturday January 19, 2002
 

Up to half a million people were fleeing the scorching lava flooding down Mount Nyiragongo in eastern Congo yesterday, as new fissures opened up in the ground and fires spread beyond the regional capital Goma.

International aid workers moved in convoy into Rwanda, to set up operations in Ruhengeri, 35 miles from the border with Congo. 
Witnesses said the lava's advance on the town in the early hours of yesterday morning had been marked by a series of explosions as petrol stations and bootleg fuel stores ignited in the fierce heat of its approach. 
"It was spectacular. Again and again, there were massive explosions and petrol flames to show us how far it had got," said Ron Mininger, an American businessman supplying jet fuel to the 350-strong contingent of UN peacekeepers based in the town. 
After fleeing on Thursday night, Mr Mininger returned yesterday morning to inspect a fuel dump at an airstrip on the edge of town. 
"There was lava oozing around the fuel store. It didn't look like it could last long, so I moved out pretty quick," he said. 
Trader Isaac Kayumba said he had remained in the town until mid-morning yesterday watching the lava bulldoze across his house and warehouse, before turning and running one mile to the Rwandan border post of Gisenyi. 
"I saw it take everything I have worked for: my house, my possessions, my stores. I have only what I am wearing." 
Earlier, rebel police fought gun battles with looters in sight of the lava's creeping advance from fissures at the base of the erupting Mount Nyiragongo. "There were some robberies after the people left, and some fighting," Mr Kayumba said. "I heard five or six shots but I think no one was killed." 
Along the road beyond Gisenyi in Rwanda, 12 miles from Goma, thousands of refugees lay huddled beneath a sky glowing an apocalyptic orange, with violent earth tremors shaking the ground. 
Few appeared to have sal vaged anything from their homes. 
"There's no food and no shelter for them here," said a western aid worker. "All the NGOs have got out. There can't be five aid workers left." 
Rebel officials said last night they had not been able to contact those cut off by the lava since late morning. At the time, townspeople were congregated around the main Hotel Karibu, next to longtime dictator Mobutu Sese Seko's summer palace. 
The officials said those stranded were reluctant to leave the town in the direction open to them, away from the border, for fear of brigands and the tribal militias who roam the volcanic plains there. 
As much as 80% of the city's infrastructure was said to have been destroyed by the encroaching flames. The airport was cut in two by one of the flows. 
"We're suffocating in this town, the smoke is killing us," Stephen, 25, told Reuters as he loaded furniture into the back of a van parked in Goma's main street, just 20 metres from the black wall of lava. 
"We're just trying to save what little we can." 
The scale of volcanic activity showed no sign of easing yesterday. A kilometre-long crack appeared in the earth and fresh eruptions were heard. Seismic monitors recorded sustained underground activity every five minutes, according to the UN humanitarian relief agency, OCHA. 
Gisenyi was also threatened by lava flows and disaster coordinators were considering whether they should order an evacuation. 
More than 2.5m people are thought to have died in the long-running civil war which has seen Congo divided between rival factions. The volcanic explosions are expected to further depress the country's weakened economy. 
The foreign secretary, Jack Straw, is due to begin a visit to the country on Monday, as part of a long-planned tour of the region with his French counterpart, Hubert Védrine. 
The main purpose is to urge an end to the civil war. "We will of course be seeing what the international community can do to help [in this disaster]," Mr Straw said yesterday. 
The area has been plagued by violent explosions in the past, with lava flows reaching 40 mph. A nearby volcano exploded in 1996. 
Sue Loughlin, a geologist at the British Geological Survey, said scientists had been monitoring Nyiragongo for weeks. The volcano has a deep summit crater that fills up with lava intermittently. 
"When the crater fills up very close to the rim it can get out through fissures. This happened in 1977," she said, adding that something similar had probably occurred this week. 
Oxfam said it hoped to fly emergency aid to the Rwandan border area today. Some of the lava flows were said to be 100 metres wide, according to Rob Wilkinson, Oxfam's regional coordinator based in Kigali. 
Many of the refugees, he said, had fled towards Masisi, deep in Congo. 
"When the first eruption occurred it didn't seem so bad. But they were caught out by a much larger second explosion."

*
Scientists get close-up of Io 

Guardian staff and agencies
Tuesday October 26, 1999 

Scientists on Friday got their closest look ever at Jupiter's moon Io, believed to be the solar system's most volcanic body, as the spacecraft Galileo sent back pictures of spectacular lava flow it photographed during its Oct. 10 fly-by. 
True to form, Io produced pictures of an extraordinary lava flow from an erupting volcano as Galileo came within 417 miles (671 kms) on the closest approach yet to the Jovian moon. 
Scientists at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena said the image of Io was 50 times better than the previous best pictures, taken in 1979 by the Voyager spacecraft. 
"Visible in the image are new lava flows from the volcanic centre named Pillan, an area with erupting lava hotter than any known eruption that ever occurred on Earth within billions of years," said JPL spokeswoman Jane Platt. Nasa believes Io is the most volcanic body in the solar system. 
She added that scientists were studying the lava flow to determine the characteristics of the volcanic eruption and were eagerly awaiting more images and data due to be sent back to earth over the coming weeks. 
Galileo's approach to Io, the closest yet, was a calculated risk because the moon's orbit lies in a dense part of Jupiter's radiation belt, but it came through relatively unscathed, although slightly bruised, JPL said. 
The biggest bruising, said Galileo Project Manager Jim Erickson, was inflicted on the craft's "fast camera," which pre-processes the image to average the brightness of varying parts of the picture - much like a sophisticated automatic camera on earth. 
But Jupiter's radiation affected the camera's ability, resulting in poor pictures. 
"Fortunately, images that were taken in other camera modes apparently did not suffer ill effects from the radiation," Platt said. It was one of those images that Nasa scientists received from the spacecraft on Friday. 
Galileo's original mission was to spend two years studying Jupiter and its moons. Although it officially ended in 1997 it had been so successful, and the craft remained so healthy, that the mission was extended for two years. 
But mindful of the radiation dangers around Io, Nasa waited until the end of Galileo's extended mission to schedule the two fly-bys of the moon. The second will take place on Nov. 25 when Galileo is scheduled to come within 186 miles (300 kms) of Io's volcano-scarred surface. The image of Io being studied is available on Nasa's JPL website 

*
Fireball kills 100 in stricken Goma 

James Astill in Goma
Thursday January 24, 2002
 

About 100 looters in Goma, the eastern capital of the Democratic Republic of Congo devastated by the erupting Mount Nyiragongo volcano, died in a huge explosion on Monday when petrol was spilt on molten lava and ignited fuel tanks. 
Five days after the eruption began, making half a million homeless and forcing thousands to flee, soldiers of the rebel group that controls eastern Congo, the Rassemblement Congolais pour la Démocratie (RCD), fired on youths looting burnt-out buildings beneath the 60m fireball caused by the petrol station blast. 
The interior minister in neighbouring Rwanda said the volcano had erupted again on Sunday, and called on Goma's 500,000 residents to evacuate for a second time. "Last night there was a new eruption on the north side of Nyiragongo. We recognise a great risk. There were many vibrations last night," said Jean de Dieu Ntiruhungwa. 
However, describing the eruption as "a minor spillage", the Congolese vulcanologist Dieudonné Wafula said further flows of lava were unlikely. 
Goma's residents have been starting to rebuild. Most had been given access to piped water by early Monday, in an effort to prevent a cholera epidemic. But the water was being pumped directly from nearby Lake Kivu, which contains traces of the cholera that killed 50,000 Rwandan Hutu refugees after the 1994 genocide. "We have several confirmed cases, but the town is picking up incredibly fast and the threat is diminishing," said Monica Castellarnau of the charity Médecins Sans Frontières, "though we won't know if there's going to be a full-blown epidemic until after a week." 
Dieudonné Mabutua, 15, was one of 16 survivors from the crowd of adults and children who on Monday rushed on the Mama Fifi petrol station, half-buried by the main lava flow. He siphoned fuel from below the black crust, then walked away as a fight broke out over whose turn was next. It is almost certain that petrol was spilt as a result. "There were more than 100 people there. All my friends," said Dieudonné, shivering. 
The relief effort was complicated by regional politics. The RCD split responsibility for Goma with its Rwandan sponsors. RCD soldiers patrolled west of the lava flow while to the east were mostly Rwandans. 
The shooting was all on the west side, cut off from aid arriving through Rwanda. Next to hundreds of burns victims in Goma's hospital were several with gunshot wounds. 
According to the RCD's secretary- general, Azarias Ruberwa, the soldiers were firing into the air to protect people. But a Rwandan lieutenant said: "They appear to be shooting to kill thieves." 
Aid agencies said serious shortages of food existed, yet the United Nations, wrongfooted last Sunday when refugees left its camps in Rwanda and returned to Goma, refused to distribute aid in the town. "We are not moving to Goma when there is a risk of eruptions," said Laura Melo, spokeswoman for the World Food Programme. 
Ms Melo said 40,000 of an initial 350,000 refugees from Goma were still in Rwanda. 

*
Philippines prepares for avalanche 

John Aglionby, south-east Asia correspondent
Tuesday September 4, 2001

Philippine disaster prevention teams are scrambling to evacuate tens of thousands of people in the next two days from the slopes of a volcano rapidly filling with water, after local labourers botched an attempt to control the overflow. 
Non-governmental organisations coordinated by Oxfam accuse the local authorities around Mount Pinatubo of negligence and being poorly prepared. 
They say that if the workers preparing a canal to divert the overspill had been properly supervised, the lake in Pinatubo's crater would not have breached the rim for at least another two weeks. 
But instead, in an attempt to retain a modicum of control over the expected avalanche of water, mud and rocks, the authorities in the municipality of Botolan are having to breach the crater rim on Thursday morning. This leaves them only two days to evacuate 46,000 people from the 18 villages most at risk. 
"We will force everyone to leave even if they don't want to," the mayor, Roger Yap, said. "I will have to answer if anything happens to them." 
Residents of nine other villages will be given a stockpile of supplies in case they are cut off. 
At worst, 60m cubic metres of water could overflow, mixing with mud and rock to create an avalanche of 300m cubic metres of slurry which could reach the town of Botolan, 25 miles away. 
The emergency precautions began when the water level rose to within about 80cm of the lowest point on the rim yesterday, compared with 1.5 metres on Friday. 
Five weeks ago it was more than 4.5 metres. 
Paul Del Rosario, the Oxfam official on the scene, said: "The indigenous people that were asked to work there [on the canal] were not properly supervised. They thought they were doing a good job, but they were wrong." 
Some of the workers are reported to have said that their supervisors remained on the other side of the crater. 
Oxfam's project team leader, Rosalito Alonso, said it was "pretty obvious" that qualified engineers had not adequately monitored the work. 
"If the diggers had been properly supervised, then they would not have forgotten to leave a big plug in place." 
He said the plug left between the canal and the crater rim should have been several metres thick but it ended up only a fraction of that. 
Oxfam's country director, Lan Mercado, said: "There was definitely negligence. There's no other way to describe it." 
The authorities deny that anything is amiss. Raymundo Punongbayan, head of the national vulcanology institute, said they were operating in unknown territory. 
"An intervention like has not been done in the Philippines before. I don't know if this has been done anywhere in the world." 
Ramon Lacbain, the provincial vice-governor, blamed the weather. 
"It has been much wetter this year than was forecast. This means the water will be harder to control and so we are taking extra precautions and evacuating more people." 
But Botolan councillors complained at the weekend that experts from the institute had said last week that they had at least three weeks to prepare. 
"They've now left us with only a few days," one was quoted as saying. 
More than 800 people died, mostly from diseases in overcrowded evacuation centres, when the 1,422-metre (4,667ft) volcano last erupted, in 1991.

Saturday July 7, 2001
The Guardian 

Surviving Galeras
Stanley Williams
(Little, Brown, £16.99) 
If you've ever idly wondered what it's like to have a volcano erupt beneath your feet, you're in luck. In 1993, vulcanologist Williams was mooching around on top of the Colombian volcano Galeras with friends and colleagues when all hell broke loose. He was hit by fiery rocks travelling faster than bullets; others were killed. The central chapters on the eruption and Williams's subsequent rescue are gripping stuff; the rest of the book is a more sober account of fieldwork and a scoot through volcanic history. The dustjacket rather wishfully compares the book to Jon Krakauer's superb Into Thin Air, an account of an Everest expedition that went wrong. Good though this is, Williams doesn't have Krakauer's iron literary fist.

Thousands evacuated in Philippines 

John Aglionby, south-east Asia correspondent
Monday June 25, 2001


More than 20,000 Filipinos living in the shadow of the volcano Mt Mayon fled their homes yesterday after it began belching truck-sized lumps of rock, molten lava and a 9.5-mile high mushroom cloud of ash. 
A 900C river of fire travelling at up to 60mph threatened to incinerate nine villages but caused no direct casualties, because people had been on the alert since January, when the 2,474-metre (8,118ft) mountain began rumbling. 
The only recorded fatalities were a woman who died of a heart attack and a man fleeing on a bicycle who was hit by a speeding rescue vehicle. Another woman was so shocked she gave birth prematurely. 
The local authorities raised the alert status in the farming region 200 miles south-east of Manila to the maximum, meaning eruption in progress, yesterday morning. 
The the volcano shook the region on Saturday night, and began spewing lava. The first big explosion was just before 1pm yesterday. People in towns up to eight miles away could feel the rumbling. 
Priests rang church bells and village officials used megaphones and sirens to rouse thousands sleeping in the path of the lava flows. Oblivious of the danger, children watched the glowing lava cascading down the mountain as their parents packed what belongings they could carry. 
Raymundo Punongbayan, head of the Philippines Institute of Vulcanology and Seismology, said the eruption was likely to last one to two weeks. The local authorities said up to 60,000 people might have to be evacuated. 
Mt Mayon, which last exploded 16 months ago, has erupted at least 48 times since the first recorded activity in 1616. In 1814, 1,200 people were killed and a whole town was buried under volcanic mud.

Galeras tragedy 

Sunday April 1, 2001


As the wife of the late Professor Geoff Brown, the UK geologist killed during the eruption of Galeras volcano, Colombia, in January 1993, I am distressed at the content of your article 'Fatal volcano trip row boils over' (News, last week). 
As a geologist myself, I am confident that what happened on 14 January 1993 (not 16 January, as your article states) was a tragic accident that could not have been predicted at that time. Trying to apportion blame is unproductive, distressing to both the survivors of the eruption and the relatives of those who died, and symptomatic of a society that prefers to seek scapegoats rather than accept responsibility for its own actions. 
Evelyn Brown 
Loughborough, Leics
