Letting off steam 

Japanese resorts evacuated as volcano threatens to blow 

Jonathan Watts in Tokyo
Thursday March 30, 2000


Thousands of people abandoned their homes in northern Japan yesterday after experts put out the alert that a volcano could be about to erupt. 
In the past few days, the area around Mount Usu, a 732m peak in Hokkaido, has been rocked by more than 40 earthquakes an hour. 
Yesterday, they grew sharply in frequency and intensity - the biggest tremor registered 4.2 on the Richter scale - prompting vulcanologists to warn that the mountain could be about to blow. 
"It is highly likely that an eruption will occur in the next few days," the government's coordinating committee for prediction of volcanic eruption declared in an emergency announcement. 
Scenic hot-spring resorts at the foot of the mountain were evacuated of more than 8,000 residents. Many abandoned their homes with only a handful of belongings when municipal officials advised them to leave behind all but money, a change of clothes and other essentials. 
As well as laying on buses to collect the elderly and bedridden, the authorities put 3,300 troops on standby in case the evacuation area had to be expanded. Within hours, streets, hospitals wards and classrooms in the initial area were left empty. 
"It could erupt in a week or any second now so we are asking people to leave all the most dangerous places as soon as possible," said Hiromi Hiraguchi of the local Date council. 
Yoshiaki Ida, head of the eruption prediction committee, warned that Mount Usu could produce the same deadly flow of superheated gas and ash that killed 43 people when Mount Fugen erupted in southern Japan in 1991. 
Even if there are no pyro clastic flows, made up of rocks, volcanic ash and gas, residents face the threat of mudslides and avalanches caused by tremors and snow melting as the mountain's temperature rises. 
When Mount Usu last erupted, in 1978, three people were killed when mudslides buried them. Vulcanologists said that at this mountain, such eruptions happened every 20 to 30 years. 
Many evacuees spent last night in emergency shelters at municipal gymnasiums and halls. 
"I wasn't able to sleep a wink on Tuesday," said one woman, 85. "This morning, the earthquakes made the building squeak, which was frightening." 
A task force has been set up in the prime minister's office to coordinate disaster measures in the event of an eruption, and troops have prepared food, water and blankets for tens of thousands of people in case a wider evacuation becomes necessary. 
Mount Usu's slopes are now deserted, except for a handful of scientists preparing monitoring equipment, and troops on surveillance missions.

*
Asian volcano 'changed Britain's cultural map' 

Monday July 26, 1999


The separate identities of England and Wales are the result of a massive volcanic explosion in South-East Asia in the 6th century, according to a TV documentary. 
The explosion caused a devastating change to the global climate which triggered an outbreak of disease that changed the course of history. 
Channel 4's two-part documentary Secrets of the Dead - to be screened tomorrow - claims ancient civilisations were destroyed. 
It is based on a book Catastrophe, an Investigation into the Origins of the Modern World by historian David Keys who claims western Britain - like many other countries - was devastated by a killer disease triggered by a huge volcanic explosion in Indonesia in 535 AD. 
The eruption, which lasted several weeks, darkened the sky with dust and debris and blocked out the sun for 18 months. It destabilised world climate, distorted the world's ecology and triggered the first known outbreak of bubonic plague, the rat and flea-borne disease. 
The catastrophe led to the birth of many nations, including Ireland, France, Spain, England and Wales, says Mr Keys. 
"Before the plague the Celtic British controlled all of western Britain so there was no cultural difference between Wales and the West Midlands or between Wales and the Cotswolds. 
"But the plague so decimated the Celtic British that it created a partial population vacuum which allowed the embryonic English - the Anglo Saxons - to migrate westwards. 
"They pushed on as far as the Welsh uplands - and stopped. Early England was thus formed - and Wales was cut off from Cornish Britain and from the British of the north-west. 
"Thus it is as a direct result of the plague - and the volcano that ultimately triggered it - that England was born and the borders of Wales were determined. 
"England and Wales as a cultural entity are therefore products of the catastrophe of the 6th century." 
He claims the demise of important towns such as Wroxeter - a Roman town in Shropshire - around that time could have been the result of the plague. 
Drawing on new interpretations of data from tree rings and lake sediments, Mr Keys suggests that the volcanic explosion was far bigger than anything in the past 1,500 years. 

*
Scientists sound a warning as Etna goes on the boil again 

Robin McKie, science editor
Sunday August 27, 2000


Mount Etna - the realm of Vulcan, god of fire, and the Cyclops - may be entering a new cycle of catastrophic eruptions, say scientists. 
In the past few weeks, vulcanologists noted intensifying pattern fissures, and lava pouring from its 11,000ft peak, on the east coast of Sicily. 
Nearby towns have been coated with volcanic dust, roads need constant clearing from ash that has settled over the area, which the local government has declared an emergency zone. 
'There was a similar pattern of activity in 1978 and 1979, shortly before Etna produced some powerful flank eruptions that destroyed buildings, roads, vineyards and orchards,' said vulcanologist Dr John Murray, from the Open University. 'I think the same thing is set to happen again.' 
It is unlikely that Etna will produce a cataclysmic eruption like those that have typified its northerly counterpart, Vesuvius. Nevertheless, it can leak sudden streams of rapidly moving lava. One, in 1928, completely destroyed the town of Mascali. 'All volcanoes have their own distinctive way of behaving,' said Murray, who has been studying Etna for the past 30 years. 'They have different personalities. Etna has a very leaky one. It grumbles along in almost permanent activity, occasionally producing flank eruptions in which lava bursts from fissures low down its slopes. 
'When that happens, you have to move very quickly. The lava comes out under pressure and moves very rapidly. 
'Villagers can get cut off very easily, though none have been killed in recent times.' In fact, all fatalities on Etna have been tourists. In 1979, nine were killed during a visit to one of its summit cones when it produced a massive eruption, the entire party was overwhelmed by the volcano's hot ash. 

*
Three minutes of horror when 30,000 perished 

100 years after: The world's worst volcano disaster 

Robin McKie, science editor
Sunday April 28, 2002


First came waves of yellow ants and large, black centipedes. They scrabbled down the scrub-covered slopes of Martinique's Mount Pelée, scuttled over roads and tracks, and attacked workers in nearby cane fields. They even invaded the local landowner's house. 
Then the snakes began their exodus. Hundreds, including deadly pit vipers, twisted and writhed down the volcano's flanks and headed across the countryside. It could have been a biblical plague. 
Finally, at 8am on 8 May 1902, Mount Pelée blew its top, sending a massive cloud of incandescent gas hurtling down its flanks. Travelling at more than 100mph, it struck St Pierre at 8.02am. 
Three minutes later, the 'Paris of the West Indies' lay in ruins, its 30,000 inhabitants suffocated and burnt. Only one person survived: Auguste Ciparis, the sole occupant of the city's dungeon. 
The destruction of St Pierre was complete, and unprecedented. The cause, scientists now know, was a nuée ardente (glowing cloud) or pyroclastic flow - a mixture of gas, steam, glowing dust, ash and pumice. It was the first time such an event had been observed, however. 
Since then scientists have learnt much about these deadly eruptions and have established how to predict volcanic behaviour with precision. Yet as researchers prepare to mark the centenary of history's worst volcanic disaster, many now fear that this knowledge could prove useless and that future eruptions could have even more devastating effects on humanity. 
'There are more than 3,000 volcanoes in the world, and only about 150 are being monitored,' said Professor Bill McGuire, a volcanologist at University College London. 'There are also so many more people alive today and that makes us more, not less, vulnerable to eruptions in the twenty-first century. 
'And although we can predict eruptions, we cannot force politicians to take action and be ready to implement expensive evacuation plans. 
'For instance, around Vesuvius in Italy, a million people would be under threat the next time it erupts, so poor are local evacuation plans. Very few people seem to understand the danger we still face.' 
Such complacency mir rors how local authorities ignored the dangers of Mount Pelée. Apart from visitations by escaping insects and snakes, major earth tremors and mud flows had killed several inhabitants by the end of April 1902. 
Yet municipal leaders refused to act. The island was in the midst of general elections, with socialists poised to take control from right-wing politicians. However, St Pierre was the main centre of conservative votes, and so the governor, keen to keep his right-wing colleagues in power, put off evacuation until polling day on 11 May. 
The horrific consequences of this delay were described by Charles Thompson, assistant purser of the steamship Roraima which was moored in St Pierre. 'The fire rolled down upon St Pierre,' he recalled. 'The town vanished before our eyes.' 
Another ship, the Rod ham, managed to sail out of the harbour as pumice and ash rained on its deck. It headed for St Lucia, most of its crew dead or dying. The Rodham was met by stunned customs officials who asked the survivors of the scorched ship where it had come from. 'From the gates of hell,' came the captain's answer. 
'Two other volcanic eruptions have had worse death tolls - Krakatoa in 1883, which killed 36,000, and Tambora, in 1815, which killed 92,000,' said McGuire, whose book, A Guide to the End of the World (OUP), has just been published. 
'But many of these deaths were caused by secondary effects. Tambora destroyed rice fields throughout the Dutch East Indies and people starved to death, while Krakatoa triggered a tsunami, a massive tidal wave that led to the drowning of most of its victims. However, Mount Pelée was the direct cause of its victims' deaths.' 
But the effects of Pelée's eruption went beyond killing people in its neighbourhood. Its impact is still felt today, as Jelle Zeilinga de Boer and Donald Theodore Sanders point out in Volcanoes in Human History (Princeton). 
In 1902, the United States was preparing to fund a canal to connect the Pacific and Atlantic oceans, either through Panama or through Nicaragua. 
Nicaragua was known for its volcanic activity and, after the destruction of St Pierre, the prospect of another major eruption damaging the canal was enough to persuade the US Senate to approve the Panama project by eight votes. 
As for Auguste Ciparis, after surviving four days in his cell, which was buried beneath layers of ash, his sentence (for assault) was suspended and he spent the rest of his days touring with the Barnum and Bailey Circus - as an exhibit in a replica of his prison cell. 
· Additional research by Hannah Richards

Saturday, July 27, 2002, p. 20
Congo hit by second eruption
Adrian Blomfield in Nairobi
THE skies over the Congolese town of Goma glowed an ominous red yesterday after Africa's most active volcano began throwing lava 300 feet into the air, seven months after its sister mountain entombed parts of the city in molten rock.

*
Monday, July 15, 2002, p. 25
Volcano's Velcro effect offers help for hangovers
Rosie Murray-West
A HEALTHCARE company is seeking funds to develop a volcanic mineral that it believes could treat cancer, remove pests from your pets . . . and cure your hangover.
This magic elixir is called zeolite, and Global Health Products (GHP) wants to sell packs of it in pubs and clubs as a hangover treatment, before starting clinical trials on the substance.
"If you drink alcohol and take six capsules of this, then basically you could drink four to five pints," said Dr Kenneth Maule, director of GHP. "It won't stop you from getting drunk but I can guarantee you won't suffer from that morning-after feeling."
The company wants to raise pounds 250,000 to start marketing the mineral, which Dr Maule says has been used as a traditional detoxifying treatment for many years. It aims to raise money through a private placing of redeemable convertible loan notes and warrants. Its bankers are HSBC, and its accountants are BDO Stoy Hayward.
"In Malaysia it is used for farming and to feed animals," said Dr Maule. "If you go to a volcano and there are any pools of water, animals that drink from that water will be healthier than ordinary animals."
He added that, after the Chernobyl disaster, Bulgarian communities were using Clinoptilolite, this particular form of zeolite, to deradiate people. "They would make it into rusks for children who wouldn't take tablets," he said.
The substance basically acts "like Velcro" and attaches itself to the toxins that make you ill. "You urinate away the cause of a hangover," Dr Maule said.
In terms of cancer treatment, he said it had immense potential to contain the after-effects of chemotherapy by "mopping up" excess toxins left in the body.
In the same way, it could stop multiple sclerosis patients going blind by eliminating the toxins that cause this.
Dr Maule said the mineral would be marketed as Zetox as a hangover cure, and that GHP is currently applying for a patent. The company is entering into a joint venture with True North Partners to develop the mineral for cancer treatment.
It will also be marketed under the name Adzorb as a treatment for parisitic infections in domestic animals.

*
Sunday, April 21, 2002, p. 14
An Englishwoman abroad.
Looking into the volcano's chasm.
LINDSAY HAWDON
Antonio walks ahead of me. He is small, polite and shy. "You are ok?" he keeps turning around to ask me as we climb the path that leads up to Guatemala's active Pacaya volcano. Around us are fields of beans and corn. Cows graze in the distance and the only sound is of chickens squawking. Antonio comes from a family of seven who live in a small village beneath the volcano. He watched the lava flows heading down the valley towards his village three years ago. "Was it beautiful?" I ask.
"Yes," he nods. "It was beautiful - but frightening." The volcano has been erupting almost continuously since the 1960s. His parents abandoned the village during the 1976 eruption, returning to find their house full of volcanic ash.
We reach 5,000ft. The path twists through a forest of pines and cypresses, the ground dotted with the yellow of wild flowers. The smell of damp leaves becomes sharper as we climb. In time, mist creeps across the path, dampening my hair and my clothes.
At almost 7,000ft the trees end and the ground opens out into a rocky upland of pale green grass. The clouds sweep across it in bands, great patches of land disappearing in the fog. My feet crunch over fine black volcanic sand. I am breathing heavily in the thin air.
"We are almost there," Antonio says. But I can see nothing except clouds. They close in again, and as we crunch across the ridge only whiteness surrounds us. I can't tell how far the ground drops away beneath me, nor how far it climbs above. There is just this black volcanic path and the clouds.
"We are in heaven, yes," Antonio says with a grin. But as he says it the clouds to my right thin and my eye catches a huge dark shadow looming above me. It is a deep black against the white of the sky, stretching way above us. "There it is," whispers Antonio.
"When did it last erupt?" I ask.
"A month ago," he replies, walking briskly onwards.
I stare up at the vast slope we have to climb. We begin, slipping and sliding as small rocks give way beneath each step. It's two steps upwards, one down, but we struggle on, scrambling upwards. Much of the time I am on my hands and knees. 
The rock feels warm to the touch. Around us the only sounds are the wind and the crunching of our feet.
"You are ok?" Antonio asks, clambering ahead of me. I nod. Head down, I don't realise we've reached the top until the ground suddenly flattens out at the crater's rim and the rocks become patched with a vivid residue of red, yellow and blue.
I stand straight and look around me. Huge clouds billow up, their grey tinged with a dirty orange hue. "It's the sulphur," Antonio explains, and as he does so a great wall of mist hits us and there's a stench that reminds me of a school chemistry lab. It leaves me coughing and my eyes
watering.
When the cloud clears, the crater is suddenly before me, a steep drop into nothingness, appearing and disappearing as the clouds blow back and forth. I peer over the edge and feel that strange dizziness that comes with knowing that death is merely a step away. If I took it I would drop into the red hot lava. I can feel the heat of the rocks rising through my boots. The fumes burn the back of my throat and when I look up the sun is a red ball behind the sulphurous clouds, a perfect circle of vermilion.
When we leave, Antonio and I almost sprint down the steep volcanic slope, our feet sinking into the scree, steadying our steps. It's like a fairground ride, a breeze in comparison with the ascent.
I grin all the way down. The view spins past me and the sun peeks out from the clouds, yellow once again, warm on my skin, as I run back towards the green land below.

Saturday, March 2, 2002, p. 31
Catch this
Rosemary Behan
France's latest tourist extravaganza, a scientific theme park dedicated to volcanoes, opened in the mountains of the Auvergne last week, 10 years after it was conceived by the country's former president Valery Giscard d'Estaing.
Situated 10 miles from the city of Clermont-Ferrand in central France, Vulcania is built on a 140-acre former military base at the heart of the chain of extinct volcanoes that is the region's principal attraction.
The 100-million-euro ( pounds 62 million) project aims to provide an "educational and recreational journey into volcanoes and earth science". 
Two-thirds of the site - which is crowned by a 100ft artificial cone - is underground.
Visitors descend through a massive crater before enjoying a variety of simulations and visual presentations. There is a volcanic garden and a vibrating cinema with one of the world's largest projectors. The "Rumbling Gallery" recreates the sounds of the inside of a volcano.
Guides accompany tours of the interior and exterior of the building. There is also an information centre, with more than 2,500 works on volcanology and earth sciences, plus three restaurants and a bookshop.
Vulcania, Rte de Mazayes, 63230 Saint Ours, Auvergne, France (00334 73 19 70 00, www.vulcania.com). Admission costs pounds 11.25 adults and pounds 7.50 children. Open 10am-6pm Wednesday-Sunday February-May and September-November, and 9am-7pm daily in summer.

January 24, 2002, p. 03
Gorillas emerge from the volcanic mist. Earthquakes, war, eruptions . . . nothing seems to shake mountain giants, writes Tim Butcher
Tim Butcher
IF MUNANE, one of the world's few surviving wild mountain gorillas, was bothered by the helicopter passing overhead yesterday to deliver aid to victims of central Africa's volcanic eruption he did not show it.
Ignoring the clatter he lifted his 700lb bulk on to his legs, placed his face against a cliff and began teasing tasty insect larvae from the soggy moss with his tongue.
"It is amazing but they have never seen or heard a helicopter before but they don't seem to mind," Franois, a Rwandan mountain guide, said.
After surviving a decade of war, earthquakes and a resurgence of poaching, the mountain gorillas reacted to the volcano eruption as they have to every other emergency in recent years, by disappearing into the mist.
"They are used to the earthquakes living in this region but last week's eruption was followed by many, many tremors," Franois said.
"It did not bother them but the other animals in the mountain range did not like it.
"Elephants and buffalo from the Congo side of the mountain were scared over this side but the gorillas stay on the steep cliffs and among the trees so there was no problem."
The Virunga volcano range, straddling the borders of Rwanda, Uganda and the Democratic Republic of Congo, is one of the few remaining natural habitats for the increasingly rare mountain gorilla.
The last census, now 10 years out of date, estimated there were only 650 left in the world, of which about 300 are in the Rwandan sector of the range.
It was here that Dian Fossey, the American scientist, carried out pioneering research on the mountain gorilla, a story told by Hollywood in the film Gorillas in the Mist.
Nyiragongo, the volcano that devastated the Congolese town of Goma last week, forms the southernmost end of the Virunga range and while the lava flows came nowhere near the gorilla habitats the tremors certainly did.
As Rwanda's growing population demands more agricultural land the gorillas of the park are pushed further up towards the mist of the volcano summits. Two gorillas were killed in recent months by poachers who were widely believed to be diehards from the interahamwe, the Hutu extremist militia responsible for the bulk of the massacres of Tutsis and moderate Hutus in the 1994 genocide. This was the first time any had been poached in years.
The fear in Goma is that the interahamwe, who have been operating in the jungle since 1993, may be pushed further into the gorillas' habitat, endangering them more.
As for Munane, he took noisy exception to a small group of humans sweating their way through the mat of jungle undergrowth yesterday. He lifted his huge head above the dense foliage and beat his chest with vigour.
The dense jungle of the Virunga chain soon returned to silence, broken only by the screech of birds and the grunts of Munane, a silverback, and his nine-strong family group on their daily search for food. Through the dense undergrowth the adults trooped, dragging vines out of trees, stripping leaves from branches, and teaching their young the ways of the mountain gorilla world.
One young gorilla tried to copy his larvae-sucking leader, leaning up against the cliff face next to Munane and for a second looking like a human child trying to impress his father through imitation. Then they disappeared into the jungle.

Wednesday, January 23, 2002, p. 17
Expert with a perfect prediction of disaster
Tim Butcher, flying over Mt Nyiragongo
PRESSING his face against the helicopter window yesterday for the best possible view of Mt Nyiragongo's smoking summit, the local vulcanologist, Dieudonne Wafula, was too well-mannered to gloat.
After years of trekking up and down the volcano, dodging murderous rebel fighters to measure seismic activity and record his findings, Mr Wafula predicted last week's eruption perfectly.
"We can expect an eruption in the very near future," he wrote in a report dated Jan 8. But as he flew over the summit for the first time since the blast, Mr Wafula was too curious about his beloved mountain to say "I told you so".
Like a wide-eyed schoolboy he scurried up and down the helicopter pointing at huge cracks in the volcano's flank, taking notes, drawing lava fields on his map and babbling in technical terms incomprehensible to the layman about magma, splatter-bombs and tremor amplitudes.
"It was exactly what we thought," he said. "There was no explosive eruption but a series of flank fractures from which the lava escaped."
He knew each of the three main active peaks on the summit of Nyiragongo perfectly and was itching to touch down so he could measure the depth of the lava lake in the main crater.
But the heat, dust and cloud made it too dangerous so he had to content himself with an airborne observation, which confirmed that the eruption had now ended with no fresh lava surging down the hillside.
What could be seen however was a series of ugly, smoking gashes in the ground, looking like something out of Tolkien's Middle Earth, from which huge puddles of blackened lava stretched miles down the hillside.
"People have to understand that it is possible to monitor a volcano but they must understand the dangers that are inside," said Mr Wafula. If he felt any bitterness that his warning were not heeded, he did not show it. Unpaid for six years, he has got on with his passion - the study of volcanoes and Nyiragongo in particular.
The flight was organised by the United Nations for its own volcano experts. Perhaps in future they could save their money and pay better attention to Mr Wafula's reports.

Petrol blast kills looters in volcano town
Adrian Blomfield; Tim Butcher in Goma
SCORES of looters were killed in the stricken Congolese town of Goma yesterday when a petrol station exploded, apparently ignited by smouldering lava.
A series of explosions sent fireballs high into the air and caused billows of dense black smoke that could be seen from miles around.

It appeared that a series of earthquakes hit the region last week and at least two cracked the earth on the volcano, allowing its lava to flood out.
M Durieux could not rule out further and more devastating earthquakes in the region, which lies in the southern part of the Great Rift Valley, one of the Earth's fault lines between tectonic plates.
International relief efforts gathered momentum around the Rwandan- Congolese border but only a fraction of Goma's 500,000 population had access to food or clean water.

January 21, 2002, p. 01
Volcano refugees return to search for families Tim Butcher, in Goma, watches desperate people cross rivers of lava to see if their homes survived the devastation
Tim Butcher
A SOLID wall of volcanic rock looming 10ft high met the braver residents of the Congolese town of Goma as they dodged pockets of noxious gas and blasts of hot smoke to try to reclaim their homes yesterday.
They found a town centre that had been sliced in two by a river of red hot lava, engulfing houses, cars and even the Catholic cathedral before spewing deep into the green water of Lake Kivu in clouds of steam.
On the edge of the lava field the molten rock had sluiced up side streets at roof level before cooling into a black barrier that from a distance looked like a grotesque delivery of tarmac.
"I don't know what we will find," Musambia Ikango, 20, said from beneath a bursting suitcase balanced on his head.
His house was on the other side of the lava field and he had no idea whether it had survived. First he had to work out how to get across. Cautiously he dabbed his finger on the rock. It was uncomfortably hot to the touch but not burning.
Treading lightly like an Indian fakir not entirely confident in his ability to walk on coals, Mr Ikango climbed up the lava and made his way through the clouds of sulphurous gas to the other side.
Many had even more pressing reasons to risk the crossing. "My house is not important but I want to find my wife," said Mahindo Sale, 37. "I was working the day it happened and have not seen her or my five children from that moment."
His story was repeated by dozens of people who fled Goma last week when Mt Nyiragongo volcano threatened to wipe out the town. Mothers sought daughters, fathers sought sons and children sought parents.
Within a few minutes others dared to follow Mr Ikango and a stream of returners hopped lightly over the hot rock barrier dividing east and west Goma.
They carried the few possessions they had fled with - a soggy mattress, a basket of clothes or a bag of food - and hoped their homes had been spared.
In the middle of the lava field the destruction was complete. Nothing could have survived the heat and the crush of the molten rock.
Goma's Boutique Bora may never get back to normal trading; less than a foot of its facade peeked out yesterday from lava that had cooled into odd twisted shapes like oversized liquorice.
The canopies of shops hung in charred shards and the blackened top of a fuel tanker could just be seen.
Only on the edge of the lava was it possible to see more hopeful signs. 
Corrugated iron sheets twisted by the heat had bobbed on the surface of the lava. Children had already started to drag them off to beat them back into shape.
From a Rwandan army helicopter it was possible to see the scale of the lava flow which had run down the side of Mt Nyiragongo more than eight miles away in a matter of minutes. It looked like spilled treacle running down the hillside, splitting into rivulets and carrying all before it.
In places the lava was more than a mile across. Closer inspection showed that while some had come from the volcano's main crater, a completely new crater more than five miles from the peak and much lower in the foothills had opened, spewing out vast volumes of molten rock.
The Catholic cathedral was ruined but its angular concrete walls stood proud and almost alone amid the pumice.
Down on the edge of Lake Kivu - the main reason Goma was popular with tourists during the colonial era - red hot lava continued to flow into the water.
Even 100 yards away the water was as warm as a bath and all day long steam billowed along the shore.
One holiday home on the water's edge had clearly seen better days but its rusty old boathouse, equipped with rails leading down a slipway into the water, had somehow survived.
The Hotel Karibou was not so lucky. It had a hoarding boasting proudly of "views of the lake and the volcanoes". This was no lie: the gardens have been completely re-landscaped in lava.

Half a million flee river of molten rock

Saturday, January 19, 2002, p. 14
River of lava flowed fast enough to outrun people
David Derbyshire Science Correspondent
IT IS extremely rare for a volcano to produce a river of lava fast enough to outrun and kill a person.
Almost all the victims of volcanic eruptions die in clouds of gas, rock and ash, known as pyroclastic flows, mudslides or tidal waves from undersea eruptions, said Prof Bill McGuire, one of Britain's leading volcano experts.
Nyiragongo, part of a chain of eight volcanoes lying along the borders of Uganda, Rwanda and DR Congo, is one of the continent's most active and most deadly.
Formed on a fault line connected to the African Rift Valley, it has erupted every decade in recent history.
On Jan 10 1977 a lava lake that had filled the crater for 83 years was drained within an hour. Molten rock streamed towards Goma at 40 mph, and within half an hour around 2,000 were dead.
Because Nyiragongo's lava lake is high, and the slopes of the volcano are steep, escaping lava flows at remarkable speeds.
In 1883, 31,400 people died in a tidal wave after the eruption of Krakatoa, Indonesia. Another 5,000 were killed in the explosion, which could be heard 1,900 miles away.
The eruption of Mount Pelee on Martinique in 1902 generated a pyroclastic flow that killed around 29,000.
In May 1980, 66 people died when a bulge on the side of Mount St Helens, Washington, collapsed, sending a hot, thick cloud of ash and gas sliding down the mountainside.
Around 25,000 people died in Colombia in 1985 when Nevado del Ruiz buried the town of Armero in an avalanche of mud and rocks.
Two years ago, Mayon in the Philippines sent rivers of fire down its slopes, forcing around 70,000 people to leave their homes. One woman died. When the volcano erupted in 1993, 68 people died.

Saturday, October 20, 2001, p. 06
Blown away by a rugged beauty. The volcano had been stirring of late. We could smell the singed pumice
REBECCA STEPHENS
`Why bother with Reunion?" inquired a Mauritian hotelier, a touch indignantly. He let it be known that the best beach in Reunion wasn't a patch on the least favoured in Mauritius.
"To walk," I said.
For the French, who have kept this island very much for themselves, its rugged and mountainous landscape is one of its main attractions. A friend and I planned to spend a few days wandering around one of the more remote regions in the north-west, the Cirque de Mafate - a caldera formed from a vast, dead volcano - and then head south and east for a glimpse of Piton de la Fournaise, the 
island's one volcano that is still very much alive. Only then would we move to Mauritius and the beach.
We booked ahead at the cheap, no-fuss gites de montagne strategically dotted around the cirque, through the Maison de la Montagne in the capital Sainte-Denis. But it's a long flight to Reunion and we were delayed. To make it to that first gite we had to hand over most of our French francs to a taxi driver, and then wave goodbye and walk - a two-hour hike in the fading light.
Was this wise? The thought gripped me only for a moment before I caught a flag-shaped splash of red and white paint in the beam of my torch. On Reunion, just as on the mainland, the Grande Randonnee offers beautifully maintained trails that thread their way over rocks and through undergrowth.
We were led up to a pass on the caldera rim and steeply down the other side, into the cirque. We were aware only of the miniscule world defined by our torches: a stony path, trees, bulls, untethered and disconcertingly numerous. 
All was silent, until, resonating through the night air, we heard laughter. 
There, far below us, were the lights of a small village, La Nouvelle.
I can think of nowhere else quite like this. Home to some 130 people, it comprises a scattering of wooden and corrugated iron buildings - a chapel, a school, a "boutique" - pitched on a knobbly patch of grassland. It has no street lights, few paths linking one building to another . . . no roads. The only way in and out is by foot (or helicopter).
The beasts we passed on the trail revealed the traditional livelihood of the inhabitants. But since a government initiative to promote tourism in an effort to relieve the island's staggeringly high unemployment (more than 40 per cent), the Cirque de Mafate region relies more on the likes of my friend Jovan and me . . . but somewhat reluctantly.
We eventually stumbled into our gite - a simple, chipboard-lined room with communal shower and loo around the corner. Food was quite another matter. It was 8pm, everyone was in bed.
We tried a second gite, across the tufted grass. There was a light - hope, at least - and inside a small gathering of Frenchmen leaning heavily into their chairs with obvious post-prandial satisfaction.
"Table pour deux," Jovan suggested.
"Pas possible. C'est finis," said the young waiter.
We didn't know what to do - unable to muster enough words in French to persuade this young man otherwise. Slowly the message sank in. We should have read the small print and booked supper. The young man relented and produced a couple of plates from somewhere.
But the lesson wasn't over. We arrived in the next village at about 2pm the following day, just as the island was enveloped in a dank and chilly cloud. This time we weren't about to be caught out. Immediately we booked dinner - but again, "non". It didn't matter that the table was laid, or that in the evening we watched as a party of schoolchildren tucked into an overly generous spread of Creole chicken, beans, chutney and French wine. We were relegated to the garden with thick jumpers, two spoons and a tin of lentils.
"In England, maybe, but on French territory," cried Jovan, incredulously. The small print again - we should have booked ahead, this time by 48 hours.
Breakfast, the guardian could manage. Dry biscuits and jam. Good coffee. We sat out in the garden, the sun shining, and gazed at a sort of Tolkien-like fantasy landscape of criss-crossing gullies and razor ridges. The caldera rim rose at an almost vertical pitch 3,000 feet above our heads, a bright, tropical green. And all about us there were familiar-looking house plants and palms and vividly painted petals. The morning skies were clear, the air warm - the perfect time to walk - and but for the school party we hardly saw a single person.
It was all very different from our night in the shadow of Piton de la Fournaise. There must have been 20 of us in the Gite de Volcan that night, all hopeful of a sunrise scramble to the summit - and all sadly disappointed. The volcano had 
been stirring of late, causing great consternation and traffic jams of Reunionnais eager to see it blast. We could smell the singed pumice hanging in the air.
Too dangerous, we were told.
Back on the east coast of Mauritius, everything was glittering lights, sprinklers, uniforms and golf buggies.
"Anything I can get you, Madam? A cocktail, Champagne?"
It's always the same: a few days of denial in the hills and then that first morsel of refined food and that first crisp, cold glass of wine - and all is lost, or, more accurately, gained.
But I had no complaints. Le Saint Geran sits on a promontory surrounded by white sands and ocean. The style is colonial, the service impeccably unintrusive, the prices high - about pounds 700 a night for a double room. And that's low season, with water sports thrown in for free. In the evenings you can dine at Alain Ducasses's Spoon des Iles.
Even the beach vendors here have credit card facilities.
Getting there
Rebecca Stephens booked her Reunion accommodation through Maison de la Montagne in Sainte-Denis (00 262 90 7878), which is happy to arrange personal itineraries. In Mauritius, she was the guest of Sun International (www.sunresort.com). Le Saint Geran can be booked through Leading Hotels of the World (0800 181123, www.lhw.com). French Government Tourist Office (09068 244123 - 60p a minute, www.franceguide.com). Reunion Tourisme website: www.le-reunion- tourisme.com.

Sunday, September 16, 2001, p. 24
UK team finds rare bird under the volcano
BRIAN UNWIN AND ADAM LUSHER
A BRITISH-LED expedition has discovered one of the world's rarest species of bird surviving yards from the crater of the volcano that devastated the 
Caribbean island of Montserrat four years ago.
Led by a scientist from the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds, the research team found at least 25 pairs of Montserrat Orioles (Icterus oberi) living beneath the rim of the Soufriere Hills volcano. Since 1997, the birds have remained hidden, marooned by ash in a square-mile patch of forest less than a mile from the crater. They have survived regular showers of volcanic debris and frequently endured rock falls caused by the active crater.
Their existence was only revealed after a joint RSPB and Montserrat Forestry Department team flew onto the upper slopes of the volcano by helicopter to try to chart the effects of the eruption on the island birds. The discovery brings fresh hope for the Montserrat Oriole, which has suffered an unprecedented decline elsewhere on the island since 1997 and is found nowhere else in the world.
Chris Bowden, the RSPB biologist who led last month's expedition, said: "It's incredible to think that one of the last remaining havens for a bird teetering on the verge of extinction is so close to the crater of an exploding volcano.
"We saw 10 birds in three hours, including juveniles, which suggests they have been breeding successfully. It was a great sight."
The thrush-sized oriole - the male is black and yellow, the female mainly olive yellow - is the island's national bird, proudly displayed on the British dependency's stamps. At least 60 per cent of its prime habitat was destroyed by the Soufriere Hills volcano. Scientists feared that the bird, confined to what they thought was its last stronghold in the Centre Hills area, had no better than a 50- 50 chance of avoiding extinction.
The RSPB, the Montserrat Forestry Department and the Montserrat National Trust started emergency work to save the oriole, and are now being aided by a pounds 130,000 Foreign Office grant. The researchers became intrigued by a small patch of surviving forest in the foothills near the crater. "We'd spotted it on the aerial photographs and were dying to get in to see if any orioles had survived," Mr Bowden said.
The four-strong team flew in by helicopter. "We just didn't know what to expect. Looking at the soil, it was clear that the orioles have had fairly regular ash and mud falls.
"There's no questioning the orioles' determination to survive."

Thursday, September 6, 2001, p. 18
Thousands flee as volcano lake is drained
Alex Spillius South East Asia Correspondent
THOUSANDS of people on army lorries, buffaloes and horses joined a state-ordered evacuation yesterday, fearing that their town could be flooded if a daring 
attempt to drain a volcano's lake goes wrong.
The exodus from a district of Botolan in the Philippines came after scientists warned that their homes might be swamped by up to 13 billion gallons of water from Mount Pinatubo, 25 miles away.
A canal has been dug through a wall of the crater to direct the waters down channels and into the South China Sea. But scientists said there was a 20 per cent risk that the volume of water freed might exceed estimates. If the operation goes according to plan, five billion gallons will be drained off in the first 24 hours.
The Pinatubo lake has filled with rainwater since the volcano's top was blown off during an eruption in 1991 that claimed 800 lives. It left a hole covering two square miles.
Oxfam and other emergency agencies have for months warned the Filipinos of disaster, as the crater nearly filled during the rainy season, the pressure threatening to break the crater walls. Alex Renton, a spokesman for Oxfam East Asia, said: "We are very glad the authorities are finally taking action.
"It is, however, troubling that the evacuation is taking place with 24 hours warning rather than 24 days. Our staff are going door to door to make sure people are leaving."

Thursday, August 30, 2001, p. 12
Etna becoming 'more violent'
David Derbyshire Science Correspondent
MOUNT Etna is going through an identity crisis and is likely to emerge a more violent volcano, geologists said yesterday.
The Sicilian volcano, which had its biggest eruption for a decade this summer, is changing its nature and making an unprecedented switch from one type of volcano to another.
Over the past 100,000 years it has moved from being a "hotspot" volcano, where a plume of molten rock rises through the Earth's mantle, to one resembling a more powerful "island arc" volcano.
Here, eruptions are triggered by the collision of tectonic plates. A slab of crust is pushed deep into the Earth, it melts and creates magma that rises to the surface.
The geologists studied lava emitted by Mount Etna over the past 500,000 years. Over time, the nature of the volcano changed from one mostly sourced by mantle plumes to one with a greater contribution from the collision of Africa and Europe.
Dr Pierre Schiano, of the Blaise Pascal University, in Clermont- Ferrant, France, who reports the change in the journal Nature, said the discovery explained Etna's peculiar behaviour.
"If the plume-arc interaction we have identified continues, then we anticipate that Mount Etna will become more explosive," he said.
Etna, which had its first of 200 recorded eruptions in 1500BC, lies close to the boundary between two regions that have very different types of volcanoes.
The volcanoes in the Aeolian island arc were created in the collision of the European and African tectonic plates. However, on Sicily, there is no evidence of island arc volcanoes and Etna appears to have been the result of a mantle plume.

Saturday, August 25, 2001, p. 05
Gavin Bell
Etna after the fireworks The eruptions are terrifying, but local villagers regard their volcano as more money-spinner than menace, finds Gavin Bell.
The Greatest Show on Earth began with a deep rumble. Mike Burton felt it distinctly when the ground beneath his feet trembled. He was standing on the rim of the south-east crater of Mount Etna at the time, admiring and measuring a fountain of lava, which is what he does for a living (he's a vulcanologist). 
Sensing that something was stirring in the bowels of Europe's biggest volcano, he and his colleagues wisely retreated.
"We knew that something was going to happen, but what or when exactly was hard to say," he recalls.
Four days later, the lair of ancient gods and monsters erupted with rare violence, hurling molten rock hundreds of feet into the air and spewing rivers of lava that devoured ski-lift pylons and threatened a tourist station.
At the foot of the mountain, Angelo Nicolosi, manager of the Hotel Villa Paradiso dell'Etna, watched the pyrotechnics in awe. "In 50 years, this is the most spectacular I have seen. There was a line of fire - it was as if the mountain was splitting open."
Images of the eruption were flashed around the world, with dramatic reports of mayhem on the mountain; bulldozers battling to divert the lava, villagers in its path praying for salvation. For three weeks, it seemed the most dangerous place on Earth.
Well, it wasn't. The truth is that Etna, in fact, is quite a placid volcano, whose frequent tantrums may be observed from a respectful distance with equanimity. Unlike the unstoppable rivers of fire that gush from other volcanos at more than 60 mph (Vesuvius, for example), the viscous lava of Etna moves ponderously at less than half a mile per hour.
"The mountain gives us time to pack our bags and leave safely," says Antonio Massaglia, a retired civil servant who has lived in a village beneath its craters all of his life. Burton, the vulcanologist from Oxford, agrees: "It's dangerous if you are close to an eruption, but, generally, it's not going to kill anyone. The lava flows tend to harm buildings, not people."
Historians reckon that Etna, notorious as a destroyer of ancient cities, killed fewer people in its early eruptions than now die on Italian roads at weekends. To thousands of people who live on the 3,310m (10,860ft) mountain, it is known as il gigante buono, the good giant. This is because its ash fertilises the soil, its winter snows provide rivers of clear water, and its basaltic rock is ideal for building bridges and dams. It also brings tourists by the busload. On an island heavily in debt, blighted by a moribund economy and the Mafia, the convoys of visitors that trundle up the mountain every day are another blessing of the good giant.
Many of them pass through the village of Nicolosi, which was founded by Benedictine monks in 1437, wiped out by an eruption in 1669, and rebuilt and recently repackaged as "The Door to Etna".
More than halfway up the mountain, it was in the line of fire of the latest lava flow, which halted barely a couple of miles away. The locals were understandably concerned, but temporal and spiritual emergency plans - bulldozers and Virgin Marys - saved the day.
Such experiences engender philosophical attitudes. "What can we do?" says Giuseppa Rapisarda, widow of a farm worker. "Our house was built here. We have this nice volcano: he is beautiful to look at, but sometimes he gets angry and scares us. That's the way it is."
After all the excitement, the rhythms of Sicilian life have resumed their leisurely pace in Nicolosi. In the Piazza Vittorio Emanuele, old men sit on benches in the shade of chestnut trees and watch approvingly as the tourist buses queue up opposite the offices of the Christian Democratic Party.
The cafes are busy and the souvenir shops are doing a steady trade in tacky figures sculpted from lava and covered with sparkly glitter. The Madonnas and Roman chariots seem to be selling well. The only reminder of Etna's recent performance is a small residue of black ash in the streets that the first rains will wash away.
Behind the old men, on a patch of grass, squats a memento of a more serious eruption. It is a huge lump of dark, craggy rock bearing the inscription: "Bomba Vulcanica 1669". The message is one of pride, rather than fear - it may be a fiery mountain, but it is their mountain.
It is also, from all aspects, a very impressive mountain. It rises from the shores of the Ionian Sea with the kind of majesty and classical splendour one would expect from the mythical furnace of Vulcan, the maker of Jupiter's thunderbolts.
Occasionally, its smouldering summit is framed by a thin layer of cloud and, from a distance, it appears hazy and dreamlike, the stuff of legends. There should be graffiti saying Zeus was here.
On closer inspection, it is a mixture of heaven and hell. The lower slopes, fertilised by volcanic ash, are clothed in orchards and vineyards, rising to forests of oak and pine and thickets of broom that blossom golden yellow in spring.
Then you see the lava. Great barren swathes of it, a monstrous jumble of molten rock that has solidified into a dark, sharp-edged wasteland. And towering above it is the summit, with its cones and craters, like a gigantic slag heap emitting noxious fumes.
Visitors may inspect the course of the latest lava flow, which was diverted by earth barricades a few steps from souvenir shops and restaurants in the tourist station of Rifugio Sapienza. It swept away pylons of a cable car lift, however, which lie mangled in mute testimony to the impotence of man against the forces of nature.
Looking up, one can see clearly the path of the lava, like a river of sludge, where it flowed over a shoulder of the mountain, past the huddle of tourist facilities and over an access road that has been deluged countless times.
The lava flow is still warm, and a popular pastime is lobbing rocks at it in the hope of seeing them melt, which they don't. The other apparent attraction is collecting bits of it in plastic bags, which is unwise.
The late Sicilian author Leonardo Sciascia put his finger on the relationship between Etna and those who live on it: "It's like a huge house cat that snores quietly: every now and then, it wakes, yawns, streches lazily and, with a swipe of its paw, destroys a valley here or there."
At such times, the spectacular effects may be viewed from the gardens of the baroque Hotel Villa Paradiso dell'Etna, while a pianist entertains guests with a selection of popular melodies.
Beneath the volcano, the band plays on.
Gavin Bell travelled with Citalia (020 8686 5533, www.citalia.com/ -italy). Seven nights in the four-star Hotel Villa Paradiso dell'Etna in San Giovanni la Punta, at the foot of Etna, costs pounds 765, including charter flights from Gatwick or Manchester to Catania, b & b and car hire. Three nights with scheduled Alitalia flights from Heathrow for pounds 635.
In Nicolosi, the tourist office runs coach trips to the Rifugio Sapienza for about pounds 7. Book a ticket when you get there.

Saturday, August 18, 2001, p. 11
Gavin Bell
Lava saga Things are more complex in nearby Iceland, where Gavin Bell takes his cue from Jules Verne and journeys to the centre of the Earth
It is not easy to get to the centre of the Earth. First, you must travel to an island near the Arctic Circle that looks as if it has just emerged from the Ice Age. Then there is a journey of more than 100 miles along a wild shoreline, to the end of a peninsula of dark mountains. There you must ascend a dormant volcano, to a summit encased in a glacier. Then, according to Jules Verne, comes the hard part.
It was on this mountain, or rather in it, that Verne sent the intrepid Professor Lidenbrock of Hamburg and his nephew Axel on their Journey to the Centre of the Earth on June 28, 1863. Not many people come here. But those who do leave with memories of a magnificent wilderness sculpted by Nature while listening to Wagner. The mountain is Snaefells, which means Hill of Snow, and it lies on the tip of a bony finger of land pointing towards America from the west coast of Iceland. It is a place of Viking sagas, the spiritual home of a legendary half-man half-troll who safeguards fishermen, and according to a New Age community at its foot, it is one of seven primary energy sources of Mother Earth. It is also very beautiful, and easier to get to than in Verne's day.
On a clear day you can see Snaefells from Keflavik international airport, 70 miles away as the Arctic tern flies, across a broad sweep of the north Atlantic. 
It has the classic symmetrical profile of a volcano and, with its mantle of snow, looks like a Nordic Mount Fuji. From a distance it seems detached, like an island rising from a cobalt sea, and at nearly 5,000 feet it is by far the most prominent feature in a barren landscape of lava and ice. Such sightings are rare. The average number of fine days in Iceland in July is one, so I regarded its apparition in bright sunshine on my arrival as a good omen.
Prof Lidenbrock's nephew was not impressed by Reykjavik (two "bleak, depressing avenues" in a dismal landscape; its citizens seemed resigned to being outcasts). 
Anthony Trollope, who passed by a few years later, described it as "a fishy town".
Fishing is still the main industry, but the capital and the folk who live in it are cheerier nowadays. A substantial part of the country may be under layers of ice, but in a coffee shop called Uncle Tom's Cabin life has evolved rich cultural diversity. One day I found a woman singing to her partner at a table by the window, a youth reading poetry to an attentive girl and a middle-aged man knitting a chunky sweater. He said it made a nice change from writing computer programs.
Buses leave for the centre of the Earth, so to speak, on weekdays from Reykjavik, collecting and delivering people and mail on the way, and linking with smaller coaches to more remote areas. In the absence of bus stops they halt at farm tracks, affording time for the locals to enjoy a sociable chat, and for the rest of us to admire the scenery.
Young Axel did not enjoy this part of the trip, which took a week on horseback. 
Bemoaning "the melancholy of this untamed nature", he declared: "I hardly realised at this stage what a sight awaited us on the Snaefells peninsula, where the damage wrought by an impulsive nature forms a fearsome chaos." All good dramatic literary stuff, but a touch exaggerated.
The landscape is certainly wild. This is a place where the distance between the 21st century and the Triassic era is the width of a two-lane highway. In geological terms, Iceland is at the adolescent tantrum stage, and it shows. Most of the hills are like giant slag heaps, as if they have just spewed out of volcanos that rumble every five years or so. The highlands that range along the peninsula form a continuous fossilised wave, as if frozen in the instant of crashing on the shore. Beneath lowering grey skies and squalls of rain that pass for summer weather on Iceland, they are a daunting sight. Then a shaft of sunlight pierces the gloom and illuminates a white farmhouse by the sea, and the effect is magical.
At the end of the surfaced road, a mini-bus was waiting to take us the last few miles on a track of lava ash to Arnarstapi, a colourful straggle of houses at the foot of Snaefells, occupied in summer by fishermen. It also has a restaurant in a wooden chalet, with a grass roof, where I enjoyed freshly landed cod and heard an Icelandic saga.
The tale of Bardar, as related by an obliging waitress, went as follows: "He is a legend in our history. He was a fisherman who lived here soon after the first settlers came. He had nine daughters, and the youngest was his favourite. Her name was Helka. One winter morning she was playing with two nephews, and they pushed her on to an iceberg. They thought it was funny, but then the iceberg drifted away.
"When her father came home he was very angry and he killed the boys. The story says he threw one down the mountain so hard it caused a crack; the other he threw far out to sea. Then he went to live alone on the glacier, and they say he is buried there in a crater filled with water. The fishermen say he still comes to them and warns them of storms."
It was no surprise to find a giant dry-stone statue of Bardar on a cliff overlooking the sea, keeping a benevolent eye on the local fishing fleet.
My guide for the ascent of Snaefells was Kari, a carpenter from Reykjavik who leads tours as a summer job. He was a practical man: "The New Age people say this mountain gives you energy, but I don't believe the mystical stuff. I think beautiful nature anywhere gives you energy." As if on cue, as we wound up a cinder track in a four- wheel drive, nature parted the clouds and revealed the peaks of Snaefells, rising like the curved horns of a mythical beast.
Where Professor Lidenbrock and Axel struggled up the final 1,500 feet, we donned fur-lined snowsuits and hopped on snowmobiles to zip up the glacier in a matter of minutes, to a ridge between the two principal summits.
This was the moment I had been waiting for. This was the spot where Verne's heroes had been drawn by a cryptic message from a 16th- century scholar: "Go down into the crater of Snaefells jokul (glacier), which the shadow of Scartaris caresses before the calends of July, O audacious traveller, and you will reach the centre of the Earth."
By a curious coicidence, I had come at the right time to observe this phenomenon. Unfortunately Kari did not know which, if either, of the peaks was Scartaris, and the sun was obscured by clouds anyway. So I edged gingerly forward to the ridge and peered over, into a vast white bowl hundreds of feet below, and imagined peerless adventurers descending into this trackless wilderness and beyond, into the bowels of the Earth.
"So this is the crater," I said.
"No," Kari said. "This is a bit of the mountain that disappeared in an eruption."
"So where's the crater then?"
"You're standing on it."
I looked around, puzzled, at a gently sloping snowfield. The bottom of the crater, Kari explained, was 820 feet beneath us. It was filled with ice, a minor detail Verne omitted to mention.
Kari sensed my bemusement. "There are crevasses in the glacier; they could have gone down one of those."
On reflection, I was prepared to forgive Verne. He had, after all, lured me to a place of extravagant natural beauty, and as we descended, the skies cleared and the peninsula was transformed. Colours returned to hills and coastal meadows, clouds of Arctic terns and fulmars swirled around dramatic rock formations by the shore, and a lone fishing boat carved a silver wake on a quiet sea.
Before disappearing down a lava tunnel, Axel finally found something good to say about Iceland: "Here nature has constructed a severe order which has never been surpassed, even by the marvels of Babylon or the wonders that were Greece."

hibernation.

Monday, July 30, 2001, p. 10
Bruce Johnston in Rome
Sicily asks God to stop Etna's lava flows
SICILIANS whose homes are in the path of lava running down the slopes of Mount Etna prayed yesterday for divine intervention, as efforts by man failed to tame the volcano.
In Nicolosi, worshippers crowded into the Santa Maria della Grazia church, where they laid flowers at the shrine of St Anthony, their patron saint, who is said to halt eruptions.
In the nearby Madonna dell Roccia di Belpasso sanctuary, Archbishop Luigi Bonmarito of Catania celebrated a special Mass for thousands in an attempt to save the town of Belpasso, which computer projections say could also be overrun.
The two-week eruption is proving unpredictable as it speeds up or slows down almost daily. Experts say it could go on for months.
"Local people still believe in miracles," Gianbattista Martinazzoli, a teacher, said as he left Mass in Nicolosi. "If human technology can't keep the lava back, the Eternal Father is our only salvation."
The eruption has already claimed several farmhouses, a restaurant, stretches of road and a ski lift. Catania's airport was forced to close on Saturday because the dust was so thick.
Higher up from Nicolosi and Belpasso, bulldozers worked round the clock yesterday to build embankments to contain the lava, which is now at the gates of a tourist resort, the Rifugio Sapienza.
Although its front recently began to slow down, the lava is now building up in a depression about 1,100ft above sea level and experts fear it could burst like a dam without warning.

Wednesday, July 25, 2001, p. 15
Bruce Johnston in Genoa
Hopes of saving towns rise as Etna lava flow slows down
STREAMS of lava heading for communities on the slopes of Mount Etna slowed yesterday, raising hopes that built-up areas might be saved from destruction. 
Experts said the lava flow threatening two towns on Etna's southern slopes, Nicolosi and Belpasso, had almost halted 2 1/2 miles away, or about a third of the way down Europe's largest active volcano (10,705ft).
"The lava moved forward only about 10 metres. It shows signs of fatigue. It is broadening out and becoming more dense," said a civil protection spokesman.
The lava, which was 30ft deep in some places, slowed after two new fissures opened on Etna's south-eastern slopes. These were said to be helping to ease pressure on the original streams.
The civil protection team said that it would take advantage of the lull to use bulldozers to try to deviate the path of the flow from inhabited areas.

*
Saturday, June 30, 2001, p. 01
Michael Crichton
Master of the fantastic Jules Verne's novels dealt with the future in incredible ways. Why haven't they dated? Michael Crichton, best- selling author of books including Jurassic Park, explains the lasting appeal of his great forebear.
WHEN the weather is clear, the white cone of Snaefellsnes's volcano is visible from Reykjavik harbour, looking very much as Jules Verne described it 140 years ago in his novel Journey to the Centre of the Earth. It is a testament to the enduring fame of this novel that no Icelander today refers to Snaefellsnes without, in the same sentence, mentioning Verne: "That's the volcano where Jules Verne set his story . . ."
Tourist literature calls Snaefellsnes (now a national park) "Jules Verne's Volcano". And when the Nobel Prize-winning Icelandic novelist Halldor Laxness wrote his novel Under the Glacier in 1972, be felt obliged to note in the first few pages that Verne had long before staked an enduring literary claim to this same glacier.
The strength of Verne's claim derives, in large part, from the continuing popularity of his tale, which has captivated generations of readers, while its title and plot are familiar to many millions who have not read it. Journey to the Centre of the Earth is one of the most famous novels ever written.
Its author was 36 years old when he wrote it, a young lawyer who had chosen a career in the arts, in defiance of his strict father's wishes. Jules Verne had first turned his hand to the theatre, and his early plays were well received. But they did not earn their author much money. Verne's father continued to press his son to choose a more practical occupation. Verne doggedly continued his writing career. At one point, to see his name in print, he began writing short articles on scientific subjects for magazines.
This was a time of enormous interest in the achievements of scientists and engineers, for it seemed each week brought the report of fresh technological wonders. Trains now travelled at 50 miles an hour. London was building an underground rail system beneath the heart of the city. Bridges spanned vast gorges; hot-air balloons rose into the air; submarines slid beneath the water. 
It seemed that men were everywhere exploring and conquering new realms, empowered by the latest developments of science.
French education did not yet include instruction in science, so there was a great demand among readers for popular articles to educate them on scientific subjects. Verne was one of those who helped supply this demand.
At some point Verne conceived of a novel that would be as informative about science as his magazine articles, but would also combine elements of adventure and discovery in an entertaining way. Verne wrote such a book in 1862, calling it "An Air Voyage". Retitled Five Weeks in a Balloon by his new publisher, Pierre-Jules Hetzel, Verne's story was an immediate smash hit. And Verne's literary career was finally launched.
Freed from doubts about the direction of his career, Verne experienced a phenomenal burst of creativity. In the decade following Five Weeks in a Balloon, he wrote nearly all of the novels for which he is remembered: Journey to the Centre of the Earth (1864); From the Earth to the Moon (1865); Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea (1869); and Around the World in Eighty Days (1872).
Now, almost a century and a half later, these novels are all still familiar to readers around the world, still in print, still widely read. Indeed, Verne is one of the few 19th-century novelists young people read for pleasure, and not merely to fulfil a school assignment.
Verne's continuing readership is impossible to explain if one thinks of him as a science-fiction writer, trading on new technological wonders. Verne himself once denied that he had any real interest in science, and he emphasised his lack of scientific training. In any case, Verne's miraculous technologies are by now antique, his dazzling adventures old hat. We have cruised in atomic submarines; we have travelled to the moon; we have gone around the world in 80 days - then 80 hours - and finally 80 minutes. His technology no longer holds any interest. Yet Verne's novels continue to excite readers, just as they did 140 years ago. 
He is, by some accounts, the most popular author in the world. His prose style contributes to this. Verne's prose is lean and fast-moving in a peculiarly modern way, although this has not always been seen as a virtue by critics.Indeed, from his earliest success until his death in 1905, Verne's literary reputation never matched his popularity; in later life he was bitter that he had not been made a member of the Academie Franaise. Today, he is regarded much more seriously by French critics than he ever was during his lifetime.
Verne's lean prose reads quickly, generating much of the headlong rush so familiar to readers. It does not belabour descriptions or mental states; rather, it moves swiftly to Verne's primary concern, which is physical action: movement through the external world. Verne always maintained that his enduring love was not science but geography. And most of his writing, both fiction and non-fiction, concerns travel or geographical exploration. His stripped-down, athletic prose is perfectly suited to this end.
But taut prose, like science fiction, is inadequate as an explanation for Verne's popularity. To explain that, we must turn to the story itself. What Verne does, in book after book, is to recount a fantastic adventure with verisimilitude. In doing so, he revives our sense of mythic wonder, our deep feeling of connection to the physical world, and our appreciation of the practical possibilities of human imagination and human effort. It is a deep and powerful combination. And it was Verne's speciality for some 60 novels.
Jules Verne was not the first author to write a novel as if it were true, to imitate a popular true adventure form, or to incorporate quantities of fact into the narrative. All that had been done by Daniel Defoe, an author Verne much admired. Verne was doing something else.
Verne was the first author to write novel-length fantasies in a realistic manner. He found a way to tell absolutely fantastic stories as if they were true. This is his innovation, and I believe this is the source of his continuing hold on readers. One could say that Verne found a technique that merged romance and realism, and the result is enormously pleasurable. It is also inherently conflicted - a conflict mirrored within the author himself.
As I read him, Jules Verne never felt comfortable writing realistic fiction; he always tried to escape realistic constraints. He was, after all, strongly 
influenced by the Romantic tradition. His earliest writing had shown a polemical tendency and a taste for tragedy; he was at heart anything but realistic. All his life, Verne was drawn to the extreme, the fantastic. There is certainly abundant evidence of this tendency in Journey to the Centre of the Earth, one of his least plausible novels.
At the same time, Verne - spurred on by Hetzel - was writing novels intended to be educational. Inevitably, this meant that many passages had to be as straightforward and factual as a textbook. Such passages would not blend smoothly into the narrative unless the rest of the text adopted a similarly factual tone. Thus, Verne had no choice but to write his fantastic story as if it were true. He was forced into it by the educational material embedded within it.
The resulting tension between fact and fantasy is what energises Verne's tales. 
It is a delicate balance, and he did not always achieve it. When his stories are too documentary-like, they become pedantic and dull; when they become too overtly fantastic, credibility suffers and tension collapses. Verne works best when he grips both strands firmly, and weaves them seamlessly.
There is no better example than Journey to the Centre of the Earth.The story has many fantastic elements. Professor Otto Lidenbrock, with the help of his young nephew Axel, deciphers a mysterious, coded message concealed in a 12th-century Icelandic book. The message, from one Arne Saknussemm (a celebrated alchemist of the 16th century), claims that he has gone through Snaefellsnes volcano to the centre of the Earth.
Lidenbrock decides to repeat the journey, with Axel at his side. Starting in Iceland, the three men travel deep beneath the Earth, where they discover an inland sea, a race of giants, and other marvels. Clearly a fantasy. Clearly difficult to make credible. And yet much of the pleasure of reading this book is to see such outrageous events portrayed so convincingly.
Verne has left us an extraordinary book, which has withstood the test of time better than some of the science described within it. It has brought delight to generations of readers, and will for many more. There is nothing so rare as the chance to take an impossible journey, and to believe it so powerfully that we wonder if we will make it out alive. That's magic. And that's Verne's gift.
This is taken from Michael Crichton's introduction to Jules Verne's `Journey to the Centre of the Earth', published on July 19 at pounds 19.95 by the Folio Society, available direct from the Folio Society only, on 020 7400 4200

Monday, June 25, 2001, p. 11
Thousands flee as volcano erupts
Alex Spillius, South East Asia Correspondent
THOUSANDS of Filipino villagers fled from their homes yesterday as the Mayon volcano erupted, spitting out flaming ash and sending huge boulders tumbling down its slopes.
Booming sounds were heard just before 1pm and a giant mushroom cloud of dust and ash shot six miles into the sky from the volcano's mouth.
Villagers living at the foot of the volcano, in Albay province, 205 miles south-east of Manila, began leaving their homes during the night as smaller blasts shook houses up to eight miles away.
Sirens were sounded and megaphones used to rouse sleeping residents. Dozens of army lorries, police cars and other government vehicles sped out from the provincial capital, Legazpi, to villages at the foot of Mayon to speed the evacuation.
In the panic, a woman collapsed with a heart attack while another gave birth prematurely. A villager fleeing on a bicycle was killed when he was struck by a rescue team's van. Officials at the Philippines Institute of Vulcanology and Seismology said Mayon had erupted 47 times since 1616.
