Saturday, May 12, 2001, p. 13
Heaven for vulcanologists In the remote Auvergne, geology has played timeless tricks with the landscape. James Bedding climbs where lava once flowed.
James Bedding
From our cottage to the top of our volcano was about a minute's climb. Out through the kitchen door to the garden gate, and a scramble up the grassy outcrop beyond. Around the volcano's edges rose columns that looked man-made. 
Round here they call these formations orgues, because they resemble clusters of organ pipes. Before the rock cooled and crystallised into geometric columns, it was red, scorching, sulphurous lava, surging up through punctures in the surface of the earth.
From the volcano, I could see tens of miles. Thick forest and the occasional patch of pasture covered most of the undulating landscape, which was scored by deep valleys. In the distance I could make out villages, groups of houses around a church, all of grey volcanic rock; and between them, like geological punctuation marks, the solidified cores of other long-extinct volcanoes.
This is the Auvergne, the volcanic core at the centre of France. Long isolated because of its rugged terrain, the largest volcanic ensemble in Europe is still one of the least visited corners of the country.
We had come to its south-easternmost limit, the departement of Haute-Loire. 
Here, just short of the deeply gorged limestone of the Ardeche region, the lush, forested landscape has a pockmarked feel; look hard beyond the squat, huddled villages and the pastures, and everywhere you see the pimples and scars left by volcanic activity over much of the past 10 million years.
Clustered below one such pimple was our own village, Bigorre. In a lazy loop slung below the outcrop lay a couple of dozen houses, most with stone roofs, a handful thatched. One of the latter was an ecomusee - a rural museum. Back in 1930, 200 people lived here, said the young guide; now only nine people are here year-round. She pointed out the small windows in the houses. "People were taxed according to the size and number of the windows," she said. "But they also made them small because of the wind."
Across the road, in L'Herminette - a large farmhouse converted into a simple auberge de pays, with views over miles of thick forest - the hotel owner elaborated. "Oh yes, the wind," he said, "la burle. It blows and blows. The weather is tough here. We're at 1,130 metres [3,700ft], so we get a lot of cross-country skiers. Winter lasts five months. The wind blows the snow into drifts, which block the roads. But then maybe another wind comes from the south, and two metres of snow will melt in 24 hours.
"It's too tough for most people to live here," he said. "The school closed in 1965; now most of these are holiday homes, belonging to people who live in the town or the city. But their parents, or grandparents, were probably born in the village."
Back at our cottage, I began to understand the introverted feel of the 18th-century stone farm building. It was squat, low and thick- walled, as if cowering for protection in the lee of the volcano, sheltering from some natural force - even in August, there was a breeze every day, if not a blustery wind. 
Inside, we had a vast, dark living space of exposed stone walls and wooden floor, a big kitchen overlooked by a stuffed boar head with a sneer; below, in the basement, a table tennis table, and outside, a small terrace, sheltered from the breeze, and a garden overlooking, at the end, a small stone chamber - formerly the village's communal oven.
From the top of our little volcano we set off for walks past the thatched cottages, and into the woods and pastures beyond. Footpaths led us along walls of rough-hewn volcanic boulders, and in and out of the pine forests. Most striking of all was the vastness of the sky; and whichever direction we looked, we saw birds of prey gliding, hovering, wheeling, scanning the ground below them. I have never seen skies so freely speckled with raptors: buzzards, kites, kestrels, harriers - living off a land I presumed to be relatively free from chemical contamination.
One day we set our sights on the tallest peak on our horizon, the summit of Mont Mezenc, at 5,750ft, one of the highest peaks of the Massif Central. The wide path from the car park led us up through pine forests to a summit scattered with giant slabs of volcanic rock that rang out a distinctive "chink" when they bumped together. Geologists call them phonolites - sound stones - and the dull chimes accompanied our climb to the blustery summit, where we lost count of the volcanic plugs and lava outflows that lay scattered below in every direction.
All around, we discovered a wild and empty landscape, hilly rather than mountainous, of huge open spaces that are somehow liberating and giddying; an open boundlessness that gives you, in the words of one local writer, "vertige de l'horizontale". You feel that you could easily lose yourself here; and indeed, many have. During the Second World War, these wild lands were a stronghold of the Resistance, and hunted people disappeared into the emptiness, to be whisked to safety in Switzerland. In the villages around Mont Mezenc - a haven, over the centuries, for Protestants fleeing persecution - as many as 5,000 Jewish children were taken in, and saved from deportation.
Closer to our cottage, we visited some of the nearby villages. At Boussoulet, locals had opened up the old communal oven to celebrate the Fete de Pain, and were idling away the afternoon chatting as batch after batch of bread, brioche and pizza emerged from the oven, golden and crisp, to be gobbled on the spot. 
Near St Front we walked along the wooded shore of a tranquil, perfectly circular lake - the flooded crater left by a huge explosion about 10 million years ago, now fed by underwater springs.
St Front itself was gearing up for the arrival of the women's circuit of the Tour de France. A handful of policemen, immaculate in navy uniforms with black trouser stripes and tinted mirror shades, were holding back a surging, restless mob of children from the nearby colonie de vacances. When the cyclists finally appeared, they passed in such a tight knot that the blur of coloured Lycra and glinting chrome flashed by in just a couple of seconds, and the village promptly lapsed back into its normal stupor.
Most memorable of all was the capital of the departement, Le Puy- en-Velay, a town draped over the remains of a giant volcanic crater. Above the carpet of red-tiled roofs rose a couple of spiky volcanic plugs. Atop one needle, the 270ft Rocher d'Aiguilhe, perched a Romanesque chapel, reached by a flight of steps giddyingly cut into the rock.
A chunkier rock towered above the Romanesque arches of the cathedral, and was crowned by a pink, 52ft statue of the Virgin and Child. We climbed the stairway up the rock to the foot of the statue. Hinged windows opened in the robes of the hollow Virgin, rather like the doors on an Advent calendar. A plaque explained that the iron lady was erected in 1859 and weighed 110 tonnes. She was born of the redeeming, transforming power of fire: her materials, 213 cannons captured at Sevastopol during the Crimean War and smelted down.
I climbed through the doorway, and up the staircase that spiralled heavenwards through her body of bolted panels. Generations of visitors had written, painted and scored their prayers, hopes and pleas on the Virgin's insides: "Please Mary," said one, "may my sister get on better with her boyfriend." "Look after us, our children, great-grandchildren and all the others." "Next time I come to see you," confided another, "it will be because I'm back with my lover." And underneath: "I'm with my lover now, together here. Look after us."
Just below her crown, I peered out of one of the hatches, down to the foot of the rock and the cemetery below, and the tombstones that seemed to be ranged in rows, gazing upward. I looked out over the sea of roofs blanketing the floor of the old volcanic crater, and tried to imagine the searing heat and all-consuming fire that once roared under the streets, shops and houses of the town.
VFB Holidays (01242 240340, www.vfbholidays. co.uk) has a handful of gites in the Auvergne; the two-bedroom property in Bigorre costs from pounds 631 fora week in June, including ferry crossing (up to pounds 829 in August).

Thursday, April 12, 2001, p. 13
Refugees trying to shelter from Vesuvius were fried alive by volcanic ash
David Derbyshire Science Correspondent
AFTER 12 hours huddled in the beachside boat houses, the refugees from Herculaneum had probably assumed that the worst was over.
Vesuvius had been erupting all day and, apart from the hail of pumice, there seemed to be no obvious danger.
Yet as the 300 men, women and children sat in the semi-darkness debating whether to return to their homes or flee down the coast, a scorching cloud of superheated volcanic ash burst into the crowded shelters. They were instantly fried alive.
More than 1,900 years later archaeologists have learnt how some of the townsfolk died. In Nature today they report on an analysis of 30 skeletons excavated in the 1980s and 1990s.
The people of Herculaneum were unaware that their town, a resort for wealthy Romans, was in the shadow of an active volcano. Vesuvius had not erupted for centuries and the series of earthquakes 17 years before had not been linked to it.
Then, in 79AD, explosions began the best-documented eruption of antiquity. For 12 hours, according to Pliny, the volcano sent up a column of ash and hot gas and hurled out hot stones and pumice.
Most of the 4,000 to 5,000 inhabitants appear to have evacuated the city. Since the first excavations in the 18th century, few bodies have been found in Herculaneum.
Many fled to the beach, probably to escape by boat. Others waited in 12 boat huts, each about 100ft square.
The study of their remains shows that the column of gas and ash from the volcano collapsed, sending a 500C pyrosclastic surge through the town and to the waterfront. The cloud dropped down the 60ft cliff and blasted the shelters.
The relaxed postures of the skeletons suggest that they died instantly from heat shock and not suffocation. The hot cloud vaporised their flesh and then covered their remains with volcanic ash.
A team led by Dr Alberto Incoronato, of the University of Naples Federico II, studied 80 skeletons taken from ash that had solidified. These showed no signs of a "voluntary self-protective reaction or agony contortions, indicating that their vital organs must have stopped within a shorter time than the conscious reaction time.
"The cloud was a mixture of hot gas and ash," he said yesterday. "It caused little damage in the town itself but killed these people instantly."
The position of the victims suggested that the ash expanded slightly and then deflated, becoming denser and smothering the remains. Some people had fractures and holes blown into their skulls by the heat. The patterns of cracks in tooth enamel and patterns in the bones suggest 500C temperatures.
Dr Pier Petrone, a co-author of the study, said: "It is the first time that there is the possibility to study a group of people who did not die from illness or age. It is a cross section of a living population."
The victims were mostly young adults or children and babies, he added. The boat chambers were crowded, with one containing more than 40 skeletons.
Herculaneum was a favoured holiday destinations of Romans. Merchants and landowners often had second homes in the shadow of Vesuvius. Most workers in the towns were employed in agriculture, fishing or trade industries.

Sunday, March 4, 2001, p. 03
Far from the tanning crowd weekend to remember San Roque David Sandhu feared that Tenerife was going to be mostly sun, sea and sangria, but a few hours in the lap of luxury and a trip up Mount Teide showed him that this Canary Island can also be cool
David Sandhu
His mother-in-law, my fellow guest assured me in a conspiratorial whisper that suggested much more, was "a particularly fastidious woman". But, try as she undoubtedly did, she had found nothing to fault the San Roque, a converted 17th-century mansion-turned- boutique-retreat in the sleepy fishing hamlet of Garachico, in the western half of Tenerife.
Once owned by the de Ponte family (Cristobal de Ponte, a banker from Genoa, established Garachico in 1496), the abandoned building has been lovingly renovated by Dominique Carayon, a French hotelier. With the help of his family and a local architect, Carayon has fashioned a distinctive hideaway: a 20-room hotel where contemporary art and furniture (including Le Corbusier and Mies van de Rohe classics) are set within the warm, earthy tones of the mansion. Huge Jacuzzis are included in the eclectic loft-style suites, and everyone - staff as well as guests - appears serenely relaxed. "We want the atmosphere here to be informal," Carayon says. And it is - you can have breakfast at 2pm.
Though it is informal, it is still luxurious. At dinner, I descended a huge stone stairway into a candlelit courtyard and tucked into grouper served with papas arrugadas (salted potatoes) and mojo (a mildly spicy sauce), and white wine from nearby Icod de los Vinos. This was Tenerife - but not as I knew it.
My sun-starved body had brought me here on a quest for fast-track late winter sunshine, but I had several prejudices to address: could the Canaries, only four hours' flying time from gloomy Gatwick, really be hot? Would it make a relaxing long weekend destination? Would I end up sandwiched between Millwall tattoos and dental-floss bikinis on a fake beach? Answers: yes, yes and yes!
Following a Saturday morning scheduled flight with GB Airways, from Gatwick, the first blast of sunshine kicked off a serotonin rush that lasted throughout my anti-clockwise drive around the island to Garachico.
Tenerife, the largest - and highest - of the Canary Islands, features a mountainous ridge stretching across the island from north- east to south-west. 
At its centre is Mount Teide, the world's third biggest volcano, which acts as a climatic barrier between the verdant north and the arid south.
Garachico ("Little Rock") was once Tenerife's principal port, where steamers, bound for England, picked up wine, until a volcanic eruption engulfed the port in lava and ash in 1706. The volcanic treacle remains, embalming the town in a strange time warp; nearby, deserted black sand bays are insulated by walls of solidified lava.
Garachico struggled to recover from the catastrophe and many buildings were rebuilt, including the monasteries of San Francisco and Santo Domingo, and the residential palace of the Marques de la Quinta Roja.
By day, this beautifully preserved, friendly village attracts a scattering of day-trippers. By night, the upmarket clientele of the San Roque (the only hotel in Garachico) has the place virtually to itself - although, a few laid-back fish restaurants aside, there is little that can be called nightlife.
As part of the Isla Baja region, currently being promoted as the "secret Tenerife" (encouragingly, there are strict restrictions on the number of hotel beds permitted), Garachico makes an excellent base for exploring the island.
The 25-mile ascent up Mount Teide through Teide National Park was no ordinary Sunday afternoon drive. It certainly had its scary moments (the number of ambulances squeezing past was hardly reassuring) and I wouldn't recommend it in rainy conditions.
Teide is a shield volcano, characterised by both its size and broad cone shape - and it remains active, having last blown its top in 1909. As Spain's largest peak, Teide stands 12,195ft above sea level, a super volcano formed by the eruptions of several others. Its snow-capped tip (a crater more than eight miles wide) can be seen from most parts of the island.
I stopped off at regular intervals to wander across a lunar landscape that best resembled a sci-fi film set; the almost brutal scenery features multi-layered lava flows and bizarre rock formations sculpted by the winds that whistle across the sandy plains. Amazingly, some plant life (mostly Macronesian in origin) survives in this harsh climate, including the El Teide broom and Canary cedar and pine trees. The Teide violet is the only plant to grow at the highest altitude.
Although the wind did not seem excessively strong, the teleferico cable-car ride (that would have lifted me the final 3,280ft to the crater within eight minutes) was closed. An anti-climax, although, after such an exhilarating journey, not too disappointing.
After a bowl of watercress soup (a Canarian speciality) at the Teleferico restaurant, I headed down to Puerto de la Cruz, the island's original tourist resort. Acclimatising to brochureland Tenerife,I sipped an ice-cold
Dorada beer as holidaymakers strolled down the promenade.
On Monday morning I battled with aggressive traffic en route to Santa Cruz, Tenerife's capital and one of Spain's busiest ports. On the shore, in the city's former industrial quarter, a spaceship appeared to have landed. The Tenerife Auditorio, designed by the Valencian architect Santiago Calatrava, is an outlandish structure conceived as a statement for 21st-century Tenerife. After four years' construction, this building, more sculpture than architecture, is almost finished; from 2002, it will host music, dance, drama and opera.
Also located in the industrial quarter is the El Tanque cultural centre; housed within an enormous oil tanker drum, 165ft in diameter and 66ft in height, it provides astonishing acoustics. With a reverb of approximately 17 seconds, El Tanque hosts cacophonously avant- garde performances that are certain to make a lasting impression.
With my return flight scheduled for late Tuesday afternoon, there might have been time to explore Teno, a protected national area featuring a volcanic landscape with narrow ravines, marine cliffs, a Tertiary age forest and a wealth of indigenous flora.
But I chose to do something that the vast majority of Tenerife's visitors choose to do - head for the imported Saharan sand beaches. Playa de las Teresitas could have been almost any Mediterranean resort in early summer.
Homer believed that the Canaries were Elysium, a place where the righteous spent their afterlife, and thereafter they have been known as the "Fortunate Islands". Whether the suncream-lathering masses of Tenerife's "international" resorts realise how fortunate they are to visit this topographically diverse island, is another matter.

Sunday, February 25, 2001, p. 11
Hotspots Tim Jepson suggests some other places to see the lava flow
Tim Jepson
The Caribbean
The eastern Caribbean has about 20 active volcanoes, including 10 on Dominica, where the highlight is the world's second-largest "boiling lake" (New Zealand has the largest). On Martinique you can climb the dormant Mont Pelee (40,000 people were killed when it erupted in 1902), and on St Vincent follow a trail to the 700ft deep and one-mile wide crater of La Soufriere. Further information from the Grenadines Tourist Board (020 7937 6570; www.svgtourism). Caribbean Experience (020 7602 4021; www.caribbean-ex.co.uk) offers tailor-made packages, flights and hotels in the region.
Costa Rica
Sunvil Discovery (020 8758 4774; www.sunvil.co.uk) offers independent fly-drive packages with suggested itineraries - including Volcan Poas (8,870ft), a bubbling and steaming cauldron - and two 10- night guided tours (departing on June 11 and Oct 8) visiting a range of sights including Volcan Arenal (5,357ft), Central America's most active volcano. The price is pounds 1,280 and includes flights, transfers, accommodation, excursions and some meals.
Chile
Journey Latin America (020 8747 8315; www.
journeylatinamerica.co.uk) offers add-on excursions to Chile's principal volcanic regions. A two-night trip in the north of the country to the Lauca National Park and Lake Chungara volcanoes costs from pounds 195. Two nights' "soft adventure" to southern Chile's Lake District volcanoes costs from pounds 252 and includes a day's riding and day's rafting in the shadow of the Calbuco, Puntiagardo and Osorno volcanoes.
Ecuador
Exodus (020 8675 5550, brochure line 020 8673 0859; www.exodus.co.uk) has an 18-day Avenue of the Volcanoes trek, which combines cultural highlights with walks around some of South America's premier volcano country. The trip includes the chance to climb Cotopaxi (19,347ft), the world's second highest active volcano (a road runs to 15,750ft). It costs from pounds 1,645, including flights, most meals and a mixture of accommodation in hotels, tents and mountain 
huts.
Hawaii
Hawaii has two main active volcanoes, Mauna Loa and Kilauea, both of which lie within the Volcanoes National Park, one of the world's safest places to observe volcanic activity. Hawaiian specialists North America Travel Service (0113 398 3003; www.northamericatravelservice.
co.uk) offers a three-day excursion from Honolulu staying at Volcano House at the heart of the park from pounds 195, including internal flights and accommodation.
Other operators include Jetlife (01322 614801; www.jetlife.co.uk) and Page & Moy (0870 010 6456; www.page-moy). Further information: Hawaii Visitors Bureau (020 8941 4009; www.gohawaii.com).
Nicaragua
Journey Latin America (see above) has a 23-day "Alcion" tour that takes in most of Central America's volcanic spine, including Baru (Panama), Arenal (Costa Rica), and Masaya, Concepcion and Madera (Nicaragua). The trip cost from pounds 1,673 and includes flights, all transfers, accommodation and excursions.
Italy
Italy boasts Europe's highest active volcano in Mount Etna (10,902ft) and - in Vesuvius - the one that will cause the most damage when (not if) it next erupts. Roads lead part way up Vesuvius - the final haul to the 4,200ft summit involves a 30-minute climb. On Etna, a cable car runs to 7,875ft, where you can walk or join 4WD vehicles that take you as close to the summit as current volcanic activity allows. Eruptions can also be observed on Stromboli in the Aeolian Islands off the Sicilian coast. Contact Magic of Italy (08700 270500) for details of packages to Naples (for Vesuvius), Taormina (for Etna) and the Aeolian Islands.
New Zealand
The area around Rotorua on the North Island is a hotbed of volcanic activity - geysers, steaming fissures and bubbling pools. For tailor-made itineraries that include the area, contact Bridge the World (0870 444 7474; www.bridgetheworld.com) or Tailor Made Travel (01386 712050; www.tailor-made.co.uk). Russia

Saturday, January 20, 2001, p. 11
Best buys after the big bang Volcanic eruptions caused house prices on Montserrat to plummet. Now they are rising again- so get in quick, says Quentin Letts
QUENTIN LETTS
The golf course has been covered by a mudslide and the former capital is a modern Pompeii, buried under hard volcanic dust. Welcome to the Caribbean island of Montserrat. Or, as they say at the Foreign Office since half this dependent territory was destroyed by a volcano: "You're welcome to it - what's left."
But suddenly the Montserrat property market is perkier. The Soufriere Hills volcano, which erupted from 1995 to 1997, has started to cool. The autumn hurricane season passed without incident. And more to the point, locals report the return of the "snowbirds" - the prosperous north Americans who rent and buy in Montserrat to escape the cold winters back home.
Paula Dutcher, of West Indies Real Estate, says: "As you would expect of a small island with a live volcano, sales have not exactly boomed in the past few years. But they are now improving."
In 1997, a few villas sold for as little as 10 per cent of their values before the eruption. Most houses were coated in ash and many were buckled out of shape or burnt. Now, vegetation is growing back, water and electricity supplies have resumed and the climatic seasons have returned to pre-eruption patterns. Prices have yet to reach pre- 1995 levels, but the days of 10 per cent "firesales" have gone.
For US $370,000 ( pounds 255,000) - all transactions are conducted in dollars - you can pick up The Anchorage,
a three-bedroom villa with mahogany trees in its third-of-an-acre garden.
At $525,000 ( pounds 370,000) there is Villa Maurtone, a family house with views towards the neighbouring island of Nevis. Caribbean View, in the Woodlands Bay area, has three double bedrooms, handsome reception space, a pool patio/deck and gardens, all for $295,000 ( pounds 207,000). And at $205,000 ( pounds 145,000), West Indies Real Estate offers another Woodlands house called Topaz: three bedrooms, a small swimming pool and garden gazebo.
The south and east of the island were badly damaged by the volcano and remain so, but the north and west are back to near normal. Montserrat is 13 miles long and three miles wide. Two thirds of the island have been put out of bounds in an "exclusion zone" since the volcano blew.
Most of the expat buyers have been Americans, Britons and Canadians. "They are professional people who are thinking of retiring here in a few years' time but buying now while prices are good," says one local. "We have also had artists and musicians, a bit like the old days when Elton John, Sting and the Rolling Stones used to record their music at George Martin's studios."
Sales are sometimes the result of impulsiveness. One recent buyer was a tourist who saw a house he liked, went to a local nightclub and signed on the bonnet of a car by torchlight as the sun was coming up at 5am, just as his helicopter was preparing to take him off the island.
John Renton, a London architect who developed the Isles Bay Plantation in the early 1990s, recently returned from 10 days on the island. "It is beginning to look its beautiful self again," he says. "There are about 1,500 private villas on the island and, given that the population is now only 4,500, that indicates the proportion of private investment. The Montserrat government is starting to appreciate the contribution villa owners make
to the economy."
All seven houses that Mr Renton designed and sold on Montserrat, remain in the hands of their original buyers. Derek Layton, a Gloucestershire scientist, owns a four-bedroom house in the Old Towne area. "We are sometimes asked why we stayed `loyal' to the island after the eruption," he says. "The answer is that we love Montserrat and its people and want to help them out with their sense of frustration at the British government. Conditions are slowly improving, but there is a shortage of skilled labour."
The BBC recently broadcast
a downbeat report on the island's prospects and there are dark theories that some Montserrat politicians are happy to see the bad news spread, as it might keep property prices down and allow them to buy up houses themselves.
Most villas are in the plantation style, with deep verandahs and swimming pools. 
A few are air-conditioned but most have high ceilings and fans - and there is almost always a breeze on the island.
Michael, a retired Brit who prefers to keep his surname private, points out a few snags: "Local records of who owns land are not exact, so with plots of land you need to be careful about the right of the vendor to sell it." Plots big enough to build a villa cost about US $25,000 ( pounds 17,500), but building supplies are not easy to secure.
Putative buyers will not be food snobs: Montserratian cooking is widely accepted to be dismal. Its drink cannot be faulted, however. Apart from the few little restaurants and beach bars, it has some excellent rum shops such as Gary's Wide Awake Bar in Salem. Political discussions laced with reggae flow on into the night.
Transport off the island is a problem, with an intermittent helicopter service and two ferries a day. Do not move here if you have a medical condition that might necessitate being rushed to a major hospital. Air links might improve, however, if rumours of a new airport come to anything.
"The scientists tell us that the plates under the volcano are beginning to close and that it might be sealing itself," says Mr Renton. "Rental inquiries are bouncing back and that always leads to people buying houses."
If you hanker for a West Indies bolthole where you can watch whales frolicking in the Caribbean Sea and pelicans gorging on fish, Montserrat could be a good place to look - provided you are brave, and quick.

Wednesday, December 20, 2000, p. 08
40,000 abandon their homes under the volcano
Ronald Buchanan in Mexico City
THE Mexican army evacuated 40,000 people from their homes yesterday after Popocateptl, the active volcano on the edge of Mexico City, erupted twice.
The 18,000ft volcano threw rocks 18in in diameter up to 650ft into the air, spewing debris across a six-mile radius. A huge plume of incandescent lava was visible from 40 miles away.
President Vicente Fox pleaded for calm, but added: "We remain on maximum alert."
After the first eruption on Monday night 3,000 troops from the army and federal police were called in and began moving the surrounding inhabitants to school shelters and town halls. The only reported casualty was a 65-year-old man who died from a heart attack.
Oscar Navarro, the head of civil defence, said: "People love the volcano. Its volcanic dust has made the earth fertile. They are understandably reluctant to leave their crops and their animals."
The Interior Minister, Santiago Creel, said the volcano, known as Popo, remained unstable. He added: "It's like a pressure cooker."
Servando de la Cruz, a vulcanologist at the National University, said the eruption was the greatest since before the Spanish Conquistadors arrived about 500 years ago.
Popo, whose name in the Aztec tongue means Old Smoky, began emitting smoke and ash about six years ago. Few nearby residents heeded earlier calls to evacuate the area as the lava dome grew to three times its usual size.
Popo was used as the backdrop for Malcolm Lowry's drunken British consul in his novel Under The Volcano. Scientists believe that the last big eruption happened about AD 800.

Wednesday, May 9, 2001, p. 1
Pinatubo: 10 Years Later Philippine Eruption Snuffed Out Tribe's Way of Life
Thomas Fuller
PATALBATO, Philippines - The sky darkened and the ground shook. It sounded like a "stampede of 100,000 animals," said a Filipino who witnessed it.
When Mount Pinatubo erupted 10 years ago, it spewed a column of ash 40 kilometers (25 miles) into the sky. Fist-sized rocks and sand rained down here for weeks, blanketing the area with a moon-like layer of ash that stretched for dozens of kilometers, a "giant sand trap," in the words of a resident. The eruption, on June 15, 1991, was the second biggest of the 20th century, according to the U.S. Geological Survey. Nearly 1,000 people were crushed by collapsing roofs or swept away by mud slides.
The eruption's effects were felt around the globe: Like a giant aerosol can, the volcano sent a dense cloud of climate-changing gases into the atmosphere. By blocking heat from the sun, scientists say, the cloud of gases lowered the ground temperature of the earth by about half a degree Celsius.
A decade later, there are signs both of rejuvenation and misery in the shadow of Pinatubo. The "sand trap" has sprouted green. Most people, especially city dwellers, have brought normality back into their lives.
Some found ingenious ways to turn tragedy into opportunity. Ash was cleared and sold to construction companies that use it as a building material. Dump trucks took the ash to Manila, a two-hour drive to the south.
Pumice stones that once rained from the sky were gathered and sold by the bag. They have a wide range of uses from cosmetics to carpentry; residents say they are used to help in the process of stone-washing jeans.
Travel agencies offered tours of Pinatubo's crater and the large lake that now sits in the middle of it. The mountain is 300 meters (1,000 feet) shorter than it was before the eruption, a testament to the fact that the volcano literally blew its top.
But for a group of mountain-dwelling people who knew the volcano best who lived on its slopes and hunted in its jungles recovery and reconstruction have been slow, if at all.
The eruption marked the end of a lifestyle for them, one their ancestors pursued for hundreds, if not thousands, of years. They are known as Aeta, a small aboriginal tribe who numbered about 60,000 before the eruption. The Aeta are distinct from most Filipinos because of their starkly different features. They look more African than Asian. They called themselves highlanders and for good reason: they rarely mixed with the people of the valleys and the cities.
When the mountain began to smoke and tremble 10 years ago, many Aeta fled from the hills around Pinatubo and were evacuated to distant resettlement camps.
Ramon and Josefina Diaz, an Aeta couple in their 40s, were taken by dump truck from the town of Patalpinto, where Mr. Diaz was the village chief. They left behind their thatch house, their farm tools and their livestock two water buffalo, three pigs and more than 100 chickens.
In the confusion of the evacuation two of their nine children were also left behind in the village. Both perished.
The village today is buried under so much ash that Mr. Diaz says it would be impossible to excavate it.
Buried, too, is a lifestyle they will probably never see again. Before the eruption, they hunted wild boar, deer, mountain cats and a variety of birds. They grew mountain rice, sweet potatoes, bananas, beans and other root crops.
Those who visited the Aeta tribes in their habitat described it as a veritable Eden. There was spring water in the jungles, and the streams were filled with fish, electric eels and fresh-water shrimp. With nature so bountiful, there was very little use for money.
Many Aeta today say they yearn to return to Pinatubo's slopes, to resume the lives they had before the eruption. But the mountain, they say, does not seem to want them back. The sandy soil is arid and hostile to crops. Mountain rice, their dietary staple, turns yellow and withers when planted in the ash.
Andres Bondoc, an Aeta villager in San Martin, northeast of Pinatubo, says even when crops successfully ripen, they are often eaten by rats, a problem that they never had before the eruption.
"Maybe after the eruption the rats ran down here to escape," Mr. Bondoc said, attempting to explain the scourge.
In the jungles, the huge trees that once provided shelter and shade are gone, replaced by shrubs and other plants with no practical uses. Many banana trees have grown back, but the Aeta say they cannot live off those alone.
Mr. Bondoc shows a visitor a bow and three disused arrows, each with its own, distinctive arrowhead: one for hunting lizard, one for birds and the most elaborate for wild boar. Animals have returned to the jungles, he says, but not in the same numbers as before the eruption.
Today, many Aeta are stuck in resettlement areas that resemble refugee camps. Mr. Diaz, who lives in such a camp, says every year his neighbors die of measles, chicken pox and diarrhea, diseases they rarely encountered before the eruption.
When they lived in the jungles, they wore loin clothes and sarongs. Today many wear Western-style clothes, ill-fitting government hand-outs that hang on their skinny frames like rags.
In the decade since the eruption, the government has provided workshops for the Aeta, teaching them how to make handicrafts from materials in the jungle. But Mrs. Diaz, who attended such a workshop, says making handicrafts is impractical.
"How can you go into the jungle to get materials for baskets when you have nothing to eat?" she asks.
Families here support themselves by finding banana blossoms in the jungle and selling them or bartering them with local traders for rice. A big bag of the blossoms, which are used in Philippine cooking, sells for between $1 and $2.
Because most Aeta are illiterate, finding jobs in cities or towns is difficult. 
They lack the job skills of lowlanders.
"They can't compete," said Guy Hilbero, a local official who has defended the native land rights of the Aeta. "All they can do is be a janitor or a groundskeeper. Even being a housekeeper they sometimes have trouble with." It could be that the eruption of Pinatubo accelerated the inevitable. The nomadic, wild lifestyle of the Aeta was perhaps destined to clash with technology and development.
This is no consolation to Mr. and Mrs. Diaz. "Aeta people before were like a broom," Mr. Diaz said, "all bundled together. Everybody shared everything. We lived together."

Friday, June 25, 1999 10
The Wonder of the Post-Apocalyptic Mount Pinatubo
Katherine Tanko
ANGELES CITY, Philippines
"The amazing thing about Pinatubo," Owen said, "is that it's continually changing." Scooping up a handful of lahar, the fine- grained mixture of ash and stone ejected from Pinatubo during its headline-grabbing eruption, he explained how wind and rain constantly reshape Pinatubo's post-apocalyptic landscape. 
"Every time I climb it, it's completely different."
But then, Pinatubo is not your average volcano. It has been only eight years since this once little-known mountain erupted in a fit of volcanic fury that made Mount Saint Helens look like a backdoor barbecue. Over three days in June 1991, Pinatubo blasted 10 billion cubic meters of debris 40 kilometers (25 miles) into the stratosphere, turning day into night and Manila, 90 kilometers to the south, into a giant ashtray. By the time it was over, hundreds of people had died, thousands had been evacuated and the landscape around Pinatubo had been transformed forever.
So when I heard that you can now climb all the way to Pinatubo's crater, I started packing my bags. It is rare to come across a volcano like Pinatubo: Its post-eruption landscape is dramatic, unique and utterly wild. Yet it is easy to get to, just a short drive west of Angeles City, giving anyone with a sturdy pair of boots the chance to explore nature in the raw. To get to Pinatubo's crater and back in one day, we had to set out early. Owen, our guide, picked us up at 4 A.M. for the two-hour drive to the start of the trail on the northern slope. It was just starting to get light when we pulled up beside a makeshift camp of Aetas the highland people who lived on the slopes of Pinatubo before the blast near the start of the trail. The eruption of Pinatubo was a catastrophe for the Aetas. These dignified people have long preferred an independent life on Pinatubo's slopes to the rat race of the lowlands a place they consider synonymous with human corruption. Hundreds of them were killed in the eruption, when they preferred to hide in caves rather than be evacuated. Others escaped a fiery end only to die from measles and other lowland diseases in resettlement camps. Some, like this group, have moved back to the wilderness of Pinatubo, living as close as they can to their former homes. Here on this remote patch of land, they build new houses, grow their own food and wait for the day the mountain will be able to support them again. We set out along a wide, flat riverbed. At the tail-end of the dry season the river was little more than a shallow ribbon of fast flowing water; at the height of the wet it can become a raging current and a conduit for lahar slides. The grassy banks that flanked us at the outset disappeared and we soon found ourselves wandering through a surreal moonscape of ash. Enormous cliffs of lahar towered a hundred meters above us, their surfaces eroded into a sculpture of ashen steeples and spires. 
The entire canyon was a mix of God meets Gaudi, an ash-covered badlands utterly devoid of life. At the mercy of typhoons and monsoons, these fragile canyons are about as permanent as an ice sculpture in the Sahara. It's the sheer volume of lahar that makes Pinatubo so spectacular and so deadly. At the Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology's Pinatubo Observatory, the resident volcanologist, Jaime Sincioco, estimates that about 7 billion cubic meters of debris more than 200 meters thick, were deposited on the volcano's slopes. "When Mount Saint Helens erupted, pyroclastic flows only went down one side of the volcano," he said, "With Pinatubo it was different." Lahar flowed down eight major drainage channels, some passing through towns, villages and farmland, burying entire communities in meters of stinking mud. As we neared the crater, Pinatubo's haunting, lunar landscape eventually gave way to something resembling planet Earth. We clambered over ocher and sand-colored boulders, along a tumbling freshwater stream littered with mineral-rich rocks bleeding brilliant shades of green and red. Here, too, were the first signs of life returning to Pinatubo's slopes: saplings, wild grass and tadpoles darting about in shallow pools of water. After four hours we finally arrived at the crater, a ring of jagged cliffs enveloping a shimmering turquoise lake. We had been advised not to swim in the water because of its high acidity, but no one in our group could resist a dip. The water was warm and as we paddled out into the lake we could see steam rising from smoking vents on the far shore. Floating above the volcano's gaping mouth, gateway to the planet's fury, there was now only silence. The next day we drove to Bacolor, a small town southeast of the volcano. Still living in fear Here residents still live in fear of the lahar slides that have engulfed the town half a dozen times since 1991. Driving into town we were greeted by the eerie sight of rooftops poking out of the ground and the 18th-century church of San Guillermo half buried in the earth. "This was all farmland once," said the parish priest, Father Nestor Tayag, as he surveyed the barren land covered in wild grass that now surrounds the village. The ground is useless now, although locals have had some success growing peanuts and a few other plants. A handful of new homes all built on stilts dotted the bleak horizon. "As you can see," he said, "we are not victims, we are survivors." There were other casualties as well. The Americans abandoned their military bases buried beneath a foot of ash at Clark and Subic Bay. Angeles City, the town that grew rich catering to the off-duty needs of Clark's servicemen, went into an economic nosedive. Since then, Clark has slowly found its feet as an industrial park and leisure zone while Angeles has begun catering to the new breed of foreigner in town: tourists. "It used to be a real honky-tonk town," Owen said as we cruised the golden mile of restaurants, bars and massage parlors many either closed down or boarded up that Angeles was famous for. "When the Americans were here, they'd come to town and blow their whole week's pay," Owen explained, "but the tourists that come here now, they don't have that kind of money. Many are backpackers traveling on tight budgets. So now they call Angeles Kuripot Town, or Tightwad Town." Locals have been slow to respond to the changing market, however, and it will be some time before the bars beloved of GIs are replaced by something more suitable for trekkers and nature lovers. An excellent base On the plus side, years of catering to American palates has left Angeles with an excellent range of hotels, shops and international restaurants, making it an ideal base for a Pinatubo Trek. Hotel prices range from $5 to $40. The Holiday Inn on Clark Field ($120; tel: 632-845-1888) is a quieter, greener place to stay, but its location on the far side of Clark means getting around is difficult unless you have your own vehicle. Many hotels will arrange Pinatubo treks. Most companies charge around $40 a person for the one day trip, including pick up and drop off at your hotel. Overnight trips start at $70 including food, water and camping gear. We arranged our trip with Summit Tours (tel: 045- 892-5779); Dale City Tours (045-887-1825) offers similar rates, or contact the Philippine Department of Tourism (045-961-2665) for more information. Treks are restricted to the dry season from October to April. In the wet, lahar slides and the risk of secondary explosions make trekking hazardous. But it's worth making the effort to go now, before too many more rainy seasons change Pinatubo's ethereal landscape again. Katherine Tanko is a journalist who travels frequently in Asia.

4 Nov 1993, page 16 
Technology: Taming the volcanoes - Improved forecasting techniques are making it easier to predict eruptions
By VICTORIA GRIFFITH

Volcanoes, which spit ash, ooze lava and create darkness in the middle ofthe day, are impressive displays of nature's restlessness. They are alsolife-threatening: more than 28,500 people died from eruptions during the1980s. They can cause millions of dollars in property damage and bringindustrial activity to a grinding halt.New technology to improve the accuracy of eruption forecasts is helping tominimise the devastation volcanoes can cause. After the Nevado del Ruizeruption killed nearly 25,000 people in Colombia in 1986, the US governmentbegan taking volcanic forecasting seriously. The US Geological Survey, whichtracks volcanic activity around the world, was infused with new funds tocreate a detailed database and update its techniques.The new technology will not only help to save thousands of lives, it mayalso save millions of dollars. According to the Aviation Safety Journal,more than 60 aircraft have been damaged by drifting clouds of volcanic ashsince 1980. The repair of a 747 aircraft damaged during the 1989 eruptionfrom Redoubt Volcano in Alaska cost Dollars 80m (Pounds 53m).The continuous eruption of Hawaii's Kilauea since 1983 has caused more thanDollars 5m in damage, much of it to properties and crops affected by theacid-bearing volcanic pollutants. Mount St Helens in Washington state wipedout thousands of acres of productive timberland.Losses from interrupted economic activity are harder to quantify, but may bemore devastating. Redoubt's eruption, for instance, caused a valuable oilstorage terminal to close for several weeks and halted most flights into andout of the region.Tourism often takes the hardest hit of all. When US geologists issuederuption warnings in California's Long Valley in 1982, the resort areaturned into a ghost town almost overnight. And the tourist-based economy ofGuadeloupe neared collapse in 1976 after an international group ofvolcanologists forecast the eruption of La Soufriere.The Long Valley and Guadeloupe incidents are tinged with bitterness sincethe predicted disasters never happened. Guadeloupe evacuated 72,000 peopleand tourists stayed away. Yet the only crisis that hit the Caribbean islandwas in the economic sphere.Scientists blame these fiascos on insufficient data. 'The identification offresh volcanic glass in the erupted ash - which seemed to indicate that thevolcano was about to erupt violently - was a mistake,' wrote Richard Fiske,a volcanologist at the Smithsonian Institution, about the incident.Volcanologists today use more sophisticated techniques. Detailed databasesare maintained on all life-threatening volcanoes around the world.High-frequency monitors to measure debris flows are now in place.Earthquakes - often the first warning of volcanic activity - are trackedwith increasing accuracy. And changes in gas composition, electricalconductivity and other clues are carefully monitored.As a result, volcanic activity can now be forecast with substantialaccuracy, often pinpointing the eruption to within days or even hours of itsactual occurrence. When Redoubt erupted in Alaska in 1989 and Pinatubo blewits top in the Philippines in 1991, volcanologists provided importantinformation, not only about the timing of the events, but also about thedirection of debris flows and ash blooms - vast clouds formed when tinypieces of lava or rock are thrown into the air.'We used information on the ash blooms (during the Redoubt eruption) to knowwhich areas to stay away from, and which were safe to fly through,' saysGreg Witter, a spokesman for Alaska Air.Companies can also take advantage of eruption forecasts to move valuableequipment out of the way, and evacuate employees from the area.'Businesses with sensitive electronics may want to shut down their airfiltration system during an ash bloom,' says Steven Brantley, publicinformation scientist with the US Geological Survey. Since ash blooms oftendrift for many miles, they can wreak havoc on property well beyond thelife-threatening zone of eruption.Volcanology can also be used for future planning. After much of its timberwas wiped out during the eruption of Mount St Helens, the paper groupWeyerhaeuser consulted experts to decide which areas should be replanted andwhich avoided as too high-risk.Not all businesses welcome the interference of volcanologists, however. InLong Valley developers have refused to heed warnings in land use planning.'We've had mixed results, because we can't force people to follow ouradvice,' says Daniel Miller, a geologist with the US Geological Survey.'We've had a very negative and unpleasant response from businesses in LongValley. They just don't believe that they might be in a risk zone and insiston building things anywhere they please.'Developers in the region complain that the volcanologists' warnings haveresulted in higher insurance rates, limited areas of potential developmentand stoked the fears of tourists.The relationship between active volcanoes and the communities that surroundthem is not always confrontational. Kilauea has become a leading Hawaiiantourist attraction. It is considered the ideal volcano. Because the eruptionis continuous, it is seldom life-threatening and ash blooms are rare.Instead, the volcano throws up a scenic display of colourful lava, whichattracts hikers by day and creates a natural light show at night.Scientists have gleaned much useful information from the decade-longeruption.'The resorts look to us to provide information on best viewing times, whichthey pass on to the tourists,' says David Clague, scientist in charge of theHawaii Volcano Observatory at Kilauea. 'It's generally pretty tame as far asvolcano eruptions go, but it's spectacular at night because it'siridescent.'

Travel: Not many people know about El Salvador.
By MARK HODSON
      
TWO HUNDRED years ago, a hole appeared in the ground somewhere in western ElSalvador and a huge fountain of lava and ash spewed out to form a perfectvolcanic cone 4,000ft high. 18 Sep 1993, Page XIII
Travel: Violent landscape in bubbling repose - Michael J Woods flies above the volcanoes of Rotorua, climbs into their craters and bathes in their sulphur springs
By MICHAEL J WOODS
      
HOT sulphurous steam belched from the mountainside and rose in stiflingclouds from the main crater, rolling upwards towards the rim before beingtorn to shreds and melting away to invisibility in the powerfulsouth-westerly wind.The helicopter, insignificant against this great mountain, banked over thecrater, bucking in the uplift. As it did so I stared into the volcano's evildepths to glimpse the sump of viscous grey liquid in the bottom. Only thebilious yellow of sulphur coloured the moonscape. Like iodine around awound, the sulphur had left a saffron deposit round every vent and crack.The helicopter landed on the slippery surface of the old mudflow, deeplyscored by water channels, where the wind piled in from the sea between twocliffs. This was White Island, an active volcano 31 miles off the east coastof New Zealand's North Island. Fishing boats may shelter in its lee andgannets and mutton birds may nest on its outer edges, but the interior isfar less hospitable - the living planet in the making.White Island is at one end of a volcanic region which stretches inlandsouth-west to Ruapehu volcano, 150 miles away, and contains all NewZealand's historically active volcanoes. One of its most notablemanifestations is Mount Tarawera which erupted in the early morning of June10 1886 to cause New Zealand's biggest natural disaster.We flew over it on our return from White Island, looking down into agigantic cleft 850ft deep, blasted out of the mountain's three-domed summitin a rift eruption which runs for more than 10 miles.While a helicopter ride gives you a good overview, nothing beats climbingdown into the crater, so later I was driven close to the top beforeslip-sliding down a long, steep scree slope into the crater itself.Stand still and the silence is almost overwhelming.But the earth has not finished its business here. Although my guiderepeatedly reminded me that the giant beneath Tarawera was only sleeping,there was no sign of geothermal life. Go down the hill to the south-west andcross Lake Rotomahana into Waimangu Valley and there is enough activity tosatisfy the most ardent enthusiast. And it would be harder to find one moreardent than Bradley Scott, from the volcano surveillance team of NewZealand's Institute of Geological and Nuclear Sciences, who took me there.He regularly monitors temperatures and water levels of the two lakes, FryingPan Lake and Inferno Crater Lake. As they gently steamed before us, heexplained that the two swap water via a freak underground chamber from whichit is forced as if from a subterranean pressure cooker.Over a 38-day cycle, the level of Inferno Crater Lake can vary by as much as39 feet, by far the largest such fluctuation in the world. By keeping an eyeon things here, Brad should be able to predict any further eruptions andavoid the surprise that Tarawera sprung just over a century ago. In volcanicterms that was a minor eruption. Far larger ones have taken place here inthe past, throwing out huge amounts of molten rock.Tourism based on hydrothermal activity was already growing before the 1886eruption. Displays in Rotorua museum, located in a failedturn-of-the-century bath house, explain that Europeans were then making thelong journey to New Zealand to bathe at the magnificent pink and whiteterraces which looked like two great glaciers pushing into the original LakeRotomahana, except that these were created by heat rather than cold. Theywere regarded as one of the wonders of the world in their day.The Victorians enjoyed describing these delicate silica cascades in flowerytones. The hottest, deepest pools were at the top, cooler, shallower ones atthe bottom. The topmost pools on the pink terraces contained shimmering bluewater.Sadly, the terraces were blown away during the Tarawera eruption, Bradassured me, but, to his obvious amusement, optimistic expeditions stillarrive occasionally, intent on excavating the terraces from the mud whichburied the two Maori villages of Te Ariki and Moura and partially engulfed athird during that fateful night.This last, Te Wairoa, has been excavated and can still be seen on its site,south-east of Rotorua. It was here that visitors to the terraces would stayovernight before setting out by boat or on horseback with Maori guides,often purchasing freshwater crayfish on the way to cook in the terracepools. The introduction of a cash economy meant that the destruction oftheir money-spinner was an even greater disaster for those who survived.It is still possible to enjoy a soak in the steaming opaque Polynesianpools. The acid and alkaline baths are open to the sky and at night they aredimly lit by strings of white fairy lights. The half-naked figures whichsilently came and went through the thick plumes of steam made my baths herea relaxing but surreal experience.Today there is a growing fascination with geothermal activity, and the Maoriarts and crafts institute on the edge of Rotorua is partly funded by itspopular guided visits to the boiling mud pools and geysers in its grounds.The institute fosters the craft of Maori carving.An evening at a Maori marae (meeting house), where a concert is followed bythe customary hangi (meal cooked under the ground), gives an insight intothe rituals of these people. The arriving party is treated as a rival tribeby the residents of the village and various rituals are observed.Warriors come forward with appropriately fierce threats and gestures untilthe peaceful intentions of the visitors are established. The night I went wewere approached through the darkness by a tattooed, spear-wielding, gruntingwarrior. I am not sure which impressed me most  - this ferocious man or theunintentional helicopter acrobatics over White Island's yawning maw.Michael Woods was a guest of the New Zealand Tourism Board, from whichfurther information can be obtained: New Zealand House, Haymarket, LondonSW1Y 4TQ, tel: 071-973-0360. The attractions he visited in and aroundRotorua included White Island, with Tarawera Helicopters, based at the Maoriarts and crafts institute, tel: Rotorua (07) 348-1223; the summit of MountTarawera, with Mount Tarawera 4WD Tours, PO Box 5157, Rotorua, tel:07-357-4026; Waimangu volcanic valley, tel: 07-366-6137; the Bath House artand history museum, tel: 07-348-4197; and the buried village of Te Wairoa,tel: 07-362-8287. Brad Scott's tel: 07-374-8211.

17 Sep 1993
Commodities and Agriculture: Volcano pushes Patagonian sheep over the brink - After years of struggle the eruption was the last straw for many.
By JOHN BARHAM
      
THE SHEEP farms of Patagonia are gradually disappearing. Sheep farming, theonly agricultural activity the barren, windswept steppes can support, hasbecome a ruinously loss-making business. Farmers burdened by rising debtsand falling incomes are abandoning their properties in increasing numbers.Patagonia's sheep sector began declining in the 1960s, but the downturnaccelerated dramatically two years ago. The collapse in the internationalwool market - a glut has driven prices to the lowest point in living memory -coincided lethally with spreading desertification, a radical shift ingovernment economic policy and natural disaster.On August 13, 1992, Mount Hudson, a volcano high in the Chilean Andeserupted, spewing vast quantities of ash over the southern half of Patagonia.The ash ruined the sheep's wool, making it worthless, and transformed areasof the province of Santa Cruz into wasteland. Sheep could not graze on theash-covered land and slowly died.Mr Jimmy Patterson, a wool trader and descendant of the Scottish farmers whofirst introduced sheep to Patagonia from the nearby Falkland Islands in1885, says the ash made his parents close their 30,000-hectare family farmon the east coast of Santa Cruz. Last year, 452 farms covering 8m hectaresin Santa Cruz went the same way. For most of them, the eruption was the coupde grace that followed years of mounting losses.Closures are common elsewhere in Patagonia and Mr Juan Ventura, who ownsthree farms, says they will become more frequent. 'You don't see the effectsimmediately. What is happening is that farmers are consuming their capital.They're not spending on maintenance. Eventually they go bankrupt.'Many farmers are trying to hang on. Mr Raul Assef, who owns a 1,500-hectarefarm on the western edge of Patagonia, says 'both my wife and I work in townand use our wages to cover the loss of running the farm. You never know whatmight happen in this country and the market might even recover one day'.Patagonia's isolated farms cover huge areas but can only support smallflocks, making them expensive to run. In arid central Patagonia a sheepneeds 5 ha to graze on and farms of 2,500 ha are common.Few farmers can afford the investments needed to improve efficiency or switch over to more profitable cattle farming. Those who can are expanding their cattle herds, now that Patagonia has been declared free offoot-and-mouth disease.Beef 'imports' from the infected north are banned, allowing local producersto charge premium prices.Others are branching into flower or fruit production. In the watered,protected mountain valleys to the west, strawberries, boysenberries andraspberries grow well. The government is negotiating a joint World Bank andInter-American Development Bank loan for an irrigation project in the eastof the province.Even if wool prices do recover, Patagonia's farmers will not be able toraise output much. A century of over-grazing has devastated the centralplateau, which covers about one third of Argentina's territory.Desertification is a serious problem.The arid plains are framed by distant low-lying hills and dotted withoccasional termite hills The stony soil is covered with khaki-colouredshrubs and tufts of tough grass. Occasionally, small groups of sheep can beseen searching for foliage.Mr Guillermo Defosse, economic development under-secretary in the provinceof Chubut, says that although the region's wool is considered to among 'thefinest in the world, little consideration was given to the vegetation andthe soil which supported that production'.Production this year is forecast at 90,000 tonnes, 13 per cent less thanlast year. In Chubut, wool production has fallen to 18,000 tonnes in 1992from 26,833 tonnes a decade earlier.Argentina's adoption four years ago of free market policies compounded thesesetbacks. The government abolished its hated agricultural export taxes andreduced other taxes. But its anti-inflation policies led to a strongrevaluation of the currency, reducing export revenues and increasing costs.These policies hit farmers throughout Argentina, but few are suffering asmuch as those in Patagonia. Federal and local governments are helping withcheap loans, subsidies, grants and tax breaks worth over USDollars 75m areavailable to support or convert farms to other activities.Policy is confused, however. A Chubut official said 'one department wantssmall farms to merge to reduce stocking levels and another encourages themto survive by sharing equipment or through credit unions'. He also recognises that the government has done little to introduce modern farmingand water-management methods that are less harmful to the land.Although the disappearance of Patagonia's sheep farms is leading to thedepopulation of a vast area of the country and creating serious socialproblems, it could at least have the long-term benefit of relieving pressureon the land and slow the advance of desertification.

Volcano damages.
HAROUN Tazieff, the French vulcanologist and former government minister, has been fined 10 000 francs (about Pounds sterling 1000) for libelling the geologist Claude Allegre, a high-ranking education ministry adviser. Tazieff had called him a forger, 'Claude the Fraud', a 'charlatan' who 'descended from Stalin's favourite geneticist, Lysenko'. 
The remarks, in an interview in Penthouse magazine, reflect Tazieff's fury dating back 14 years to a quarrel over the chances of a volcano erupting in Guadeloupe. Tazieff, sure there was no danger, left the French island; Allegre then arrived, had the local population evacuated and, although there was no eruption, sacked Tazieff from his post at the Global Physics Institute for having left the island prematurely. 
The judges followed the scientific argument closely, turning down Allegre's claim for damages of 10 000 francs because Tazieff 'had the right to denounce mistakes and even incompetence' in the affair. 
But they fined the vulcanologist the same amount and made him pay one franc in symbolic damages to Allegre because his accusation of political manoeuvring was unproven and his animosity 'went beyond purely scientific polemic'

Volcano in Oz.
ONLY the second active volcano ever to be discovered on Australian territory has been found on McDonald Island? tiny speck of land some 4500 kilometres southwest of Perth.

vol 122 issue 1669 - 17 June 89,
Small volcano in Chile.
SATELLITE images which suggested that a volcano in northern Chile might become active have been proved correct. Lascar, a volcano in the central Andes which appeared unusually hot on images taken between 1984 and 1987, has begun to erupt lava in the past few months. The geologists' findings are reported in a letter to Nature (8 June, p 434) by David Rothery of the Open University in Milton Keynes. 
British and American scientists using infrared images from the Landsat Thematic Mapper spotted Lascar as an unusually hot volcano some time ago (This Week, 15 April). They suggested that the heat meant that Lascar was active. The observations of lava show that they were right.
