27 April 2001
BOOKS: VOLCANOLOGY.
Not "A Piece of Cake"!
Haraldur Sigurdsson.
Thousands of people have died in volcanic disasters this past century. The notable 1902 eruption of Mont Pelée in Martinique killed 28,000, the more recent in 1985 eruption of Nevado del Ruiz in Colombia, 25.000. We tend to attribute such death tolls to a combination of poor planning and the lack of response by the general public, who remain unaware of often obvious alarms. What is generally less known, however, is that those who should be best informed about volcanic hazards continue to die on active volcanoes around the world: at least 32 volcanologists have been killed in the field since 1947. Is volcanology such a primitive science. that repeatedly its practitioners die in action because of our poor understanding of this violent natural process? Or are these scientists a fool-hardy lot, whose hard-driving ambitions lead them to take unacceptable risks'?
In January 1993, an international group of scientists met in Pasto, Colombia, at the foot of Galeras volcano, to conduct a workshop on volcanic hazards. Galeras was one of fifteen volcanoes targeted for a decade of intensive study under a United Nations program for the reduction of natural hazards. The scientists included volcanologists, volcanic gas geochemists, seismologists, and other specialists on active volcanoes. The meeting's importance was greatly heightened by the 1985 Nevado del Ruiz disaster, because the death toll from the mudflows caused by that eruption could have been prevented altogether had Colombian civil authorities heeded a hazard-zone map and other warnings of scientists who were monitoring the volcano.
After a half century of inactivity Galeras experienced several small explosive eruptions between 1988 and July 1992. But it appeared quiet when, for one of the workshop's field trips, 14 scientists descended into the caldera to examine the gases emanating from its inner cone. They were led by Stanley Williams. an American volcanologist who had convened the meeting. As they were winding up their studies on the floor and rim of the crater, the release of pent-up gas pressure inside the volcano ripped apart a dome that had plugged the vent. The small explosion ended the lives of six scientists and threw their remains hundreds of meters from the crater. Three tourists who had tagged along were also killed. Several survivors, some badly wounded, struggled up the caldera walls to safety. Two remarkably brave female volcanologists rushed up Galeras and descended without hesitation into the caldera to rescue others, their quick action clearly saved the lives of the most seriously injured including Williams. Surprisingly, only two of the scientists had worn hard hats or used other safety equipment. The international volcanological community was dumbfounded over the disaster and the loss of their friends and colleagues, but the rest of the world wondered how so many "experts" could become the victims of the phenomenon they claimed to know so well.
The Galeras volcanic disaster is the topic of two recent books, which approach the tragedy from very different directions. In No Apparent Danger, former science writer and geologist Victoria Bruce offers a vivid picture of the event, one based on thorough investigation and extensive interviews with survivors and rescuers. A journalistic account, her riveting and suspenseful book is hard to put down. One of Bruce's main theses is that the scientists, and in particular Williams, had not fully evaluated the dangers before descending into the caldera and climbing the active cone. She raises sensitive issues of competition and professional jealousy among scientists, and she exposes the sad truth that available information is not always shared - sometimes, such as between the seismologists and gas chemists, with deadly results.
A peculiar type of low-frequency l2 to 3 Hz) or long-period seismic events, called tornillos (screws) by Latin American volcanologists. had been observed from Galeras for about two weeks before the fatal eruption. These events are thought to be caused by near-surface bubble formation in magmas or some sort of fluid pressurization process, they had been used successfully to predict an eruption elsewhere. While seismologists thought the tornillos could mean an eruption was imminent, the gas chemists could point to the low sulfur dioxide emission and therefore claim that there was little likelihood of an eruption. Sadly, volcanologists do not look good when each sub-speciality likes to promote its own predictive method and ignores the others.
Bruce makes relatively few judgments and manages to maintain her distance from the subject, leaving interpretation and conclusions to the reader. Regrettably, one gets the feeling that the actions of the volcano experts are often driven more by ego and infighting than by balanced judgment based on scientific information.
In Surviving Galeras, Williams, working with professional writer Fen Montaigne, provides a completely different perspective on the disaster. In his frank but admittedly unclear account, Williams honors those who died in the crater. He paints a wonderful picture of their lives and work, and he movingly describes the grief of their families. The flow of his narrative, however, is frequently interrupted by explanations about how volcanoes work and examples of famous eruptions. These distracting forays merely repeat published work. Regrettably, Williams emphasizes the bravado of work (sometimes with questionable goals) in and around craters at high risk. Thus, there are frequent references to "macho" elements, such as "sucking volcanic gas" as the proper rite of passage for a budding volcanologist. But the only heroes to emerge from his tragic story are those who entered the caldera to rescue the wounded.
For scientists, perhaps the most interesting details are the survivors' reports of geophysical changes that occurred shortly before the explosion. According to Bruce's sources, a tornillo was noted at the Pasto Volcano Observatory about four hours before the eruption, and the information was radioed to the group in the crater. At least a half hour before the explosion, microgravity expert (and victim) Geoff Brown started to detect "rapid fluctuations in gravity" inside the crater. At the time, he attributed them to instrument problems, but in retrospect these signals were probably related to near-surface bubbling or fluid pressure fluctuations in the magma below the dome that plugged the crater. Two other warning signs were a small ash emission from a small vent in the crater floor and a large number of rock falls from the crater walls in the "final minutes before the eruption."
In the months after the disaster, Williams was widely featured in the media, coverage that, he admits, "fed my not inconsiderable ego." Others in the crater that fateful day were increasingly concerned about how his version of the story tended to diminish their roles, and they were dismayed when Williams was referred to as "the sole survivor." To his credit, Williams is disarmingly frank in admitting an error of judgment on this issue. He speculates that his severe head injury may have affected his memory and subsequent actions.
Many volcanologists, including myself, strongly disagree with Williams's claim that "the best work ... comes from those of us who walk into the crater." The 20th-century transformation of our discipline from a descriptive endeavor to a true science stemmed from the meticulous geologic observations and deductions of outstanding field geologists like George P L. Walker on volcanic deposits from past eruptions and from the application of such observations by physics-minded volcanologists like Lionel Wilson to develop numerical and physical models of volcanic processes. None of these advances, nor our progress in understanding the origin and evolution of magmas, required setting foot in an active crater.
Does a young and evolving science learn from a tragedy like Galeras? As a result of the disaster, in 1994 the International Association of Volcanology and Chemistry of the Earth's Interior issued the first safety recommendations for scientists and the public. These guidelines encourage volcanologists to approach active volcanoes with greater caution and better preparation. But the deaths continue. On 27 July 2000, a large party of volcanologists was visiting the summit crater of Indonesia's Semeru volcano when an early-morning explosion killed two scientists and badly injured five others. Like the tragedy at Galeras, this incident reminds us that we know a lot about the workings of volcanoes, but clearly not enough to judge when an active volcano can be safely trodden on. Do we need to continue to take such huge risks`? Let us hope that we can instead bring the concept of "telepresence" to bear on the world's most dangerous volcanoes. By developing and using robots and remotely controlled unmanned vehicles (for scientific instrumentation and for direct observation) we can better protect the public and those whose research may help reduce volcanic hazards.

No Apparent Danger. The True Story of Volcanic Disaster at Galeras and Nevado del Ruiz by Victoria Bruce.
HarperCollins, New York, 2001. 251 pp. $26, C$39.50. ISBN 0-06019920-2.
Surviving Galeras by Stanley Williams and Fen Montaigne. Houghton Mifflin, Boston, 2001. 280 pp. $25. ISBN 0-618-03168-5.
Earlier eruption. May 1989 blasts propelled a plume of ash over Galeras.
Unrecognized warnings. Small numbers of tornillos were recorded at Galeras in the weeks before the fatal eruption.

The author is at the Graduate School of Oceanography, University of Rhode Island, South Ferry Road, Narragansett, RI 02882, USA. E-mail: haraldur@ gsosunl.gso.uri.edu.

Feb 1997 v6 n1 p76(4). 
Title: Saba: hiking a volcano in the sea. 
Author: Daniel Pendick 
Abstract: Saba, a Caribbean island northeast of Puerto Rico, is an ideal location for scuba diving. Saba is part of a volcanic chain, some of which has appeared in historical time. Seafarers brought goats and breadfruit to this island in earlier centuries. S
With a last look at the dormant volcano that made the island of Saba, I slipped beneath the warm waves of the Eastern Caribbean with Hank and George. The last time I'd seen my diving buddies in scuba gear we were in colder surroundings: flailing in a stiff North Atlantic current 15 miles out from New York, preparing to go down to the capsized wreck of a World War I armored cruiser. The sky above was gunmetal-gray, the ocean surface was swelling about two feet up and down and beneath us lay 130 feet of cold, murky seawater. This sunny July day five years later could not have been a greater contrast. Saba is a scuba paradise. The relatively unsullied reefs and rock pinnacles around the island are a coffee-table book of unfamiliar colors and creatures. We felt we had entered a Jacques Cousteau film, except this time we were the cameramen. After we returned from our morning dive, my friends and I would take long, hot hikes, exploring Saba's volcanic face -- which to me, as a volcano weenie, is just as exotic as the underwater landscape. It is one of the many volcanic islands in the Caribbean. Over millions of years, they have formed at the seam between two chunks of seafloor, the Caribbean and Atlantic plates. The Atlantic Plate noses beneath the Caribbean Plate at a rate of about three-quarters of an inch per year. The result is several arc-shaped lines of volcanic islands. Saba lies at the northern tip of the currently active arc, which stretches 375 miles from Saba to Grenada. A half-dozen of the islands have erupted in historical time, including a submarine volcano near Grenada with the charming name Kick 'em Jenny. One of these, the 1902 eruption of Mont Pelee on Martinique, killed 28,000 people. From the air, Saba's volcanic nature is immediately obvious: The 1,312-foot runway of the tiny airport is built across a massive tongue of lava lapping the ocean at the northeast corner of the island. The tip of this flow is one of the very few flat places on the island. Take a step in any direction just about anywhere else, and you're getting a free aerobic workout. One hot afternoon we set out for Fort Bay, a small port on the southwest side of the island. Someone had recently bulldozed a rough road along the shore from the port east to a place called Comer Point. We walked the road to Corner Point and started to ascend the slope up to Windwardside, a town 1,800 vertical feet overhead. At first the slope was gentle and grassy but it quickly became a steep, rocky ridge bordered by two deeply incised canyons. We began to enter the kingdom of the infamous Saban goat -- an alien intruder brought here by seafarers of yore. Eroded pathways strewn with dung pellets crisscrossed the ridge, Small groups of goats lazed in the shade of the occasional tree or pile of lava boulders along the ridge. To us, the goats were a welcome sign of life in a hot, gray, dusty landscape. To the Sabans they are an occasional nuisance and a steady source of stew meat. In the backyard of a house overlooking the slope, we saw a deer hanging from the noose of an animal snare. This served as a warning to that other cloven-hoofed offender: Forage in our gardens at your own risk. At the top of the ridge, we stumbled across a dilapidated section of stonepaved footpath leading off into the brush. Before 1964, when the serpentine road bisecting Saba was completed, people hauled all their needs and belongings along these footpaths -- food, pianos, water, stoves, furniture, whatever. The Sabans are resourceful and independent by necessity and are quite proud of their road. It was once declared an impossibility and still referred to as "the road that couldn't be built." But after taking a correspondence course in civil engineering, some Sabans strung their road along the sides of the volcano. It seems to hang on the slopes with only the lowest of curbs between passing cars and 1,000-foot drops into the abyss. Blind corners on the road are not for the faint of heart. When I asked an elderly man, Mr. Lynch, what life was like before the road, he said, "People were stronger in those days." They must have been. Day after day, he said, the settlers carried water in buckets from springs at the base of the sea cliffs for themselves and their animals, until somebody figured out that they could funnel rainwater from their shingled roofs into underground cisterns. The only place where water isn't hard to come by lies above the towns where people actually live, in the tropical rain forest on the peak of Mount Scenery. This particular hike attracts the most tourists. The trip involves walking a steep trail that includes an incredible 1,064 stone steps. The tip-top of the island lies 2,855 feet above sea level. Here, moss wrings moisture from the trade winds, sustaining the dense vegetation. At the very top lies the Elfin Forest, a verdant cap of old-growth rain forest canopy. It is the only part of the island people have never cut or altered. At the edge of the overgrown crater at the top of Mount Scenery, there's a rock where you can sit to catch your breath and bask in the cool trade winds. From this vantage point, gazing out over Windwardside into the blue Caribbean Sea, Saba feels very much like a small rock lost in a big ocean. To learn how to contribute to Shots, send a self-addressed, stamped envelope to Earth Shots, 21027 Crossroads Circle, Waukesha wi 53186-4055. Or fax us at (414) 796-1142. Or e-mail us at mail@earthmag.com. We'll forward guidelines.

Feb 1997 v6 n1 p32(2). 
Title: Ashes, ashes, all fall down. (oceanic volcanoes)(Four Disasters That Shaped the World) 
Author: Daniel Pendick 
Abstract: Sonar and geochemical studies suggest a large portion of the Mauna Loa Volcano slid into the ocean approximately 105,000 years ago. Data from these studies indicate volcanic islands are not created by a single volcano but belong to a cycle of eruption and crumbling. 
Steaming 50 miles off the west coast of Hawaii's Big Island in 1986, the research vessel Farnella methodically sailed back and forth, scanning strip after strip of seafloor with a sonar beam. This monotonous, 24-hour-a-day course prompted shipboard scientists to call it "mowing the lawn." It was a lawn with enough rocks in it, however, to more than ruin any real mower. Peter Lipman, the scientist on board in charge of scrutinizing each day's batch of sonar images, suspected that 15,000 feet below on the seafloor lay the chunky remains of one of the greatest landslides ever. In the early 1960s, researchers poring over Navy seafloor maps had spotted some curious deposits. One of Lipman's colleagues at the U.S. Geological Survey, James Moore, had proposed the rocks had been dumped there by a catastrophic failure of the west flank of Mauna Loa Volcano. Many of his fellow scientists were skeptical. "They were so astoundingly large," Moore says. "Nothing like that had been talked about before." Then, during Lipman's cruise, a technician handed him a stack of four-by-five-inch images made from the digital side-scanning sonar data. One shot caught Lipman's eye: a tiny corner of the speckled toe of the landslide deposit. Instantly, Lipman thought of Mount St. Helens. The debris field was eerily similar to the lumpy avalanche deposits left behind in 1980 after the flank of the infamous Washington State volcano collapsed. "It looked so blatantly like what we saw from Mount St. Helens that we knew instantaneously we had a very catastrophic feature," Lipman says. "Beyond being a scientific curiosity, this becomes one of the most hazardous events known on Earth." And one of the most creative. The discovery of huge landslide deposits off Hawaii, some carpeting the seafloor out to a distance of 150 miles, has begun to change geologists' understanding of how a lot of volcanic islands, not just those in Hawaii, evolve over time. For a long time, geologists believed that such islands came into being as lava gradually accumulated to form large, domelike, "shield" volcanoes on the seafloor. But, says David Clague, a marine geologist at California's Monterey Bay Aquarium Research Institute, "what we have now is a much more catastrophic picture: Hawaiian volcanoes may grow quite large, and then big pieces of them slide into the ocean, and then you rebuild them. It's a more repetitive process of growth and destruction, growth and destruction." Indeed, catastrophic collapses have shaped the face of the planet as surely as a sculptor's chisel transforms a block of marble. "A's near as I can tell, every exposed oceanic shield volcano in any of the oceans has evidence for landslides," says Robin Holcomb, a geologist with the Geological Survey who is producing the first comprehensive map of all the Hawaiian slides. He says some 70 slides have been found in the island chain so far. Moreover, on the Big Island, the clock is ticking toward the next one. Holcomb believes the Hawaiian island of Kauai is made up of at least two and probably three different volcanoes, each with a different plumbing system that channeled magma to the surface from slightly different sources. He expects this to take some of his colleagues by surprise. "Because of the island's nearly circular shape and radial pattern of lava flows, most researchers have assumed that there was only one volcano on Kauai," Holcomb says. More important, he thinks that after each volcano had heaped enough layers of lava on the surface, part of it collapsed into the sea. The next volcano was then built on the ruins of the previous one. Kauai lies at the northwest end of the Hawaiian island chain. Piled on its steep, thickly grown slopes are myriad lava flows from past eruptions. To distinguish the work of one volcano from another, Holcomb had to find a way to sort out one flow from another. Unfortunately, lava flows are not nearly as orderly as, say, the stacked layers of sediment in a place like the Grand Canyon. "Instead of being like a layer cake, they're like spaghetti," Holcomb explains. "They come out one on top of each other, but because they are like long strings of spaghetti you can't trace them laterally very far." Last year, Holcomb and two graduate students at the University of Washington in Seattle, Peter Reiners and Nuni Anders, found a way to untangle the strings. They did a precise study of the chemistry of lava flows on the east and west flanks of Kauai and identified two different types, presumably erupted by different volcanoes. "If the magma were coming up from the same plumbing system at the same time, it should be the same on all flanks," Holcomb says. "And it's not." One of the ancient volcanoes lies west of a trough called Waimea Canyon. Holcomb believes the east flank of this old volcano collapsed into the sea at some point. Then a new volcano emerged to the east, building a new lava shield up against the remnant of the previous volcano. Eventually, the east flank of this volcano collapsed, too. There's even preliminary physical and chemical evidence for a third volcano in the northwest corner of the island. Clague doesn't agree with all Holcomb's interpretations of Kauai, but he says a lot of features of volcanic islands -- from Reunion Island in the Indian Ocean to the Canary Islands in the Atlantic -- now make sense when landslides are taken into account. "It's having more of an impact on understanding ocean islands elsewhere now than it is in Hawaii," he says. With the discovery of undersea landslide deposits off Reunion, for example, it's now clear that the island has seen a history similar to Kauai's, with a young volcanic peak built in the ruins of an older collapse. Back on the Big Island of Hawaii, on the south flank of Kilauea, time is running on toward the next catastrophic collapse. Since a peak in volcanic activity in 1975, the island has quieted down -- so much that the chance of a collapse any time soon is very low, according to Roger Denlinger, a Geological Survey scientists who has studied the hazards at Kilauea for years. But that could change dramatically if the plumbing of Mauna Loa should begin to inflate with magma and cause strong volcanic earthquakes, Denlinger cautions. In 1975, powerful volcanic earthquakes caused a 25-mile-wide chunk of the island beneath Kilauea to move seaward some 30 feet and sink an average of six feet. This, Moore says, was "a little spasmodic jerk, a kind of hiccup." But what made the difference between that hiccup and a massive collapse? According to Lipman, this is the "$64,000 question." And it still doesn't have an answer.

Feb 1997 v6 n1 p28(2). 
Title: Waves of destruction. (tsunamis)(Four Disasters That Shaped the World) 
Author: Daniel Pendick 
Abstract: An undersea volcano created a wave at least 50 feet high that killed approximately 32,000 people on August 27, 1883. Tsunamis may be generated by lava flows that erupt into the sea bed and displace large amounts of water. 
People in Anjer, a port town on the west coast of Java, awoke on August 27, 1883, to the not-so-distant rumbling of Krakatau. The volcanic island lay 25 miles to the west, in the Sunda Straits, the narrow body of water between Sumatra and Java. For tens of thousands of people on the Sunda's prosperous shores, the world was about to end. At 10:02 that morning, a tremendous explosion boomed across the ocean. Thirty-five minutes later, Anjer's telegraph master gazed out over the sea and saw what appeared to be hills of water rolling toward him. He ran madly for high ground. Behind him, he heard the sound of the 50-foot wave swatting down coconut palms and crushing houses like so much kindling. When the waters receded, Anjer was a soggy, muddy ruin. Elsewhere along the coast, tsunamis triggered by the eruptions at Krakatau had attacked without mercy, and at least 32,000 people were killed. Some of the waves are estimated to have reached more than 100 feet in height. Ship captains reported that corpses choked some harbors. The telegraph master was one of the few in Anjer who lived to tell the tale. The eruptions he witnessed forever altered the Sunda Straits, obliterating most of Krakatau and excavating a 860-foot-deep hole in the seafloor. Today, surprisingly, scientists are still debating how the eruptions actually caused the waves. The matter is of more than historical interest. Between 1992 to 1996, 17 tsunami attacks around the Pacific killed about 1,700 people. Tsunami researchers would dearly like to understand the waves' physical processes. "We're looking for better warning that will tell us which areas are most likely to be affected," says Costas Synolakis of the University of Southern California. "I think if we could get the warning time to three minutes we could really save lives." Though scientists haven't quite solved the mystery of the Krakatau tsunamis, they are focusing on three explanations. One is that seawater leaking into the volcano and mixing with molten, gas-charged magma generated underwater explosions, pushing a dome of water upwards. The second holds that when the magma reservoir beneath the island emptied, it sucked a mass of water down, setting the surrounding ocean in motion. And the third is that torrents of ash and pumice, or pyroclastic flows, fell into the sea and shoved water to the side from above, creating killer waves. In a 1995 study at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor, tsunami researchers Kenji Satake and Nazli Nomanbhoy focused on the worst of the tsunami attacks, the one that engulfed Anjer. The researchers inundated Anjer again -- on a computer. They ran simulations of a wave generated by each scenario, basing its size and speed on assumptions about the different water movements in each event. In the computer, the waves smashed against the coast of Java. Nomanbhoy then compared their sizes and arrival times to eyewitness accounts of the real thing. She concluded that the computer tsunami generated by the underwater explosions fit reality better than the other two. The waves from the other models were such a poor fit, she says, that they can be ruled out as physically impossible. But other Krakatau experts prefer to rely directly on geology, not models. According to volcanologist Stephen Self of the University of Hawaii in Honolulu, what happened to the water around Krakatau is best determined by looking at the physical evidence on the seafloor around the island's blasted remnant. In 1990, two of his colleagues, Haraldur Sigurdsson and Steven Carey, made the first direct examination of the ash and debris fields around Krakatau. This evidence points not to underwater explosions at all, but to waves created by the pyroclastic flows. Sigurdsson and Carey strapped on scuba tanks and dove to the floor of the Sunda Straits 65 times, drilling out samples along the way. Everywhere they looked, they found only one thing: pyroclastic flow deposits, made up of ash and pumice rock. "These flows have velocities in excess of 100 miles per hour, and the mass is just enormous. There's no way you can get those things in the water without generating enormous waves," Carey says. The researchers couldn't find any examples of the type of debris that would be produced by undersea explosions -- a rocky mixture blasted from the foundation of the island. "So far, none of that stuff has been seen," says Sigurdsson. As scientists struggle to understand what happened at Krakatau and how tsunamis begin, other researchers are focusing on how killer waves end up: crashing into coastlines. Amidst the interaction of the dark walls of water and the coastline, they wonder, what makes the difference between a tsunami that gently inundates a town like a very high tide and a high-speed wave that bulldozes a town flat? A team of scientists and students led by Synolakis has picked through the wreckage of nine tsunami attacks in the Pacific since 1992, gathering physical evidence and eyewitness reports on the sometimes bizarre and unexpected behavior of the waves. Back at the lab, Synolakis and his student, Vasily Titov, try to get their computer models to reproduce the same effects seen in the field. These "run-up" models calculate the height and speed of a wave once it reaches shallow water and washes onto the shore. In practical terms, run-up models can tell people how far the will have to run to escape a tsunami. Synolakis says one of the most important lessons from this work is that tsunami hazards can vary tremendously from place to place on a coastline. Case in point: During a 1995 tsunami attack in Mexico, the wave hit two neighboring villages. At both locations, the maximum run-up of the water was about 12 feet. But although the villages are only a mile apart, "the destruction was so different that it was just amazing," Titov recalls. In one village, Boca de Iguanos, stone walls were knocked from their foundations. But in the neighboring town, La Manzanilla, the water just slowly rose and receded, causing minimal damage. Titov's current modeling work points to a possible explanation: a 50-foot-deep canyon in the harbor, pointing straight at La Manzanilia. Like a mountain biker bogging down in a patch of deep sand, the tsunami may have lost most of its forward momentum in that canyon. Synolakis and Titov hope their modeling ability will mature to the point where they can issue very specific warnings within minutes of the birth of a tsunami on the ocean, informing people which areas will inundated by the coming waves. And Sigurdsson and Carey will return this year to Krakatau and use special bottom-penetrating sonar to peel away the layers of ash and history beneath the Sunda Straits. Taken together, scientists hope, all this information may give more people like the Anjer telegraph master a running chance.

August 1997 v6 n4 p76(4). 
Title: On the volcano trail. (Kilauea, Hawaii Volcanoes National Park)(includes travel information) 
Author: Jacqueline Wiora Sletto 
Abstract: Kilauea, located in Hawaii Volcanoes National Park on Hawaii Island, has erupted 4 times since 1900. Volcanic eruptions have caused the area of Hawaii Island to increase by more than 300 acres since 1983. The floor of Kilauea is 2.5 miles long and 2 miles wide. 
Subjects: Kilauea - Description and travel Hawaii Volcanoes National Park, 
On the flank of the world's most active volcano, we stood transfixed, watching glowing fingers of lava creep relentlessly over the cliffs and into the sea. They writhed and curled, sometimes surging ahead, sometimes nearly stopping. When one finger touched the ocean, a towering plume of steam shot into the sky, adding a gigantic whoosh to the constant sizzling roar that accompanied this elemental meeting of fire and water. This was genesis in all its raw power and glory. We had come to Hawaii's Big Island, my husband and I, to see creation -- to see where volcanoes had formed, developed, and died and to see an island grow. Since the latest eruptions began in 1983 alone, the island has increased by over 300 acres. So the chance to see one of these live eruptions was one compelling reason to visit Hawaii Volcanoes National Park, but we also hoped to see life returning to a blasted landscape. Today's target was Kilauea, which has erupted 49 times since 1900. To tour the volcano, we took the popular 11-mile Crater Rim Drive, which loops around the Kilauea summit. Just inside the entrance to the park, we stopped at the visitors center to get the latest scoop on the current eruption and guides to sights in the park -- the first for us being the Sulphur Banks. These are deposits that have accumulated in brilliant yellow layers around solfataras, vents in the lava that allow groundwater, heated to steam and mixed with volcanic gases, to escape from deep in earth. The raw smell of rotten eggs hangs in the air, and on a cool, humid day, the steam almost obscures the hillside. Fumaroles, vents that release pure steam with no volcanic gases, are also common in the park. This is true especially at Kilauea's primary pit crater, Halemaumau, which we would visit later. But first we stopped at the observatory, where volcanologists keep a careful watch on eruptions. It's offlimits to the public, but from the viewing platform we studied Kilauea's floor, a huge caldera 2.5 miles long, 2 miles wide, and 400 feet deep. It formed when a large well of underground magma drained away from under the summit, causing the mountain to collapse. We also had a good view of Halemaumau, which lies in the caldera and is believed to be the home of Pele, goddess of fire, according to early Hawaiians. They would pray to her and leave offerings to placate her unpredictable wrath. Even today some people bring gifts, but out of reverence rather than fear, throwing them into Halemaumau after a brief prayer or occasionally leaving them on the rim of the crater. For nearly 100 years, a lava lake roiled in Halemaumau. It was continuously in motion, rising and falling sometimes several hundred feet a day, with molten material surging against the crater walls, fountains spouting 30 feet high, and sulfurous fumes shrouding the crater. This drama was caused by a semi-solid plug of lava in the main conduit that brings the molten rock to Kilauea. Liquid lava continued to surge from below through cracks in the plug and formed a pool 50 feet deep. Both the plug and the liquid lava would move up and down the conduit, with the fluid rising and sinking more quickly so that the plug emerged through it, like an island in a lake of fire. When the liquid drained totally, the glowing plug rested on the crater floor. Then, in 1924, steam explosions ripped open the floor of the crater: Groundwater had come in contact with the lava, turning to steam and building to explosive pressure. Today Halemaumau is quiet except for the lone seabird riding the heated air above the crater and the occasional puff of steam rising from the surface. On the southwest side of the crater, we followed the drive through cooled lava flows from years of eruptions. Here, we stopped along the road and compared the types of lava thrown off by volcano. The more common ones are aa, a rough jumbled lava with a dense interior, and pahoehoe, a smooth or ropey lava. Less common are Pele's tears, Pele's hair, cinders, and spatter. The tears are hardened droplets formed when lava fragments get thrown into the air and cool during flight. Pele's hair is volcanic glass spun out by the wind, forming strands strongly resembling human hair (early Hawaiians regarded these as proof of Pele's existence). Cinders are spongy-looking chunks of lava about the size of a pea, and spatter is a dense lava that flattens when it hits the ground. As we neared the place where the road dips into the caldera and we could sidle up close to Halemaumau, we skirted the edge of Kau Desert, a desolate place on the southern slope of the volcano. It receives 30 to 50 inches of rain a year, more than enough to remain green, yet it is a blasted landscape of scrubby plants eking out a living in the shelter of lava boulders. The cause of the desolation is the rain itself, which carries massive amounts of acid from the summit of Kilauea. Every day the volcano releases 300 tons of sulphur dioxide into the atmosphere, and because of prevailing wind patterns, most of this ends up mixing with the rain that falls on the Kau region. It is a sobering lesson on the effects of acid rain. On the outer slope of the volcano we saw huge gashes in the land. This was the southwest rift zone, a zone of weakness where flank eruptions most often occur. It runs along the volcano from the summit to the coastline and sometimes under the ocean. Huge fissures can be up to 6 feet wide and a mile long, the result of ground movement when magma close to the surface drains out of the area. When we descended to the crater floor, we walked the 3.2-mile trail around Halemaumau; it took us past shards of lava from 40 years of explosions and eruptions. We saw still-active vents, which reminded us that Halemaumau could at any time be the site of Kilauea's next eruption. At Devastation Trail, our next stop, we paused at a cinder cone called Puu Puai, created in 1959 when a lava fountain surged out of a vent in Kilauea's side and threw up cinder bits that fell steadily around the vent, eventually forming the cone. The area has earned the right to the name "Devastation." Puu Puai lies in a shattered landscape littered with cinder and spatter. More than 30 years have passed since this lava smothered a thriving forest here, and plants have now begun to move back in. Some of them are older species that arrived on the islands' shores centuries ago and adapted to this stressed environment -- species such as ohia lahua trees, amau ferns, and sword ferns. Others are exotics brought in during the last 100 years, which often push out native species. It's not clear yet which will prevail. All along the trail, we kept an eye out for local fauna of the avian type: The nene, Hawaii's rare goose and state bird, waddles around these trails, searching for the juicy, bright red berry of the native ohelo bush. Once 25,000 nene roamed Maui and the Big Island, but now their future is questionable -- only 500 remain, most within the park. Humans hunted them nearly to extinction early in the century, and feral cats and mongooses have picked up where humans left off. The Thurston Lava Tube was our last stop on Crater Rim Drive itself. It is a remnant of a channeled pahoehoe lava flow that formed when the outer lava cooled, creating a tube enclosing the still-molten lava river. Lava can travel great distances inside a tube before cooling completely and halting. Once the flow has stopped, the lava inside the tube drains away, leaving a cavelike formation. Most lava tubes are simple vaults, but the Thurston Lava Tube is a huge tunnel rivaling those found in major caves. Leaving Crater Rim Drive behind, we turned onto Chain of Craters Road, descending the eastern slope of the volcano to the Pacific. Along the road we spotted kipukas, islands of rain forest surrounded by lava, left behind when the molten river inexplicably forked and flowed around them. Kipukas provide the seeds of life to recolonize the lava fields and shelter the animal species that will, in time, follow the plants onto the lava. Approaching the sea, we saw a magnificent series of cliffs, or pall, like a giant's staircase leading down to the shimmering Pacific. These form when the ground drops along fault lines or settles along the coast. When enough land drops away, several feet might be added suddenly to a cliff's height. The pall are a dramatic backdrop for the lava flows that pour steadily into the sea when Kilauea is in a gentle eruption phase. Hot lava and icy water produce spectacular explosions, so it's foolhardy to stand close to the point where lava enters the water. Yet standing back is not always easy at a lava flow. The heat and fumes inspired us to take precautions, but the flow was so mesmerizing we wanted to inch closer. At night, it's even more primordial; the hellish glow of the molten rock lights up the jet-black Hawaiian sky and splatters the sea with jewels of fire. When walking back to the car later that evening, we carried the memory of creation. RELATED ARTICLE: GETTING THERE FLIGHTS. Inter-island planes fly into both Kona and Hilo, 30 miles from Kilauea. Flights from the mainland land in Kona, which is about 100 miles from Kilauea. ACCOMMODATIONS. The Hawaii Visitors Bureau (808-961-5797) will gives tips on lodgings, restaurants, car rental, and more. Or leave a message at 800-648-2441; someone from the bureau will mail information, including the names of companies that provide motor tours for visitors who are unable to hike around the park. Be sure to call at least two weeks ahead of arrival time. Once on the island, check the Yellow Pages of the phone book; this is an often-overlooked TOURING. For information on Hawaii Volcanoes National Park, call 808-985-6000.

April 1997 v6 n2 p42(8). 
Title: Loihi rumbles to life. (Hawaiian undersea volcano) 
Author: Noreen Parks 
Abstract: The 1996 rumblings of the Hawaiian undersea volcano called Loihi allowed scientists a unique opportunity to study this phenomenon. Despite the earthquakes and the partial destruction of its summit, scientists are unable to prove the volcano actually erupted. 
Somewhere beneath the waters southeast of Hawaii, the ground was shaking. In mid-July 1996, seismometers at the Hawaii Volcano Observatory began to register a furious series of tremors from the region. Fred Duennebier, a seismologist from the University of Hawaii at Manoa, suspected that Loihi, a submarine volcano 21 miles from Hawaii Island, was erupting. And he knew this was a tremendous opportunity: He and his colleagues could be the first people to see an undersea volcano in action. Their research ship, Ka'imikai O Kanaloa (Hawaiian for "investigator god of the sea"), reached the area over Loihi in early August. Deep-sea earthquakes boomed through the ship's hull. Sonobuoys (underwater microphones) lowered into the water carried a steady stream of ominous cracks, bangs, crashes and shudders back to radio receivers on board. A speaker in the ship's lab broadcast the incessant din. "It was very nerve-racking," recalls geochemist Frank Sansone of the University of Hawaii at Manoa. "It sounded like all hell was breaking loose under the ship." It was. Duennebier, Sansone and other scientists who descended to Loihi's inky depths over the next couple of months found a transformed landscape. The summit of the volcano was "a physical wreck," one researcher said. Loihi's hydrothermal vents -- places where streams of heated seawater flow out of the volcano's interior -- had undergone drastic "replumbing." And a remarkably rich layer of bacterial life was thriving around the vents. Most astonishing of all, part of Loihi's peak was somehow, mysteriously, gone. As researchers struggle to solve this puzzle, some of the pieces seem to challenge conventional ideas about how undersea volcanoes erupt. Scientists have been intensely studying Loihi ("long, tall one" in Hawaiian) for a decade. The volcano stands 9,000 feet tall with its peak more than 3,000 feet beneath the water. During the past 10 years that we've been studying it, Loihi has been quiet," says Alexander Malahoff, director of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's Hawaii Undersea Research Lab. "We thought it was a gentle volcano. " The young volcano will emerge someday as the next island in the Hawaiian chain, so scientists have been watching it closely, hoping to glean clues into the processes that presumably created a string of 125 volcanic islands and under mountains that run several thousand miles north-northwest from Hawaii. Geologists do have a general idea of the processes shaped the chain of islands. A plume of hot rock -- the Hawaiian "hot spot" -- rises from Earth's mantle deep beneath Hawaii Island, often called the Big Island. Scientists believe that during the last 80 million years, as the plate of crust forming the Pacific seafloor crept across this hot spot, magma punched through the crust's surface, slowly building mountains from the seafloor to the air. With Loihi's recent rumblings, scientists got the chance to observe the immediate aftermath of a major event in the submarine stage of that mountain-making process. The burst of seismic activity began on July 16. On July 20 "the volcano started going wild," says Duennebier. "There were more than 40 quakes during one six-hour period." Seismometers recorded over 4,300 earthquakes in July and August - the largest swarm ever recorded on a Hawaiian volcano. Clearly, something major was happening. Duennebier realized that to capture details of the geological event scientists had to get to Loihi quickly. "After seismic and volcanic activity stops, things change very rapidly," says Duennebier, "and many of the effects will just go away." Thunderous landslides of rock loosened by earthquakes could smother fresh regions of lava, for example. Duennebier swiftly contacted a dozen colleagues at Manoa to join in a "rapid response" research cruise, and on August 7 the scientists found themselves rocking in the waters above Loihi. The Ka'imikai cruised back and forth over the volcano, mapping the summit with sonar. Something was missing. For as long as researchers have been diving down to Loihi, the summit had been marked by a football field-sized area of hydrothermal vents called Pele's Vents, named after the Hawaiian goddess of volcanoes. Pele's Vents was a broad expanse of mineralized "chimneys" and shimmering streams of hydrothermal fluids. Such vents form when magma heats up the water percolating through a volcanic edifice. The hot water dissolves minerals and metals from rock inside the volcano and carries them out to the surface through holes. On the Ka'imikai's sonar images, Pele's Vents were nowhere to be seen. A deep depression seemed to mark the old position of the familiar landmark. Duennebier refused to believe it at first. "I said, look we've just made a mistake in navigation -- we'll cross the summit again. So we did, and it was still gone. And we crossed it again, and it was still gone. It was a real shocker." By the second day of the cruise the earthquakes had tapered off, and the crew launched the submersible Pisces V. Duennebier and Sansone dove with veteran submersible pilot Terry Kerby to the near-freezing darkness 3,200 feet below the surface. They approached the volcano's summit after a half-hour descent. Peering through the sub's tiny windows, the researchers confirmed what the ship's sonar had suggested. Pisces Peak -- previously the highest point on the volcano -- was almost completely obliterated. The submersible followed a line of cliffs east of the devastated peak where Pele's Vents once shimmered. Duennebier and Sansone found themselves looking over the edge of a cavernous hole instead of the peak and vents. Dubbed Pele's Pit, the hole measures almost 2,000 feet across and perhaps 800 feet deep and lies just west of two craters already at the summit. David Clague, former chief scientist at the volcano observatory and now director of research and development at Monterey Bay Aquarium Research Institute, estimated the new crater's volume at well over a million cubic yards. "That's close to the total amount of material that has been erupting annually from Kilauea volcano [on the Big Island during the last several years," he notes. The crater was one of many changes at Loihi's surface. Researchers descended to Loihi a dozen times in the months following last summer's seismic shakeup, and every dive turned up something new. Malahoff discovered precariously balanced boulders the size of buses strewn across a four- to five-square-mile area at the summit. And Sansone found new vents. Though Pele's Vents had vanished, others had opened up elsewhere. "Everywhere we looked we were finding hydrothermal vents," says Sansone. "We visited areas where vents had gone extinct, and there they were, alive again. This says to me that the recent seismic events really have shaken up the plumbing." In hydrothermal fluids collected last summer, Sansone found signs that magma suddenly moved out of a deep chamber inside the volcano. Rapid movements of magma can generate hydrothermal fluids with extremely high concentrations of methane, carbon dioxide and hydrogen sulfide - and that's exactly what Sansone discovered in his samples. Sharply elevated water temperatures also implicated a plumbing shake-up. Loihi's hydrothermal circulation apparently went into overdrive last summer, and the temperature of the fluids streaming from its vents reached about 180 degrees Fahrenheit -- double the previous record. This even affected the surrounding ocean. "The temperature of the water column above Loihi is usually a few hundredths, or at most tenths, of a degree warmer than the surrounding seawater," explains Sansone. "The fact that it was several degrees higher, despite the enormous cooling capacity of the ocean, certainly indicates there was a tremendous amount of heat being pumped out." All that heat and the gasified fluids nourished a surge of new life. When hydrothermal fluids flow out into cold, oxygenated seawater, a host of chemical reactions takes place, producing chemicals such as hydrogen sulfide and iron compounds. Bacteria live off these substances, forming colonies in the shape of spongy, stringy mats. Researchers have often seen bacterial mats on Loihi, but last summer, bacterial growth was surprisingly lush. "In places, the mats have dancing streamers several inches long flowing in the water, and it almost looks like they're on fire. It's really quite beautiful," says Craig Moyer, a microbial geneticist at Michigan State University. The bacteria were not only striking in appearance but astonishingly prolific as well. When the scientists vacuum-cleaned patches of rock using a suction sampler on the sub's robotic arm, they found fresh bacterial growth smothering the patches a few days later. These dramatic transformations left scientists with a big question: What happened on the inside of Loihi to force these changes on the outside? Scientists agree that magma must have drained from somewhere beneath the summit, collapsing Pele's Vents and most of Pisces Peak and leaving a huge crater in their place. It's still not clear, however, where that magma went. It either erupted somewhere on Loihi's surface, or it may have shifted around deep inside the volcano, pushing into cracks inside the flanks. Duennebier thinks that an eruption occurred and that it took place on the north end of the summit. "It's hard to imagine what all that noise was on the sonobuoys if not an eruption," he contends. Water chemistry measurements also suggested an eruption. Researchers found a plume of particularly warm water containing suspended rock dust flowing from the north end of Loihi's summit. What they didn't find was an eruption site. Dust limited visibility in some places to less than three feet. And since physical evidence of an eruption could have been anywhere on Loihi's huge surface, Duennebier argues, it's not surprising that no submersible dives disclosed an eruption site. Loihi measures eight miles by 16 miles, and an eight-hour dive inside Pisces V may carry scientists one or two miles at best. Visibility is never much better than 50 feet. Moreover, an eruption could have occurred below the submersible's depth limit of 6,000 feet. "It was kind of like looking for a dime with a flashlight on a dark football field," says Duennebier. But there's a chance that a dime might not even exist. Earthquake data do not support the idea that an eruption wreaked havoc at the summit. Earthquakes often signal magma movements that precede an eruption of lava, and knowing earthquake locations can help scientists pinpoint eruption sites. The seismic waves produced by the shocks indicate that Loihi's summer earthquakes occurred far below the volcano, six to seven miles deep, and not at Pele's Pit or anywhere else on the summit. At this point, seismologists can conclude only that magma at that depth shifted considerably. Rocks collected from Loihi add to the confusion. Using the submersible's robotic arm, Duennebier collected black glassy rocks that look like they came from an explosion. But scientists didn't think that explosive eruptions could happen under the crushing pressures at Loihi's depths. Rocks collected from past trips to Loihi show that during most eruptions on the young volcano, lava has oozed out slowly -- like toothpaste from a tube -- forming lobes of "pillow" lava. It's also odd that Duennebier picked up the rocks from the west side of Loihi's summit: July's sonobuoy recordings pointed to the north side of the summit as the most tumultuous area last summer. It's possible that the rocks are remnants of some past explosion having no connection to this summer's rumblings. But Michael Garcia, a petrochemist at the University of Hawaii at Manoa, is dubious. He has scrutinized many of the rocks collected from Loihi over the years. Garcia says he's never seen anything like the samples from the west side. The strong chemicals in the hydrothermal fluids around Loihi tend to dull or discolor lava rock quickly after it is erupted, Garcia says. "These samples show no alterations -- they're absolutely pristine," he says. Garcia's studies suggest that the rocks originated from material stored in a magma chamber six miles deep. Magma could have flowed up from that depth and perhaps sat in a more shallow location before being ejected in a recent explosion. Garcia admits it is conceivable that the volcano spit out those rocks before last summer's seismic activity. He hopes to pinpoint the ages of the rocks with a new dating technique that relies on radioactive polonium. Researchers discovered additional mysterious rocks on Loihi's southern flan-k. Clague found fragile needles of rock called Pele's hair, for example. Pele's hair - formed when lava is ejected rapidly through the water and stretched -- hints that a surprisingly explosive eruption took place. "I don't know how you'd do this at water depths of more than a kilometer," Clague muses. The strange collection of rocks from Loihi implies that some sort of explosive eruption actually can occur at depths like Loihi's. "It's telling us something about the style of eruptions at this volcanic stage, and we just have to learn more about it," says Clague. While the Loihi explorers puzzle over the geological processes that shake the deep-sea volcano, they are also strengthening their appreciation for the volcano's possible links with global processes. John Lupton of the National Oceanographic and Atmospheric Administration's Pacific Marine Environmental Laboratory has direct evidence of Loihi's potentially far-reaching influence on the oceans. Even before Loihi's season of change, Lupton found a plume of helium in the deep waters of the North Pacific that bore Loihi's signature. Water from Loihi's vents contains a distinctive mixture of helium isotopes -- versions of the element that differ from each other only in atomic weight. Researchers can use that unique mixture to track water from Loihi's vents. Helium with Loihi's signature appeared in extremely high concentrations in Hawaiian waters, but Lupton could still detect it 3,000 miles away, near coastal Mexico. Deep ocean currents presumably transported the volcano's fluids across that vast distance. If helium could travel that far, so might other chemicals, such as iron. Iron is an essential nutrient for phytoplankton -- microscopic ocean plants that form the base of many oceanic food chains -- and some scientists have suggested that the ocean's supply of this key element may limit plant growth. Loihi's hydrothermal fluids contain 20,000 times more iron than normal seawater does, so the underwater volcano could significantly affect iron's flow through the oceans. "Anyone trying to figure out how iron and a number of other chemical elements cycle through the oceans has to consider the significance of hydrothermal systems," Sansone explains. Along with helium-laden water and rocks, the latest explorations on Hawaii's "long, tall" underwater volcano have pulled many questions from Loihi's depths. "We're learning a lot," Garcia says. "Our old prejudices about how things work, which perhaps we gained by looking at processes on land, may not be all that reliable underwater. It's a story that's still evolving."

Source: Earth, April 1997 v6 n2 p15(1). 
Title: Earth Chronicles. (significant geological events in the November 13, 1996 to January 14, 1997 period) 
Abstract: Global geological events occurring between Nov. 13, 1996 and Jan. 14, 1997 are described. These include earthquakes, volcano eruptions, mud or landslides, avalanches, snow, and freezing weather conditions. Mary Leakey's death in Dec 1996 is also noted. 
This dateline covers the period from November 13, 1996, to January 14, 1997. It includes all reported earthquakes of magnitude 6.4 and higher. November 14 -- Torrential rains cause a landslide in the Makaha Valley on the island of Oahu, Hawaii. Two people are reported missing. November 19 -- Spokane, Washington, experiences one of the worst ice storms in its recorded history, enduring power outages that leave parts of the town without electricity for three days. November 19 -- Heavy rains cause mudslides in Oregon, killing 4 people; a snowstorm in the Cascade Mountains leads to 1 death. November 19 -- A magnitude 7.1 earthquake shakes a remote region of the Karakoram Range of eastern Kashmir. November 21 -- Hurricane Marco pounds Nicaragua with heavy rains that wash away homes and leave 2 people dead. November 21 -- Me-Akan Volcano in Hokkaido, Japan, erupts for the first time since 1988, causing minor ash falls. November 26 -- Snowstorms and icy weather throughout Texas and across the Midwestern United States cause at least 19 deaths. November 30 -- Near the Japanese island of Kyushu, a 6.6-magnitude earthquake creates a minor tsunami that hits the southeast coast. November 30 -- Earthquake swarms intensify under Soufriere Hills Volcano in Montserrat, West Indies, collapsing part of the crater wall. December 3 -- Manam Volcano, on Port Moresby Island, Papua New Guinea, erupts violently. The village of Buduwa, which was relocated after a volcanic eruption in 1957, is destroyed again. Seventeen people are injured and at least 2 people are killed. December 6 -- Rain and snow in Otari, Japan, cause a mudslide along the banks of the Kamaharasawa River, killing 14 construction workers. December 9 -- Mary Leakey dies at age 83. Leakey made significant archaeological and anthropological discoveries indicating that humans evolved in East Africa earlier than once believed. December 9 -- Atmospheric scientist William Gray, the world's leading expert on hurricanes, predicts that 11 named hurricanes will develop in the Atlantic Ocean in 1997. December 11 -- Pavlof Volcano, on the Alaskan Peninsula, sends ash up 17,000 feet, continuing the eruptive series that began September 15. December 16 -- In the backcountry of Canada's Garibaldi Provincial Park in British Columbia, an avalanche kills three German tourists skiing the Phalanx Glacier. December 23 -- An avalanche in the Cascade Mountains in Washington claims the lives of 2 teenage hikers. December 23 -- Nine feet of snow buries parts of the Sierra Nevada, knocking out power and shutting down highways. December 25 -- Tropical storm Greg rips through Malaysia, claiming at least 111 lives. January 2 -- Powerful storms hammer the northwestern United States, causing the worst flooding in Reno, Nevada, in 40 years and forcing thousands of people to evacuate their homes. January 7 -- Rushing floodwaters capsize a bus in Rabat, Morocco, and claim more than 20 lives. January 8 -- For at least two weeks, freezing weather grips Europe from Scandinavia to the Mediterranean, leading to nearly 250 deaths. January 11 -- A magnitude 6.8 earthquake rocks Michoacan, Mexico. January 14 -- Heavy snow contributes to 14 deaths in the northeast mountains of China's Xinjiang region.
