Dec 1997 v6 n6 p32(8). 
Title: Chasing the volcano.(geological discovery of the world's largest volcanic crater) 
Author: Peter Lipman 
Abstract: A geologist describes the procedure by which the La Garita volcanic depression became to be recognized as the largest in the world. The discovery led to a remapping of the San Juan Mountains. The huge La Garita volcano is capable of an output that dwarfs eruptions of modern times. 
The outrageous idea came to me while I was eating lunch. I was on a rocky ledge in the La Garita Mountains in southwestern Colorado, munching on a salami and cheese sandwich on a summer afternoon in 1969. I was also worrying about work. The U.S. Geological Survey had sent my boss, Tom Steven, and me here to spend a few months appraising the mineral potential of the peaks in this region. Things were not going well. Tom and I had been mapping thick layers of solidified ash, but the rocks seemed to be speaking to us in a language that we didn't understand. Trying to figure out which rocks came from where in any region is a messy job, because the rock record is full of gaps that need to be bridged and irrelevant details that need to be ignored. To work effectively, geologists need some kind of conceptual framework to tell them what they can safely overlook and what to look for next. So while they try to piece together the big story of the rocks, geologists tell themselves smaller, provisional stories -- working hypotheses about what their observations might ultimately mean. Unfortunately, a good working hypothesis for La Garita was just what we lacked. We knew that the area, along with other nearby parts of the San Juan Mountains, was strewn with the cores of ancient volcanoes. Four of them lay within thirty miles of us, recognizable by the masses of volcanic rock, thousands of feet thick, that they had left behind. We also knew that the mountains were littered with much thinner sheets of volcanic ash. But which sheet had come from which volcano? Which sheets had come from the same explosions, and in what order? Nobody could say. Geologists before us had tried to sort the ash beds into older and younger layers, assigning them to different volcanoes, but teams working in different areas had come up with conflicting results. Tom and I joked that if you traced an ash bed from exposure to exposure in a huge circle through the San Juan Mountains, you would wind up two layers above the one you started in. We called it "San Juan spiral stratigraphy." Now Tom had gone away for the Fourth of July weekend. Except for a few cows grazing in the distance, I seemed to be alone in the mountains. As I gazed across the vast flower-filled grassy meadows of Saguache Park to the treeless mountain ridges above, some of them still white with patches of snow, I started to make up a story about the rocks. Twenty-five miles to the south, across the La Garita Mountains, lay the Creede mining district, which Tom had mapped years earlier. The ash layers there looked different from the ones we were working in, but one layer in each area contained an unusual assortment of minerals, including green bladed hornblende -- a peculiarity the layers shared with as many as six previously identified kinds of ash in the vast San Juan region, among them the enigmatic thick brown rock that made up the La Garita mountains themselves. What if all the hornblende-rich ash layers came, not from several volcanic eruptions, but from one enormous blast? It might explain the common mineral patterns. And I could be sitting inside the biggest volcano ever discovered! Almost thirty years later, my wild idea is accepted fact. La Garita was made by one of the largest volcanic eruptions, if not the largest, ever. The twenty-eight-million-year-old explosion that created the collapsed crater, or caldera, must have been more than a thousand times the size of the 1991 eruption of Mount Pinatubo in the Philippines and ten thousand times the size of the 1980 eruption of Mount St. Helens. It took us decades of careful work, matching up many different kinds of evidence, to come to these rather remarkable conclusions. INCONCEIVABLY BIG Tom Steven and I were not the first mappers to be stymied by the rocks in the San Juan Mountains. In the 1910s and 1920s, field geologists found that the region was blanketed with enormous sheets of a pale gray to brown volcanic rock called rhyolite, some of them stretching for a hundred miles or more. Laboratory geologists scoffed. Their experiments had shown that molten rhyolite lava is too thick to ooze more than a few miles from its source vent. There couldn't possibly have been enough volcanoes around the flood the west with rhyolite. The deadlock lasted until the 1950s, when geologists realized most of the rhyolite hadn't come from lava flows at all. It was welded tuff -- solidified volcanic ash -- which exploded out of volcanic vents tens of millions of years ago and avalanched across the countryside at speeds as high as seventy-five miles per hour and temperatures of 1,300 to 1,500 degrees Fahrenheit. Tuff starts out full of gas bubbles and other spaces, but as it piles up it flattens and flows under its own weight, kneading itself into a wadded-up mass of ash and pumice fragments that can be a dead ringer for solidified lava. Soon after learning what the rock was, geologists started to uncover where it had come from. By the early 1960s they had begun to recognize the broad features of a few prehistoric craters and ash flows in the Rocky Mountains, such as the 1.1-million-year-old Valles caldera near Los Alamos in northern New Mexico; Tom, in fact, had discovered a 26.5-million-year-old caldera, the Creede, in the San Juan Mountains. The eroded volcanic cores gave volcanologists a natural laboratory for studying what goes on in the depths of active volcanoes, places where no human being can go. The Colorado volcanoes, however, were to modern volcanoes what the Great Pyramid of Giza is to a pup tent. At the time of their discovery they were among the largest volcanoes recognized on Earth. Their craters, as much as twelve miles across, testified to eruptions incomprehensibly grander and more violent than anything human beings have ever witnessed. For field geologists, those ancient volcanoes were also damnably difficult to map. After the last one went extinct about twenty-five million years ago, streams and glaciers carved the landscape into canyons and mountains that bear little relation to the original volcanic surfaces. As a result, deciphering the history of old volcanoes is like putting together a jigsaw puzzle without a cover picture to guide you and with many pieces lost -- through erosion of the original rocks, burial beneath younger geologic deposits, the camouflage of lush mountain vegetation, and the veiling haze of geologic time. In understanding the volcanic features and the eruptions that caused them, aerial photographs and even satellite images are little help. Geologists must go into the field and map the preserved remnants of those eruptions one by one -- a hard, time-consuming, often frustrating process. Tom had tasted some of that frustration in 1962, when a spend a long summer trying to fathom the rocks of the La Garita Mountains. The rocks themselves were easy enough to identify; the problem was that there were too many of them, and they were all the same. To discover how big the La Garita caldera was, Tom needed to find its margin -- some change in the rock that would show where the inside of the former crater left off and the wall began. In the La Garita Mountains, however, the entire range is all of a piece: one huge block of welded tuff. There seemed to be no end to it. As I munched my sandwich on the Fourth of July of 1969, I finally had an explanation for Tom's frustration. The reason he couldn't find the edge of the caldera was that he was nowhere near it. My new picture of La Garita seemed to fit the facts perfectly. As far as I could tell, there were only two things wrong with it. First, the caldera would have to be almost inconceivably big. And second, many crucial things geologists knew about the San Juan Mountains would have to be wrong. That included Tom Steven and me. Tom took the news well. He didn't mind that my picture of La Garita's history contradicted some of his own theories. Instead, he enthusiastically suggested ways of testing it. It all boiled down to answering a few key questions: Was it physically possible for all the distinctive hornblende-bearing tuff sheets in the San Juan region to have been a single sheet? Were they the right age to have been blasted out in a single massive eruption? Just how big was the La Garita caldera, and where were its boundaries? We started by singling out places where earlier mappers might have made mistakes. The first site we re-examined lay in the canyon of the Rio Grande, between South Fork and Creede. Within a few hours we knew we were on the right track. The rocks there changed abruptly across a side valley. Earlier mappers had decided that the layers of tuff must have slid apart along a complex series of now-hidden faults. We saw a much simpler picture: the rock changed because the valley marked the eroded remnants of the La Garita caldera wall. Near the river lay a shattered block of the hornblende-bearing welded tuff almost half a mile across. Clearly it had skidded from the caldera rim partway down the wall, where it had been covered by younger tuff sheets that flooded the interior of the volcanic depression. It was all so obvious, now that we what to look for. Within a few weeks, we were well on our way to redrawing the geologic map of the San Juan Mountains. Previously, geologists thought the San Juan calderas had collapsed almost as soon as they started erupting, trapping and thickly ponding all the erupting tuff inside them. We soon proved that each caldera was surrounded by its own sheet of outflow tuff, commonly about a hundred feet thick and stretching as much as seventy-five miles beyond the caldera rim. Similar outflow deposits have since been found in most major ash-flow eruptions throughout the world. The biggest outflow sheet in the San Juans belonged to the tremendous La Garita volcano itself. Of more than twenty previously identified "different" tuff sheets ringing the La Garita Mountains, six turned out to be the same material. All of them contained the same telltale set of chemicals and minerals, and radioactive dating showed they were the same age, about 27.8 million years old. Later the various tuff sheets were renamed Fish Canyon Tuff, after an outflow sheet ten miles northwest of Saguache Park. By the end of the summer, we had blocked out the shape of the La Garita caldera as an elliptical volcanic depression twenty by thirty miles across. Our mental picture of the area now looked something like this: On the outskirts of La Garita lay patches of Fish Canyon Tuff, scattered erosional remnants of a single sheet of outflow tuff. In the middle, at ground zero, rose the La Garita mountains themselves -- those peculiarly thick blocks of welded tuff that had so maddened Tom only a few years before. Now they didn't look maddening at all. They, too, turned out to be made of Fish Canyon Tuff. It was harder, denser, browner than the other rocks with the same name, but that was only because it had piled up miles deep and been slow-roasted inside the immense caldera of La Garita volcano. Twenty-seven and a half million years ago, after the big eruption, the ash compacted, cooled, and turned to rock. The center of the volcano caved in, forming a caldera. In time the volcano, too, cooled and went extinct. On its massive flanks, younger volcanoes -- smaller than La Garita but still enormous -- erupted and collapsed, erupted and collapsed, leaving behind more calderas that now dot the central San Juan Mountains. Faults and fractures opened by the eruptions later filled with the billion-dollar silver-lead-zinc ores of the Creede mining district, now the standard textbook example of volcano-related vein deposits. When those younger volcanoes collapsed, they took much of the La Garita caldera with them. The southern edge of the caldera in particular seemed to have vanished. We assumed that it was now somewhere beneath Creede, buried under thousands of feet of younger volcanic ash from the Creede caldera. SHRAPNEL FROM THE EXPLOSION Our 1969 story of the La Garita caldera and the Fish Canyon Tuff held up well for almost twenty-five years. In that time the San Juan volcanic field became a world-famous example of large-scale continental volcanic activity associated with important ore deposits. Five international conferences and field workshops were held there in the 1980s. Meanwhile, my research took me far afield, to active volcanoes in Hawaii and at Mount St Helens, and to the deeply eroded roots of ancient volcanoes in New Mexico, Arizona, Utah, and Russia. It was almost twenty years before I returned to La Garita. I went back in 1986 as the head of a geologic team laying the groundwork for a scientific drilling project to study how metallic minerals such as silver form in volcanic settings such as the Creede district. Volcanologists had neglected the area since Tom had worked there thirty years earlier. Now, with new scientific techniques and concepts at our disposal, my co-workers and I could see things in the old volcanic rocks that nobody had noticed before. One important discovery was additional segments of the La Garita caldera wall. We found them while revisiting some large volcanic deposits that Tom and I had mapped as lava flows and welded tuffs on the flanks of the volcano. Now, looking more closely at those rocks, I saw that they were ponded against steep slopes that had formed when the Fish Canyon Tuff erupted. In other words, the tuff had piled up not on the shallow sides of the volcano, but inside its very rim. That discovery showed that the northern and western margins of the La Garita caldera lay miles farther out than anyone had thought. La Garita was growing again. From 1990 to 1994, my research was interrupted while I managed the USGS Volcano Hazards Program. In the summer of 1995, however, I was back at La Garita, with the Swiss volcanologist Michael Dungan, of the University of Geneva, and his student Olivier Bachmann. This time the story of La Garita took an even stranger twist. While out in the field, we stumbled onto something that made us completely overhaul our mental maps of the caldera. Not only was the caldera even bigger than we had thought, but its shape was different, too -- in a way that we never would have predicted and are still trying to explain. We started out near Wolf Creek Pass, where Dungan and Bachmann were studying some bizarre rocks I had noticed long before in roadcuts along Highway 160. The rocks had perplexed me for years. They were obvious cousins of the Fish Canyon Tuff but looked unlike anything I had ever seen or heard of, like a weird hybrid of volcanic ash and lava. Instead of containing the pumice typical of explosive eruptions, they contained flattened blobs of what seemed to be solidified dense magma. After mapping a continuous body of the lava-like rocks for more than ten miles, Bachmann and I backpacked into the rugged Weminuche Wilderness south of Creede to see where these mysterious rocks came to an end. And there, above the tree line, in superb glacially scoured exposures, we ran into the familiar gray features of the Fish Canyon Tuff. Years earlier, Tom had reported that there was tuff in the area, but his sketchy geologic map didn't prepare us for what now loomed before us. We were expecting to see a thin veneer of outflow tuff. As far as we were concerned, the thick, dense tuff of the La Garita caldera ended miles behind us, across the Continental Divide. Yet here it was again, more than two thousand feet thick, with no sign of a bottom. It would have looked right at home in the La Garita Mountains. There was no question about it: that rock, and we, were still inside the caldera. After a few hours of searching, we found the caldera wall -- twenty miles south of where it was supposed to be. On our mental maps, the La Garita caldera had now become a twenty-by-fifty mile oval. And that takes some explaining, because most calderas are nearly round. We think that the enormous explosion that created La Garita must have started out in the southern part of the area and, over a few days or weeks, migrated progressively northward. As the center of the eruptive fury shifted, three sections of the volcano, each more or less round and about twenty miles across, collapsed one after another and in different ways. The result was an oval-shaped caldera, bounded on the south by the early lava-like rocks and filled with tuff that included the entire uplifted block of the La Garita Mountains. The more we thought about those odd-looking lava-like rocks, the more important they seemed. If our interpretation was correct, they were the earliest traces of the La Garita eruption. In fact, they appeared to have been erupted before the main explosion and, in a way we could not quite fathom, might even have caused it. A lot hinged on finding out how closely they were related to the rocks in the core of the caldera. Dungan, Bachmann, and I wanted to compare the composition of rocks from the two areas. The volcano's core lay in the what are now the La Garita Mountains. We didn't have samples from that area, but in the USGS archives I found microscope slides of some samples of Fish Canyon Tuff that Tom had collected in the heart of the mountains thirty-five years before. When I studied them, the composition of the caldera rock turned out to be the same as that of the lava-like rock, with one surprising difference: the tuff in Tom's samples was strewn with small rock fragments, less than a tenth of an inch across. The fragments were made of the same minerals as the tuff but differently arranged in interlocking crystals. They were granite. Neither I nor any of my volcanologic colleagues had ever seen anything like them in a volcanic tuff. Between the large crystals were intergrowths of what geologists call graphic granite, wedge-shaped blades that resemble the cuneiform writing of ancient Babylonians. Tuff forms suddenly, in a rain of exploded rock. Granite forms crystal by crystal, in slowly cooling molten rock deep in the crust. The distinctive texture of graphic granite comes about in exactly one way, by rapid crystallization in pools of magma at most a mile or two beneath the surface. We believe the rock fragments in Tom's samples are blown-apart material from the very walls of the subsurface storage reservoirs for the Fish Canyon eruption, caught at the moment of solidifying into granite. Seven years before anyone dreamed there had been a La Garita explosion, Tom had carried home shrapnel from the bomb that set it off. SNAPSHOTS AND SECRETS In combination, the odd lava-like rocks and the flecks of Fish Canyon granite give us snapshots of the magma body at the moment of eruption and at its end. They show that the magma body was spectacularly uniform in composition, despite its huge size. The minerals are beautifully fresh and unaltered, a sign that the rock must have been ripped off the miles-deep magma chamber and rocketed to the surface before they had a chance to react with chemicals in the magma. In laboratory simulations, minerals in magma undergo detectable reactions after only a week or two. That suggests that the eruption of the entire 1,200 cubic miles of Fish Canyon magma, and with it the formation of the La Garita caldera, must have taken a few weeks at most. How did the volcano generate that much magma? How did so much of it accumulate in the crust without triggering an earlier eruption? We are still trying to answer those questions. There are many other things still to be learned about La Garita. Was the magma mostly made of melted crust, or did most of it come from deeper in the earth? How could a volcano erupt so much material with so little variation in composition? Why did different parts of the caldera behave so differently? If the eruption of the lava-like rocks really did trigger the big La Garita explosion, how did they erupt? It may take many years to find good answers to those questions. Some of them I may have to leave to other geologists. A geologist's career lasts only a few decades, and the mountains seem to be getting steeper every year. I have been lucky to see La Garita surrender some of its secrets during my lifetime, but often, while walking down a mountain trail after a strenuous day of fieldwork, I wonder how much more there is to learn and what key pieces of the puzzle we may have missed.

April 1998 v7 n2 p24(8). 
Title: Cooking up a volcano. (researcher and volcanologist John Holloway; includes related articles) 
Author: Michael Milstein 
Abstract: Holloway at the Univ of Arizona, is experimenting with exploding liquid rock in a model volcano to learn how to predict eruptions. How the model volcano works, is discussed. In 1993, an Arizona colleague had his legs crushed, and six people died, when a Colombian volcano erupted. The work of others is discussed. 
With home-brewed lava and fumes, geochemist John Holloway is recreating the deadly recipe that makes liquid rock explode. Diamonds, diamonds, diamonds. John Holloway has a machine that, when it's not working right, makes diamonds. What a pain. "When we're trying to do science, diamonds just get in the way," says Holloway, a geochemist at Arizona State University in Tempe. He is sitting sideways in his office chair, his sandaled feet hanging over one armrest, his tropical shirt ablaze with southwestern color. Overhead, a mobile of the solar system bobs lightly in the air-conditioned breeze. "It's funny. Diamonds are really just a distraction for us." To understand why, you have to walk down several flights of stairs in the squared-off, dowdy building that forms part of Arizona State's physical science complex. There, screwed to the basement door, is an official-looking plastic sign: DEPTHS OF THE EARTH, INC. Beyond the door lies a chamber in which Holloway and his students take rocks, cut them down to the size of marbles, and put them into devices that heat and squeeze them to the temperatures and pressures that the rocks once experienced deep underground. By thrusting rocks back into the inferno of their birth and growth, Holloway opens portals on the chemical and physical processes that drive the planet's insides -- that build mountains, recycle continents, and fuel volcanoes. He swears it's only coincidence that his laboratory resides in a basement. Unfortunately, when Holloway's rocks return to their hellish roots, the equipment that sends them there goes with them. Under the intense pressure, the white-hot graphite rods in the electric heaters tend to recrystallize into microscopic industrial-grade diamonds. That's bad, because the rods must conduct electricity, and diamonds don't. To Holloway, these diamonds are a nuisance. For thirty-five years he has been pursuing something much more elusive: details of the interplay between gases and rocks that determines how rock will melt into magma, where that magma will flow, and precisely when water trapped in rising magma will build unstoppable heads of steam that blow the tops off volcanoes. He does that by building small-scale models -- physical, working models -- of places and processes no flesh-and-blood scientist can ever observe in person. By mimicking volcanoes in the laboratory, for example, Holloway and his colleagues are figuring out how to translate the belches of real volcanoes into warnings of coming violence. And recently Holloway has stepped beyond volcanoes to undertake an even more ambitious project: an imitation deep-ocean hot spring that may help scientists decide whether its ancient real-world counterparts gave birth to life itself. "We do this to understand processes that we really can only dream of seeing or measuring in real life," Holloway says. "The next best thing is simply to replicate them ourselves in an environment where we can see and measure them." In an era of computer models, hands-on science like Holloway's seems almost quaint. Yet experimentalists say the work they do is as crucial as ever. Number crunchers, after all, need numbers, and when direct measurements can't supply them, laboratory models often can. They may be detailed enough to zoom in on individual molecules (see "Smash It with Diamonds," page 28) or broad enough to simulate entire ecosystems (see "Breaking Up the Biosphere," page 31). "Computer models are only as good as the data on which they are based," says Jennifer Blank, a chemist researching high pressure at the University of California in Berkeley. "There's something romantic about actually developing experiments to get that data, which is not available anywhere else." DEADLY PRESSURE Holloway, a fairly low-key individual, nonetheless likes a high-pressure environment. His lab harnesses some impressively muscular equipment. The senior citizen of the place is Big Bertha, a 1960s-vintage vessel about the size and shape of a waist-high stack of paint cans, standing next to a plywood control panel that looks as if it was built by Captain Nemo on a budget. Water-cooled and driven by compressed argon gas, Big Bertha squeezes rock samples at pressures up to 145,000 pounds per square inch. That's about ten thousand times sea-level atmospheric pressure -- roughly what your toes would experience if a Boeing-747 rolled across your foot. Another device nearby goes even further, Using an eighteen-inch diameter hydraulic piston like those in truck jacks, it applies pressures of close to 250,000 atmospheres. Ordinary jacks don't wield such strength; the trick is to focus its force down to one small point, just as the head of a hammer concentrates the force of your swinging arm. In Holloway's machine the "hammerhead" resembles a Chinese puzzle, a complicated, interlocking Rubik's Cube screwed into the jaw of the jack. It is made of glimmering tungsten carbide, the strongest substance next to diamond. In its center lies about one cubic centimeter (six hundredths of a cubic inch) of the rock under scrutiny, encased in a capsule of nonreactive platinum or gold. Using this technique, Holloway and his colleagues have matched the pressures of rock about four hundred miles below Earth's surface, deep within the mantle and dozens of times times deeper than the deepest drillhole. At higher pressures, even everlasting tungsten carbide begins to give. By ratcheting down the jack to the highest pressures, Holloway can keep even very hot rock compressed into a solid. But if the pressure then eases -- as it would when heated mantle rock rises upward and outward -- the rock melts into a more plastic fluid, laboratory magma, of the type that eventually finds its way out of Earth as either lava or other volcanic handicrafts. Long before he thought of building a volcano, Holloway used this pressure-drop technique to study gases trapped in magma. Volcanic magma is charged with dissolved gases such as carbon dioxide, sulfur dioxide, and water vapor. As the magma rises into the volcano, the plunging pressure lets the gases come out of solution and coalesce into bubbles -- just as carbon dioxide does when you pop the top of a soda bottle. In a volcano, the mounting gases can cause explosions with deadly consequences. Volcanologists had long hoped that they could use the gases coming out of volcanic vents, or fumaroles, as a barometer of a volcano's changing moods. In all but a few volcanoes, the gas that actually blows the magma apart is water vapor. The first gas that bubbles up out of magma, however, is carbon dioxide. In the 1980s, Holloway and colleagues at the California Institute of Technology discovered that carbon dioxide starts to fizz when rising magma is about three miles underground -- almost two miles deeper than the level at which water vapor starts to escape. Maybe, they mused, fizzing carbon dioxide could serve as an early warning that dangerous water vapor explosions were in the offing. By tracking the changing levels of different volcanic gases, scientists might be able to gauge a magma's explosive potential -- or even predict when a volcano was about to blow. Holloway was soon to get a somber lesson in how urgent such a warning could be. In. January 1993, his Arizona State colleague Stanley Williams was leading a team of volcanologists studying Galeras Volcano in Colombia. The volcano had been quiet for months. But suddenly, just as the scientists ventured into the crater, it erupted. Fiery rocks hurtled through the air, killing six scientists and three tourists and crushing Williams's legs. (See "Dr. Williams vs. the Volcano," August 1995.) Reviewing the disaster, Williams and his graduate student Tobias Fischer discovered that there had been warning signs of an eruption, but that the scientists had misread them. In the months before Galeras exploded, for example, sulfur dioxide gas had surged from the volcano and then dropped off again. Williams and his colleagues had assumed the volcano had cooled off, in fact, it had come to a quiet boil. Hardening magma had choked off escape routes for the gas, causing the pressure to build and build until it blew. CANNED HEAT Holloway was stunned by the disaster. How could a team of experts have been caught so completely off guard? There must have been other clues; years of experience with magma told him so. But that was experience in the lab; Holloway himself had never studied an active volcano. A year later, when Williams mounted a return expedition to Galeras Volcano, Holloway decided to go along. On the flight to Colombia, Holloway and Fischer had a long talk about the Galeras disaster. In principle, the two men agreed, the chemistry of the gases pouring out of Galeras could have revealed everything that was going on inside the volcano: how much pressure the magma was under, how fast it was cooling and rising, how agitated it was, even when the magma started hardening enough to plug up outlets. But in practice, Fischer said, nobody knew how to interpret the signs. A large part of the problem was that the source of a volcano's gases, the magma chamber, is inaccessible. Scientists usually have to take gas samples from tens or even hundreds of feet above the magma. By the time the fiercely reactive volcanic gases reached the sampling tubes, they might have transformed themselves into a drastically different mix of chemicals. To translate the samples back into the original gases, volcanologists needed to be able to study the gases in the laboratory. Someone really ought to build a model volcanic vent -- an artificial fumarole. Hey, the two thought: let's build a fumarole. And as soon as they got back to Arizona, they set about doing just that. The first prototype, a twelve-dollar pressure cooker from the local Target discount store, was quickly replaced by a much more elaborate system so tall that Holloway and Fischer had to cut a hole in the basement ceiling. (The university quickly offered them a lab on the top floor.) The fumarole resembles an Erector Set skyscraper with a central chimney swaddled in insulation to keep the heat in. The scientists inject simulated volcanic gases through pipes at the base of the chimney. Meanwhile, an industrial-strength pressure cooker sends steam through a heat-resistant quartz tube that brings it to about 1,300 degrees Fahrenheit. The superheated steam and gases shoot up the chimney, through exit ducts, and past a series of sensors that measure how the mixture of gases changes in transit. By studying enough gas mixtures under enough different conditions, the researchers should get a much clearer picture of how the gases pouring out of a real volcano reflect what is going on inside. Eventually, gas-chemistry profiles may prove more accurate than familiar seismic rumblings at telling scientists what volcanoes are up to. As a step toward that goal, next summer Holloway, Williams, and their students will travel to Mount Vesuvius in Italy to measure gases coming out of the volcano and study the chemistry of surface rocks made of cooled-off magma. Then they will try to recreate the readings using the mock fumarole. If all goes well, the results will give them a clear picture of what is happening inside the volcano. RECIPE FOR LIFE? Meanwhile, Holloway's volcanic leanings are also taking him in a different direction: underwater -- in fact, to the bottom of the sea. The idea came to him two years ago at a meeting of the American Geophysical Union in San Francisco. Scientists at the meeting were abuzz with the idea that life may have begun in hot volcanic environments, which were much more common on early Earth than they are now. (See "Life's Crucible," February 1998.) One key piece of evidence is that the most primitive organisms known, bacteria called thermophiles, thrive in the scalding heat of geysers and undersea hot springs. Earlier in Earth's history, similar primordial incubators would have offered water, energy, and perhaps a safe refuge from the meteors that bombarded newly minted Earth. In modern oceans, dissolved minerals emerging from the seafloor vents solidify into towering "black smokers," which are quickly colonized by chains of life feeding off chemicals rising from the deep. Some scientists think such life-giving volcanic vents might dot the ocean beneath the icy surface of Jupiter's moon Europa. Others believe something similar may exist beneath the surface of Mars. The problem with all those ideas, Holloway realized, was that nobody knew whether vents really are capable of brewing up the chemical hallmarks of life -- chemicals such as amino acids, the steps in the spiral staircases of DNA. Other laboratories had coaxed amino acids out of various recipes for "primordial soup," but as far as Holloway could tell, nobody had tested what happens when superheated water swirls out of the ocean bottom into the frigid, saline environment of the open sea. Studies of modem vents can't settle the question; it's difficult to look for primordial amino acids when organisms full of amino acids are running all over the place. "The problem with looking at the vents now is that all these creatures living there now are mucking up the system," Holloway says. "You've got to have them out of the way before you can look at the basic chemistry of what's going on there -- whether all the ingredients are there." One night at the meeting, Holloway was drinking wine and excitedly discussing these ideas with his friend John Delaney, an oceanographer and early-life researcher at the University of Washington. "So," Delaney remembers asking him, "are you just going to melt rocks until you die?" Instead of replying, Holloway picked up his conference program and sketched out plans for a model deep-sea vent. By the time the conference wrapped up (and after continued prodding from Delaney), he had decided to build it. Holloway's hot vent stands across the room from his fumarole. Like the faux volcano, it is built around a souped-up pressure cooker, which heats seawater to about 750 degrees Fahrenheit -- so hot that it would vaporize if it weren't under pressure. The water rises through a simulated seafloor, a corrosion-resistant titanium cylinder filled with chunks of basalt that Delaney's research subs have plucked off the real seafloor. Then it streams through a pinhole-sized opening -- the vent -- at about a foot per second, a typical speed for true seafloor flows, and winds up in a tank of cool seawater. It was a challenge to find seawater in Tempe, which lies in the middle of the desert, but Holloway solved that problem with a mix for saltwater aquariums. For the model's maiden run, Holloway cranked the vent up and left it overnight. The next morning, the inlet pressure had shot off the dial. The vent was plugged. But that was a good thing, Holloway explains. It meant that the basalt was dissolving in the hot seawater, yielding a chemical plume that might hold within it the ingredients for the recipe of life. It was also behaving as nature behaves: unpredictably, which may be the true mark of a realistic experiment. Now Holloway has the model running again. Inside the seawater tank around the pinhole, a tiny black smoker is growing, made of silica, quartz, and pyrite -- just like the real thing. The gases coming out of the model are right, too: the rotten-egg odor of hydrogen sulfide fills the lab. The next step, a big one, is to test the water in the tank for chemical harbingers of life. Using a gas chromatograph, Holloway's team has found encouraging traces of what "pretty much has to be a volatile organic compound," but identifying it will be a painstaking, time-consuming business. For all the time and care that goes into them, Holloway's experimental models will never be anything more than models. "We're not under any illusion that we can reinvent the world in a laboratory," Holloway says. "But if we're careful and if we're thoughtful and patient, maybe we can poke our nose into one little comer of it. The more you learn, the more you come to respect the real thing." RELATED ARTICLE: Smash It with Diamonds John Holloway isn't the only scientist building models of things too hot to handle in real life. There are others using the tabletop model approach to investigate incredible forces brought to bear on molecules that may have started life on Earth -- forces generated by a deep-sea geyser or perhaps the impact of a comet. Jennifer Blank, an experimental geochemist at the University of California in Berkeley, spends her days torture-testing organic chemicals like the ones that, billions of years ago, must have come together to carry out the mechanics of the earliest living things. That's important because some scientists think life may have started in the extreme heat and pressure of hot water vents in the deep sea. Others, however, have questioned whether anything alive could hang together in such natural broilers. To find out, Blank takes a drop of water containing organic molecules such as pyruvic acid, a chemical critical to the metabolic processes of life, and puts it into a cell, or chamber, in a vise made of two diamonds. Then she then tightens the diamonds down like bookends. Molybdenum wires as thin as dental floss coil around each diamond and, when electrified, heat the diamond cell to hundreds of degrees. To gauge the pressure inside the cell, Blank trains special light meters on tiny rubies suspended in the water. Then she zaps the rubies with an argon laser, which makes them fluoresce. (See "That Inner Glow,") The higher the pressure, the more energy the rubies emit. Heat tends to break organic molecules apart. But Blank has learned that high pressure can put them back together again. She has found that some molecules shatter, but then, in a sort of molecular evolution, recombine into other larger and more complex molecules. Now Blank is working with geophysicist Gregory Miller to simulate even more extreme conditions: those wrought by the colossal impacts of ancient comets. If organic molecules didn't come out of the sea, some researchers suspect they arrived here as passengers on these giant balls of ice. According to some calculations, a comet crash would generate temperatures of thousands of degrees. Could organic molecules survive? Or perhaps the temperatures aren't so high after all. The pair plans to create artificial comets -- snowballs laced with organic chemicals -- and shoot them with a special gun Miller maintains in the subbasement of his building at the University of Chicago. The gun, forty feet long and just over three inches in diameter, is usually used to blast rock samples up to temperatures and pressures found in Earth's mantle, hundreds of miles underground. Miller and Blank plan to fire a metal plate at their makeshift comets and see whether any organic chemicals survive. They have begun test-firing the gun at mock-up comets. Their biggest challenge now is to build a sealed shell for the high-impact snowballs that won't rupture when struck by a flat-nosed bullet going five thousand miles per hour. RELATED ARTICLE: Breaking Up the Biosphere First the tropical birds -- emerald-throated hummingbirds and blue finches -- began dying. All seven species of frogs disappeared. Tropical forests declined. The coral reef started to dissolve. Greenhouse gases rose out of control. The most ambitious environmental modeling experiment ever attempted was in trouble. The place was Biosphere 2, intended to be a self-sustaining, glass-enclosed, three-acre model of Earth constructed by Texas billion-aire Edward Bass for somewhere around $200 million in the Arizona desert north of Tucson in 1990. While experimentalists like John Holloway study regions of the planet by modeling their components, the people behind Biosphere 2 planned to do the opposite: investigate the pieces by building a simplified whole. Unfortunately, it wasn't long before the pieces began falling apart. Overseers abandoned the project's lofty aims of self-sufficiency when they installed (secretly at first) scrubbers to remove the greenhouse gas carbon dioxide. They also injected fresh air to rejuvenate the initial team of "Biospherians" who had become light-headed when oxygen thinned to concentrations found at an altitude of 17,500 feet. A scientific advisory panel then broke up, and Bass fired top managers for financial mismanagement. Engineering an ecosytem, it now seems clear, is much more difficult than it looked. New Biosphere 2 has a new lease on life. In 1996 Bass agreed to pay Columbia University's Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory $50 million over five years to run the structure that Columbia's press releases now refer to not as an artificial ecosytem, but as a "research apparatus." Columbia has backed away from Biosphere 2's miniature rain forest, desert, and ocean and has instead parceled parts of the giant terrarium into bays where student and faculty researchers can gauge the effect of greenhouse gases in living, though managed, environments. Meanwhile, the species extinctions, failing environments, and skewed mix of atmospheric gases that doomed the original goals of Biosphere 2 appear to be showing up on "Biosphere 1" -- Earth itself. In a darkly ironic way, the great experiment in the Arizona desert might turn out to have been a successful model, after all.

June 1998 v7 n3 p38(6). 
Title: Exploded mountain: Alaska's Aniakchak caldera is remote, sometimes violent - and beautiful. 
Author: Bill Sherwonit 
Abstract: A description of the Aniakchak caldera in Alaska is presented. The caldera was created 3,500 years ago when a volcano exploded and collapsed on itself. What makes this caldera so unique is that as a result of erosion it lacks ice, water and vegetation. 
Alaska's Aniakchak caldera is remote, sometimes violent--and beautiful. Bleak and blasted. It's hard to think of other words, looking out the window of a small plane flying over the mountain boundary surrounding the Aniakchak caldera. The peaks wall off Aniakchak from the green tundra that covers much of the Alaska Peninsula. The first glimpse of the caldera reveals a black, brown, and gray otherworld of cinder cones, lava flows, and explosion pits. It seems lifeless. Appearances, however, can deceive. Once on the ground inside this six-mile-wide crater, visitors are rewarded with belts of color and life, formed of scattered grasses and wildflowers. During the short, two-month Aniakchak summer, crimson rhododendrons, purple lupine, yellow arctic poppies, bluebells, and pink fireweed stubbornly hug the ground against the persistent winds that sweep across the caldera's width. Tucked into its northeast corner, algae-rich Surprise Lake harbors trout and a seasonal run of sockeye salmon. Terns and gulls nest in the lush marshes at both ends of the two-and-a-half-mile-long turquoise-colored lake. Brown bears feed on the salmon in late summer and early fall. An occasional caribou roams the crater's expansive flatlands, and bald eagles roost on the caldera's rim. One rarely seen species is Homo sapiens. The caldera, the standout feature of the 580,000-acre Aniakchak National Monument and Preserve, is some 425 difficult miles southwest of Anchorage. Fewer than twenty people a year camp inside it, drawn by a harsh yet beautiful landscape and the power of a once-awesome volcano. Although dormant since 1931, the caldera is part of the Pacific's "rim of fire." It was created about 3,500 years ago after a volcanic mountain, possibly 7,000 feet high, exploded and then collapsed on itself, forming the bowl-like caldera. Aniakchak is different from most other calderas -- Oregon's Crater Lake comes quickly to mind -- because its features aren't covered by ice, water, or vegetation. Erosion long ago worried a notch into the caldera's rim that allowed water to drain away; today, the Aruakchak River runs through the notch on its way to the Pacific. An estimated three to seven cubic miles of gas-rich molten rock and ash spewed out of the ground in just over four days from a magma chamber located close to the surface. The eruption was far larger than that of Mount St. Helens, says Tom Miller of the U.S. Geological Survey's Alaska Volcano Observatory; that volcano sent out less than a cubic mile of the hot stuff in 1980. Roaring down the mountain at speeds up to one hundred miles per hour, Aniakchak's molten flood wiped out everything in its path for a distance of thirty-five miles, while its cloud of ash and gases covered an area of more than 2,500 miles. "Undoubtedly, ash from the eruption circled the globe," says Miller. "We've traced deposits almost to the North Slope," some nine hundred miles away. More than twenty major eruptions have occurred since that first monster explosion. One of the caldera's principal features, 3,300-foot-tall Vent Mountain, is a spatter cone that formed by "blobs of molten material spitting out" during one of these eruptions, Miller says. Explosion pits, hardened lava flows, and cinder cones reveal other major volcanic episodes. The last blast, in 1931, deposited ash on villages forty-five miles away and left a five-mile-wide mass of pumice floating in Bristol Bay, fifty miles north of the volcano. Today, Aniakchak's remaining rim rises 3,300 feet above the crater floor. Evidence of current geothermal activity includes the hot, mineral-rich springs near Surprise Lake, which bubble out of the ground at a scalding 185 degrees Fahrenheit. Near the 1931 blast site, ground temperatures still approach 175 degrees. Indeed, Jesuit priest and geologist Bernard Hubbard described the caldera as a "valley of death" after exploring the area a month after that blast. But in the sixty-six years since the explosion, the scorched earth has slowly undergone a transformation by a stubborn array of plant and animal life. Nearly 500 species of plants have repopulated the caldera, including some 250 species of mosses and lichens. It isn't just Aniakchak's remote location that keeps people from witnessing life's resurgence. It's the weather. The Alaska Peninsula is prone to violent storms. Surging out of the southeast across the Bering Sea, rain-soaked clouds slam against the caldera's walls, sweep up the side, then cascade down the interior face; park rangers call it the "Niagara effect." They warn that Aniakchak can have violent winds and heavy rams even when the weather outside the caldera is relatively calm. Linda Hasselbach, a botanist who has studied the crater's botanical diversity, knows Aniakchak's violent nature firsthand. During a ten-week stay one summer, she and her colleagues were buffeted by four major storms. They were pelted by three inches of rain and seventy-mile-per-hour winds that shredded their supposedly rugged mountaineering tents. "It was frightening," she recalls, "but also wonderful to experience the caldera's different moods." That kind of experience, say the hardy few who visit, is worth the trip inside the rim.

A to Z of volcanoes
Hot-tempered and unpredictable, volcanoes can be dangerously fascinating. Sarah Barnett reveals what's bubbling away beneath the Earth's fragile crust, just waiting for a chance to escape.
A is for ash
The 1,000°C lava is not necessarily the most dangerous thing associated with a volcano. One of the most disruptive aspects of any eruption is volcanic ash, which can be carried on the wind for thousands of kilometres. It poses a major problem for aircraft, because the ash rapidly clogs their engines. Dozens of planes have suffered damage or even crashed after flying into eruption columns. Apart from the problems of inhalation, accumulation on buildings, water contamination, destruction of crops and damage to power lines, ash can linger in the Earth's atmosphere and have a long-term influence on the global climate.
B is for bombs
Volcanic bombs are clots of lava ejected from a volcanic vent which then solidify in flight. " Sometimes measuring several metres across, they can take various shapes, including spindles (formed as they spin and cool in mid-air),
fine ribbons, or even cow pats.
C is for cryovolcanism. 
It's hard to imagine cold volcanoes but, on some bodies in the outer Solar System, icy eruptions are, or have been, the norm. Images sent back to Earth from the Voyager and Galileo probes have revealed smooth surface textures on moons such as Enceladus (Saturn) and Europa (Jupiter) that could only have been caused by volcanism. On such cold worlds, ice and slush would have been erupted, not lava.
D is for the Deccan Traps
The Deccan plateau in India covers 250,000 square kilometres and is a 65 million-year-old reminder of one of the most devastating eruptions ever. The basalt rock that covers it is the result of an eruption of extremely fluid and mobile lava from fissures in the planet's crust, called a flood basalt. The Deccan Traps would certainly have had a big impact on the Earth's climate, possibly contributing to the demise of the dinosaurs.
E is for eruptions
Eruptions are rated in order of explosivity, and are named after typical volcanoes: Hawaiian-type eruptions are characterised by very fluid lava; Strombolian ones are more gaseous; Vulcanien eruptions are viscous with large amounts of ash; the most feared are Plinian-viscous and gas-rich, ejecting a huge amount of pyroclastic material.
F is for fumaroles 
These are vents in the crater or on the flanks of a volcano, which emit hot gases. Caused by magma heating groundwater, their temperature can reach 1,000°C. Volcanologists sometimes take samples of fumarole gases, as the detection of a decrease in sulphur can be an early warning sign that an eruption is imminent.
H is for hot spots
Hot spots are plumes of ultra-hot material in the mantle, from where magma flows into the crust. The motion of a tectonic plate over a static hot spot forms a chain of volcanoes, such as Hawaii or the Canaries. Volcanoes form as the plate passes over a hot spot and become inactive once it's clear of it.
I is for Io
Io, one of Jupiter's largest moons, is the most volcanically active object in the Solar System. The huge tidal forces between this moon and its planet result in an ever changing landscape blanketed by eruptions. Io, which is roughly the size of our moon, bas around 300 volcanoes, some of which spew sulphurous lava to a height of nearly 300km.
J is for jokulhlaup
This Icelandic word means `glacier-burst' and is the result of a volcanic eruption beneath an ice-cap that lies in a crater. The result of such huge heat breaking up the ice causes a colossal deluge of water. When Katla volcano erupted in Iceland in 1918, the flooding had a peak of about 100,000 cubic metres per second. That's about the same rate of discharge measured at the mouth of the River Amazon.
G is for the Giant's Causeway
Giant's Causeway Northern Ireland's most spectacular tourist attraction is a prime example of 'columnar jointing' of a basalt lava flow. The mostly hexagonal columns were formed when lava erupted about 60 million years ego; it cooled, contracted and fractured. Around 37,000 columns extend from the cliffs of the North Antrim coast to the sea. But if you prefer to believe the legend, they were laid by the warrior giant Finn MacCool as a path to his lover, who lived on the Scottish Island of Staffa.
K is for Krakatau 
The tiny Indonesian Island of Krakatau was in one of the great sea lanes of the 19th century (the Sunda Straits between Java and Sumatra) and many a sailor passer] it by without much interest. But in 1883 it became much better known, when a series of huge explosions of the, island's volcanoes sent vast columns of ash into the sky, blocking out the sun for nearly two days. About two thirds of the Island collapsed into the sea, generating tsunami (tidal waves) that devastated the shores of Java and Sumatra, resulting in a death toll of 36,000.
L is for lava
To most it's just molten rock but lava comes in many consistencies and compositions. Lavas range from those poor in silica (which are called basalts)to those rich in silica (rhyolites) with several phases in between. Two of the most common kinds of basaltic lava have the Hawaiian names AA and pahoehoe. The former is a jumble of loose irregular cindery blocks: the latter is smooth, ropy and resembles cow pats.
M is for magma
Magma is the name for molten rock below the Earth's surface, before it erupts as lava. Magma is generated deep within the Earth's trust (or upper mantle) and tan pool to form an underground reservoir inside the trust, which may become a magma chamber beneath the throat of a volcano. The build up of pressure and gases in the magma chamber results in an eruption.
N is for nuée ardentes
When a volcano collapses explosively, it may cause a nuée ardente. This turbulent, incandescent gaseous cloud consists of a pyroclastic flow and ash. A notable example took place at Mt Peleé, on Martinique, in 1902. The 200-450°C flow raced along at 500km/h, killing nearly 30,000 people.
Q is for Olympus Mons
Towering 24km above the surface of Mars, this is the largest volcano in the solar system. It stretches 600km across. But unlike Earth, Mars has no plate tectonics so its lava built up on the same static spot, during the course of aeons. Olympus Mons has lain dormant for 500 million years.
is for plate tectonics The Earth's lithosphere (crust and upper mantle) is made up of several plates, which interact with each other. Volcanoes occur at subduction zones, where one plate plunges beneath another causing heat and friction, and at constructive margins, where the plates move apart and new crust forms
Q is for quakes
Earthquakes generally take place in the same tectonically active areas as volcanoes. When magma moves closer to the surface beneath a volcano, the surrounding rocks are put under strain and fractures occur. This, in turn, is what leads to tremors.
R is for Ruiz
The eruption of Nevado del Ruiz in Colombia, in 1985, illustrates how a Jack of monitoring and poor evacuation can lead to loss of life. The eruption was small and didn't kill anyone but disaster came when molten rock melted the ice cap and caused mudflows, which wiped out 23,000 people.
T is for Tambora
The largest eruption on record took place in 1815, when the top blew off Tambora in Indonesia, spewing out 50 cubic km of pyroclastic material. The peak collapsed to form a 7km crater and 92,000 people died.
U is for Unzen
Unzen volcano, in Japan, first made history in 1792, when the collapse of its dome resulted in tsunami that bit the shores of Japanese provinces killing around 14,500 people. It sprung back to life in 1991, when block and ash flows hurtled from the summit and 10,000 people had to be evacuated from the vicinity. This time, 42 people were killed, including several over-curious journalists.
V is for Vesuvius
Images of cowering bodies immortalised in stone make the eruption of Vesuvius in 79AD one of the most famous events in history. Pompeii, about 9km south of the volcano, was a bustling town with a population of 20,000. But disaster struck when Vesuvius unleashed clouds of ash, followed by pyroclastic surges (incandescent clouds of pumice and dust that race along the surface at up to 100km/h), which swept through the town. Pompeii was destroyed and nearby Herculaneum suffered a similar fate.
S is for St Helens In May 1980, Mount St Helens, in Washington State, US, decided to blow its top - big lime. After erupting a huge column of ash, steam and pumice, which developed into a mushroom cloud 70km across, the northern flank of the mountain was blasted off. unleashing pyroclastic flows and mudflows as ice melted. The eruption destroyed 250 homes, 300 km of roads and devastated large areas of forest. On a more positive note, there were few casualties in the sparsely populated area and the region has become a living laboratory for ecologists studying nature's remarkable recovery since the eruption.
W is for warning signs 
Although volcanoes remain fairly unpredictable, scientists can use various measures to help foresee an eruption. These Include monitoring earthquakes, which can become more prolonged in the run-up to an eruption, and measuring ground deformation around the volcano.
X is for xenolith
These chunks of mantle rocks can be brought to the surface via volcanic eruptions. Often sold in new-age shops, they are rich in green olivine and its gem-quality equivalent, peridot. Xenoliths can tell us the composition of the Earth's upper mantle.
Y is for Yellowstone
Famous to most as a breathtaking national park in Wyoming, US, Yellowstone is a huge caldera, 70 km across. It is the most powerful volcano ever to erupt on Earth: 600,000 years ago it spewed out 1,000 cubic km of material. And it's not extinct.
Z is for Zambales
This mountain range in the Philippines is home to Pinatubo, which gave vent to the third largest eruption of the 20th century on 15 June 1991. Ash rose 30 km into the air, and about 500 died, many due to it falling on homes which caused the roofs to cave in. The eruption coincided with a typhoon and the torrential rain and ash caused some of the worst mudflows ever. On the plus side, thousands of lives were saved due to prompt evacuations.


Top 10 active volcanoes
Bill McGuire, professor of geohazards and director of the Benfield Greig Hazard Research Centre at UCL, lists the 10 most active volcanoes. (Danger is determined by the number of people likely to be affected by a big eruption)
1 Stromboli, Italy
Continuous mild explosions and lava flows have been recorded here since Roman times. It's predictable, benign and attracts many visitors. Danger potential 1
2 Kilauea, Hawaii
The most continuously active volcano on Earth, Kilauea spews out five cubic metres of lava per second but is not considered that dangerous, having a hotel on the rim of one of its craters. Danger potential 2
3 Etna, Italy
Etna has persistent eruptions from Its summit and from fissures along its flanks. It's constantly monitored, but a big eruption could happen. Danger potential 3
4 Colima, Mexico
The Colima complex consists of two volcanoes, Nevado de Colima and Volcan de Colima. The latter has been the source of large debris avalanches and pyroclastic and lava flows. Danger potential 4
5 Popocatepetl, Mexico
Popocatépetl is North America's second highest volcano. It is covered in Ice and a large eruption could lead to mudflows that would engulf the heavily populated surrounding areas. Danger potential 5
6 Tungurahua, Ecuador
Historical eruptions Include sudden explosions and lava flows, mudflows and pyroclastic flows that reached people at the volcanoes base. Danger potential 4
7 Soufrière Hills, Montserrat
Soufrière Hills' first historical eruption did not take place until 1995. Ash and pyroclastic flows forced evacuation of the southern half of the island and destroyed the capital city of Plymouth. Danger potential 3
8 Merapi, Indonesla
Merapi lies in one of the world's most densely populated areas. Pyroclastic flows and mudflows have devastated crops and caused many fatalities during historical times. Danger potential 5
9 Semeru, Indonesia
The highest volcano on Java has been erupting almost continuously since 1967. Frequent small eruptions and pyroclastic flows and mudflows have damaged villages and caused deaths. Danger potential 3
10 Karymsky, Russia
Karymsky began erupting 500 years ago, after a 2,300-year quiescence. Eruptions have been moderate with occasional lava flows. Danger potential 1


Montserrat: a living laboratory
The Caribbean Island of Montserrat was once considered the ideal holiday destination. That all changed on 18 July 1995, when the eruption of the Soufrière Hills volcano resulted In half the Island being evacuated as pyroclastic flows threatened towns and villages. Now, as Soufrière Mils continues to erupt, the Island has been transformed into a 'living observatory' for volcanologists.
The Montserrat Volcano Observatory (MVO), mainly funded by the UK, was established soon after the disaster, and has helped Soufrière Hills become one of the most intensely studied volcanoes on Earth.
Dr Peter Dunkley, director of the MVO and contributor to the British Geological Survey, explains how Montserrat attracts volcanologists from all over the world. "Firstly, the Island is easily accessible," he says. 'Plus the eruption is prolonged, so researchers are keen to Install ' equipment for long-term study."
But isn't this work dangerous for the volcanologists? ' We only enter risky areas as a fast resort and we limit our lime there," says Dunkley. 'Much of the monitoring Is done by remote Instruments, seismometers, GPS, gas monitoring equipment and digital cameras, which send their data to the Observatory by radio. The only time we get close to the volcano is during maintenance visits.'
The team has gathered evidence which indicates that the volcano may carry on erupting for several more years, even decades. They are now beginning to recognise patterns of eruption behaviour and anticipate some forms of activity. The main hazards remain pyroclastic flows, explosions, fails of ash and volcanic mudflows, which are a high probability due to long periods of tropical rainfall.
But Montserrat is still considered to be a fairly sale place to live. The population resides outside an 'Exclusion Zone' set up around the volcano and has a good relationship with the MVO, which keeps the community Informed through regular radio interviews and bulletins, public meetings and school visits.

Volcanic ash may also linger in the atmosphere

Not just molten rock, lava takes various forms differentiated by the amount of silica they contain

The build up of pressure and gases in magma pools within the Earth's trust causes eruptions

Mudflows swamped homes but few died at Zamales.

Much of the Island has been evacuated but, thanks to MVO, Soufrière Hills bas become one of the most intensely studied volcanoes.

Title: Volcano project draws fire in France.(European Park of Vulcanology) 
Author: CH 
The massive `European Park of Vulcanology', France's "only great cultural project of the year 2000" according to former president Valery Giscard d'Estaing, hopes to attract half a million visitors a year to the relatively poor Auvergne region when it opens in spring next year. Like London's Millennium Dome, however, the `Vulcania' project continues to draw opposition from environmentalists, Green politicians and local residents, many of whom are concerned at the spiralling cost and likely impact of the centre. Despite protests, little of the centre will be seen at ground level apart from the cone-shaped reception area. Much of the 15,000-square-metre complex is being built underground amid Auvergne's extraordinary volcanic heart. On three subterranean levels visitors will be offered a virtual tour via giant screens and loud speakers of the eruptions of Vesuvius, Mount Etna or Mauna Loa, the world's largest active volcano, in Hawaii. Volcanic geysers, the movement of volcanic plates and lava flows will all form part of the `Vulcania experience'. Exhibitions will also explain the role and techniques of volcanic surveillance. [Graphic omitted]But getting the centre off the ground, or rather into it, has been a stormy ride. An alliance of environmental groups including WWF France, Amis de la Terre (Friends of the Earth), and Green politicians have opposed several aspects of the project. From the beginning they campaigned for a different location, not within the volcanoes, but on the adjacent plain or in a former quarry north of Clermond-Ferrand. Work was suspended for four months at the beginning of 1998 while technical aspects were reconsidered but the appeal court gave its final go ahead for the scheme. Although environmentalists lost that campaign, close environmental vigilance has ensured that the construction is being carried out using the latest eco-friendly techniques -- including vegetal fuel for earth-moving vehicles at around 9 [pounds sterling] a litre. The project's spiralling cost has also drawn criticism. Originally budgeted at 300 million francs (30 million [pounds sterling]), costs have since more than doubled, raising the wrath of local tax payers who also fear the influx of mass tourism the centre could bring. Detractors like to compare the park to the tackiness of Disneyland, while proponents prefer comparison with the home-grown and hugely successful Futuroscope at Poitiers. Neither comparison is entirely appropriate since `Vulcania' may have. difficulty in attracting return visits. Some fear the centre could simply become an overnight stop for tourists heading south. It remains to be seen if sufficient visitors will be prepared to pay a proposed 12 [pounds sterling] a head to give Auvergne the economic boost the centre's promoters hope it will provide. IT'S FACT Scientists estimate the rate of extinction of plant and animal species in rainforests, from human activity, to be 50,000 every year, around 140 each day.

Nov 2001 v73 i11 p13(1). 
Title: Eruption would cause killer tsunami. (Natural Disaster).(volcano in Canaries could erupt) 
Huge waves, or tsunami, higher than any in recorded history, could hit Atlantic-facing coasts if the most active volcano in the Canaries over the past 165,000 years erupts -- and it could occur some time in the next 50 years. If part of Cumbre Vieja, on the island of La Palma erupts and falls into the sea, coasts directly facing it will suffer the brunt of the massive waves, despite being on the other side of the Atlantic. This is the frightening scenario proposed by Dr Simon Day of the Benfield Greig Hazard Research Centre at the University College London, and Dr Steven Ward of the Institute of Geophysics and Planetary Physics at the University of California. [Graphic omitted]The scientists reported that any future eruption on the geologically unstable, 2,000-metre-high volcano is liable to cause "catastrophic failure" of its entire western flank. Evidence suggests a huge segment, perhaps 15-20km wide and 15-25km in length, (perhaps 500 cubic kilometres), may collapse into the sea. Their computer model has predicted that if this were to happen, at an assumed 100 metres-per-second, giant tsunami would expand outwards in an arc greater than 180 [degrees], covering 250km in just ten minutes. Within 60 minutes waves possibly 100m high would then combine to hit Africa. To the west, waves would space out over 500km as they crossed the Atlantic basin, retaining much of their power. [Graphic omitted]Tsunami as high as 25 metres would reach Newfoundland and South America's northen coast after six hours. After nine hours Florida and the Caribbean would be hit by tsunami still 25 metres high and with the power to surge up to 15km inland. Closer to home, Britain, Portugal, Spain and France would experience waves of up to seven metres. Speaking to Geographical, Dr Day acknowledged that in one sense the computer model, which is corroborated by other international studies, is extreme. "It is a worst-case scenario in terms of volume of rock that could slide into the sea," he said. But he warned that a landslide faster than 100m per second was feasible. This would narrow the focus of the tsunami but increase their strength. As for when an eruption will occur, Dr Day said, "Based solely on probability, an eruption within the next 50 years is more than likely."

Title: Red-hot Luck.(Tungurahua volcano)
Tungurahua was stirring, but clouds had blocked the view of the volcano for weeks. Photographer Pablo Corral Vega had traveled a hundred miles south of his home in Quito, Ecuador, to try to get a shot. Perched on a steep outcrop, he waited blindly. Suddenly the sky cleared. As he opened the shutter, glowing rocks and lava erupted with a roar from the blazing crater and rolled down the slopes. Almost simultaneously a thunderbolt backlit one side of the cone. "It was a real gift" he says. "The clouds covered the volcano again in seconds." Some 25,000 people living around Tungurahua were evacuated to safety. But in Quito 1.5 million live under the threat of smoking Guagua Pichincha (page 20). To illustrate the volcanic hazards of the Andes for Corral Vega's story, clear danger won out over beauty.
